column2: You spoke by the Holy Spirit through David, our forefather and your servant, saying ‘Why did the people of the other nations become so angry? Why did they plot so foolishly against me?
column3: Ab aptki cheha g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag mat wo amichudach g m‑pionagbad David. K hekaj hab kaij:

column2: Now this has really happened right here in this city! Both Herod and Pontius Pilate, together with the foreigners and the people of Israel, united together against your holy servant Jesus, whom you anointed as Messiah.
column3: “Neh, Jiosh t‑ohg, t wa woho am e hemapai g t‑wehm oꞌodham ha wehm g gawul mahs hemajkam ch hegam kokownal mo d Herod ch Pilate. Wehsijj at ab wui gegokiwua g hekia s‑apꞌekam m‑Kehsha, Jesus.

column2: They did whatever you had already decided because you had the power and the will to do it.
column3: Heki apt hu am i apꞌech mapt wo ha hiwigi mat wo mua g si m‑Kehsha. Kut idam mat ab chum m‑wui gegokiwua hab wabsh juh mapt haschu heki hu i apꞌech.

column2: Now Lord: look at all their threats against us! Help us your servants to speak your word really boldly.  As you exercise your power to heal, may signs and miracles be done through the name of your holy servant Jesus!”
column3: Pegih, t‑ohg Jiosh, am g i ha neid mo ab si t‑ebkiod k ab wo i t‑mah g gewkdag matt s‑gewkam wo aꞌagad g haꞌichu m‑ahga ch wo ha dodaj g kokꞌodam ch si s‑hasigam haꞌichu hab wo juh g gewkdajkaj g hekia s‑apꞌekam m‑Kehsha, Jesus.”

column2: When they had finished praying, the building they were meeting in was shaken. All of them were filled with the Holy Spirit, and spoke the word of God boldly.
column3: Tsh am i haꞌasa e hoꞌigeꞌidahu. Tsh g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag am si uꞌugij hegai kih mo am e hemapadch k ab si i ha mah g gewkdag. Tsh am hahawa baꞌich i si s‑gewkam ah g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga.

column2: All the believers were of one heart and mind. None of them claimed anything they had as their own, but shared everything with each other.
column3: Wehsijj ash ab aꞌai si e tatchua g Jesus ihmdam ch ab si i hemakoch g e‑chegitoi k pi hedai shaꞌi s‑daꞌa g haꞌichu e‑eniga ab aꞌai e wui.

column2: The apostles gave their testimony regarding the resurrection of the Lord Jesus with tremendous power, and God greatly blessed them all.
column3: Sh idam Jesus chuhchai si s‑gewkam am ahgachug mat uhpam i wuhsh g Jesus muhkig t amjed k d wehs ha‑kownalig. Kush g Jiosh am si i ha wehmt.

column2: None of them needed anything because those who had lands or properties sold them.
column3: Sh haꞌi am ha gagda g e‑oꞌoidag ch e‑kihki ch ab i uꞌu g lial

column2: They took the proceeds and presented them to the apostles to be shared with those in need.
column3: ch ab ha mamka g Jesus chuhchai mash hekid i e tatchua. Sh am hahawa aꞌai ha mamka hegam mash pi haꞌichu edgid. Sh hekaj pi hedai haꞌichu pi edgid.

column2: Joseph, the one the apostles called Barnabas (meaning “son of encouragement”), was a Levite, a Cypriot national.
column3: Sh hema d Joseph ch ab Cyprus jewed t ab d kihkam ch d chum papal ha wehm chikpandam nash pi ab d Levibad amjedkam. Sh id hab ep chechcheg g Jesus chuhchai Barnabas mo hab d ahga I ha Gewkemhundam.

column2: He sold a field that belonged to him. Then he brought the money and presented it to the apostles.
column3: Id atsh gagda g e‑oidag k ab i ui g namkigaj k wehs ha mah g Jesus chuhchai.

column2: Now a man called Ananias, with his wife Sapphira, sold some property.
column3: Sh am hema d Jesus ihmdam ch hab chehgig Ananias. Kush g wehmaj kihkam hab chehgig Sapphira ch hab waꞌap d Jesus ihmdam. Kutsh ihda Ananias epai gagda g haꞌichu e‑eniga

column2: He kept back some of the money he received for himself, and brought the rest to present to the apostles. His wife knew what he was doing.
column3: k hab masma hab chum e juh mat wehs ha mah g namkigaj g Jesus chuhchai k wabshaba ged hu haꞌi si toa e‑wohshag ed.

column2: Then Peter asked him, “Ananias, why has Satan filled your heart to lie to the Holy Spirit and keep back some of the money from the land you sold?
column3: Sh hab kaij g Peter ab wui, “Shahchu apt ahgk hiwigi g Jiawul mat am pad haꞌichu hab juh m‑ihbdag ed. Pt heg hekaj iattogi g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag mapt heg wepogi mo id d wehs g haꞌichu m‑eniga namkig.

column2: While you had the land, didn't it belong to you? And after you sold it, didn't you still have control over what you did with the money? Why did you decide to do this? You haven't lied to human beings, but to God!”
column3: Hegai haꞌichu m‑eniga o d m‑eniga mapt koi gagda. Pt am i gagda. K hegai namkigaj d m‑lialiga. Pt eda hab juh ihda si geꞌe pi apꞌekam. Pi apt ahchim waꞌi chum t‑iattogi mach d wabsh oꞌodham. Jiosh apt ep chum iattogi.”

column2: Hearing these words, Ananias fell down and died. Everyone who heard what happened was terrified.
column3: T am wabsh i chum kaiok ihda g Ananias k muhk k i gei.

column2: Some of the young men got up and wrapped him in a shroud. Then they carried him out and buried him.
column3: Tsh ab hahawa i wahp g wechij oꞌodham k am i apꞌech g chuhkugaj k ged hu cheh.

column2: About three hours later his wife arrived, not knowing what had happened.
column3: Sh am ep s‑mahch g wehmaj kihkam g muhki matsh hab masma wo chum ha iattogi. Sh am d i waik ohla. Kutsh eda pi koi kah mat has e juh k hekaj am jiwia mo am daha g Peter.

column2: Peter asked her, “Tell me, did you sell the land for this price?”
column3: Kush heg ab wui hab kaij, “Namt haꞌakia ui g lial mamt gagda g haꞌichu e‑eniga?”

column2: Then Peter told her, “How could you agree together to swindle the Spirit of the Lord? Look, those who buried your husband are just returning, and they'll carry you out too!”
column3: Sh hab kaij g Peter, “Ms haschu ahgk hig ahpi g e‑wehm kihkam wehm hab chum i e taht mamt wabsh wo piꞌich g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag? Dada at hegam mat ged hu cheh g m‑wehm kihkam. Pegih, t hab waꞌap masma hab wo m‑juh.”

column2: Immediately she fell down dead at his feet. The young men came back in and found her dead, so they carried her out and buried her beside her husband.
column3: Tsh am ha hekaj muhk k i gei wecho. Tsh ab i wahp g wechij oꞌodham k am nei matki muh k gam hu i be k ged hu cheh hugidaj an g wehmaj kihkam.

column2: Great fear spread through the whole church, as well as among everyone who heard what had happened.
column3: Tsh wehsijj ab si s‑ehbeni g Jesus ihmdam ch hegam ehp mo hedai i kah ihda.

column2: Many miraculous signs were performed among the people by the apostles. All the believers used to meet together in Solomon's porch.
column3: Kush s‑hasig haꞌichu s‑ta neidamam hab junihim g Jesus chuhchai am ha shahgid g hemajkam. Sh wehsijj si s‑ap e hehemapad hegam Jesus ihmdam heg wecho Solomonbad watto.

column2: Nobody else dared to join them even though they were greatly respected.
column3: Sh g hemajkam ab si has ha elid ch wabshaba si s‑e gihug mat ab wo i ha wehmt.

column2: However many men and women came to believe in the Lord.
column3: Tsh oi wa muꞌi ab i s‑wohoch g haꞌichu ha‑ahga ab amjed g Jesus k ab i ha wehmt. Haꞌi d chechoj ch haꞌi d uꞌuwi.

column2: As a result, people brought those who were sick into the streets and laid them on beds and mats so that as Peter passed by his shadow might fall on them.
column3: Kumtsh am i ha wuwhas g kokꞌodam am i neidok mo haschu has junihim g Jesus chuhchai k an kahya oidk ha wahpakusch hab elidch mat chum hems g Peter ehkadag ab hab wo e juh ha ab mat wo e dodaj.

column2: Crowds from the towns around Jerusalem brought their sick and those afflicted by evil spirits. They were all healed.
column3: Muꞌijj atsh ab aꞌaijed i hihi Jerusalem wui ab i ha uꞌuk g e‑kokꞌodamga ch hegam mo g jijawul an ha uꞌukch. Kutsh wehs ha dodaj.

column2: However, the high priest and those with him (who were Sadducees) became very jealous and decided to intervene.
column3: Tsh g uhgchu pahl ch hegam mash hab waꞌap am oid g Sajusi himdag si s‑koꞌokam s‑ha hehgam g Jesus chuhchai

column2: They arrested the apostles and threw them in the public jail.
column3: k am i ha cheha g geꞌe cheopi nuhkuddam mat wo ha kuh. Tsh wa woho am ha kuh.

column2: But during the night an angel of the Lord opened the prison doors and led them out.
column3: Tsh wabshaba heg i s‑chuhugam ab g anghil am si kuhpiꞌo g kukpaikud k ab i ha wuwhas g Jesus chuhchai k hab ha ahg,

column2: “Go to the Temple and tell the people everything about this new way of life!” he told them.
column3: “Am g wo uhpam hihim k am wo i gegokiwua geꞌe cheopi ch ed k wo ha ahgi g hemajkam mat has masma wo bei ihda pi ha huhugedam doakag.”

column2: They did as they were told and went into the Temple at around dawn and began teaching.
column3: Kutsh ab wohog elid k am hihim k am i wahp geꞌe cheopi ch ed mat wabsh i chum mahsi k am ha hekaj i ha mashcha g hemajkam.

column2: But when the officials went to the prison they couldn't find the apostles so they went back and told the council,
column3: Kutsh am chum hihi g geꞌe cheopi nuhkuddam mat wo ha ui. Kush pi am hu haꞌichug.

column2: “We found the prison all locked up, with guards at the doors. But when we had them open up, we couldn't find anyone inside.”
column3: “M att dada kukpaikud am k am chum nei. K ab wabsh kia yahwidag. K g lilso ha nuhkuddam ab ep gegok kihjeg t ab. Tt wabshaba am i chum kuhpiꞌo g kihjeg. K pi am hu hedai haꞌichug.”

column2: Now when the captain of the Temple guards and the chief priests heard this they were totally baffled, and wondered what was going on.
column3: Tsh am i ha kaiok am wabsh i pi amich mas hebai has e juh g ha‑lilsoga.

column2: Then someone came in and said, “Look, the men you put in prison are right there in the Temple teaching people!”
column3: Tsh am hahawa hema i wahk k hab kaij, “Nehꞌe! Idani o ged hu ha mashcham g hemajkam geꞌe cheopi ch ed hegam mamt wa ha kuh.”

column2: So the captain went with his guards and brought them in, but did not use force because they were afraid that the people would stone them.
column3: Tsh am hahawa hihi g geꞌe cheopi nuhkuddam k ab uhpam wabsh s‑ap i ha ui nat pi am hu wo ha maꞌichshul g hemajkam

column2: The apostles were brought in and made to stand in front of the council.
column3: k am ha uꞌapa ha wui g e jehnigiddam.

column2: “Didn't we order you not to teach in this name?” the high priest demanded to know. “Now look—you've filled the whole of Jerusalem with your teaching, and you're trying to blame us for his death!”
column3: “Chum ach s‑gewkam pi em‑hiwgid mams an hu wo aꞌagad hegai Jesusbad. T eda g em‑mashchamadag ab amjed heki hu wehsko chehmo g Jerusalem. Kum ahpim ab chum t‑abchud g muhkigaj.”

column2: But Peter and the apostles answered, “We have to obey God rather than men.  The God of our forefathers raised Jesus from the dead—the one you killed by hanging him on a cross.  God exalted him to a position of honor at his right hand as Prince and Savior, as a way to bring repentance to Israel, and for the forgiveness of sins.  We are witnesses of what happened, and so is the Holy Spirit, whom God has given to those who obey him.”
column3: Sh hab kaij hegam Peter, “K wabshaba g Jiosh am t‑ahgid matt am wo wa ahgahid ihda mach haschu i si t‑wuhpuikaj neid. Kutt hemho wo wa i hehgch g Jiosh, pi wabsh g oꞌodham. Ahpim amt bei g Jesus k hab juh mat ab e naggia kots t ab k e muhkid. T wabshaba g Jiosh ab uhpam i wuhshad muhkig amjed k am i wahki dahm kahchim ch ed k an i kei si e‑hugid an k ab i mah g gewkdag mat wo t‑doꞌibia k wo t‑wanimedad. Kut heg ab i t‑mah g apꞌedag ahchim Tutuligo hemajkam matt gam hu wo s‑ohhod g pi ap t‑chegitoi. T hekaj g Jiosh gam hu hab wo i juh g pi ap t‑chuꞌijig. Jiosh at ab cheha g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag mat wehs wo t‑wehmajk ahchim mach ab s‑wohog elid ch am t‑gahi wuhshanim wo wohokamch g Jesus.” Neh, bash kaij g Peter.

column2: When the council heard this they were furious and wanted to kill them.
column3: Tsh wabsh wohoꞌi babgat hegam e jehnigiddam k wabsh chum s‑ha kokdaimk.

column2: But then one of the council members stood up to speak. He was Gamaliel, a Pharisee and a doctor of law who was respected by everyone. He ordered the apostles sent out for a short while.
column3: Sh wabshaba am da hegai mash d Gamaliel ch d chehanig ha mashchamdam ch am oid g Palasi himdag. Sh wehsijj ab si has elid g hemajkam. Kutsh am i kekiwua k am ha ahgi mat gm hu wo shaꞌi i ha wuwhas g e‑lilsoga. Tsh wa woho hab ha juh.

column2: Gamaliel addressed the council: “Leaders of Israel, be careful what you plan to do to these men.
column3: Sh hab hahawa kaij ihda ab ha wui g e jehnigiddam, “Ni‑hajuni, am g wo s‑e nenꞌoidk mamt has wo ha juh idam oꞌodham.

column2: Some time ago Theudas tried to make a name for himself, and about four hundred men joined him. He was killed and all who followed him were scattered and it came to nothing.
column3: Hekid o hu i mat am hema i e maskogid k hab chehgig Theudas ch hab kaij mo d ge haꞌichu s‑mahchim. Kut am hu i giꞌik siant chechoj ab i wehmt. T wabshaba e muhkid ihda. T wehsijj e gantad hegam mat wa ab wehmt. T am waꞌi huhug g ahgaj.

column2: Then after him Judas of Galilee came along at the time of the census, and he attracted some followers. He also died, and those who listened to him were dispersed.
column3: T amjed am hema ep i e maskogi eda mat g hemajkam e kuint k hab chehgig Judas ch am Galilee t am d oꞌodham. T ihda hab waꞌap muꞌi oꞌodham am i oi. T wabshaba hab waꞌap e muhkid hegai Judas. T hab waꞌap aꞌai e gantad hegam mat wa ab wehmt.

column2: So in the current case I recommend that you leave these men alone, and just let them go. If what they are planning or what they are doing comes from their own human thinking, then it will be defeated.
column3: “Pegih, k hemuch hab wa mahs haꞌichu. Pi g am hu has wo shaꞌi ha juhni idam oꞌodham. Ha g wo dagito. Hemu at wo huhug ihda haꞌichu hab ha‑juni matp d wabsh wo oꞌodham hab ha‑elidak. Tp d wo sha Jiosh haꞌichu hab junik, mt pi wo shaꞌi e nako mams wo keshwua.

column2: But if it comes from God, you won't be able to defeat them. You could even find yourselves fighting against God!”
column3: Mtp hems heg wabsh wo e wepogi mam g Jiosh wabsh cheggia.”

column2: They were convinced by what he said. So they called the apostles back in, had them whipped, and ordered them not to say anything in the name of Jesus. Then they let them go.
column3: k hab ha ahg g geꞌe cheopi nuhkuddam mat am wo i ha wahpki g lilso k wo ha gewitta. Tsh wa woho hab e juh. Kutsh ab ep si ha ahgi mat pi am hu wo shaꞌi aꞌagad g Jesus k hahawa ha dagito.

column2: The apostles left the council, happy to be considered worthy to suffer shame for the name of Jesus.
column3: Kush wabsh si s‑hehgig idam Jesus chuhchai am i wuwhak natsh pi ab si has i ha el g Jiosh k ab i ha mah g apꞌedag matsh si e shoꞌigch wehhejed g Jesus.

column2: Every day they continued to teach and proclaim Jesus as the Messiah, in the Temple and from house to house.
column3: Pi atsh shaꞌi haꞌasa aꞌaga g Jesus k wabshaba wehs tashkaj am wabsh i ha mashcham g hemajkam geꞌe cheopi ch ed ch am ha‑kihki ed mo g Jesus d Jiosh si Kehsha.

column2: At this time, when the number of believers was increasing rapidly, the Greek-speaking believers started arguing with the Aramaic-speaking believers. They complained that their widows were being discriminated against in the daily distribution of food.
column3: Kush am i muꞌidahim hegam mash am oid g Jesus himdag. Sh am haꞌi neneok g Greek hemajkam ha‑neꞌokikaj nash pi tash gam hu kihkahim ha‑jewedga ed. Kush idam hab kaij mash pi ap ha dagioꞌid hegam heheꞌejel wiꞌikam uꞌuwi mash d ha‑hajuni. Kush heg hekaj am aꞌai pi e apꞌet idam Greek neneokdam ha wehm hegam mo g hejel e‑neꞌokikaj neneok.

column2: The twelve apostles called all the believers together, and told them, “It's not appropriate for us to give up spreading the word of God so we can wait at tables.
column3: Tsh am i kah g Jesus chuhchai k am wehs i ha hemapad k hab kaij, “T‑wepnag, pi o apꞌe machs wabsh wo dagito g mihshmda ab amjed g Jiosh k im hu g lial wo hudawogad.

column2: Brothers, choose from among you seven trustworthy men full of the Spirit and wisdom. We will hand this responsibility over to them.
column3: Ab oki haꞌi ep em‑mahkch g Jiosh g gewkdag ch amichudadag mamt am hab wo junihid ihda chikpan. Pegih, mt am wewaꞌak wo i ha gawulkai hegam mam s‑ha mahch mo woho hab masma. Kutt idam am wo i ha chuhcha mat wo nuhkud ihda hab mahs haꞌichu.

column2: We ourselves will give our full attention to prayer and the ministry of spreading the word.”
column3: Tt ahchim Jesus chuhchai am hab wo si i juh matt wo t‑hoꞌigeꞌidahunad ch wo si ha mihshmdad g hemajkam.” Neh, bash kaij.

column2: Everybody was happy with the arrangement, and they chose Stephen, (a man full of trust in God and of the Holy Spirit), Philip, Prochorus, Nicanor, Timon, Parmenas, and Nicolaus (originally a Jewish convert from Antioch).
column3: Kumtsh ab si i s‑hohhoꞌi mo has kaij k am wewaꞌak i ha chuhcha. Hema idam ash hab chehgig Steven ch ab si s‑gewkam hiwig g Jesus. Sh g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag ab si mahkch g gewkdag. Kush hegam haꞌi ehp hab chechgig Philip ch Prochorus ch Nicanor ch Timon ch Parmenas ch Nicolaus. Ihda Nicolaus ash ab d amjedkam g Antiok kihhim ch d gawul mahs oꞌodham ch ab i s‑wohoch g Tutuligo ha‑himdag eda mat koi s‑mai ab amjed g Jesus.

column2: These men were presented to the apostles who prayed for them and placed their hands on them in blessing.
column3: Tsh idam ab hahawa i ha ui g hemajkam ha wui g Jesus chuhchai. Kutsh idam am e hoꞌigeꞌidahun k ab ha taht mat heg hekaj wo s‑e mahchk mo d si ha‑chuhchai.

column2: The word of God continued to spread, and the number of disciples in Jerusalem greatly increased, with a large number of priests committing themselves to trusting in Jesus.
column3: Tsh am si i geꞌeda g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga Jerusalem t am. Kutsh baꞌich i muꞌida hegam mash am oid g Jesus himdag. Tsh muꞌijj ab i s‑wohoch hegam mo d papal Tutuligo ha‑himdag ed.

column2: Stephen, full of grace and God's power, performed wonderful miracles among the people.
column3: Ab ash si s‑hoꞌigeꞌid g Jiosh g Steven ch ab si i mahkch g e‑gewkdag. Kush s‑hasigam haꞌichu hab wua.

column2: But some started arguing with him. They were from the synagogue called “the Free,” as well as Cyrenians, Alexandrians, and people from Cilicia and Asia Minor.
column3: Tsh wabshaba haꞌi ab wui gegokiwua mash am hebai e wehm e mihshmad g Tuhligo e‑himdag. Haꞌi idam ash d neneholkahim Cyrene ch Alexandria kihhim t am. Tsh am haꞌi i ha wehmt ab Cilicia jewed t amjed ch haꞌi ab Asia jewed t amjed.

column2: But they weren't able to stand against Stephen's wisdom or the Spirit with which he was speaking.
column3: Sh wabshaba g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag ab si mahkch g Steven g amichudadag. Kutsh pi shaꞌi e nako hegam mas ab uhpam wo i nodagi g neꞌokij.

column2: So they bribed some men to say, “We heard this man blaspheme Moses, and God too!”
column3: k heg hekaj am hahawa haꞌi ha namkid k am ha ahgid mat hab wo chei, “Kah ach ihda mo si has ahg hegai mo ab t‑chehani g Jiosh Mosesbad oꞌohana ed.”

column2: They stirred up the people, and together with the elders and the teachers of the law, they came and arrested him. They brought him before the council,
column3: Kush wa woho hab kaij idam ch hekaj i ha kudu g hemajkam ch geꞌeged ch chehanig ha mashchamdam. Tsh idam wabsh woho i babgat k am hihim k an bei g Steven k ged hu uꞌapa ha wui g e jehnigiddam.

column2: and called false witnesses who testified against him.
column3: Mtsh am hahawa haꞌi i ha wahpki g oꞌodham matsh am haꞌichu wo ha iattogi ab amjed. Sh hab kaij idam, “Ihda oꞌodham o chum hekid has ahg g hekia s‑apꞌekam geꞌe cheopi ch hegai mo ab t‑chehani g Jiosh Mosesbad oꞌohana ed.

column2: “We've heard him say that this Jesus of Nazareth will destroy the Temple, and will change the laws we received from Moses.”
column3: Kah ach mo hab kaij mat hegai Jesusbad wo i wua g geꞌe cheopi k wo gawul juh g t‑himdag mach ga hu hebai amjed hab i junihim mat g Mosesbad an oꞌoha.”

column2: Everyone sitting on the council looked closely at Stephen, and his face shone like the face of an angel.
column3: Kush wehsijj ab si neid g Steven. Sh g wuhioshaj hab haha wabsh mahs matp hems g anghil wuhiosha nash pi si tonod.

column2: “Are these allegations true?” the high priest asked.
column3: Kush hab kaij g uhgchu pahl ab wui g Steven, “No am wa woho map hab junihim hegai mo haschu ab m‑abchud?”

column2: “Brothers and fathers, listen to me!” Stephen replied. “God in his glory appeared to our father Abraham when he was living in Mesopotamia, before he moved to Haran.
column3: Kush hab kaij g Steven:

column2: God told him, ‘Leave your country and your relatives, and go to the country that I'm going to show you.’
column3: “Sh hab kaij g Jiosh ab wui:

column2: So he left the country of the Chaldeans and lived in Haran. After his father's death, God sent him here to this country where you now live.
column3: “Tsh wa woho am dagito g Mesopotamia jewed mash am kih g Caldea hemajkam k am chihpia Haran kihhim wui. Kutsh am i muh g Abrahambad ohgbad. Tsh ab hahawa ep cheha g Jiosh mat ia wo chihpia Canaan jewed wui. Kutsh ia i chiwia mach hemuch ia kih.

column2: God didn't give Abraham an inheritance here, not even one square foot. But God did promise Abraham that he would give him and his descendants possession of the land, even though he had no children.
column3: Tsh eda koi ab hu heꞌes shaꞌi mah ihda jewed k wabshaba am hi wa ahgid mat wo mah. T d wo ha‑enigak g amjedkamaj mat heꞌekiajj ab wo i oi. Kush eda pi koi ha aꞌaliga g Abrahambad mash eda hab ahg g Jiosh.

column2: God also told him that his descendants would live in a foreign country, and that they would be enslaved there, and would be mistreated for four hundred years.
column3: “Kush hab kaij g Jiosh ab wui:

column2: The patriarchs, who were jealous of Joseph, sold him into slavery in Egypt. But God was with him,
column3: “Tsh idam wa s‑hehgam g e‑wehnag Josephbad k ab haꞌi ha wui gagda mat d wo ha neholigak am Egypt jewed ch ed. Sh wabshaba g Jiosh am nuhkud

column2: and rescued him from all his troubles. He gave him wisdom and helped him gain the favor of Pharaoh, king of Egypt, who made him governor over Egypt and the royal household.
column3: ch ab s‑ap i wuhshad wehs haꞌichu shoꞌigdaj amjed k ab i mah g si oꞌodhamdag ch amichudadag. Tsh am i nei g ha‑kownalig g Egypt t am hemajkam k am i uhgkajid k am kownalch am dahm g e‑kownaltalig ch haꞌichu e‑eniga.

column2: Now a famine occurred throughout Egypt and Canaan. It caused terrible misery, and our forefathers had no food.
column3: “Tsh wa haha wabsh gei g bihugig k ha shoꞌigch g hemajkam wehsko Egypt jewed dahm ch iia Canaan jewed dahm. Tsh pi shaꞌi e amich hegam Abrahambad mat hebai wo bei g haꞌichu hugi.

column2: When Jacob heard there was grain in Egypt he sent our forefathers down on their first visit.
column3: Kush eda am s‑haꞌichu hugig Egypt jewed ch ed. Kutsh am i kah g Jacobbad k am ha cheha g e‑aꞌalidag matsh am wo hunio. Kutsh hab e juh.

column2: During their second visit, Joseph revealed to his brothers who he was, and Pharaoh discovered Joseph's family background.
column3: “Tsh am ep i huhug g haꞌichu ha‑hugi. Kutsh am ep hunio. Tsh g Josephbad am hahawa ha ahgi mo d ha‑wehnag nash pi pi amichud. Tsh g ha‑kownalig g Egypt t am hemajkam ab s‑ha mai g Josephbad hajuni.

column2: Joseph sent for his father and all his relatives—seventy-five in total.
column3: Tsh g Josephbad am hahawa wai g e‑ohgbad mat wehsijj ab wo i chihpia Egypt wui. Kush eda d wewaꞌakko gamai hetasp (75) hemajkam.

column2: Jacob traveled to Egypt, and died there—as did our forefathers.
column3: Tsh wa woho am i chihpia hegam Jacobbad Egypt wui k am kihkahim ch am koi.

column2: Their bodies were brought back to Shechem and placed in the tomb that Abraham had bought with silver from the sons of Hamor in Shechem.
column3: Tsh am uhpam i e ui g ha‑ohꞌo g Abrahambad ch Josephbad Shekem kihhim wui. Abrahambad atsh wa am heꞌes ha nolawt g jewed hegam mash d Hamor amjedkam matsh am wo e toa g ha‑koꞌidag.

column2: As the time approached regarding the promise that God had made to Abraham, the number of our people in Egypt increased.
column3: “Sh amjed muꞌi aꞌahidag wehgaj. Sh e aihim matsh am hab wo juh g Jiosh mash haschu i heki hu ahgid g Abrahambad. Tsh eda am i si muꞌida g t‑shohshonbad amai Egypt ch ed.

column2: A new king came to the throne in Egypt who knew nothing about Joseph.
column3: Kutsh am hema i wuhsh g kownal mash pi shaꞌi mahch matsh wa has masma am si i ha wehmt g Josephbad amai Egypt ch ed.

column2: He took advantage of our people and treated our ancestors badly, forcing them to abandon their babies so they would die.
column3: Kush ihda nahnko ha wua hegam t‑shohshon ch ha shoꞌigchud ch hab ha ahg mat gam hu wo ha shul g chuꞌuchum e‑aꞌaliga hab ahgch mat wo koi.

column2: It was at this time that Moses was born. He was a handsome child, and for three months he was looked after in his father's home.
column3: Kutsh eda mahsi g Mosesbad k si s‑kehg d ali. Kutsh am i nuhkud g jehjij waik mashad ab

column2: When he had to be abandoned, Pharaoh's daughter rescued him and took care of him as her own son.
column3: k gam hu hahawa i wuhshad. T g kownal uwi alidag am chehg k ab i bei hab masma mo d madaj.

column2: Moses received instruction in all areas of Egyptian knowledge, and he became a powerful speaker and leader.
column3: Kumtsh wehs haꞌichu mashcha mo haschu d i si s‑hasig haꞌichu am Egypt ch ed. Tsh ab si i mai ihda wehs k d si s‑has haꞌichu am heg eda mo haschu hab i kaij ch haschu hab i junihim.

column2: However, when he was forty years old, he decided to visit his relatives, the Israelites.
column3: “Batsh wa masma am i geꞌeda g Mosesbad k am i ai g giꞌikko wehst‑mahm (40) aꞌahidag. Tsh am hu hebai hab i e ah mat am wo i ha chehgim g e‑hahajuni.

column2: He saw one of them being mistreated, so he intervened to defend him. On behalf of the man he took revenge and killed the Egyptian.
column3: Kush hema g Egypt t am oꞌodham am hema shoꞌigchud g Tuhligo. Tsh g Mosesbad am i wehmt g e‑hajuni k mua ihda Egypt t am oꞌodham mat wo agwua

column2: Moses thought his fellow Israelites would see that God was rescuing them through him, but they didn't.
column3: k hab e ahg mat g hajunij wo chum s‑mahchk mat g Jiosh wo hekaj k wo ha doꞌibia. Sh wabshaba g hajunij pi hab masma hab elid haꞌichu.

column2: The next day when he arrived, two Israelites were fighting one another. He tried to reconcile them and stop the fight. ‘Men! You are brothers!’ he told them. ‘Why are you attacking each other?’
column3: Sh am baꞌich d i tash, sh am haꞌi e cheggia g Tutuligo. Tsh am ha neid k chum s‑ha daꞌid k hab kaij, ‘Kia, ahpim! Dam e‑wepngam ch eda haschu ahgch e cheggia?’

column2: But the man who had started the fight pushed Moses away. ‘Who put you in charge over us? Are you our judge now?’ he asked.
column3: “Kut hegai mo ha cheggia ab si nuꞌichkwua g Mosesbad k hab kaij:

column2: When he heard this, Moses ran away. He went and lived in exile in the land of Midian, where two sons were born to him.
column3: “Tsh am i kah g Mosesbad ihda k ha hekaj gam hu i e mehkod ab Egypt amjed k gam hu i jiwia mash am d Midian jewed. Sh am haꞌi oꞌodhamag. Kutsh am ha hohnt k gohk chechoj aꞌalidt

column2: Forty years later, in the desert of Mount Sinai, an angel appeared to him in the flames of a burning bush.
column3: “Sh am him k am d i giꞌikko wehst‑mahm aꞌahidag. Sh am hu hebai ha nuhkud g kahwal g Mosesbad am miabidch hegai doꞌag mo hab e aꞌaga Sinai. Tsh ab wui haha wabsh hema i e chehgi g anghil hab masma mo am meihim g shaꞌi ch eda pi meitto.

column2: When Moses saw this, he was amazed at the sight, and went over to take a closer look. The voice of the Lord spoke to him:
column3: Tsh ab i miabi g Mosesbad mat ab si s‑ap wo i nei nash pi pi amichud matsh wa pi shaꞌi meitto g shaꞌi. Sh g Jiosh ab wui hab kaij am gahi wuhshanim g anghil:

column2: The Lord told him, ‘Take off your sandals, because where you are standing is holy ground.
column3: “Sh hab ep kaij g Jiosh ab wui:

column2: This was the same Moses that the people had rejected when they said, ‘Who made you a ruler and judge over us?’ God sent him to be both a ruler and a liberator, by means of the angel who appeared to him in the bush.
column3: Kuni hab ep s‑cheꞌimk mo ihda Mosesbad d hegai matsh wa g hajunij pi ab hu tatchua ch hab kaij:

column2: This is the same Moses who promised the Israelites, ‘God will send you a prophet like me from among your people.’
column3: ch am ha ahgid ch hab kaij:

column2: He was the one our fathers wouldn't listen to. They rejected him and decided to return to Egypt.
column3: Tsh pi oi jiwia g Mosesbad ab doꞌag t amjed. Tsh g t‑shohshonbad pi ab hu wohog elid k im hu hab wabsh i s‑junimk g Mosesbad ch uhpam s‑hihimimk am Egypt wui

column2: They told Aaron, ‘Make gods for us to lead us, because we don't know what's happened to this Moses who led us out of the land of Egypt.’
column3: Sh g ha‑uhgchu pahlig d Aaronbad. Sh idam ab wui hab kaij:

column2: Then they made an idol in the shape of a calf, sacrificed to it, and celebrated what they themselves had made!
column3: “Kush wa am hema wisilot g ohlakaj k ab wui iagchul heg wepogidch mo d ha‑jioshga k am ep piast mat heg hekaj ab wo si i haꞌichuch hegai e‑jioshta.

column2: So God gave up on them. He left them to their worship of the stars in the sky. This is what the prophets wrote, ‘Were you giving offerings or making sacrifices to me during the forty years in the desert, you Israelites?
column3: Kutsh heg hekaj im hu hab i e juh g Jiosh ab ha amjed k am wabsh ha hiwigi mat wabsh g hejel hab e‑elida am hab wo junihid. Kush wabsh g huhuꞌu ab ha ihm mat hab masma an oꞌoha g Jiosh haꞌichu i tashogiddam mash hab kaij g Jiosh:

column2: Our ancestors had the Tabernacle of testimony  in the desert. God had told Moses how he should make it following the blueprint he had seen.
column3: “Kuni hab ep s‑cheꞌimk mash hegam an uꞌahim hegai cheopi mash heg hekaj am ha tashogid g Jiosh mash am ha wehmaj. Sh heg d wabsh hogi ch hab masma e nahto matsh wa g Jiosh am chehgi g Mosesbad.

column2: Later on, our forefathers carried it with them when they went in with Joshua to occupy the land taken from the nations the Lord drove out before them. It stayed there until the time of David.
column3: Sh g ha‑amjedkam an ep uꞌahim hegai cheopi matsh hekid g Joshuabad am i e kei matsh wo i ha wanim. Kutsh g Jiosh ia i ha wahpki id eda jewed k am ha wehhejed gam hu i ha wuwhas hegam nahnko mahs hemajkam mo ia d chum kihkam. Kush am haꞌichugkahim ihda cheopi ch ab ai mash eda g Davidbad d ha‑kownalig.

column2: David found favor with God and asked to make a more permanent home for the God of Jacob.
column3: Sh ihda Davidbad d si Jiosh tatchui ch ab ahgid mat wo hiwigi mat hema wo kihch. Tsh heg eda am hab wo e junihid g hoꞌigeꞌidahuna Jiosh wui.

column2: But it was Solomon who built a temple for him.
column3: Kutsh g Jiosh hiwigi g alidaj Solomonbad. Tsh heg am i kei g kih am wehhejed g Jiosh.

column2: Of course the Almighty doesn't live in temples we make. As the prophet said,
column3: “K eda g Jiosh baꞌich i geꞌej mo haschu i mo an hab chuꞌig t‑wehgaj. T pi wo shaꞌi e nako g oꞌodham mas wo kihch. Batsh wa masma an oꞌoha g kelibad Jiosh haꞌichu i tashogiddam mash hab kaij g Jiosh:

column2: You arrogant, hard-hearted people! You never listen! You always fight against the Holy Spirit! You act just like your fathers did!  Was there ever a prophet your fathers didn't persecute? They killed those who prophesied about the coming of the One who is truly good and right. He is the One you betrayed and murdered—
column3: “Kush wabshaba g t‑shohshonbad si e sheshemachud ch pi chechkaidag ch pi ab hu kaiham g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga. Jiosh ash am i ha wuwhasid g haꞌichu i tashogiddam. Kush wa g t‑shohshonbad ha shoꞌigchud ch haꞌi ha kokda. Kum ahpim hab waꞌap chuꞌig ch ab wabsh wui gegok g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag. Jiosh haꞌichu i tashogiddam ash am ahgachug mat wo jiwia g Jiosh si pionag k d wo si wehs s‑apꞌekamk. Kut wa woho jiwia. Kumt wa gagda mat wo e muhkid.

column2: you who received the law by means of the angels, but refused to keep it.”
column3: Ahpim amt ab em‑mah g Jiosh chehanig mat wa g anghil ia uꞌapa. Mt eda am wa pi wohoch.” Neh, bash kaij g Steven.

column2: When they heard this, the council members became mad with rage, and snarled at him, grinding their teeth.
column3: Tsh am i kah g e jehnigiddam mash has ha ahg g Steven k wabsh wohoꞌi babgat k si kuhm g e‑tahtami.

column2: But Stephen, full of the Holy Spirit, gazed up into heaven and saw God's glory, with Jesus standing at God's right hand.
column3: Sh wabshaba g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag ab baꞌich i si mahkch g Steven g gewkdag. Tsh am i nea dahm kahchim wui k nei mo si s‑masma tonod g Jiosh gewkdag. Kush g Jesus an si hugidaj an kehk g Jiosh.

column2: “Look,” he said, “I see heaven open, and the Son of Man standing at God's right hand.”
column3: Kush hab kaij g Steven, “Neido! B at e kuhpiꞌo g dahm kahchim. K ab kehk g Jiosh si Kehsha an si s‑apko hugidaj an g Jiosh.”

column2: But they held their hands over their ears and shouted as loudly as they could. They rushed together at him,
column3: Tsh si hihinkiad k am si kuhkp g e‑nahnk k ab hahawa si wui i wohp

column2: dragged him out of the city, and began to stone him. His accusers laid their coats down beside a young man called Saul.
column3: k an be k gam hu i wuhshad kihhim t amjed mat wo maꞌichkwua. Sh am hema ha wehmaj g wechij oꞌodham ch hab chehgig Saul. Kutsh heg nuhkudach g e‑liliwa hegam matsh wo maꞌichkwua g Steven.

column2: As they went on stoning him, Stephen prayed, “Lord Jesus, receive my spirit.”
column3: Kush g Steven ab si ihm g e‑doꞌibiakam ch hab kaij, “Ni‑kownalig Jesus, ia g behꞌi ni‑doakag.”

column2: He kneeled down, calling out, “Lord, please don't hold this sin against them!” And after he said this, he died.
column3: Tsh am hahawa tohtonwua g Steven k si s‑kaidam hab kaij, “Ni‑kownalig, pi g ab hu ha abchud ihda chuꞌijig mat ihab e juh.” Bash kaij ch am i muh.

column2: Saul approved of his killing. On that very day terrible persecution broke out against the church in Jerusalem, and everyone except for the apostles were scattered throughout Judea and Samaria.
column3: Sh g Saul am wabsh apꞌechud mamt mua.

column2: (Some faithful followers of God buried Stephen, with great mourning).
column3: Tsh haꞌi hegam mo ab d si ihmdam g Jiosh ged hu cheh g Steven k si s‑kaidam shoani wehhejed.

column2: But Saul set about destroying the church, going from house to house, dragging both men and women off to prison.
column3: Kush g Saul chum s‑padchudamk g ha‑mihshmda g Jesus ihmdam ch hekaj an wahkhim ha‑kihki oidch ch ab i ha chewaimed ch ged hu si ha kuhpahim, chum wa g uꞌuwi.

column2: Those who had been scattered spread the word wherever they went.
column3: Kush wa an wehsko ahgahim g Jesus hegam matsh wa e gantad.

column2: Philip went to the town of Samaria, and told them about the Messiah.
column3: Hegai Philip mash wa am d ha‑kehsha atsh am hih Samaria kihhim wui k am ha mihshmad ch am ha ahgid mat heki hu an i wuhsh g Jiosh si Kehsha.

column2: When the crowds heard what Philip was saying and saw the miracles he did they all paid attention to what he was telling them.
column3: Kush ab si kaiham hegam hemajkam mo haschu i ha ahgid ch am neid mo s‑hasigam haꞌichu hab junihim g Jiosh gewkdagkaj.

column2: Many were freed from possession by evil spirits that screamed as they came out, and many who were lame or disabled were healed.
column3: Muꞌijj ash e dodajid hegam mash g jijawul an ha uꞌukch. Kush si hihnk g jijawul gam hu hihimadch. Kush muꞌijj ha dodajid hegam mo pi hihimdag ch hegam mo pi ab hu gewpk.

column2: The people who lived in the city were overjoyed.
column3: Sh si s‑hehgig g hemajkam amai.

column2: Now there was a man named Simon who lived in the city. He practiced sorcery. He claimed that he was someone very important, and had astounded the people of Samaria
column3: Sh am hema kih g oꞌodham mash hab chehgig Simon ch heki hu waꞌi amjed am hab junihim g s‑hasigam haꞌichu ch hab chum e wua mo d ge mahkai.

column2: so they all paid attention to him. From the lowest to the highest in society they said, “This man is ‘God the Great Power.’ ”
column3: Kush wehs g hemajkam am si neidachug ch ab si has elid, chum wa hegam mo d s‑chu aꞌamichuddam.

column2: They were impressed by him because he had amazed them with his magic for so long.
column3: Bash kaij ch ab si kaiham nash pi heki hu waꞌi amjed hab junihim g s‑hasigam haꞌichu.

column2: But when they believed in what Philip told them about the good news about the kingdom of God and the name of Jesus Christ, they were baptized, both men and women.
column3: Tsh wabshaba am hahawa ha mihshmad g Philip ab amjed g Jiosh kownaltalig ch ab amjed g Jesus Christ. Kutsh ab i s‑wohochud k e pahl wapko.

column2: Simon too believed and was baptized. He accompanied Philip, amazed at the miraculous signs and wonders he saw.
column3: Tsh hab waꞌap ab i s‑wohoch g Simon k e pahl wakon k amjed pi hebai dagito g Philip k ab si has elid am i neidok mo hab junihim g s‑hasigam haꞌichu.

column2: When the apostles back in Jerusalem heard that the people of Samaria had accepted the word of God, they sent Peter and John to visit them.
column3: Tsh am i ha ai hegam Jesus chuhchai ab Jerusalem t ab matsh idam Samaria t am oꞌodham ab bei g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga. Kush am ha chehani g Peter ch John matsh am wo ha mihshmedo.

column2: When they arrived they prayed for the converts in Samaria to receive the Holy Spirit.  The Holy Spirit hadn't come to any of these converts yet—they had only been baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus.
column3: Tsh am hihi idam k ged hu dada k am ha wehm e hemapai. Kutsh eda pi koi bei g gewkdag ab amjed g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag hegam matsh e pahl wapko. Kutsh am e hoꞌigeꞌidahun k ab tai g Jiosh mat hab wo wa e juh am ha tahgio

column2: The apostles placed their hands on them, and they received the Holy Spirit.
column3: k amjed an i ha tahtamahi ab ihmch g Jiosh. Tsh g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag ab hahawa ha mah g gewkdag.

column2: When Simon saw that the Holy Spirit was given when the apostles placed their hands on people, he offered them money.
column3: Tsh g Simon am i nei ihda k chum s‑ha namkidam

column2: “Give me this power, too,” he asked them, “so that anyone I place my hands on will receive the Holy Spirit.”
column3: k hab kaij, “Ab g i ni‑mahki ihda gewkdag mant hedai ab wo i taht, t wo bei g gewkdag ab amjed g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag.”

column2: “May your money be destroyed together with you for thinking God's gift is something that can be bought!” Peter replied.
column3: Sh wabshaba hab kaij g Peter ab wui, “T wabsh wo huhug g s‑m‑kaischuda hab wa masma mapt ahpi wo huhug. Pi o hab chum chuꞌig mapt hekaj wo nolawt g Jiosh mahkigdag.

column2: “You're not part of any of this. None of this work belongs to you, because in God's eyes your attitude is totally wrong.
column3: Pi o shaꞌi apꞌe g m‑chegitoi am Jiosh tahgio. K heg hekaj pi ab hu d shaꞌi m‑wuikam ihda chikpan.

column2: Repent of your evil ways! Pray to the Lord and ask forgiveness for thinking like this.  I can see that you are full of bitter envy, and chained down by your sin.”
column3: Gan o hu wabsh i si m‑uꞌukch g pi apꞌekam napki pi s‑chu hehgamk. Pt gam hu wo s‑ohhod g pi ap e‑chegitoi k ab wo i e hoꞌigeꞌidahu Jiosh wui. Tp hems gam hu hab wo i juh g m‑chuꞌijig.”

column2: “Please pray for me, that nothing you've said may happen to me!” Simon replied.
column3: Sh hab kaij g Simon ab ha wui, “Ab g wo si i s‑ni‑hoꞌigeꞌid k am wo e hoꞌigeꞌidahu Jiosh wui ni‑wehhejed mat pi gam hu hab wo ni‑juh.”

column2: After they had given their testimony and shared the word of the Lord, they returned to Jerusalem, sharing the good news in many Samaritan villages along the way.
column3: Tsh am hahawa ha mihshmad g Peter ch John ab amjed g Jesus k am ha ahgi mo haschu g e‑wuhpuikaj neid. Tsh am hebai i cheka. Kutsh gam hu uhpam hihi Jerusalem wui am ahgachugch g s‑kehg haꞌichu ahgaj g Jiosh am aꞌai kihhim ch ed heg eda Samaria chekshani.

column2: An angel of the Lord told Philip, “Get ready and go south to the desert road that leads from Jerusalem to Gaza.”
column3: Kush g anghil am hema neok ch hab kaij ab Philip wui, “Am g i e nakog k gam hu hihm k am wo i ai hegai wohg m an hims tohono jewed ch ed am ha shahgid g Jerusalem ch Gaza.”

column2: So Philip set out, and met an Ethiopian man, a eunuch who had a high position in the service of the Kandake, Queen of Ethiopia. He was her chief treasurer. He had gone to Jerusalem to worship there, and  was returning from his trip, sitting in his chariot. He was reading out loud from the book of the prophet Isaiah.
column3: Tsh wa woho am i e nako g Philip k gam hu hih.

column2: The Spirit told Philip, “Go over close to the chariot.”
column3: Kush hab kaij g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag ab wui g Philip, “An g i miabid hegai kalit k gan hu hugidaj an wo i hih.”

column2: So Philip ran over, and heard the man reading from the prophet Isaiah.
column3: Tsh am hahawa si meh g Philip k an i miabi g kalit. Kush ihda am neꞌokchulid hegai matsh g Isaiabad an oꞌoha.

column2: “How can I, unless someone explains it?” the man replied. He invited Philip to get in and sit beside him.
column3: Sh hab kaij ihda s‑has haꞌichu, “Pi ant has masma wo s‑amich, heg hi wa matp am hema wo i ni‑tashogi,” ch amjed ab i wai g Philip mat gan hu wehmaj wo dahiwua kalit ch ed. T wa woho an i chesh.

column2: The Scripture passage he was reading was this: “He was led like a sheep to be slaughtered. Like a lamb is silent in front of his shearer, he didn't say a word.
column3: Kush eda id an neꞌokchulid mo hab chuꞌig an Jiosh oꞌohana ed:

column2: The eunuch asked Philip, “Tell me, who is the prophet talking about? Is it himself, or someone else?”
column3: Sh hab kaij g s‑has haꞌichu ab Philip wui, “Am g ni‑ahgid. Dohꞌo hab ahg g Jiosh haꞌichu i tashogiddam? No hejel hab e ahg aha no wabsh hema hab ahg?”

column2: Philip started explaining, beginning from this Scripture, telling him about Jesus.
column3: Tsh g Philip amjed am i shonch id ab mash am neꞌokchulid k am ahgid g s‑kehg haꞌichu ahga ab amjed g Jesus.

column2: As they continued on, they came to a stretch of water. The eunuch said, “Look, there's water here—why shouldn't I be baptized?”
column3: Sh am wabsh kia wohpo wohg oidch ch am hu hebai neꞌibij mash am ge shuhdagi. Sh hab kaij g s‑has haꞌichu, “Neh, m ia ge shuhdagi. No am hig haꞌichu ehp manis heg hekaj pi wo ni‑pahl wako?”
Sh am hahawa ahgid g Philip, “Bapt waꞌi masma wo e pahl wako mapt wehskaj am wo i e dagito Jesus wui.”

column2: He ordered that the chariot be stopped. Philip and the eunuch both went down into the water and Philip baptized him.
column3: Sh am hahawa i ahgid hegai e‑pionag mo melchudahim g kalit mat wo keshwua. Tsh am huhud ab kalit t ab k am i huhud shuhdagi ch ed. Tsh am pahl wako g Philip ihda oꞌodham.

column2: When they came out of the water the Spirit of the Lord took Philip away. The eunuch never saw him again, but he continued on his way full of joy. Philip found himself at Azotus.
column3: Tsh g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag gam hu wa hekaj i bei g Philip. Sh amjed si s‑hehgig ihda s‑has haꞌichuch gam hu uhpam meh pi hekid ep shaꞌi neidk g Philip.

column2: He spread the good news in all the towns along the way until he arrived at Caesarea.
column3: Tsh g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag gam hu uꞌapa g Philip Ashdod kihhim t am. Tsh am i ahgahi g haꞌichu ahga ab amjed g Jesus k ga hu ai g Cesaria kihhim.

column2: But meanwhile Saul was making violent threats against the disciples of the Lord, wanting to kill them. He went to the high priest
column3: Kush eda id oidam g Saul wabsh kia ha oid hegam mash am oid g Jesus himdag ch s‑gewkam ha ebkiod ch s‑ha kokdaimk. Sh am hu hebai i, sh ab si tahni g uhgchu pahl

column2: and asked for letters of authorization to take with him to the synagogues in Damascus, giving him permission to arrest any believers in the Way that he found, men or women, and bring them back to Jerusalem as prisoners.
column3: matsh am wo ha oꞌohani g papal am Damascus kihhim t am. Kutsh heg wo be k am wo him k wo ha chehgi. Tsh hegam wo s‑mahchk mo uꞌukch g e‑apꞌedag. Kutsh wo ha ui hegam mo am oid g Jesus himdag k am wo uhpam i ha ui Jerusalem wui, chum wa g uꞌuwi. Tsh wa woho hab e juh g uhgchu pahl.

column2: As Saul approached Damascus, suddenly he was surrounded by a light that blazed down from heaven.
column3: Tsh am hih g Saul haꞌi ha wehm g chechoj k gam hu i aihim g Damascus kihhim. Tsh haha wabsh haꞌichu si ton ab dahm kahchim t amjed an wehgaj.

column2: He fell to the ground, and heard a voice saying, “Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me?”
column3: Tsh am i gei g Saul jewedo. Sh ab hema si neok ab dahm kahchim t amjed ch hab kaij, “Saul, s‑wohom ap hig ni‑shoꞌigchud.”

column2: “Who are you, Lord?” Saul asked.
column3: Sh si has elid g Saul ch hab kaij, “Dohp wud ch ab neok?”

column2: “Get up, go on into the city, and you'll be told what to do.”
column3: Ab g i wamig k am hihm k am wo i wah Damascus ch ed. T am haha wo hema m‑ahgi mapt haschu am hab wo chum juh.”

column2: The men who were traveling with Saul stood there speechless. They heard the voice speaking, but they didn't see anyone.
column3: Tsh hegam mo am wehmaj ab wabsh i gewpka k pi has shaꞌi kaij ch ash hi wa kah g neꞌoki ch wabshaba pi shaꞌi neid mas hedai ab neok.

column2: Saul got to his feet, and when he opened his eyes, he couldn't see anything. His companions took him by the hand and led him into Damascus.
column3: Tsh am hahawa i wami g Saul k ab chum si i nea. Tsh wabshaba pi ab hu mamsi g wuhpuij. Kumtsh am haha wabsh i wanimed k ged hu uꞌapa Damascus ch ed.

column2: For three days he couldn't see, and he didn't eat or drink anything.
column3: Kush waik tashkaj pi haꞌichu shaꞌi neid ch ep pi haꞌichu shaꞌi koꞌa ch pi haꞌichu ihꞌe.

column2: A follower of Jesus called Ananias lived in Damascus, and the Lord spoke to him in a vision.
column3: Kush eda am hema d Jesus ihmdam amai ch ash hab chehgig Ananias. Tsh g Jiosh am haꞌichu hab juh nenaj tahgio mash heg eda g Jesus am chehcheg.

column2: “Get up, and go to Straight Street,” the Lord told him. “Ask at Judas' house for someone called Saul, from Tarsus. He's praying.
column3: Kush hab hahawa kaij g Jesus, “Am g i e nakog k am hihm heg kih wui Judas mo am kih Shelini Kahya oidch. Amai o hema dak ch e hoꞌigeꞌidahun ch hab chehgig Saul ch ab d kihkam Tarsus kihhim t ab.

column2: He's seen in vision a man called Ananias come and place his hands on him so he can regain his sight.”
column3: Kunt am nenaj tahgio haꞌichu hab juh mapt am wo jiwia wui ahpi Ananias ch ab wo taht mat ep wo mamsi g wuhpuij.”

column2: “But Lord,” Ananias replied, “I've heard a lot about this man—about all the evil things he did to the believers in Jerusalem.
column3: Sh hab kaij g Ananias, “Ni‑kownalig, ihda oꞌodham atsh muꞌi ha shoꞌigch g m‑hemajkamga am Jerusalem ch ed. Muꞌijj o hab ni‑ahgid ab amjed.

column2: The chief priests have given him the power to arrest everyone here that worships and follows you.”
column3: Kutsh heg hekaj ia jiwia mash uꞌukch g apꞌedag ab ha amjed g uꞌugchu papal mat wo uhpam i ha ui hegam mo ab m‑ihm.”

column2: But the Lord told him, “Get on your way, because he is the person I have chosen to take my name to foreigners and kings, as well as to Israel.
column3: Kush hab kaij g Jesus ab wui, “Am apt wo wa hih nant pi id am si i kei mat am ni‑wehhejed wo chikp am i ahgahimk g ni‑himdag ha wui g Tutuligo ch am ha wui g nahnko mahs hemajkam ch kokownal.

column2: I will show him what he'll have to suffer for my name's sake.”
column3: Nt ahni am wo wa chehgi ihda Saul mat has i masma wo e shoꞌigch am ni‑wehhejed.”

column2: So Ananias left and went to the house. He placed his hands on Saul. “Brother Saul,” he said, “The Lord Jesus, who appeared to you on the road as you were traveling here, has sent me so you can regain your sight and be filled with the Holy Spirit.”
column3: Tsh wa woho am hih g Ananias heg wui kih k ab si i s‑ha hoꞌigeꞌel g kihkam. Tsh ab i wahki. Tsh ab hahawa e mahtchul g Ananias Saul wui k hab kaij, “Ni‑nawoj, Saul, am apsh neid g geꞌechu t‑kownalig Jesus ab himadch wohg oidch. T heg ab ni‑cheha mantsh ab wo i him k ab wo m‑taht. Tsh ep wo mamsi g m‑wuhpui. Kutsh ab wo m‑mah g gewkdaj g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag.” Neh, bash kaij ch ab hahawa taht.

column2: Immediately, something like scales fell from his eyes, and his sight was restored. He got up and was baptized.
column3: Tsh ab ha hekaj i mamsi g wuhpuij. Tsh hahawa ep s‑ap haꞌichu neid k am ha hekaj i e nakog k e pahl wakon

column2: He also had something to eat and felt stronger.
column3: k ep haꞌichu hug k ab uhpam ep i gewka.

column2: He immediately started speaking in the synagogues, saying, “Jesus is the Son of God.”
column3: Kush am haꞌi chechopi g Tutuligo. Sh g Saul am ha mihshmad g e‑wehm oꞌodham ab amjed g Jesus am ah ahgidch mo d Jiosh alidag.

column2: All who heard him were amazed, and asked, “Isn't this the man who caused so much trouble in Jerusalem for those who believed in Jesus? Wasn't he coming here to have the believers arrested and taken in chains to the chief priests?”
column3: Tsh si has i el hegam mo hedai i kah k hab kaij, “Aha no pi d ihda mash an ha kokdahim hegam mash am oid hegai himdag Jerusalem t ab ch heg hekaj ia jiwia mat in wo i ha uꞌihim k am uhpam wo i ha ui uꞌugchu papal ha wui.”

column2: Saul grew more and more confident, proving Jesus was the Messiah so convincingly that the Jews who lived in Damascus could not refute him.
column3: Tsh g Saul mihshmda am i si e gewkai. Kutsh wa wohokamch mo g Jesus d Jiosh si Kehsha. Tsh hekaj pi e nako g wehmaj oꞌodham mat ab hu has wo ah.

column2: Some time later the Jews plotted together to kill him,  but Saul learned of their intentions. Day and night they waited by the city gates looking for the chance to murder him.
column3: Sh am hu i hebai amjed, tsh g Tutuligo am i e nako matsh wo mua g Saul. K eda si uhgk kolhaitas g kihhim. Kumsh si nuhkud g kihjegaj tash oidam ch s‑chuhugam oidam. Tsh wabshaba s‑mai g Saul mam s‑muꞌamk.

column2: So during the night his followers took him and lowered him down in a basket from an opening in the city wall.
column3: Tsh hegam mat ab i s‑wohoch g Saul haꞌichu ahga ab amjed g Jesus am dai washomi ch ed k ab i huduni chuhug ch ed g wijinakaj ab amjed mash ab hebai ge wintani kolhai t ab.

column2: When Saul arrived in Jerusalem, he tried to meet with the disciples, but they were all afraid of him because they were not convinced he was really a disciple.
column3: Tsh amjed gam hu hahawa hih Jerusalem wui k ab chum ha shahgid i s‑wahkim hegam Jesus ihmdam mat ab wo i ha wehmt. Sh wabshaba s‑ehbid ch pi wohochud mas woho pi has wo ha juh

column2: However, Barnabas took him to meet the apostles, and explained to them how Saul had seen the Lord on the road and how the Lord had spoken to Saul. Barnabas also explained how in Damascus Saul had spoken boldly in the name of Jesus.
column3: Kush oi wa am wehhejed neok g Barnabas am ha wui g Jesus chuhchai. Tsh hegam hiwigi matsh am i wahki ha shahgid. Sh am ha ahgid mash g Saul am himad ch haha wabsh neid g Jesus amai wohg ch ed ch ep kah mo ab neok. Sh am ep ha ahgid matsh has masma si s‑gewkam am i ha mihshmad ab amjed g Jesus amai Damascus t am. Tsh g Jesus chuhchai am hahawa s‑wohoch.

column2: Saul stayed with the apostles and accompanied them all over Jerusalem,
column3: Sh am ha wehm dakahim ch wehsko oimmed ch am si s‑gewkam ha mihshmad g hemajkam ab amjed g Jesus Jerusalem ch ed.

column2: speaking boldly in the name of the Lord. He talked and debated with the Greek-speaking Jews, but they tried to kill him.
column3: Kutsh hegam Tutuligo mo neneok g Greek neꞌokikaj am i chum e nako matsh wo mua nash pi ha wehm e neꞌowin ab amjed g Jesus.

column2: When the brothers learned of this they took him to Caesarea, and sent him to Tarsus.
column3: Kutsh g Jesus ihmdam am i kah ihda k am i bei Cesaria kihhim wui k am ahgid matsh gam hu wo hih e‑kihhim wui mash d Tarsus. Neh, tsh gam hu hih.

column2: During this time the whole church throughout Judea, Galilee, and Samaria was left in peace. The church grew strong and increased rapidly in numbers as the believers lived reverently for the Lord, encouraged by the Holy Spirit.
column3: Tsh am hahawa dodolimat haꞌichu am ha wehhejed wehsko am Judea ch Galilee ch Samaria ch ed. Kutsh muꞌi ep ab i s‑wohoch g haꞌichu ha‑ahga ab amjed g Jesus k ab si has elid g Jiosh. Kush ab si ha wehmaj g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag.

column2: Peter was traveling around and went to visit the believers who lived in Lydda.
column3: Sh eda g Peter an wehsko oimmed e‑jewedga oidk ch am i ha chehgim hegam mash ab ihm g Jesus. Sh am haꞌi dadha Lydda kihhim t am. Kutsh ged hu jiwia.

column2: There he met a man called Aeneas who was paralyzed and had been confined to his bed for eight years.
column3: Sh am hema kih g pi himidkam ch hab chehgig Aneus ch ab wabsh i s‑moik ch ash gigiꞌik aꞌahid ab pi shaꞌi e nako mas am wo i wami ab e‑woꞌikud amjed.

column2: Peter told him, “Aeneas, Jesus Christ heals you! Get up and pick up your mat!” Immediately Aeneas got up.
column3: Kutsh g Peter am i chehgim k hab kaij ab wui, “Aneus, Jesus Christ at wo m‑doaj. Ab g i wamig k am i holiwkad g e‑wahpakus.”

column2: Everyone living in Lydda and Sharon saw him, and became believers in the Lord.
column3: Kutsh muꞌijj ab i s‑wohoch g s‑kehg haꞌichu ahga ab amjed g Jesus hegam mo am kih Lydda ch Sharon kihhim t am nash pi neid matki doa ihda oꞌodham.

column2: In Joppa lived a follower called Tabitha, (Dorcas in Greek). She was always doing good and helping the poor.
column3: Sh am hema kih g uwi Joppa kihhim t am ch d e doꞌibiakam ch chum hekid s‑ap haꞌichu am hab junihim ch am haꞌichukaj i ha wehmaj g shoꞌigkam. Sh hab chehgig ihda Tabitha mo hab d ahga Kuhwid.

column2: However about this time she became sick, and died. After washing her body, they laid her out in an upstairs room.
column3: Kush am wabsh kia daha g Peter Lydda t am. Tsh am wabsh si mumku ihda uwi k am i muh. Tsh am i apꞌech g chuhkugaj k am woi mash an hema kehk g kih gan hu uhgk kih dahm.

column2: Lydda was near Joppa, so the disciples in Joppa, hearing that Peter was in Lydda, sent two men to him with the message, “Please come to us right away.”
column3: K eda g Joppa pi shaꞌi mehk ab Lydda t amjed. Kumtsh am i kah amai Joppa t am mo am haꞌichug g Peter k am gohk ha cheha g chechoj matsh am wo wohp k ab wo wai. Kutsh wa woho am wohp k am wai matsh s‑hohtam ab wo i hih Joppa wui.

column2: So Peter got ready and left with them. When he arrived they took him upstairs. All the widows were there crying, and they showed him the coats and clothes that Dorcas had made while she was with them.
column3: Tsh am wa hekaj i e nako g Peter k gam hu ha oi.

column2: Peter told them all to leave, kneeled down, and prayed. He turned to the body and said, “Tabitha, get up.” She opened her eyes, and when she saw Peter she sat up.
column3: Tsh gam hu wehs i ha wuwhas g Peter k am i tonwua k e hoꞌigeꞌidahu ab Jiosh wui k ab hahawa si neok wui g muhki ch hab kaij, “Tabitha, ab g i wamig.”

column2: He took her by the hand and lifted her up. He called in the believers and the widows, and presented her to them alive.
column3: Kutsh g Peter an i wehmt. Kutsh kekiwua. Tsh ab hahawa wehs i ha waid k ab ha chehgi mo d doakam.

column2: The news spread through the whole of Joppa, and many believed in the Lord.
column3: Tsh ihda matsh haschu has e juh am wehsko kaida Joppa t am. Tsh muꞌijj ab i s‑wohoch g s‑kehg haꞌichu ahga ab amjed g Jesus.

column2: Peter spent a long time in Joppa, staying at the house of Simon the tanner.
column3: Sh muꞌi tashkaj am dakahim g Peter Joppa t am heg wehm mash hab chehgig Simon ch ash g hogi chikpan hab wua.

column2: In Caesarea lived a man named Cornelius who was a Roman centurion of the Italian battalion.
column3: Sh am dadha g siant shondal Cesaria kihhim t am mash ab amjed g Italy jewed. Kush g ha‑uhgchuga hab chehgig Cornelius

column2: He was a religious man who, together with everyone in his household, had great reverence for God. He gave generously to the poor, and prayed regularly to God.
column3: ch ash si oid g Jiosh himdag ch am ep i ha wehmt g shoꞌigkam Tutuligo ch ab ihm g Jiosh. Kush g wehmaj kihkam wehsijj hab waꞌap ab si ihm g Jiosh.

column2: At about 3 p.m. one day he had a vision in which he saw very clearly an angel of God who came to him and called to him, “Cornelius!”
column3: Sh hema tash mash d i waik ohla im hab i juhk, tsh am nenaj ed hab e juh matsh am jiwia g anghil k am si chehch hab kaijch, “Cornelius.”

column2: Frightened, Cornelius stared at him and asked, “What do you want, Lord?”
column3: Sh ab hu wabsh si neid ihda anghil ch wabsh s‑ehbeni ch hab kaij, “Shahchu ap ahgahim ch ab neok?”

column2: “Now send some men to Joppa, and fetch Simon, also called Peter,
column3: Pegih, pt hemuch haꞌi wo ha cheha g chechoj mat am wo hihi Joppa wui k am wo nei hegai mo hab chehgig Simon Peter.

column2: who is staying at Simon the tanner's house down by the sea-shore.”
column3: Am o da heg kih am mo d hogi chikpandam ch hab waꞌap chehgig Simon ch am kih ge kahchki hugid an.”

column2: When the angel who had spoken to him had left, Cornelius called in two of his house-servants and a soldier of his personal guard, a religious man.
column3: Tsh amjed gam hu hahawa hih hegai anghil mash ab wui neok. Tsh g Cornelius am hahawa waik ha wai g e‑pionag. Sh hema idam d shondal ch si oid g Jiosh himdag.

column2: After he'd explained to them all that had happened he sent them to Joppa.
column3: Kutsh am ha ahgi idam matsh haschu has e juh k am hahawa ha cheha mat gam hu wo hihi Joppa wui.

column2: The next day, as they were on their way and approaching the city, Peter went up onto the top of the house to pray. It was about noon,
column3: Sh am baꞌich d i tash matsh am dahm i juh, sh am wabsh kia hihim idam ch ab hi wa aihim g kihhim. Tsh eda g Peter gm hu hejelko him k am e hoꞌigeꞌidahun.

column2: and he was getting hungry, wanting to eat. But while the meal was being prepared, he fell into a trance, and
column3: k ash am i si bihugim k chum haꞌichu s‑hugimk. Tsh eda koi bai g hihidod. Kutsh am Peter nena ed hab e juh

column2: he saw heaven opened. He saw something coming down that looked like a large sheet held by its four corners, being lowered onto the earth.
column3: matsh ab i e kuhpiꞌo g dahm kahchim. Kutsh ab haꞌichu i e huduni jewedo k hab mahs mo g lohna ch shaꞌi si geꞌej ch an aꞌai e uꞌukch chuhchpulij an ch ab i tadanich.

column2: Inside were all kinds of animals and reptiles and birds.
column3: Sh id eda am haꞌichug g nahnko mahs haꞌichu doakam ch wahammad ch uꞌuwhig.

column2: He heard a voice say, “Get up Peter, kill and eat!”
column3: Sh hab kaij g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag, “Peter, i g wuhshani k am wabsh chum haschu wo ha mua idam k hekaj wo e gegos.”

column2: But Peter replied, “Certainly not, Lord! I have never eaten anything that is impure and unclean.”
column3: Tsh wabshaba g Peter hab si chei, “Ih, pi ant am hu hab wo ni‑juh, ni‑kownalig. Pi ani hekid koꞌa hegai mo g m‑chehanig pi t‑hiwgid machs wo koꞌad.”

column2: He heard the voice speak again, “Don't you call unclean what God has made clean!”
column3: Sh hab hahawa kaij hegai mo ab neok, “Pi g hab shaꞌi elid mas pi apꞌe hegai mo haschu g Jiosh hemu am m‑chehgid mo s‑apꞌe.”

column2: This happened three times, and then the sheet was quickly taken back into heaven.
column3: Tsh waikko hab e juh ihda am nenaj ed. Tsh amjed im hu hahawa uhpam i e bei ihda haꞌichu am dahm kahchim wui.

column2: While Peter was puzzling over what the vision he'd seen really meant, the men sent by Cornelius had found out where Simon's house was and were standing at the gate.
column3: Sh am wabsh kia oidahim g Peter hegai matsh haschu nei. Tsh heg i eda idam Cornelius pionag am i s‑mai mo hebai i kih g Simon k am dada k ab gegok kolhai kihjeg t ab

column2: They called out, asking whether Simon, also called Peter, was staying there.
column3: ch ab si s‑kaidam ha kakke, “No ia hema daha mo hab chehgig Simon Peter?”

column2: While Peter was still wondering about the vision, the Spirit said to him, “Look, there are three men looking for you.
column3: Kush eda g Peter am wabsh kia chum aꞌamichud mas has d ahga hegai mat am nei.

column2: Get up, go downstairs, and go with them. Don't worry at all because I'm the one who sent them.”
column3: Pt am wo i e nakog k am wo ha nei. Pi g has shaꞌi ha elid mo d ge gawul mahs hemajkam k wabsh wo ha oi. Ahni o d ni‑tatchui mat ab i hihi.”

column2: So Peter went downstairs to meet the men. “I'm the one you're looking for,” he said. “Why are you here?”
column3: Tsh wa woho am i hud g Peter k hab kaij ab ha wui idam oꞌodham, “Ahni ani wud mam s‑ni‑neidamk. Shahchu amt ahgk ia dada?”

column2: “We come from Cornelius, a good, religious man who has reverence for God and is widely respected among the Jewish people,” they replied. “A holy angel instructed him to send for you to come to his house so he can hear what you have to tell him.”
column3: Sh hab hahawa kaij idam oꞌodham, “No pi ab t‑chehani g Cornelius. Heg o d shondal ha‑uhgchuga Cesaria t ab ch si s‑ap d oꞌodham k ch ab si ihm g Jiosh. K g Tutuligo hab waꞌap ab si has elid. Tsh g anghil ab wui i hih ab amjed g Jiosh k hab ahg mat ab wo i m‑wai e‑kih wui k wo m‑kah mapt haschu wo i ahgi.”

column2: So he invited them in and they stayed there.
column3: Tsh ab i ha wahpki g Peter idam waik oꞌodham mat am wo waꞌi kohk.

column2: The following day they arrived in Caesarea where Cornelius was waiting for them with his relatives and close friends whom he'd called together.
column3: Am baꞌich d ep i tash. Tsh ged hu hahawa dada Cesaria t am.

column2: When Peter entered the house, Cornelius met him and fell down at his feet and worshiped him.
column3: Tsh ab wabsh chum i wah g Peter. Tsh g Cornelius ab si daꞌiwuni k ab si i gei wecho ab si has elidch.

column2: But Peter pulled him back up, telling him, “Stand up! I'm only a man!”
column3: Tsh wabshaba hab ah g Peter, “Pi g shaꞌi ni‑wui i gehsh. Dani wabsh oꞌodham.”

column2: Peter spoke with Cornelius, and then went on in where he found many other people waiting for him.
column3: Kush am e wehm neneokhim ch am i wahp. Sh am muꞌi dadha g hemajkam.

column2: He said to them, “You certainly know that it's not permitted for a Jew to be associated with or to visit foreigners. But God has shown me that it's not for me to call anyone impure or unclean.
column3: Kush am ha neid g Peter ch hab kaij ab ha wui, “Am am wa s‑mahch mach ahchim Tutuligo pi shaꞌi hiwgidas ab t‑himdag amjed machs ab wo i s‑em‑hajunima ahpim mam d gawul mahs hemajkam, niꞌichs am hu wo em‑chehgim em‑kihki wui. T wabshaba g Jiosh am ni‑chehgi mant iꞌajed pi am hu has wo shaꞌi em‑elidad.

column2: That's why I came without any argument when I was sent for. So now I want to know the reason why you sent for me.”
column3: Nt hekaj ab i hih pi shaꞌi has elidk mam d ge gawul mahs hemajkam. Pegih, m haschu ahgch am ni‑waid.”

column2: “Four days ago, at about this time—three in the afternoon—I was praying in my house,” Cornelius explained. “Suddenly I saw a man standing in front of me, dressed in clothes that shone brightly.
column3: Sh hab kaij g Cornelius, “Am ani ni‑hoꞌigeꞌidahun ni‑kih am d hu hema i tako imhab i juhk. T am haha wabsh hema jiwia g oꞌodham. K si tonod g wehschugaj. K ab kehk ni‑wui

column2: He told me, ‘Cornelius, your prayers have been heard, and God has recognized your generosity to the poor.
column3: ch hab kaij, ‘Cornelius, ab o kaiham g Jiosh g m‑hoꞌigeꞌidahuna ch s‑hohhoꞌid hegai map haschu am hab junihim g shoꞌigkam ha wehhejed.

column2: Send someone to Joppa for Simon Peter. He's staying at Simon the tanner's house, down by the sea-shore.’
column3: Pt wo haꞌi ha cheha mat am wo hihi Joppa wui k am wo wai hegai oꞌodham mo hab chehgig Simon Peter. Am wo da heg kih am mo d hogi chikpandam ch hab chehgig Simon ch an kih ge kahchki hugid an.’ Neh, bo kaij.

column2: So immediately I sent for you, and it was good of you to come. That's why we're all here, meeting together before God, ready to hear everything the Lord has told you.”
column3: “Kunt am hahawa haꞌi ha cheha mat am hihim k ab i m‑wai. Kupt s‑ap e juh k ab i hih. Kuch hemuch ia dadha am nenaj ed g Jiosh ch s‑kaimk hegai mat haschu g Jiosh am wo i m‑ahgi mapt am hab wo chei.”

column2: Peter replied, “I'm totally convinced that God has no favorites.
column3: Tsh wa woho am hahawa haꞌichu i ahgahi g Peter k hab kaij, “Hahawa ant wa s‑mai moki woho mo g Jiosh wehs ha wepo masma ha neid g nahnko mahs hemajkam.

column2: In every nation God accepts those who respect him, and do what is right.
column3: K hegam d si tatchuij mo hedai ab i si has elid ch am hab junihim g s‑apꞌekam, chum as pi d wo Tutuligo hemajkamk.

column2: You know the message he sent to Israel, sharing the good news of peace that comes from Jesus Christ, who is Lord of all.
column3: Am amki chum heki hu kah ab amjed ihda mant haschu wo i em‑ahgi nam pi ia t‑shahgid dadha ahchim Tutuligo. K ahchim am t‑ahgid g Jiosh mash s‑ha doꞌibiamk g hemajkam am gahi wuhshanim g e‑alidag Jesus Christ. Heg o wud mat g Jiosh am i kei mat wehs d wo ha‑kownaligk g nahnko mahs hemajkam.

column2: You know that this good news spread throughout Judea, beginning in Galilee, following John's call to baptism.  It's about Jesus of Nazareth—how God anointed him with the Holy Spirit and with power, and how he went around doing good, healing all those who were under the devil's control, for God was with him.
column3: K wa am hema t‑jehnigid ab amjed g Jesus ch am t‑pahl wapkon ch hab chehgig John. T am i wuhsh g Jesus k am e pahl wako heg ab John. T g Jiosh ab mah g si geꞌe gewkdag am gahi wuhshanim g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag mat hekaj hab wo junihid g e‑chikpan. T g Jesus am i shonwuich g e‑chikpan Galilee chekshani ch ed k am hahawa wehsko hab junihim Judea chekshani ch ed. Jiosh o am wehmaj. K hekaj wehsko i ha wehmt g e‑hemajkamga ch ha dodajid hegam mo g jiawul ha shoꞌigchud.

column2: We can testify to all that he did in Judea and Jerusalem. They killed him by hanging him on a cross.
column3: “Kuch ahchim am wehmajkahim ch g si t‑wuhpuikaj neid hegai mo haschu hab junihim am wehsko t‑jewedga ed ch am Jerusalem ch ed. Kumt an be k mua ab naggiak kots t ab.

column2: But God raised him back to life on the third day, and had him appear,
column3: T wabshaba g Jiosh ab uhpam i wuhshad muhkig amjed mo d i waik tash k am i t‑chehgi.

column2: not to everyone, but to those witnesses chosen by God—including us, who ate and drank with him after he rose from the dead.
column3: K pi wabsh chum hedai neid. Ahchim ach waꞌi neid mat heꞌekiajj g Jiosh heki hu am i t‑chuhcha. Tt wa am wehmaj t‑gegos am i dahm mat g Jiosh ab i wuhshad muhkig amjed.

column2: He gave us the responsibility of publicly telling this to the people, to testify that he is the one God chose as the Judge of the living and the dead.
column3: Jiosh atsh am si i kei matsh wo ha doꞌibia hegam mat ab wo hiwgad k wo ha lodai hegam mat pi wo e doꞌibia. T g Jesus ab t‑mohtoꞌi matt am wo si wohokamch ihda k am wo ahgahid g s‑kehg haꞌichu ahgaj.

column2: He is the one all the prophets spoke about, that everyone who trusts in him will receive forgiveness through his name.”
column3: Jiosh at gam hu hab wo i juh g pi ap ha‑chuꞌijig wehs hegam mat ab wo i s‑wohoch g haꞌichu ahgaj ab amjed g Jesus. Id o wehsijj wohokamchud g kekelibad Jiosh haꞌichu i tashogiddam.”

column2: While Peter was still speaking, the Holy Spirit fell on all of them who were listening to the message.
column3: Sh am wabsh kia neok g Peter. Tsh ab i hud g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag ha dahm hegam mo am kaiham k ab si i ha mah g gewkdag.

column2: The Jewish believers who had come with Peter were astonished, because the gift of the Holy Spirit was also poured out on the foreigners.  They heard them speaking in tongues, glorifying God.
column3: Tsh am gawul neꞌokikaj neneo mat pi hebai mai k ab si ihm g Jiosh. Tsh am i ha kaiok ab si e totods hegam mo wehmaj g Peter natki pi g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag ab si i ha mah g gewkdag hegam gawul mahs hemajkam.

column2: Then Peter asked, “Is anybody going to prevent them being baptized in water, since they have received the Holy Spirit just as we have?”
column3: Sh ab kaij g Peter, “Jiosh atki ab i ha mah g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag mat hab masma ab i t‑mah. No hig pi d ha wuikam mat wo e pahl wapko?”

column2: He gave orders for them to be baptized in the name of Jesus Christ. Then they pleaded with him to spend some time with them.
column3: Kumtsh wa woho ha pahl wapko am chehchegch g Jesus Christ.

column2: The apostles and brothers in Judea heard that foreigners had also accepted the word of God.
column3: Tsh am i kah g Jesus wohochuddam amai Judea jewed t am matsh hegam gawul mahs hemajkam ab bei ihda Jiosh haꞌichu ahga.

column2: When Peter arrived back in Jerusalem, those who believed circumcision was still essential argued with him.
column3: Sh eda am haꞌi d hegam mash hab si elid mat hemho wa hab wo juh g Tutuligo ha‑himdag hegam gawul mahs hemajkam matsh ab i s‑wohoch. Kutsh am hihi idam Peter k am dada Jerusalem t am. Kutsh hegam am neꞌowin k hab si ahg,

column2: “You went into the homes of uncircumcised men, and ate with them,” they said.
column3: “Kah ach maptsh am ha wehm e gegos hegam mo d gawul mahs hemajkam ch pi pahl hikuchkas. P eda s‑mahch mo pi t‑hiwgidas machs chum hems am wo i wahp ha‑kihki ed.”

column2: Peter began to explain to them everything that had happened.
column3: Tsh am hahawa ha ahgi g Peter matsh haschu has e juh gd hu i shonchudk mo wa am e hoꞌigeꞌidahun Joppa kihhim t am ch hab kaij:

column2: “While I was in the town of Joppa I was praying, and in a trance I saw a vision. Something that looked like a large sheet was being let down by its four corners from heaven, and it came down to me.
column3: “Am ani daha Joppa t am ch am hu hebai ni‑hoꞌigeꞌidahun. T am ni‑nena ed hab e juh mat ab haꞌichu i e huduni dahm kahchim t amjed k hab mahs mo g lohna ch shaꞌi si geꞌej ch an aꞌai e uꞌukch chuhchpulij an ch am ni‑tahgio i e ul.

column2: When I looked inside I saw animals, wild beasts, reptiles, and birds.
column3: Kunt am si i nei eda k nei g nahnko mahs haꞌichu doakam, chum hegam ehp mo s‑dodajk ch wahammad ch uꞌuwhig.

column2: Then I heard a voice that told me, ‘Get up, Peter, kill and eat.’
column3: “K ab hahawa hema si neok ch hab kaij, ‘Peter, i g wuhshani k wabsh chum haschu am wo muꞌa k hekaj wo e gegos.’

column2: But I replied, ‘Absolutely not, Lord! Nothing impure or unclean has ever entered my mouth!’
column3: “Kuni hab kaij, ‘Ih, pi ant am hu hab wo ni‑juh, ni‑kownalig. Pi ani hekid koꞌa hegai mo g m‑chehanig pi t‑hiwgid.’

column2: The voice from heaven spoke again, and said, ‘Don't you call unclean what God has made clean!’
column3: “K hab ep kaij hegai mo ab neok, ‘Pi g hab shaꞌi elid mas pi apꞌe hegai mo haschu g Jiosh hemu am m‑chehgid mo s‑apꞌe.’ Neh, bo kaij ab ni‑wui.

column2: This happened three times, and then it was all taken back into heaven.
column3: Kut id hab e juh waikko. T amjed im hu hahawa uhpam i e bei ihda haꞌichu am dahm kahchim wui.

column2: At that very moment three men were standing in front of the house where we were staying. They had been sent from Caesarea to see me.
column3: “Kutki eda heki hu am haꞌi dada waik g oꞌodham. Idam ha‑geꞌejig o hab chehgig Cornelius ch am kih Cesaria t am ch ab ha cheha matsh ab wo i ni‑wai. Tki am dada mani am da.

column2: The Spirit told me to go with them, and not to worry about who they were. These six brothers here also went with me, and we went into the man's house.
column3: K hab ni‑ahgid g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag mant pi has wo shaꞌi ha el mo d ge gawul mahs hemajkam k wabsh wo ha oi. T idam chuhdp t‑wepnag m ia gegok am ni‑wehm hihi Cesaria wui k am ni‑wehm i wahp Cornelius kih ed.

column2: He explained to us how an angel had appeared to him in his house, who told him, ‘Send someone to Joppa, and fetch Simon, also called Peter,
column3: “K heg am t‑ahgid matsh g anghil am jiwia kihj am k hab kaij, ‘Am g haꞌi ha chehani mat am wo hihi Joppa wui k am wo wai hegai oꞌodham mo hab chehgig Simon Peter.

column2: who will tell you what you need to hear so you can be saved—you and your whole household.’
column3: T heg am wo em‑ahgi mamt has masma wo e doꞌibia wehsijj g e‑wehm kihkam ha wehm.’

column2: When I started speaking, the Holy Spirit fell on them, just as happened to us in the beginning.
column3: “Pegih, tki wa woho hab e juh. Kunt am him k am wabsh chum haꞌichu i ha ahgid. T g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag ab i hud ha dahm mat wa hab e juh am t‑wehhejed ga hu si i wehpeg.

column2: Then I remembered what the Lord said, ‘John baptized with water, but you will be baptized with the Holy Spirit.’
column3: Nt am hahawa i chegito mo wa hab kaij g t‑kownalig Jesus, ‘Mat ab i em‑mah g John g pahl wakona. T wabshaba g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag g si geꞌe gewkdag ab wo i em‑mah pi shaꞌi muꞌi tash iꞌajed.’

column2: Since God gave them the same gift as he gave us when we trusted in the Lord Jesus Christ, what power did I have to oppose God?”
column3: Neh, t id amjed am si i e tashogi mat g Jiosh ab ha mah hegam gawul mahs hemajkam hegai mahkigdag mat ahchim ab t‑mah mat hekid ab i s‑wohoch g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga ab amjed g t‑kownalig Jesus Christ. Kunt pi has masma am hu wo shaꞌi kuh g Jiosh id amjed.” Neh, bash kaij g Peter.

column2: After they had heard this explanation, they didn't argue with him anymore, and praised God, saying, “Now God has granted the opportunity to repent and have eternal life to foreigners as well.”
column3: Tsh idam am i kah wehs haꞌichu k pi ab hu has hahawa ep ahg ch wabsh si s‑hehgigam ab ihm g Jiosh ch hab kaij, “Pegih, boki d Jiosh hab elida mat idam gawul mahs hemajkam hab waꞌap gam hu wo s‑ohhod g pi ap e‑chegitoi k wo bei g pi ha huhugedam doakag.”

column2: Now those who had been scattered by the persecution that happened when Stephen was killed, traveled all the way to Phoenicia, Cyprus, and Antioch. They only spread the good news among the Jews.
column3: Kutsh haꞌi hegam matsh wa e gantad matsh hekid i e muhkid g Steven gam hu ahgahi g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga Phenicia ch Cyprus jejewed t am ch Antiok kihhim t am k hegam an waꞌi ha mihshmad Tutuligo.

column2: But when some of them who were from Cyprus and Cyrene arrived in Antioch, they shared the good news with the Greeks too, telling them about the Lord Jesus.
column3: Tsh am hahawa haꞌi dada Antiok t am ab amjed g Cyprus ch Cyrene k am i ha mihshmad hegam ehp mo d gawul mahs hemajkam.

column2: The power of the Lord was with them and a large number trusted in the Lord and turned to him.
column3: Tsh g Jiosh am i gewkai g haꞌichu ha‑ahga. Kutsh muꞌijj hegam hemajkam ab i s‑ha wohochud k ab i e dagito Jesus wui.

column2: News about what had happened reached the church in Jerusalem, and they sent Barnabas to Antioch.
column3: Tsh am i kah hegam mash ab ihm g Jesus ch ab dadha Jerusalem t ab matsh has i e juh am Antiok t am k ab hahawa cheha g Barnabas matsh am wo him k wo i ha wehmt.

column2: When he arrived and saw for himself how God's grace was working, he was delighted. He encouraged all of them to completely dedicate themselves to God and to stay true.
column3: Tsh ged hu jiwia k am i nei si s‑hehgigch matki wa woho g Jiosh ab si s‑ha hoꞌigeꞌel. Sh am ha ahgid mamt wehs ab wo i e dagito Jiosh wui k pi hekid wo shaꞌi dagito hegai mamt haschu ab i bei.

column2: Barnabas was a good man, full of the Holy Spirit, and put his whole trust in God. Many people were brought to the Lord.
column3: Sh wa eda si s‑ap d oꞌodham g Barnabas ch si e dagitokch Jesus wui ch ab si uꞌukch g gewkdag ab amjed g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag. Tsh muꞌijj ab i s‑wohoch g haꞌichu ahgaj ab amjed g Jesus.

column2: Then Barnabas went on to Tarsus to look for Saul,
column3: Tsh hekaj hab i e ah g Barnabas matsh am wo i bei g Saul mat heg am wo i ha wehmt. Sh eda heg am kih Tarsus kihhim t am.

column2: and when he found him, he took Saul back with him to Antioch. Over the course of the next year they worked together with the church, teaching the message to crowds of people. It was in Antioch that the believers were first called “Christians.”
column3: k am i chehg k ab uhpam i wai Antiok wui. Tsh am uhpam hihim k am dada Antiok t am k hemako ahid ab am i ha wehmt g e wehm wohochuddam amai. Sh eda muꞌij idam. Amai ash Antiok t am mamtsh si wehpeg hab ha chehch Christian.

column2: It was during this time that some prophets went from Jerusalem to Antioch.
column3: Tsh wa eda am haꞌi dada g Jiosh haꞌichu i tashogiddam ab Jerusalem t amjed amai Antiok t am.

column2: One of them called Agabus stood up and gave a prophetic warning by the Spirit that there would be a terrible famine that would affect the known world. (This came true in the reign of Emperor Claudius).  The believers decided to send funds to help the brothers that lived in Judea, with everyone giving according to what they had.
column3: Sh idam hema hab chehgig Agabus. Tsh g Jiosh am i tashogi ihda mat g bihugig wo gei an wehsko jewed dahm. Kutsh am ha ahgi g Jesus ihmdam amai Antiok t am. Tsh amai i amjed am i e nakog k am wehsijj i shuligahi g lial am ha wehhejed hegam e‑wehm wohochuddam mo am kih Judea jewed ch ed. Kutsh gei hegai bihugig mash eda g Claudius am d kownal.

column2: So they did this and sent the money with Barnabas and Saul to the church leaders there.
column3: Kumsh am ha chehani g Barnabas ch Saul matsh am wo i ui g lial. Tsh idam am i uꞌu k ab ha mah g ha wanimeddam g Jesus ihmdam amai Judea jewed ch ed.

column2: Around this time King Herod began to persecute some members of the church.
column3: Tsh eda am i ha shoꞌigch g kownal Herod hegam mash ab ihm g Jesus

column2: He had James, John's brother, executed by sword.
column3: k ab ha chehani g e‑shondalig. Tsh idam an bei hegai James mo d John wehnag k mua g is‑pahyokaj.

column2: When he saw that the Jews were pleased by this, he had Peter arrested too. (This was during the Feast of Unleavened Bread.)
column3: Kush muꞌi si s‑hohhoꞌid g Tutuligo matsh hab e juh ihda. Tsh heg hekaj wabsh baꞌich i si e gewkai g Herod k g Peter an ep bei. Kutsh eda e ai g si geꞌe mihshmda mo eda g Tutuligo pi koꞌa g hegai pahn mo jewajidas wewaꞌak tash oidam.

column2: After having Peter arrested, he threw him in prison, with four squads of four soldiers each to guard him. He planned to have Peter brought out for a public trial after the Passover.
column3: Tsh am ha cheha g Herod g e‑shondalig matsh wabsh wo kuh g Peter. Kumtsh am haha wo lodai am ha tahgio g hemajkam mat am wo i haꞌasa e piast. Tsh gamai chuhdp i e chuhcha g shondal matsh giꞌik e wehm wo nuhkud tash oidam ch s‑chuhugam oidam.

column2: While Peter was kept in prison the church prayed earnestly to God for him.
column3: Sh wabshaba heg oidam am hahasko e hehemapad g Jesus ihmdam ch am wehhejed si e hoꞌigeꞌidahun.

column2: The night before Herod was to have him put on trial, Peter was sleeping between two soldiers, chained to each of them, and with guards at the door keeping watch.
