column3: Kutsh am i e ai matsh baꞌich i siꞌalim wo e lodai g Peter. Tsh am i s‑chuk. Sh am woꞌo ch kohsh ha shahgid g gohk shondal mash am nuhkud. Kumsh gan hu si wupulshch g nohnhoij ch kakhioj g gohk e hukshchim wapainomikaj. Sh an gohk ep gegok g shondal ch am nuhkud g kukpaikud kihkijeg.

column2: Suddenly an angel of the Lord appeared, and a light shone in the cell. The angel shook Peter awake, saying “Quick! Get up!” The chains fell from his wrists,
column3: Tsh am haha wabsh jiwia g anghil k am wui i kekiwua g Peter. Tsh wabsh si ton am kukpaikud ch ed. Kutsh ihda anghil ab si ugij g Peter k wuhan k hab kaij, “Oi g kekiwua s‑hohtam.” Kutsh gam hu wa hekaj aꞌai shul hegai e hukshchim wapainomi mamsh an hekaj wupulshch. Tsh am i kekiwua.

column2: and the angel told him, “Get dressed, and put on your sandals.” So he did. Then the angel told him, “Put on your coat and follow me.”
column3: Sh hab hahawa kaij g anghil, “An g s‑wihnam i e giwuddad k ab si i wuhpud g e‑kaikia shuhshk.” Tsh wa woho hab e juh g Peter.

column2: So Peter followed the angel out. He didn't realize that what the angel was doing was actually happening—he thought he was seeing a vision.
column3: Tsh ab wahk k gam hu i oi. Kutsh am i wuwha ab amjed mash am kuhpikahim. Kush sha pi s‑wohoma mat woho ab i wuhshad g anghil nash pi hab e ahg mo wabsh chehchk.

column2: They passed the first and second sets of guards, and came to the iron gate that led into the city. This opened for them by itself. They went out and down the street, when suddenly the angel left him.
column3: Tsh am hihim k am i wuwha wehpeg kihjeg t ab. Kush am hema kehk g shondal ch wabshaba pi am hu shaꞌi ha neid. Kutsh am ep hihim k gam hu ep wuwha mash am kahya wui kihjeg. Kush am hema ep kehk g shondal ch hab waꞌap pi shaꞌi ha neid. Tsh wabsh hejel ab i e kuhkpiꞌo g kihkijeg. Tsh am waꞌi hekaj pi e haꞌichuch g anghil.

column2: When Peter came to his senses, he said, “Now I realize this really happened! The Lord sent an angel to rescue me from Herod's power, and from everything that the Jewish people had planned.”
column3: Tsh am haha wabsh si i e taht g Peter k hab kaij, “Neh, woho atki hab e juh. Jiosh atki ab cheha g anghil mat ab ni‑wui wo hih. Tki heg ab i ni‑wuhshad kukpaikud amjed ch ni‑doꞌibia ab amjed mat has wo i chum ni‑juh g ni‑wehm oꞌodham.”

column2: Now that he was conscious of what had happened, Peter went to the house of Mary, the mother of John Mark. Many believers had gathered there, and were praying.
column3: Tsh amjed am hih kihj wui hegai Mary mo d John Mark jeꞌe. Kush eda muꞌijj am e hemapadch ch e hoꞌigeꞌidahun.

column2: When he knocked on the gateway door, a servant girl called Rhoda came to open up.
column3: Kutsh ab si shontpag g pualit g Peter. Tsh am hema hih g ha‑pionag k hab chehgig Rhoda.

column2: But recognizing Peter's voice, in her excitement she didn't open the door. Instead she ran back inside shouting, “Peter's at the door!”
column3: Tsh heg am i amich mo d Peter ch ab neok k si s‑hehgig ch gam hu uhpam meh pi ab hu i kuhpiꞌok g pualit k ged hu ha ahgid mo g Peter ab kehk jeg ed.

column2: “You're mad!” they told her. But she kept on insisting it was true. So they said, “It must be his angel.”
column3: Sh hab kaij hegam ab wui, “Ptp wabsh chehch mo ab s‑kehkadma.”

column2: Peter continued knocking. When they did eventually open the door, they saw it was him, and were totally shocked. Peter held up his hand for them to be quiet, and then explained to them how the Lord had led him out of the prison. “Let James and the brothers know about this,” he told them, and then left to go somewhere else.
column3: Kush eda ab wabsh kia shontpag. Tsh ab hahawa i kuhpiꞌo g pualit k nei mo ab kehk. Tsh am ha hekaj i wah k ab ha ihm k am i ha ahgid mat has masma g Jiosh i wuhshad ab amjed g kukpaikud. Kush si has i elid mat has e juh. Tsh hab hahawa ha ah, “Am g wo ha ahgid hegam James mat g Jiosh ab i ni‑wuhshad,” k amjed gam hu hahawa ep hasko hih.

column2: When daylight came the soldiers were totally confused as to what had happened to Peter.
column3: Tsh am baꞌich i mahsi. Tsh am shaꞌi si e kudu hegam mash am nuhkud g kukpaikud. “T hebai hih g Peter?” bash kaij.

column2: Herod had a thorough search made for him, but he couldn't be found. After interrogating the guards, Herod ordered that they should be executed. Then Herod left Judea and went to stay in Caesarea.
column3: Tsh g Herod am hahawa si ha cheha mat am wo i gahghi. Tsh wabshaba pi shaꞌi mai mas hebai hih. Sh am si i ha chehani g Herod mat ab wo ha kakke hegam shondal mas has e juh. Kush pi neid ch pi mahch mas has e juh. Kush oi wa am ha chehani mat wo ha kokda.

column2: Now Herod had become furious with the people of Tyre and Sidon. They sent a joint delegation to see him and managed to win Blastus, the king's personal assistant, over to their side. They pleaded for peace with Herod because they were dependent on the king's territory for food.
column3: Tsh am hebai i cheka. Kutsh wabsh wohoꞌi bagat g Herod ab ha wui hegam mash am kih Tyre ch Sidon t ab. Kutsh ab wui hihi matsh wo chum apꞌech mash haschu i pi apꞌe nash pi am chum huniop. Sh am hema d kownal kehsha ch nuhkud g kihj ch hab chehgig Blastus. Kutsh heg wehpeg ab si i s‑nawojima k amjed am wui hihi g Herod k ab kakke mat wabsh ab wo i s‑ha hoꞌigeꞌel.

column2: When the day came for their appointment with the king, Herod put on his royal robes, sat on his throne, and gave a speech to them.
column3: Tsh hema kei g tash g Herod k ab si s‑kehg e enigadad k ab dahiwua kownal daikud ab k am si s‑hasigam ha jehnigi g hemajkam.

column2: The audience shouted in response, “This is the voice of a god, not that of a man!”
column3: Kush ab si hihnk g hemajkam ch hab kaij, “Pi oki d shaꞌi oꞌodham ch ab neok noki pi d ge hema jiosh.”

column2: Immediately the angel of the Lord struck him down, because he did not give God the glory. He was consumed by worms and died.
column3: Kutsh pi ha shohbi g Herod k pi am hu has el g Jiosh. Tsh heg hekaj g anghil ab ab hab juh g mumkidag mat waptopad k muh.

column2: But the word of God spread, and more and more people believed.
column3: Kutsh g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga i geꞌeda.

column2: Barnabas and Saul returned from Jerusalem once they had finished their mission, taking John Mark with them.
column3: Tsh g Barnabas ch Saul gam hu uhpam hihi ab Jerusalem t amjed mat am i ui g lial. Kutsh g John Mark am i ha oi.

column2: The church at Antioch had prophets and teachers: Barnabas, Simeon Niger, Lucius of Cyrene, Manaen (the childhood friend of Herod the tetrarch), and Saul.
column3: Sh am haꞌi ep d Jiosh haꞌichu i tashogiddam Antiok t am. Hema idam ash hab chehgig Simon ch wabshaba hab e aꞌaga S‑chukchu. Kush hema d Lucius ch ab Cyrene t amjed. Kush hema d Manaen ch am wehmaj geꞌeda g kownal Herod. Idam ash am ha mashcham am ha wehm g Barnabas ch Saul.

column2: While they were worshiping the Lord and fasting, the Holy Spirit said, “Set apart Barnabas and Saul to do the work I've called them to.”
column3: Kush am hu hebai wehsijj am heꞌekia tashkaj wabsh e hoꞌigeꞌidahun ch hab pi haꞌichu koꞌa. Kush am ha tashogid g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag mash g Jiosh hab kaij ab ha wui, “Neh, ab ant ha mohtoꞌi g Barnabas ch Saul mat gam hu mehk wo i ahgahi g haꞌichu ni‑ahga. Kumt am wo i ha dagito mat hab wo wa e juh.”

column2: After they had fasted, prayed, and placed their hands on them in blessing, they sent them on their way.
column3: Kush am baꞌich i himchud hegai mash wabsh e hoꞌigeꞌidahun ch pi haꞌichu koꞌa ch ab hahawa ha taht idam Barnabas ch Saul matsh hekaj am chehgi mat ha dagito heg wui mat g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag am i ha tashogi.

column2: So Barnabas and Saul, directed by the Holy Spirit, went to Seleucia. From there they sailed to Cyprus.  Arriving at Salamis, they proclaimed the word of God in the Jewish synagogues. John was with them as their assistant.
column3: Tsh gam hu hihi g Barnabas ch Saul mash wa g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag am i ha tashogid. Kutsh am ep i ha oi g John Mark matsh am wo i ha wehmt. Tsh idam ged hu dada Selucia kihhim t am. K id an hugidaj an g ge kahchki. K ab hihhim g wapalko. Kutsh idam Barnabas an i chehchsh wahlko ch ed k gam hu aigo i shulig k gam hu dada Cyprus jewed ch ed. Sh am hema kihhimag ch hab e aꞌaga Salamis. Kush am haꞌi chuhch g Tutuligo ha‑chechopi. Sh idam Barnabas am i wahpk ch am ha jehnigid ab amjed g Jesus.

column2: They traveled throughout the island and eventually came to Paphos. There they found a Jewish magician, a false prophet by the name of Bar-jesus.  He was close to the governor, Sergius Paulus, an intelligent man. Sergius Paulus invited Barnabas and Saul to come and visit him since he wanted to hear the word of God.  But the magician Elymas (his Greek name) opposed them, trying to prevent the governor from trusting in God.
column3: Sh gam hu aigo hema ep kihhimag ch hab chehgig Paphos. Kutsh gam hu hihim k am ep ha jehnigid. Sh am da hegai mash d kownal id eda jewed ch hab chehgig Sergius Paulus. Kush am hema wehmaj g Tuhligo ch hab chehgig Barjesus ch d s‑hasigam haꞌichu hab wuadam ch ha iattogid mash d Jiosh haꞌichu i tashogiddam. Kumsh hab aꞌaga Elymas mo hab d ahga Ge Mahkai. Sh g kownal d si haꞌichu s‑amichuddam oꞌodham ch ab i ha wai g Barnabas ch Saul nash pi s‑kaimk g haꞌichu ha‑ahga ab amjed g Jesus. Tsh wabshaba ab ha wui kekiwua hegai Elymas k am i chum e nako mat hab wo juh g kownal mat pi ab hu wo ha wohoch.

column2: Saul, also called Paul, was filled with the Holy Spirit, and looked straight at him.
column3: Saul o hab ep e aꞌaga Paul Greek neꞌokikaj. Tsh g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag ab ep si mah g Paul g gewkdag. Sh heg ab si shel i neid g Elymas

column2: “You are full of deception and all kinds of evil, you son of the devil, you enemy of all that is right! Will you never give up perverting the Lord's true ways?
column3: ch hab kaij, “Neh, dap Jiawul pionag nap pi ab wabsh i si shuhdags g pi apꞌekamkaj. K heg hab m‑wua map ab wui kehk g s‑apꞌekam ch chum gawul s‑junimk g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga.

column2: Look, the Lord's hand is on you and you will become blind. You will not see the sun for some time.” Immediately mist and darkness fell on him, and he had to find someone who could lead him by the hand.
column3: Jiosh at hab wo m‑juh mapt pi wo nehnt heꞌes i tash.” Neh, bash kaij g Paul.

column2: When the governor saw what happened he trusted in God, amazed at the teaching about the Lord.
column3: Tsh ab si e tods g kownal k ab i s‑wohoch neidok mash has masma g Jiosh am chehgid g e‑gewkdag.

column2: Then Paul and those with him sailed from Paphos and went to Perga in Pamphylia, while John left them and went back to Jerusalem.
column3: Tsh am hahawa gahi ep i shul hegam Paul ab Paphos t amjed k gam hu dada Perga kihhim t am am Pamphylia jewed ch ed. Tsh wabshaba g John Mark am i ha dagito amai k gam hu uhpam hih Jerusalem wui.

column2: They went through Perga and on to Antioch of Pisidia. On the Sabbath day they went into the synagogue and were seated.
column3: Tsh amjed gam hu hahawa hihi idam Paul ch Barnabas Pisidia jewed wui. K am hema kihhimag ch hab chehgig Antiok. Kutsh am dada.

column2: After the readings from the Law and the Prophets, the synagogue leaders sent them a message saying, “Brothers, please share with the congregation any words of encouragement you may have.”
column3: Kumtsh am neꞌokchul g Jiosh oꞌohana. Sh hegam mash d ha wanimeddam hab hahawa kaij, “T‑naipijju, chum ach si tatchua mamt am wo haꞌichu ha ahgi g hemajkam mat heg amjed ab wo i e gewpkai.”

column2: Paul stood up, motioned with his hand to get their attention, and began speaking. “Men of Israel, and all of you who have reverence for God, listen to me.
column3: Tsh ga hu hahawa i kekiwua g Paul ha baꞌich k hab kaij:

column2: The God of the people of Israel chose our forefathers, and gave our people prosperity during their stay in the land of Egypt. Then with his mighty power he led them out of Egypt,
column3: Jiosh atsh ab i ha gawulkai g t‑shohshonbad matsh d wo hemajkamgajk. Kutsh am i muꞌida mash eda am kihkahim Egypt jewed ch ed. Tsh ab hahawa i ha doꞌibia ab ha amjed g Egypt hemajkam g si geꞌe e‑gewkdagkaj.

column2: and he patiently dealt with them in the desert for about forty years.
column3: Kush an oiopo tohono jewed ch ed giꞌikko wehst‑mahm ahid ab. Sh g Jiosh am s‑hemajim ha nakogahim

column2: After he had overthrown seven nations living in the land of Canaan, God divided their land among the Israelites and gave it to them to inherit. This took about four hundred and fifty years.
column3: ch am wo i ha wahpki id eda Canaan jewed. Sh eda g wewaꞌak kawod dakam hemajkam ia kih. Tsh g Jiosh ha hugio k g ha‑jewedga am aꞌai i ha tahpjel g t‑shohshonbad mash hab masma heki hu ahgid g Abrahambad.

column2: Then he provided them with judges as leaders until the time of the prophet Samuel.
column3: Tsh heg i dahm am hahawa i ha chuhcha g Jiosh g s‑chu aꞌamichuddam mash am haꞌichu aꞌapꞌechud ha wehhejed.

column2: Then the people asked for a king, and God gave them Saul, son of Kish from the tribe of Benjamin, who ruled for forty years.
column3: Kush g t‑shohshonbad ab si tahni g Jiosh matsh am hema wo i kei mat d wo ha‑kownaligk. Tsh g Jiosh am i kei hegai Saul mash d Kishbad alidag ch ab d Benjaminbad amjedkam. Kush heg d ha‑kownalig giꞌikko wehst‑mahm ahid ab.

column2: Then God removed Saul, and made David their king. God approved of David, saying ‘I found David the son of Jesse to be a man according to my own heart; he will do everything I intend.’
column3: Tsh g Jiosh im hu hab hahawa i juh g Saulbad k g Davidbad am i kei matsh d wo ha‑kownaligk. Sh hab kaij g Jiosh ab amjed:

column2: Jesus is David's descendant; he is the Savior that God promised to bring to Israel.
column3: “Sh hab ep kaij g Jiosh matsh am hema wo i kei g Davidbad amjedkam matsh d wo t‑doꞌibiakamk. Kut wa woho hab e juh g Jiosh. K g Kehshaj hab chehgig Jesus.

column2: Before Jesus came, John announced the baptism of repentance to all the people of Israel.
column3: T wabshaba g Jiosh ab hema wehpeg i wuhshad g t‑wehm oꞌodham. K id hab chehgig John ch ab i ha mihshmad ch hab ha ahg mat gam hu wo s‑ohhod g pi ap e‑chegitoi k wo e pahl wapko.

column2: As John was completing his mission, he said, ‘Who do you think I am? I am not the one you're looking for. But after me one is coming whose sandals I'm not worthy to untie.’
column3: Tsh ihda John id hekaj am i kuhgi g e‑chikpan mo wa hab ha ahg g hemajkam, ‘Pi g hab wo shaꞌi ni‑elidad mani ahni d hegai mam si nenida. Pi ani d ahni ch d wabsh pi haꞌichu an hugidaj an. Mt wo wa nei mat am epai wo i e maskogi hegai mo hig woho d s‑has haꞌichu.’ Neh, bash kaij g Johnbad.

column2: My brothers, children of Abraham and those of you who have reverence for God: the message of this salvation has been sent to us!
column3: “Pegih, ni‑wehm oꞌodham ch ahpim mam hab waꞌap ab si has elid g Jiosh, ab o wehsijj d t‑wuikam ihda s‑kehg doꞌibiadag ahgaj.

column2: The people living in Jerusalem and their leaders didn't recognize Jesus or understand the words spoken by the prophets that are read every Sabbath. In fact they fulfilled the prophetic words by condemning him!
column3: Hegam kekelibad Jiosh haꞌichu i tashogiddam atki an oꞌoha matsh has wo masmak g Jiosh si Kehsha. K g ha‑neꞌoki e neꞌokchulid t‑shaꞌashagid wehs mihshmda tash. Kuki eda hegam t‑hajuni mo ab kih Jerusalem t ab pi amichud g haꞌichu ha‑ahga ch hab pi amich g Jiosh si Kehsha mat hekid am jiwia k chum s‑ha doꞌibiamk. Jiosh at am i kei g e‑alidag Jesus mat wo t‑doꞌibia.

column2: Even though they couldn't find any evidence to sentence him to death, they still asked Pilate to have him killed.
column3: K heg pi ha chuꞌijig. T eda hegam ab chum chuꞌijigch mat g kownal Pilate wo mua. Kumt ab naggia k mua kots t ab k ab hahawa i huduni k gam hu cheh hihaꞌini ch ed.

column2: After they had fulfilled everything predicted that they would do to him, they took him down from the cross and buried him in a tomb.
column3: Bat wa masma an oꞌoha g kekelibad Jiosh haꞌichu i tashogiddam mat hab wo e juh. Kut idam am wabsh wohokamch g haꞌichu ha‑ahga.

column2: But God raised him from the dead,
column3: T wabshaba g Jiosh ab uhpam i wuhshad muhkig amjed.

column2: and he appeared over the course of many days to those who had followed him from Galilee to Jerusalem. They are now his witnesses to the people.
column3: Tsh amjed muꞌikko am si i e chehgi ha wui hegam mash an wehmajkahim ch ab wehmaj i hihi Galilee t amjed ab Jerusalem wui. K idam am si s‑mahch ch ahgahim am t‑shahgid.

column2: We are here to bring to you the good news of the promise that God made to our forefathers,  that he has now fulfilled to us their children by raising Jesus from the dead. As it is written in Psalm 2: ‘You are my Son; today I have become your Father.’
column3: Kutt hemuch ia dada k ia uꞌapa ihda s‑kehg haꞌichu ahga em‑wui. Heki ash hu am ha ahgid g Jiosh g t‑shohshonbad matsh wo uhpam i wuhshad g si e‑Kehsha ab muhkig amjed. Kutsh wa woho hab e juh. Kutki id heki hu oꞌoha g Davidbad mat eda koi hab e juh. K an wa oꞌohanas gohkkam neꞌi ed heg eda Jiosh heki hu oꞌohana mash hab kaij g Jiosh ab e‑alidag wui:

column2: But David died, after he had done what God wanted in his own time, and he was buried with his ancestors, and his body decayed.
column3: “Neh, pi oki hejel hab e ahg g Davidbad natsh pi muh am hab juniok hegai mat haschu g Jiosh ab mohtoꞌi k am ha wehm e cheh g e‑shohshonbad. Tsh hi padt g chuhkugaj.

column2: The one God raised from the dead saw no decay.
column3: Heg o hab ahg Jesus mat pi shaꞌi padt g chuhkugaj nat pi g Jiosh ab i wuhshad muhkig amjed.

column2: My brothers, I want you to understand that we're telling you that through this man sins are forgiven.
column3: Pegih, ni‑wepnag, id amt hekaj wo chum s‑mahchk mat g Jiosh gam hu hab wo i juh g pi ap em‑chuꞌijig

column2: Through him everyone who trusts in him is made right from all that is wrong—in a way that you could never be set right by the law of Moses.
column3: mamt hedai ab wo i s‑wohoch g Jesus. Heg at am wo i em‑apꞌech mamt pi wo ha chuꞌijigk am Jiosh nena ed. T pi haꞌichu ep wo e nako mas hab masma am wo i em‑apꞌech, nih g chehanig.

column2: Make sure that what the prophets said doesn't happen to you:  ‘You who are scornful, look in amazement, and die! For what I'm doing in your lifetime is something that you could never believe, even if someone told you!’ ”
column3: “T an ep oꞌoha g kelibad Jiosh haꞌichu i tashogiddam mo hab kaij g Jiosh:

column2: As they were leaving, the people pleaded with them to tell them more the next Sabbath.
column3: Tsh ab i kuhgit g ha‑namki. Tsh wo chum hihi g Paul ch Barnabas. Sh wabshaba g hemajkam ab si ha waid mat am ep wo dada baꞌich mihshmda tash k am baꞌich ep wo i ha ahgi idam haꞌichu.

column2: After the meeting in the synagogue, many of the Jews and the converts to Judaism followed Paul and Barnabas who spoke with them, encouraging them to continue to hold on to the grace of God.
column3: Tsh am i himto g hemajkam. Tsh haꞌi ab i ha oi hegam Paul. Kutsh ab si i ha gewkemhu ab haꞌichu ep ha ahgidk mat am wo wa e nakogad Jiosh hemajimatalig ed. Sh haꞌi idam d Tutuligo hemajkam ch haꞌi d gawul mahs hemajkam ch am ha wehm e mihshmad.

column2: The following Sabbath almost the whole town turned out to hear the word of God.
column3: Sh am baꞌich d i mihshmda tash. Tsh chum alo wehsijj ab e hemapai g hemajkam matsh wo kah g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga.

column2: However when the Jews saw the crowds, they became extremely jealous, contradicting what Paul was saying and cursing him.
column3: Tsh hegam Tutuligo mash pi ab hu ha wohochud si s‑ha hehgam k hab kaij mo d wabsh s‑chu iattomkam g Paul.

column2: So Paul and Barnabas spoke out strongly, saying “We had to speak the word of God to you first. But now that you're rejecting it—you're deciding that you're not worthy of eternal life—well now we're turning to the foreigners.
column3: Tsh wabshaba idam Paul am haha wabsh si ha ahgi, “Ni‑hajuni, bo chum mahs matt wehpeg ab wo em‑ahgi g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga ab amjed g si Kehshaj. Kumtki wabshaba s‑ohhod k hab sha e wua mam pi tatchua g pi ha huhugedam doakag am Jiosh kihdag ed. Kutt heg hekaj wo em‑dagito k hegam ha wui wo i t‑nohnogi gawul mahs hemajkam.

column2: That's what the Lord has told us to do: ‘I've made you a light to the foreigners, and through you salvation will go to the ends of the earth.’ ”
column3: Bo wa masma am t‑chehanig Jiosh. An o oꞌohanas mash hab kaij:

column2: When the foreigners heard this they were overjoyed, praising the Lord's word, and all those chosen for eternal life trusted in God.
column3: Tsh am i kah idam gawul mahs hemajkam k si s‑hehgigam ab ihm g Jiosh nash pi ab ha makiog g e‑doꞌibiadag ahga. Kutsh hegam ab i s‑wohoch mat hedai g Jiosh i ha apꞌech mat wo e doꞌibia.

column2: So God's word was spread throughout the region.
column3: Kutsh wehsko i e ahgahi g haꞌichu ha‑ahga ab amjed g Jesus heg eda jewed.

column2: But the Jews incited the prominent religious women and leaders of the city to persecute Paul and Barnabas, and had them expelled from their territory.
column3: Tsh wabshaba g Tutuligo am si i ha chuꞌamu hegam uꞌuwi mash am ha wehm e mihshmad ch hegam mash d hahaꞌichu heg eda kihhim. Kutsh idam am si i ha shoꞌigch g Paul ch Barnabas k gam hu si ha huhuꞌi ab amjed g e‑jewedga.

column2: So they shook the dust off their feet against them as a sign of protest, and went on to Iconium.
column3: Tsh idam gam hu hahawa si i shahmud g jewed ab e‑tahtad ab am ha chehgidch mat wo ha dagito nat pi pi ap ab hu i ha nei. Tsh gam hu hahawa hihi Iconium kihhim wui.

column2: And the believers continued to be filled with joy and with the Holy Spirit.
column3: Kush hegam matsh ab i s‑wohoch ab Antiok t ab si s‑hehgig ch ab si uꞌukch g gewkdag ab amjed g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag.

column2: In Iconium the same thing happened. Paul and Barnabas went to the Jewish synagogue and spoke so convincingly that many of both the Jewish and Greek-speaking worshipers trusted in Jesus.
column3: Kutsh am hab waꞌap e juh Iconium t am matsh g Tutuligo hemajkam ab ha wui gegokiwua. Paul ch Barnabas atsh am i wahp ha‑cheopi ed k am si ha mihshmad. Kutsh muꞌi ab i s‑wohoch g Tutuligo mo g Jesus d Jiosh si Kehsha. Kutsh haꞌi hegam mash am ha wehm e mihshmad hab waꞌap ab i s‑wohoch g haꞌichu ha‑ahga.

column2: But the Jews that refused to believe in Jesus stirred up the feelings of the foreigners, and poisoned them against the believers.
column3: Tsh wabshaba am i wuwha hegam Tutuligo matsh pi ab hu wohoch k am si i ha kudu g gawul mahs hemajkam. Kutsh idam s‑ha kehꞌel g Paul ch Barnabas ch hegam ehp matsh ab i s‑ha wohoch.

column2: Paul and Barnabas stayed there a long time, speaking to them boldly in the Lord, who confirmed their message of grace through the miraculous signs that they were enabled to perform.
column3: Sh wabshaba tash am oiopo idam Jesus chuhchai ha shahgid ch am si tasho ha mihshmad ab amjed g Jesus pihk elidadag. Tsh heg ab i ha mah g gewkdag mat hab wo wuad g si s‑hasigam haꞌichu k hab masma wohokamch g ha‑ahga.

column2: The inhabitants of the town were divided, with some supporting the Jews and some the apostles.
column3: Tsh hegam hemajkam am i e gawulkai mat haꞌi ab ha wehmt g Jesus chuhchai k haꞌi g ha‑obga ab ha wehmt.

column2: But then the foreigners and the Jews, together with their leaders, decided to attack and stone Paul and Barnabas.
column3: Tsh wehsijj hegam mat ab ha wui gegokiwua g Jesus chuhchai am hahawa i e apꞌech g e‑wanimeddam ha wehm mat wo ha shoꞌigchud k wo ha maꞌichshul.

column2: However they found out about it and fled to the region of Lycaonia, to the towns of Lystra and Derbe,
column3: Tsh idam am i s‑mai mamtsh wo ha shoꞌigch k atsh gm hu wa hekaj baꞌich hahawa ep hihi Lystra kihhim wui. Ihda Lystra o am hab chuꞌig Lyconia jewed ch ed.

column2: where they continued to share the good news.
column3: Kutsh am dada k am ha ahgid g s‑kehg haꞌichu ahga ab amjed g Jesus.

column2: In the town of Lystra there was a disabled man who was lame in both feet. He had been crippled from birth and had never been able to walk.
column3: Sh am ha wui hema daha mash pi himdag ga hu i e‑alijk amjed.

column2: He sat there listening to Paul speaking. When Paul looked directly at him, and realized that the man was trusting in God to heal him,
column3: Tsh am i nei g Paul mo hab masma ab si kaiham g ahgaj mo ab si s‑wohochud mo g Jiosh woho ha doajid. Tsh ab si shel i neid

column2: Paul said in a loud voice, “Stand up on your feet!” The man jumped to his feet and started walking.
column3: k si s‑kaidam hab kaij, “Oi g kekiwua.” Tsh gam si daꞌiwush g pi himidkam k an has si oimmed.

column2: When the crowds saw what Paul had done, they shouted out in the language of Lycaonia, “The gods have come down to us looking like men!”
column3: Tsh am i nei g hemajkam matsh haschu has juh g Paul k ash am si e‑neꞌokikaj hihnk ch hab kaij, “Ia atki haꞌi dada g jijosh oꞌodham e wepogidch.

column2: They identified Barnabas as the Greek god Zeus, and Paul as the god Hermes because he was one who did most of the talking.
column3: Id oki d Zeus. Kuki heg d neokdam ch hab d Hermes.” Sh heg hab ahg Paul nash pi heg am neok.

column2: The priest of the temple of Zeus that lay just outside the town, brought oxen and wreaths  to the town gates. He planned to carry out a sacrifice in front of the crowds.
column3: Sh am mia kehk g ha‑cheopi. Kush heg eda am kehshch g Zeus. Tsh am i ha wehmaj g ha‑pahlig. Kutsh am ha uꞌapa g totolo ch haꞌichu heosig mat ab ha wui wo iagchul g Paul ch Barnabas.

column2: But when the apostles Barnabas and Paul learned what was happening, they tore their clothes, and rushed into the crowds, shouting out,
column3: Kutsh id pi ha hohhoꞌidach.

column2: “People, what are you doing? We are human beings with the same kind of nature as you. We came to bring you good news, so you could turn from these pointless things to a God who is truly alive. He is the one who made heaven, earth, and sea, and everything in them.
column3: “Pi g hab wo t‑elidad machs d jijosh. Dach wabsh oꞌodham hab masma mam ahpim. Ia att dada matt am wo em‑ahgi mamt wo haꞌasa ihm hab masma mo d Jiosh hegai mo pi d wohokam Jiosh. Heg o d wohokam Jiosh mat nahto g dahm kahchim ch jewed kahchim ch wehs haꞌichu mo an hab chuꞌig. Kumt heg wui ab wo i e dagito.

column2: In past times he allowed all the nations to follow their own ways.
column3: Heki o hu am hab wabsh junihim g hejel e‑tatchui g nahnko mahs hemajkam. Kuki g Jiosh wabsh s‑hemajim ha nakogahim.

column2: Even so he still provided evidence of himself by doing good, sending you rain from heaven and crops in their seasons, providing all the food you need, and filling your hearts with happiness.”
column3: K wabshaba chum hekid hab chuꞌig mo am e chehgidahim no pi s‑kehg haꞌichu hab em‑junid ch ab em‑mahkch g juhki ch ab bahijid g haꞌichu em‑eꞌes mamt wo s‑kokwogk ch wo si s‑ap e tahtkkad.”

column2: With these words they barely managed to stop the crowds from offering sacrifices to them.
column3: Neh, bash kaij idam Paul ch wabshaba chum alo pi ha shohbi nash pi chum si tatchua matsh ab haꞌichu wo iagchul ha wui.

column2: But then some Jews from Antioch and Iconium arrived and won over the crowds. They stoned Paul, and dragged him outside the town, thinking he was dead.
column3: Tsh am hahawa haꞌi dada hegam mash wa am ha shoꞌigchud Antiok t am ch Iconium t am k am i ha nuꞌichkwua g hemajkam. Kutsh ab wui gegokiwua g Paul k maꞌichkwua k am i chewaimed k gam hu i wuhshad ab kihhim t amjed k am wua hab elidch mat muh.

column2: But when the believers gathered around him, he got up, and went back into the city. The next day he and Barnabas left for Derbe.
column3: Tsh wabshaba am e chehm hegam mo ab ihm g Jesus k an wehgaj gegok g Paul. Tsh gam si i wamig k gam hu uhpam hih kihhim wui.

column2: After sharing the good news with the people in that town, and after many had become believers, they went back to Lystra, Iconium, and Antioch.
column3: k an i ha ahgidahi g Jesus haꞌichu ahga. Kutsh muꞌijj ab i s‑wohoch. Tsh am hahawa hihi Lystra wui ch Iconium wui ch Antiok wui

column2: They encouraged the believers to remain firm and to continue to trust in Jesus. “We have to go through many trials to enter God's kingdom,” they said.
column3: k am si i ha gewkemhun mat am wo hihimad ch ab wo si hiwgad g Jesus. Ha‑mashchama ash hab masma matt hemho wa muꞌi haꞌichu wo nakog k am haha wo i wahp Jiosh kihdag ed.

column2: After they had appointed elders for every church, and had prayed and fasted with them, Paul and Barnabas left them in the Lord's care, the One that they trusted in.
column3: Tsh am hahawa i ha chuhcha hegam mat d wo ha wanimeddamk am ha shaꞌashagid mo hebai i e wehm e nanmek. Sh am hahawa wehsijj wabsh e hoꞌigeꞌidahun ch hab heꞌekkio pi e gegosid. Sh idam Jesus chuhchai ab hahawa i ha dadagitod Jiosh wui.

column2: They passed through Pisidia, and arrived in Pamphylia.
column3: Neh, batsh wa masma am gahi wuwha g Pisidia jewed k gm hu dada Pamphylia jewed ch ed

column2: They spoke God's word in Perga, and then went on to Attalia.
column3: k am ha mihshmdahim Perga kihhim ch ed ch amjed gm hu hahawa ep hihi Attalia kihhim t am.

column2: From there they sailed back to Antioch where they had started out, having been dedicated there in God's grace to the work they had now accomplished.
column3: Tsh am i e nahto g ha‑chikpan. Kutsh am gahi i shul ge shuhdagi ch ed an geꞌe wahlko ch ed k gam hu dada hegai Antiok t am mamtsh am i ha dagito Jiosh hemajimatalig ed.

column2: When they arrived, they called the church together. They reported everything God had done through them, and how he had opened a door for the foreigners to trust in him.
column3: Tsh am wehsijj i e hemapai hegam mash ab ihm g Jesus amai. Sh g Paul ch Barnabas am ha ahgid mat g Jiosh am si i ha wehmt k ab ha mah g nahnko mahs hemajkam g apꞌedag mat ab wo i s‑wohoch g haꞌichu ha‑ahga ab amjed g Jesus.

column2: They stayed there with the believers for a long time.
column3: Tash ash am dadkkahim ha wehm hegam mash ab ihm g Jesus amai Antiok t am.

column2: Then some men arrived from Judea who started teaching the believers, “Unless you're circumcised according to the rules set down by Moses, you can't be saved.”
column3: Kutsh am haꞌi dada Antiok t ab ab Judea t amjed k hab chum ha ahg hegam matsh ab i s‑wohoch g haꞌichu ha‑ahga ab amjed g Jesus, “Jiosh o am t‑chehani Mosesbad oꞌohana ed mat g chechoj hemho wa wo e oꞌoha an e pahl hikuchk. Kumt pi wo shaꞌi e doꞌibia mamtp pi hab wo e juh.”

column2: Paul and Barnabas had many arguments and debates with them. So Paul and Barnabas and some others were appointed to go to Jerusalem and talk to the apostles and leaders there about this issue.
column3: Tsh wabshaba g Paul ch Barnabas pi shaꞌi hohhoꞌi ihda k am si ha neꞌowi idam Judea t am Tutuligo. Tsh am hahawa i e apꞌech matsh g Paul ch Barnabas am wo hihi Jerusalem wui haꞌi ep ha wehm k am wo s‑mai mat has wo chei hegam haꞌi ehp Jesus chuhchai ch geꞌeged.

column2: The church sent them on their way, and as they traveled through Phoenicia and Samaria, they explained how foreigners were being converted, which made all the believers very happy.
column3: Tsh idam am hihim k am i ha ahgidahi hegam mash ab ihm g Jesus Phenicia jewed oidk ch Samaria jewed oidk mat g gawul mahs hemajkam ab i e nodagi Jesus wui. Kutsh wehsijj ab si s‑ap i e tahtam k si s‑hehgig idam mash hedai i kah.

column2: When they arrived in Jerusalem they were welcomed by the church members, the apostles, and the elders. They explained everything God had done through them.
column3: Kutsh ged hu dada Jerusalem t am. Tsh si s‑ha hoꞌigeꞌel g Jesus chuhchai ch geꞌeged ch wehsijj hegam mash ab ihm g Jesus amai. Tsh am hahawa ha ahgi mat haschu k ab am si i ha wehmt g Jiosh mat am hab juh.

column2: But they were opposed by some of the believers who belonged to the Pharisee faction. They said, “These converts have to be circumcised, and instructed to observe the law of Moses.”
column3: Tsh wabshaba am haꞌi ab ha wui gegokiwua hegam mash si s‑gewkam oid g chehanig ch hab kaij, “Hemho wa at wo e oꞌoha an e pahl hikuchk g chechoj k am hab wo junihid hegai t‑chehanig mo g Jiosh ab t‑mahkch.”

column2: The apostles and elders met together to discuss the issue.
column3: Tsh am ep e nam g Jesus chuhchai ch geꞌeged k tash am aꞌaga ihda.

column2: After much debate, Peter stood up and said to them, “Brothers, you know that some time ago God chose me from among you so that the foreigners could hear the message of good news and trust in Jesus.
column3: Tsh g Peter am i kekiwua k hab kaij:

column2: God, who knows our hearts, has shown that he accepts them, giving them the Holy Spirit just as he did to us.
column3: Jiosh o s‑mahch g oꞌodham chegitoi ch ab ep ha mah g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag hab wa masma mat ahchim hab t‑juh.

column2: He doesn't make any distinction between us and them—he cleansed their hearts as they trusted in him.
column3: Kuch heg hekaj s‑mahch mo s‑ha hoꞌigeꞌelid ch gam hu hab i juh g pi ap ha‑chuꞌijig mat ab i s‑wohoch g haꞌichu ahgaj.

column2: So why do you want to oppose God and put a burden on the believers that our fathers weren't able to bear, and we can't either?
column3: Pegih, m haschu ahgch haꞌi piꞌichud g Jiosh ab s‑wehch haꞌichu ha mohtoꞌidch g wechij wohochuddam? Ahchim Tutuligo att pi shaꞌi t‑nako machs wehs am hab wo junihid g t‑chehanig. T g t‑shohshon hab waꞌap pi shaꞌi e nako.

column2: We're convinced that we're saved through the grace of the Lord Jesus, in the same way they are.”
column3: Pi attki hab masma wo t‑doꞌibia. Heg at wo waꞌi t‑doꞌibia t‑kownalig Jesus. Ab att i s‑wohoch g haꞌichu ahgaj. T heg ab i s‑t‑hoꞌigeꞌid k t‑doꞌibia. Pegih, t hab waꞌi masma wo e doꞌibia idam gawul mahs hemajkam.” Neh, bash kaij g Peter.

column2: Everyone listened attentively to Barnabas and Paul as they explained the miraculous signs that God had performed through them among the foreigners.
column3: Sh am hahawa ha ahgid g Barnabas ch Paul mat haschu s‑hasigam hab juh g Jiosh gewkdagkaj am ha shahgid g gawul mahs hemajkam. Kush wehsijj ab wabsh i pi shahmuni ch am ha kaiham.

column2: After they had finished speaking, James spoke up, saying, “Brothers, listen to me.
column3: Tsh am i haꞌasa neneo. Tsh g James am i kuhgi g ha‑ahga mash hab kaij, “Ni‑wepnag, ab g wo i ni‑kaiham.

column2: Simon has described how God first revealed his concern for the foreigners by taking from them a people committed to him.
column3: Peter o am t‑ahgid matsh has masma g Jiosh am chehgi mo pihk e elid ha hekaj g nahnko mahs hemajkam ch am haꞌi i ha gawulkai mat d wo hemajkamgajk.

column2: This is in accordance with the words of the prophets, as it's written,
column3: K id am wohokamchud mat wa has i masma an oꞌoha g kekelibad Jiosh haꞌichu i tashogiddam mash wa hab kaij g Jiosh:

column2: So my decision is that we shouldn't make it difficult for foreigners who turn to God.
column3: “Kuni hab ep s‑cheꞌimk mani hab hi elid matt pi ab hu wo ha mohtoꞌi g t‑chehanigkaj hegam gawul mahs hemajkam mat ab i e nohnogi Jiosh wui.

column2: We should write to them and tell them to avoid food sacrificed to idols, sexual immorality, meat of animals that have been strangled, and from consuming blood.
column3: Tt hi wabsh wo ha ahgi mat has wo e junihid. T hab ab ha wui wo si s‑ap e tahtkkad hegam t‑wehm oꞌodham mo am ha wehm kihdag. Tt wabsh wo ha cheha mat wo si e nuhkud g hejel e‑wehm kihkam wehhejed ch pi ab hu wo ihm hab masma mo d Jiosh hegai mo pi d Jiosh haꞌichu koꞌadch mo ab e toꞌid ha wui k pi wo koꞌad g ehꞌed ch hegai mo pi gam hu e iawua g ehꞌed e mumꞌajch.

column2: For the law of Moses has been taught in every town for a long, long time—it's read in the synagogues every Sabbath.”
column3: Id o wehsko si s‑ap s‑e mahch no pi an ahgachug wehs kihhim ch ed ch am e neꞌokchulid t‑wehm oꞌodham ha‑chechopi ed.”

column2: Then the apostles and elders, together with the whole church, decided it would be good to choose some representatives and send them to Antioch with Paul and Barnabas. They chose Judas Barsabbas and Silas, leaders among the brothers,
column3: Tsh idam Jesus chuhchai ch geꞌeged am i apꞌech am wehs ha wehm hegam mash ab ihm g Jesus amai matsh am haꞌi wo i ha chuhcha. Tsh idam am wo i ha oi g Paul ch Barnabas am Antiok wui. Sh idam d ha‑chuhchai Judas Barsabbas ch Silas nash pi g hemajkam ab si has ha elid.

column2: and sent them with this letter:
column3: Kutsh ab ha mah g oꞌohana matsh wo bek am Antiok wui. Sh hab chuꞌig ihda oꞌohana:

column2: We have heard that some from our group have confused you with their teachings, causing you trouble. We certainly didn't tell them to do this!
column3: “Idam Barnabas ch Paul o ab t‑ahgid mat am haꞌi hihi g t‑wehm oꞌodham k am em‑kudu am haꞌichu pi ap em‑ahgidk. Kuch eda wa chum pi shaꞌi ha apꞌechud mat hab wo e juh.

column2: So we have agreed to choose some representatives and send them to you together with our much-loved brothers Barnabas and Paul,  who have risked their lives for the name of our Lord Jesus Christ.
column3: Kutt heg hekaj wehsijj ia t‑hemapad k am i apꞌech matt has wo t‑juh. B o si i s‑ap e dagitokch idam Barnabas ch Paul am chikpanaj ed g t‑kownalig Jesus Christ ch hekaj chum alo e koꞌij.

column2: So we are sending to you Judas and Silas who can verbally confirm what we're saying.
column3: Kutt gohk ep i ha chuhcha mat am wo i ha oid k si s‑ap wo em‑ahgi mach haschu i em‑oꞌohanid. K d idam Judas ch Silas.

column2: It seemed best to the Holy Spirit and to us not to place on you any heavier burden than these important requirements.
column3: T am i t‑tashogi g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag mattki pi ab hu wo i em‑mohtoꞌi g t‑chehanig ahchim Tutuligo k wabsh wo em‑ahgi ihda mamt am hab hi wo wa junihid. T hab wabsh si s‑ap wo e tahtkkad em‑wui hegam t‑wehm oꞌodham mo am em‑wehm kihdag.

column2: You should avoid: anything sacrificed to idols; blood; meat from strangled animals; and sexual immorality. You will do well to observe these requirements. God bless you.”
column3: Neh, pi amt wo koꞌad g ehꞌed ch hegai mo pi gam hu e iawua g ehꞌed e mumꞌajch ch pi wo koꞌad hegai mo ab e toꞌid mo haschu hab chum e elid mo d jiosh. Mt wo si e nuhkud g hejel e‑wehm kihkam wehhejed. Mamtp wo si e nuhkud id ab k am wo wa s‑apꞌek. T g Jiosh am wo wa em‑wehmajk.”

column2: The men were sent on their way to Antioch. When they arrived they called everybody together and delivered the letter.
column3: Kutsh am hahawa gam hu hihi idam Barnabas ch Paul ch Judas ch Silas k gam hu dada Antiok t am. Tsh am i e hemapai hegam mash ab ihm g Jesus. Kutsh am i ha mah g oꞌohana.

column2: After they had read it, the people were so happy for the encouraging message.
column3: Tsh idam am neꞌokchulid k si s‑ap i e taht natsh pi heg hekaj ab si i e gewkemhu.

column2: Judas and Silas, who were also prophets, encouraged the brothers, explaining many things, and strengthening them.
column3: Kush g Judas ch Silas hab waꞌap d Jiosh haꞌichu i tashogiddam ch am dadkkahim heꞌes i tash ch muꞌi haꞌichukaj am i ha gewkemhu.

column2: After spending some time there they were sent back by the brothers with their blessing to the believers in Jerusalem.
column3: Kumtsh am hahawa s‑ap i ha dagito mat wo uhpam hihi.
[Tsh wabshaba g Silas hab i e ah mat wabsh ha wehm wo dakad.]

column2: But Paul and Barnabas stayed in Antioch, teaching and proclaiming the word of God along with many others.
column3: Sh g Paul ch Barnabas heꞌes i tash am dadkkahim Antiok t am am ha jehnigidch ab amjed g Jesus. Sh muꞌijj hab waꞌap ha ahgid g haꞌichu ahga ab amjed g Jesus.

column2: Some time later Paul said to Barnabas, “Let's go back and visit the believers in every town where we shared the word of the Lord, and see how they're doing.”
column3: Sh am hu hebai amjed, sh hab kaij g Paul ab Barnabas wui, “Am att ep wo hihim k am wo i ha gewkemhu wehs kihhim ch ed mach wa hebai ahgachug g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga k am wo ha nei mas has waꞌi masma.”

column2: Barnabas planned to take along John Mark too.
column3: Kush g Barnabas hab chum kaij mat wo bek g John Mark.

column2: But Paul didn't think it was a good idea to take him with them, since he'd left them in Pamphylia and hadn't continued working with them.
column3: Tsh wabshaba g Paul pi hohhoꞌi mat wo bek nat pi wa am wabsh i ha dagito Pamphylia t am k pi am hu ha wehm i nahto g chikpan.

column2: They had such a strong disagreement that they separated. Barnabas took Mark with him and sailed to Cyprus.
column3: Kutsh id am si pi ha apꞌet. Tsh hekaj i e gawulkai. Kutsh g Barnabas bek g Mark k gan hu aigo i shul geꞌe wahlkokaj Cyprus jewed t am.

column2: Paul chose Silas, and as they left, the believers committed them to the grace of the Lord.
column3: Tsh wabshaba g Paul g Silas am epai bek mat wo oi. Kumtsh am e hoꞌigeꞌidahun k am i ha dagito Jiosh hemajimatalig ed.

column2: Paul traveled through Syria and Cilicia, encouraging the churches there.
column3: Tsh idam Paul am hihi Syria ch Cilicia jejewed oidk k am i ha gewkemhunahim hegam mash ab ihm g Jesus.

column2: Paul went first to Derbe, and then on to Lystra, where he met a believer by the name of Timothy. He was the son of a Jewish Christian mother, and his father was Greek.
column3: Kutsh hegam Paul am hahawa hihi Derbe kihhim wui k amjed gam hu dada Lystra kihhim t am. Kush eda amai am hema kih g wechij oꞌodham ch am oid g Jesus himdag ch hab chehgig Timothy. K g jeꞌej hab waꞌap am oid g Jesus himdag ch d Tuhligo uwi. Sh wabshaba g ohgbadaj d Greek hemajkam.

column2: The brothers at Lystra and Iconium spoke well of him.
column3: Sh wehsijj g Jesus ihmdam am Lystra t am ch Iconium t am am si wehhejed neok g Timothy.

column2: Paul wanted Timothy to travel with him, so he circumcised him because the Jews in the area all knew that Timothy's father was Greek.
column3: Tsh g Paul s‑behim g Timothy e wehm. Sh eda wehs s‑mahch g Tutuligo amai mat g ohgbadaj pi pahl hikuch g Timothy. Tsh heg hekaj g Paul an pahl hikuch k hahawa bek.

column2: As they went through the different towns they gave them the requirements the apostles and elders in Jerusalem had said should be observed.
column3: Kutsh am hihim k hebai i daiw kihhim t am ch am ha ahgid hegam mo ab s‑wohochud g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga hegai matsh ha oꞌohani g Jesus chuhchai ch geꞌeged am Jerusalem t am k hab ha ahgid mat s‑ap am hab wo chum junihid.

column2: The churches were strengthened in their trust in the Lord and every day their numbers increased.
column3: Tsh am i muꞌida hegam mash am e wehm e mihshmad wehs kihhim ch ed. Tsh g ha‑wohochudadag am i gewka.

column2: They traveled through the districts of Phrygia and Galatia, since the Holy Spirit prevented them from going to the province of Asia to speak the word.
column3: Tsh am gahi wuwha g Phrygia jewed ch Galasia jewed idam Paul k am ahgahim g haꞌichu ahga ab amjed g Jesus. Tsh wabshaba pi ha hiwigi g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag mas am wo i ahgahi am Asia jewed ch ed.

column2: When they arrived at the border of Mysia they tried to enter Bithynia, but the Spirit of Jesus would not allow them to enter.
column3: Tsh gam hu dada mo an i chekshani g Mysia jewed k hab chum i e ah mat imhab uhpam wo hihi Bithynia jewed wui. Tsh wabshaba ep pi ha hiwigi g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag.

column2: So they passed by Mysia and went down to Troas.
column3: Tsh hekaj gam hu gahi hihi Mysia jewed oidk k gam hu dada Troas kihhim t am. Kunt am ha nam ahni Luke.

column2: There Paul saw in vision during the night a man from Macedonia standing up, pleading with him, “Please come over to Macedonia and help us!”
column3: Tsh g Jiosh am haꞌichu hab juh nenaj ed g Paul. Sh am hema neid g Macedonia jewed t am oꞌodham. Kush id ab kehk ch hab kaij, “Ab g i hihm Macedonia wui k wo i t‑wehmt.”

column2: After Paul saw this vision, we immediately made arrangements to go to Macedonia, since we concluded that God had called us to share the good news with them.
column3: T g Paul am hahawa t‑ahgi ihda. Kuch hab kaij moki tatchua g Jiosh matt am wo hihim k am wo i ha ahgidahi g haꞌichu ahgaj. Tt am ha hekaj i t‑nako matt am aigo i chehchsh Macedonia jewed t am.

column2: We set sail from Troas and made straight for Samothrace. The next day we went on to Neapolis,
column3: Kutt an ha hekaj gahi i shul g geꞌe shuhdagi geꞌe wahlko ch ed k ga hu dada Samothrace kihhim t ab. Am baꞌich d i tash, tt am dada Neapolis kihhim t am

column2: and from there to Philippi, the most important town in Macedonia, and also a Roman colony. We stayed in this city for several days.
column3: k amjed gam hu baꞌich i wahp mo am d Philippi kihhim amai wehpeg chekshani ch ed g Macedonia jewed. Ihda Philippi o d si s‑has haꞌichu. K muꞌi am dadha g si geꞌe kownal shondalig. Kuch am heꞌes i haꞌichugkahim id eda kihhim.

column2: On the Sabbath day we went out of the town gates down to the riverside where we thought people would come to pray. We sat down and talked with the women that had gathered there.
column3: Pi o am hu hema kehk g Tutuligo hemajkam ha‑cheopi. Kutt heg hekaj am hihi mo an ge akimelig kihhim aigo mach hab t‑ahg mo am hu hebai apchudas mo am e hoꞌigeꞌidahun g Tutuligo. K am hebai e hemapaidch g uꞌuwi. Kutt am i dadhaiwua k am ha wehm neneo.

column2: One of them was called Lydia, who sold purple cloth from the town of Thyatira. She worshiped God, and she listened to us. The Lord opened her mind to what Paul was saying, and she accepted what he told her.
column3: K hema hegam uꞌuwi hab chehgig Lydia ch ab amjed g Thyatira kihhim ch d s‑ihbhaimagi lohba gagdadam ch ab si ihm g Jiosh. Jiosh at ab i mah g wohochudadag. Kut ab s‑wohog el g Paul

column2: After she and all her household were baptized, she pleaded with us, “If you really think that I'm truly committed to the Lord, then come and stay at my house.” She kept on insisting until we agreed!
column3: k e pahl wako. T wehs hab waꞌap e juh g wehmaj kihkam. K hab hahawa kaij g Lydia, “Oi g wo t‑oid k am t‑wehm wo i dadhaiwua t‑kih am nach pi d hahawa em‑wehm wohochuddam.” Kutt wa woho hab t‑juh heg hekaj mat pi t‑dagito k ab ep t‑waid.

column2: One day when we were going down to the place of prayer we met a slave girl possessed by an evil spirit. She earned her masters a great deal of money by fortune-telling.
column3: Kuch am hu hebai am hihim matt gam hu wo hihi mo am e hoꞌigeꞌidahun. T ab hema i t‑oi g uwi. Kuki g jiawul an uꞌukch ch ab mahkch g amichudadag mo gam hu baꞌich tash haꞌichu ahg. K am haꞌi si uꞌukch ch muꞌi lial uꞌu ab amjed mo am haꞌichu ha ahgid g hemajkam.

column2: This girl followed Paul and the rest of us around, shouting, “These men are the servants of Almighty God. They are telling you how to be saved!”
column3: T ihda uwi ab i t‑oid k si hihnk ch hab kaij, “Idam oꞌodham o d piongaj g si uhgchu Jiosh ch am em‑ahgidahim mamt has masma wo e doꞌibia.”

column2: She went on doing this for several days. This bothered Paul so he turned around and told the spirit, “I command you in the name of Jesus Christ to leave her!” The spirit immediately left her.
column3: Neh, bo kaij ch muꞌi tashkaj an t‑oidahim.

column2: But when her masters saw they had lost their means of making money, they grabbed hold of Paul and Silas and dragged them before the authorities at the marketplace.
column3: T am i nei hegam mo an uꞌukch mat hahawa pi has masma ep wo uꞌud g lial heg hekaj chehia k hekaj an ha ui g Paul ch Silas k gam hu i ha chewaim hahaꞌichu ha wui. Idam o am dadha si eda g kihhim.

column2: They brought them in front of the magistrates, and accused them: “These Jewish men are causing a great disturbance in our town,” they said.
column3: K hegam mat am i ha ui g Paul ch Silas hab ha ahg, “Idam o d Tutuligo. Kutt ha cheh mo ha kudut g ia kihkam

column2: “They're advocating things that are illegal for us as Romans to accept or to practice.”
column3: no pi chum t‑ahgid mash hema d si geꞌe kownal mattsh ab wo chum si has elidad. K eda pi hiwgidas machs hab wo t‑wuad nach pi ab si wecho g Rome kownal. K pi d t‑wuikam ihda haꞌichu ha‑ahga.”

column2: The crowd joined together in an attack on them. The magistrates tore off Paul and Silas' clothes, and ordered them beaten with rods.
column3: T wehsijj hegam mat ab i e hemapai ab i ha wehmt k ab ha wui gegokiwua g Paul ch Silas. T g hahaꞌichu gam hu wuashul g ha‑wehschuga k am haꞌi ha chehani mat wo ha gewitta.

column2: After giving them a severe beating, they threw them into prison, ordering the jailer to keep them locked up.
column3: Kumt am i si s‑koꞌokam ha gewittani k ged hu ha uꞌapa kukpaikud wui k hab ahgid g lilso ha nuhkuddam mat si s‑wihnam wo ha kuh.

column2: The jailer followed his orders. He threw Paul and Silas into the inner cell and shackled their feet in the stocks.
column3: T wa woho hab e juh k ged hu si chuhko ha kuh k an ha wahpki g ha‑kakhio uhs wupulshpadag ed.

column2: Around midnight Paul and Silas were praying and singing praises to God, and the other prisoners were listening to them.
column3: Kutsh am eda i huh g s‑chuhugam. Sh g Paul ch Silas am si e hoꞌigeꞌidahun ch si neꞌed ch ab si ihm g Jiosh. Sh am haꞌi ep kuhkpi g lilso ch ha kaiham.

column2: Suddenly a tremendous earthquake shook the foundations of the prison. Immediately all the doors flew open and everyone's chains fell off.
column3: T am haha wabsh si s‑gewkam ugij g jewed. Tsh g kukpaikud am si wehs uꞌugij. Tsh gam si e kuhkpiꞌo g kukpaikud kuhkpadag. Tsh g ha‑wupulshpadag e padch.

column2: The jailer woke up and saw the doors of the prison wide open. He drew his sword and was about to kill himself, thinking that the prisoners had escaped.
column3: Tsh ab si i nea g ha nuhkuddam k hab e ahg mat neꞌiopa g lilso k hekaj an bei g is‑pahyo mat wo hejel e mua.

column2: But Paul shouted out, “Don't hurt yourself—we're all still here!”
column3: Sh wabshaba g Paul am si s‑kaidam hihnk ch hab kaij, “Pi g am hejel e muaꞌi. Ia ach wabsh i wehs haꞌichug.”

column2: The jailer asked for lights to be brought and rushed in. Shaking with fear he fell down before Paul and Silas.
column3: Tsh am hahawa bei g lahmpa k am si med k am i wahk k si gigiwuk. Sh am wabsh kia dadha g lilso. Kutsh ab i gei ha wecho g Paul ch Silas

column2: He escorted them out and asked them, “Sirs, what do I have to do so I can be saved?”
column3: k ab i ha wuwhasid k ab ha kakke, “Shahnt masma wo ni‑doꞌibia?”

column2: “Trust in the Lord Jesus, and you will be saved—you and your whole household,” they replied.
column3: Sh hab kaij idam Paul, “B apt wo i s‑wohoch g haꞌichu t‑ahga ab amjed g t‑kownalig Jesus Christ. T heg wo m‑doꞌibia. T idam m‑wehm kihkam m ia gegok hab waꞌap wo e juh.”

column2: Then they shared the word of the Lord with him and everyone who lived in his house.
column3: Tsh idam Paul am hahawa i ha mihshmad ab amjed g Jesus.

column2: Even though it was late at night he bathed their wounds, and he was baptized right away, along with all his family.
column3: Tsh am ha hekaj i ha uꞌu k ab i wako g ehꞌed mat wa am ha gewitta. Tsh amjed am ha hekaj i e nakog k e pahl‑wapko g e‑wehm kihkam ha wehm

column2: He took them home and had a meal prepared for them. The jailer and his whole family were full of joy because they trusted in God.
column3: k gan hu hahawa i ha wahpki g Paul ch Silas e‑kih ed k ha gegos. Kush si s‑hehgig ihda wehs ha wehm g e‑wehm kihkam no pi ab hahawa wohochud g Jiosh.

column2: Early the next day the magistrate sent officials to the jailer, telling him, “Release those men.”
column3: Sh am baꞌich d i siꞌalim. Tsh g hahaꞌichu am ha ahgi g chich‑lilihi mat wo ha dagito idam Paul.

column2: The jailer told Paul, “The magistrates have sent word to release you. So you can leave, and go in peace.”
column3: Sh hegai lilso ha nuhkuddam ab ahgid g Paul ch hab kaij, “Ia at gei g ahga ab ha amjed g hahaꞌichu matsh wo em‑dagito. Mt gamai wabsh s‑ap e taht k wo hihi.”

column2: But Paul told them, “They publicly beat us without a trial—and yet we're Roman citizens! Then they threw us in prison. Now they want to quietly let us go? No, they should come themselves and release us!”
column3: Kush wabshaba g Paul hab kaij ab ha wui g chich‑lilihi, “Pi att hab wo t‑juh. Hemho wa at ab wo i hihi hegam s‑has hahaꞌichu k ia wo i t‑wuwhas am ha tahgio g hemajkam nat pi t‑gewitta am ha tahgio wa chum pi mahchch mas haschu d t‑chuꞌijig. K heg pi d chum t‑wuikam nach pi uꞌukch g t‑shel hab masma mo g Rome t am hemajkam.”

column2: The officials went back and reported this to the magistrates. When they heard that Paul and Silas were Roman citizens they were really worried,
column3: Kush g chich‑lilihi am hahawa ha ahgid g s‑has hahaꞌichu mo has kaij. Tsh am i kah ihda k si e totodsid k am hihim

column2: and went to apologize to them. They escorted them out and begged them to leave town.
column3: k ab ha ahgi mat wabsh wo i s‑ha hoꞌigeꞌel k am hahawa i ha wuwhasid k hab ha ahg mat hig gam hu wo hihi ab amjed g kihhim.

column2: So Paul and Silas left the prison and went to Lydia's house. There they met with the believers, encouraged them, and then went on their way.
column3: T g Paul ch Silas am i wuwhag k gam hu hihi Lydia kih wui. Kut am e nam hegam mat ab i s‑wohoch g haꞌichu ha‑ahga ab amjed g Jesus. T idam Paul ab si i ha gewkemhun k gam hu hahawa hihi.

column2: After Paul and Silas had passed through Amphipolis and Apollonia they arrived at Thessalonica, where there was a Jewish synagogue.
column3: Tsh idam Paul am wabsh gahi wuwha g Amphipolis kihhim ch Apollonia kihhim k gam hu dada Thessalonica kihhim t am. Sh am hema kehk g Tutuligo ha‑cheopi.

column2: As usual, Paul went into the synagogue and over the course of three Sabbaths he debated with them using the Scriptures.  He explained what the Scriptures meant, proving that the Messiah had to die and rise from the dead. “This Jesus I'm telling you about—he is the Messiah,” he told them.
column3: Tsh heg wui am hihi hegam Paul mo hab wa e wua chum hekid. Tsh g Paul am ha wehm aꞌaga ab amjed g Jiosh oꞌohana k id hekaj am chum wohokamch mat g Jiosh si Kehsha hemho wa wo e shoꞌigchud k wo e muꞌa k wabshaba ep wo i wuhsh ab muhkig t amjed. Sh hab ep kaij, “Ihda Jesus mani ia mahsko wua em‑shahgid d hegai Jiosh si Kehsha.” Sh waik domig oidam am ha jehnigid mihshmda tash ab.

column2: Some of them were convinced and joined Paul and Silas, along with many Greek-speaking worshipers and some leading women of the town. But the Jews became jealous and with some rabble-rousers they gathered from the marketplace they formed a mob. They rioted in the town, and attacked Jason's house. They tried to find Paul and Silas so they could bring them before the people.
column3: Kutsh haꞌi ab i s‑wohochud k ab i ha wehmt hegam Paul. Tsh muꞌi hegam Greek hemajkam ch hegam s‑has haꞌichu uꞌuwi mash ab ihm g Jiosh ab hab waꞌap i s‑wohoch g haꞌichu ha‑ahga k ha wehmt. Sh hema idam hab chehgig Jason.

column2: When they couldn't find them they dragged Jason and some of the other believers before the town leaders, shouting, “These people are famous for causing trouble, turning the world upside down. Now they've come here,  and Jason has made them welcome in his house. They all defy Caesar's decrees, committing treason by saying there is another king called Jesus.”
column3: Sh wabshaba pi am hu haꞌichug. Kush heg hi wa Jason am da. Kush haꞌi ep dadha g wehmaj wohochuddam. Kumtsh idam ha uꞌu k am i ha chewaim hahaꞌichu ha wui k si hihnk ch hab kaij, “Ia at haꞌi dada g oꞌodham k ash wa wehsko ha kudut g hemajkam ch ab wui gegok g si uhgchu kownal hab kaijch mo am hema d ep kownal ch hab chehgig Jesus. K ihda Jason ab ha toꞌakch e‑kih ab.”

column2: The people and the leaders of the town were very disturbed when they heard this.
column3: Neh, bash kaij ch hekaj ab si i ha kudut g hemajkam ch hahaꞌichu mat wabsh wohoꞌi babgat.

column2: So they made Jason and the others post bail before they let them go.
column3: Tsh g hahaꞌichu am cheha g Jason ch hegam haꞌi mat wo ha namkid haꞌakia mo haschu d i ha‑chehanig. Kutsh am hab e juh. Tsh hahawa ha dagito.

column2: The believers had Paul and Silas leave for Berea that very night. When they arrived in Berea they went to the Jewish synagogue.
column3: Tsh am i s‑chuk. Tsh hegam Jesus ihmdam am ha ahgi idam Paul matsh gam hu wo hihi Berea kihhim wui. Tsh ged hu dada k am ha hekaj hihi Tutuligo ha‑cheopi wui.

column2: The people there had a better attitude than those in Thessalonica in that they were very quick to accept the word, and every day they examined the Scriptures to make sure what they were told was right.
column3: Tsh idam s‑ap ab i ha nei. Sh am ha mihshmad. Kush si s‑hohhoꞌid ch ab kaiham g haꞌichu ha‑ahga ch wehs tashkaj am si hoan g Jiosh heki hu oꞌohana mat wo s‑mai mas wa woho hegai mash g Paul am ha ahgid.

column2: As a result many of them became believers, along with some highly-placed Greek women and men.
column3: Tsh muꞌijj ab i s‑wohoch g Tutuligo. Tsh muꞌijj g gawul mahs hemajkam hab waꞌap ab i s‑wohoch. Haꞌi idam ash d s‑has hahaꞌichu uꞌuwi.

column2: But when the Jews in Thessalonica heard that Paul was also spreading the word of God in Berea, they went there and caused the same kind of trouble, stirring up the crowds.
column3: Tsh am wabsh i chum kah g Tutuligo am Thessalonica t am mash idam Paul am ha mihshmad Berea t am hab wa ehp k am ha hekaj i hihim k am i ha kudu g hemajkam.

column2: Immediately the believers sent Paul to the coast, while Silas and Timothy remained behind.
column3: Kutsh heg hekaj am ahgi g Paul hegam mash ab s‑wohochud mat gam hu wo hih ge kahchki hugidgo. Tsh wabshaba g Silas am waꞌi wih Berea t am g Timothy wehm.

column2: Those escorting Paul took him as far as Athens, and then returned with instructions from Paul to Silas and Timothy that they should join him there as soon as possible.
column3: Tsh hegam matsh am i bei g Paul gam hu uꞌapa Athens kihhim t am. Tsh am hahawa ha ahgi g Paul mat wo ha ahgi g Silas ch Timothy mamt hekid wo i e nakog k ab ha hekaj wo i hihi. Tsh amjed gam hu hahawa uhpam hihi idam e‑kihhim wui.

column2: While Paul was waiting for them in Athens he was very troubled to see all the idolatry in the city.
column3: Sh am daha g Paul Athens t am ch am ha nenida g Silas ch Timothy. Sh eda wehsko chuhch g ha‑jijoshta. Sh g Paul am ha neid idam ch hab si pi ap e tahtk.

column2: He debated in the synagogue with the Jews and those who worshiped God,  as well as in the marketplace with those he happened to meet from day to day.  Some Epicurean and Stoic philosophers also argued with him. “What is he going on about?”  they wondered. Others concluded, “He seems to be teaching about some foreign gods,” because he was speaking about Jesus and the resurrection.
column3: Tsh am wabsh apꞌet mat ha wehm wo si i aꞌaga g hemajkam am ha‑cheopi ed. Kush am haꞌi ha wehm e mihshmad g gawul mahs hemajkam.

column2: So they took him to the Areopagus  and asked him, “Please tell us about this new teaching that you're promoting.  We're hearing from you things that sound odd to us, so we'd like to know what they mean.”  (All the Athenians, including foreigners who lived there, spent their whole time doing nothing except explaining or listening to something new).
column3: Kush eda hegam kihkam ch hegam mo am wabsh sha dadha s‑hohhoꞌid mat tash oidam wo kaihamad ch wo aꞌagad hegai mo haschu d si wechij ahga. (19) Kumtsh ab i bei g Paul k ged hu uꞌapa mo am e nanmek k hab kaij ab wui, “Shahꞌo d ahga ihda wechij mashchama map ab amjed neok. (20) Pi ach am wa chum amichud.”

column2: Paul stood up right in the middle of the Areopagus and said, “People of Athens, I notice you are very religious about everything.
column3: Tsh am hahawa kekiwua g Paul k hab kaij, “Ahpim kihkam amki ab si has ha elid g jijosh.

column2: As I was walking along, looking at your shrines, I found an altar that had the inscription, ‘To an Unknown God.’ This unknown God whom you worship is the one I'm describing to you.
column3: Am ani neid m an chuhch g em‑jijoshta kahya oidk. Kuki am hema kehk g iagchulidakud mo id an oꞌohanas, ‘Ia amt wo haꞌichu dai heg wehhejed jiosh mattp hems pi mahch.’ Pegih, ihda pi em‑machiga o d hegai mant am haha wo em‑ahgi ab amjed.

column2: The God who created the world and everything in it, the Lord of heaven and earth, doesn't live in temples we make.
column3: “Do ihda Jiosh mat wehs haꞌichu nahto ch d kownal wehs haꞌichu dahm. Wehsko o an haꞌichug g Jiosh. K pi hab shaꞌi mahs mas am hebai wabsh wo e dai hab masma mam hab ha wua g e‑jijoshta.

column2: He doesn't need to be served by us as if he needed anything, since he is the source of all life for every living being.
column3: Jiosh o ab t‑mahkch g doakag ch wehs haꞌichu. K pi am hu haꞌichu d shaꞌi hegai mas ab i si tatchua ab amjed g oꞌodham mat ab wo mah chikpank.

column2: From one man he made all the peoples who live on the earth, and decided beforehand when and where they should live.
column3: “Jiosh at am hemako nahto g oꞌodham k ab amjed i wuhshad g wehs nahnko mahs hemajkam k an aꞌai i ha gantad wehsko jewed oidk mat hebai heki hu i apꞌech mat an wo kihkad.

column2: God's purpose was that they should seek him, hoping they would reach out for him and find him—though he isn't far from any one of us.
column3: K hab d elidaj mat am wo i e gahgidahi g Jiosh k atp hems wo cheh. Pi o shaꞌi mehk ab hema i t‑amjed

column2: In him we live, move, and exist. Just as one of your own poets wrote, ‘We are his family.’
column3: ch ab t‑mahkch g doakag ch kihdag. Haꞌijj g em‑wehm oꞌodham o d haꞌichu aꞌamichuddam ch hab kaij, ‘Ahchim hemajkam ach d Jiosh aꞌaliga.’

column2: Since we are his family we shouldn't think that God is like gold, or silver, or stone, shaped by human artistry and thinking.
column3: “Pegih neh, id o d wohokam mach d aꞌaligaj g Jiosh. Tt pi hab wo ge t‑ahgad mas g wohokam Jiosh hab mahs mo idam em‑jijoshta mat wabsh g oꞌodham am nahto g ohlakaj o g plahdakaj o g hodaikaj.

column2: God disregarded people's ignorance in the past, but now he commands everyone everywhere to repent.
column3: Heki o hu pi mahch g hemajkam g Jiosh tatchui. K g Jiosh si s‑hemajim am ha nakog. Ni wabshaba hemu em‑ahgid mo hahawa ab si i ha chehani g hemajkam wehsko mat gam hu wo s‑ohhod g pi ap e‑chegitoi.

column2: For he has set a time when he will rightly judge the world by the man he has appointed, and he proved to everyone that he is the one by raising him from the dead.”
column3: Am at i apꞌech g tash mat wehs wo ha lodai g hemajkam k heki hu am hema si i kei mat hab wo juh g lodaita. Tsh id ia mahsi t‑shahgid k ia oimmelhim ch e muhkid. Tsh g Jiosh ab i wuhshad muhkig t amjed mat wo wohokamch mo d si Kehshaj.” Neh, bash kaij g Paul.

column2: Some of them laughed when they heard about the resurrection of the dead, while others said, “Please come back so we can hear more about this later.”
column3: Tsh idam am i kah mo hab kaij matsh hema i wuhsh ab muhkig amjed. Kush haꞌijj wabsh si ash ch wabshaba haꞌi hab kaij, “Am g wa ep t‑jehnigid ab amjed ihda.”

column2: So Paul left them.
column3: Tsh amjed gam hu hahawa hih g Paul.

column2: A few men joined him and trusted in God, including Dionysius, a member of the Areopagus, as well as a woman called Damaris, and some others.
column3: Tsh haꞌi ab s‑wohochud k ab i wehmt. Sh hema idam d Dionysius ch d hema hegam s‑chu aꞌamichuddam. Kush am hema d ep uwi ch hab chehgig Damaris.

column2: Paul then left Athens and went to Corinth
column3: Tsh gam hu hahawa hih g Paul ab Athens t amjed k am him k am jiwia Corinth kihhim t am.

column2: where he met a Jew named Aquila. Aquila was originally from Pontus, and had just arrived from Italy with his wife Priscilla because Claudius  had ordered all Jews expelled from Rome. Paul went to see them,
column3: Sh am hema daha g Tuhligo ch hab chehgig Aquila ch ab d mahsikam Pontus t ab. K g wehmaj kihkam hab chehgig Priscilla. Idam o d ikus kihtdam. Kutsh hab wa e juh am ha tahgio matsh g geꞌe kownal Claudius gam hu ha huhuꞌi Tutuligo ab amjed g Rome kihhim. Sh idam Aquila ch Priscilla am ahhio Corinth wui.

column2: and because they were in the same business of tent-making, he stayed with them.
column3: Tsh g Paul am i ha chehgim k am ha wehm i dahiwua k am ha wehm chikpan no pi hab d waꞌap ikus kihtdam.

column2: He debated in the synagogue every Sabbath, convincing both Jews and Greeks.
column3: Kush wehs mihshmda tash am hihim Tutuligo ha‑cheopi wui mat am wo haꞌichu i ha tashogi ab amjed g Jesus. Kush am haꞌi ep ha wehm e mihshmad hegam mo pi d Tutuligo ch am kah g haꞌichu ahgaj.

column2: When Silas and Timothy arrived from Macedonia, Paul felt he had to become more direct in what he said, and told the Jews that Jesus was the Messiah.
column3: Kutsh am i dada g Silas ch Timothy ab Macedonia jewed t amjed. Tsh g Paul am hahawa i dagito g e‑chikpan k heg am himch matsh am hahawa si i ha mihshmad am si s‑mahch ch ahg ab ha wui g Tutuligo mo g Jesus d Jiosh si Kehsha mat wo t‑doꞌibia.

column2: When they opposed him and cursed him, he shook out his clothes and told them, “Your blood is on your own heads! I am innocent of any guilt, and from now on I will go to the foreigners.”
column3: Tsh wabshaba ab wui gegokiwua idam k am si pi ap has ahg. Tsh oi wa g Paul ab si i shahmud g e‑wehschuga ha wui mat wo ha chehgi mat ha dagito k hab kaij, “Dat wo hejel em‑chuꞌijigk mamtp wo sha pi e doꞌibia. T ahni pi ab hu haꞌichu d wo ni‑chuꞌijigk. Nt iaꞌi amjed g gawul mahs hemajkam ab wo i ha mihshmad.”

column2: He left and went to stay with Titius Justus, who worshiped God and whose house was next door to the synagogue.
column3: Neh, tsh iaꞌi dagito g ha‑cheopi k ged hu hahawa ha mihshmad g hemajkam hema kih am g gawul mahs oꞌodham. Id ash ab ihm g Jiosh ch hab chehgig Titius Justus ch an kih hugidaj an g Tutuligo ha‑cheopi.

column2: Crispus, leader of the synagogue, believed in the Lord together with his whole household. Many of the people of Corinth who heard the message became believers and were baptized.
column3: Kutsh muꞌi ep ab i s‑wohoch am i kahk k am e pahl wapko. Hema ash d chum ha wanimeddam g Tutuligo ch hab chehgig Crispus ch ab i s‑wohoch g e‑wehm kihkam ha wehm.

column2: The Lord told Paul in a vision at night: “Don't be afraid. Speak up, don't keep quiet—  because I am with you, and no-one will attack you, for many people in this city are mine.”
column3: Tsh am hu hebai chuhug ch ed am haꞌichu hab e juh Paul nena ed mash kah g Jesus. Kush ab wui hab kaij, “Pi g am shaꞌi haꞌichu ehbidad. Ia ani m‑wehmaj ch pi hedai wo shai hiwigi mas wo s‑koꞌokam m‑juh. Pi g shaꞌi haꞌasa ha mihshmad. Muꞌijj o ia kih id eda kihhim mat d wo ni‑hemajkamgak.”

column2: Paul stayed there for eighteen months, teaching the people the word of God.
column3: Sh heg hekaj hemako ahidag ch eda hugkam ehp am haꞌichugkahim ch am ha mashcham g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga.

column2: However during the time when Gallio  was the governor of Achaia, the Jews united in an attack against Paul and brought him before the court.
column3: Tsh am hahawa hema i dahiwua g kownal am Greek hemajkam ha‑jewedga am k hab chehgig Gallio. Tsh g Tutuligo am i e hemapad k an bei g Paul k am uꞌapa geꞌe kih t am

column2: “This man is persuading people to worship God illegally,” they declared.
column3: k hab kaij, “Ihda oꞌodham o chum ha chehani g hemajkam mat hab masma ab wo i ihmad g Jiosh mam has masma pi t‑hiwgid.”

column2: But just as Paul was about to defend himself, Gallio told the Jews, “If you Jews were bringing criminal charges or some serious legal offense, there would be a reason for me to listen to your case.
column3: Kutsh am haha wabsh wo i chum neo g Paul. Sh wabshaba Gallio hab ha ahg, “Pi oki ab wui kehk g geꞌe kownal chehanig. T heg hekaj pi wo ni‑apꞌet mant ab wo em‑kaiha.

column2: But since you're only arguing over words and names and your own law, then you deal with it yourselves. I won't rule on such matters.”
column3: Doki wabsh haꞌichu ahga ab amjed g em‑himdag ch ab hema i amjed g em‑wehm oꞌodham. Mt heg hekaj am hejel wo i apꞌech. Pi ant am hu wo shaꞌi i hudaw hab mahs haꞌichu.”

column2: Then Gallio had them ejected from the court.
column3: Neh, bash kaij ch gam hu si i ha wuwhas geꞌe kih amjed.

column2: Then the crowd turned on Sosthenes, the leader of the synagogue, and beat him right outside the court, but Gallio wasn't concerned about this at all.
column3: Kutsh idam an wabsh si bei hegai mash d ha wanimeddam am cheopi ch ed ch hab chehgig Sosthenes k am si gewitta geꞌe kih bahsho. Tsh pi ab hu has shaꞌi e taht g Gallio.

column2: Paul stayed on for a while. Then left the believers and sailed for Syria, taking Priscilla and Aquila along with him. He had his head shaved while in Cenchrae, because he had taken a vow.
column3: Sh muꞌi tash am haꞌichugkahim g Paul Corinth kihhim t am ha wehm hegam mash ab s‑wohochud g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga. Tsh amjed hab i e ah matsh gam hu uhpam wo hih Syria jewed wui. Sh eda gam hu hihhim g geꞌeged wapalko Cenchrea kihhim t amjed. Kutsh gam hu hih g Paul. Tsh g Priscilla ch Aquila gm hu oi. Tsh koi am hu i chehchsh geꞌe wahlko ch ed, tsh g Paul hih g e‑moꞌo matsh wa am heꞌes i tash pi hih mo d ha‑himdag heg hekaj mat ab haꞌichu ahꞌad g Jiosh.

column2: They arrived in Ephesus, where Paul left the others behind. He went to the synagogue to reason with the Jews.
column3: Tsh am hahawa gahi i shul g geꞌe wahlkokaj k ga hu dada Ephesus kihhim t am. Kutsh am i dadhaiwua g Priscilla ch Aquila. Tsh g Paul am hih mat am wo sha i wah Tutuligo ha‑cheopi ed k am ha wehm haꞌichu aꞌaga.

column2: They asked him to stay longer, but he refused.
column3: Sh idam ab ahgid mat am wabsh wo i wih ha wehm.

column2: He said his goodbyes, and set sail from Ephesus, telling them, “I'll come back and see you if it's God's will.”
column3: k ash hab wabsh ha ahg am wo i himk, “Matp g Jiosh d wo tatchuik, nt wo wa uhpam ep jiwia.” Neh, bash kaij ch amjed ab i chesh geꞌe wahlko t ab.

column2: After landing at Caesarea he went to greet the church members, and then carried on to Antioch.
column3: Tsh heg gam hu gahi i gei Cesaria kihhim t am.

column2: He spent some time there and then went from town to town through the region of Galatia and Phrygia, encouraging all the believers.
column3: Sh am heꞌes i haꞌichugkahim amai ch am hahawa ep ha dagito k atsh gam hu hahawa ep hih ha oidk g Galasia ch Phrygia jejewed k am i ha gewkemhunahim g e‑wehm wohochuddam.

column2: In the meantime a Jew named Apollos, originally from Alexandria, arrived in Ephesus. He was a gifted speaker who knew the Scriptures well.
column3: Tsh am hema jiwia g Tuhligo Ephesus kihhim t am k hab chehgig Apollos ch ab d mahsikam Alexandria kihhim t ab ch si s‑e mahch ab s‑neokimakam t ab ch ash si geꞌe s‑mahch g Jiosh oꞌohana.

column2: He had been taught the way of the Lord. He was spiritually passionate, and in his speaking and teaching he presented Jesus accurately, but he only knew about John's baptism.
column3: Kumtsh heki hu mashcha ab amjed g Jesus. Kush si s‑hohhoꞌid ch am ahgahim ch si s‑ap ha mashcham ch eda heg waꞌi s‑mahch John pahl wakona.

column2: He started speaking openly in the synagogue. So when Priscilla and Aquila heard him, they invited him to join them and explained the way of God to him more fully.
column3: Tsh am i kah hegam Priscilla ch Aquila nash pi am si ha mihshmad Tutuligo ha‑cheopi ed. Tsh idam am i wai e‑kih wui k am s‑ap ahgid mo haschu i koi s‑mahch ab amjed g Jesus.

column2: When he decided to go to Achaia, the brothers encouraged him, and wrote to the disciples there telling them to welcome him. When he arrived he was very helpful to those who through grace trusted God,
column3: Kutsh hab hahawa i e ah g Apollos mat am wo hih Greece jewed wui. Tsh am i wehmt hegam mash ab s‑wohochud g s‑kehg haꞌich ahgaj g Jiosh ch am kih Ephesus t am k am ha oꞌohani g e‑wehm wohochuddam amai Greece ch ed k ab si ha ahgid mat s‑ap ab wo i nei g Apollos. Tsh gam hu jiwia k ab si geꞌe i ha wehmt.

column2: because he was able to strongly refute the Jews in public debate, demonstrating from the Scriptures that Jesus was the Messiah.
column3: Sh am haꞌi neꞌowin g Tutuligo. Tsh wabshaba am ha gewito am ha‑kaichudch g muꞌi hemajkam k am si i wohokamch heg hekaj Jiosh oꞌohana mo g Jesus d Jiosh si Kehsha mat wo ha doꞌibia g hemajkam.

column2: While Apollos was in Corinth, Paul took the inland route and arrived in Ephesus where he found some believers.
column3: Tsh gam hu baꞌich ep hih g Paul k ged hu jiwia Ephesus t am mo eda g Apollos am oimmed Corinth t am. Kush am haꞌi kih ch ab chum s‑wohochud g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga.

column2: “Did you receive the Holy Spirit when you believed?” he asked them.
column3: Sh g Paul ab ha kakke, “Namt am wa bei g gewkdag ab amjed g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag mamt hekid ab i s‑wohoch g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga?”

column2: “So what baptism did you receive?” he asked.
column3: Sh hab hahawa kaij g Paul, “A namt koi e pahl wapko g Jesus pahl wakonakaj?”

column2: “John baptized with the baptism of repentance,” said Paul. He told the people that they should trust in the one who would come after him—that is, they should trust in Jesus.
column3: Sh hab hahawa ep kaij g Paul, “M o wa woho mash heg am ha ahgid mat gam hu wo s‑ohhod g pi ap e‑chegitoi ch wabshaba am ep ha ahgid mat ab wo i s‑wohoch hegai mat am epai wo i e maskogi. K heg d Jesus.”

column2: When they heard this, they were baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus.
column3: Tsh idam ab i s‑wohochud k e pahl wapko ab chehchegch g Jesus.

column2: After Paul had placed his hands on them, the Holy Spirit came upon them and they spoke in tongues and prophesied.
column3: Tsh g Paul an i ha tahtamahim k ab ihmahim g Jiosh. Tsh ab si i bei g gewkdag ab amjed d Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag k am si gawul neꞌokikaj neneok mat pi hebai mai ch am ahg g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga.

column2: There were about twelve of them in total.
column3: Kush am hu d i gamai gohk idam chechoj.

column2: Paul went to the synagogue and over the course of the next three months spoke boldly to those who were there, discussing with them and trying to convince them about the kingdom of God.
column3: Sh am wapke g Paul Tutuligo ha‑cheopi ed ch am ha wehm haꞌichu si i aꞌaga waik mashad ab chum s‑ap s‑ha mahtchudamk ab amjed g Jiosh kownaltalig.

column2: But some of them were stubborn, and refused to accept. They denounced the Way to the crowd. So Paul gave up on them and left the synagogue, taking the believers with him. Then he had discussions every day at the hall of Tyrannus.
column3: Tsh wabshaba haꞌi pi wohochud k wabsh si pi ap neneok ab amjed g Jesus himdag am ha kaichudch g hemajkam. Tsh heg hekaj am ha dagito g Paul k gam hu hih ha uꞌuk hegam mat ab i s‑wohoch. Sh am hema d Tyrannus ch ge mashchamakud ch id ha hiwigi. Kush heg eda g Paul am ha wehm aꞌaga g Jiosh kownaltalig wehs tashkaj

column2: This went on for the next two years, with the result that everyone who lived in the province of Asia, both Jews and Greeks, heard the word of the Lord.
column3: gohk ahid ab. Tsh wehsko e kah g Jesus ahga heg eda Asia jewed.

column2: God performed unusual miracles through Paul,
column3: Kush g Jiosh am si i wehmaj g Paul mash am hab junihim g s‑hasigam haꞌichu.

column2: so much so that they took handkerchiefs or aprons Paul had touched to heal the sick and to drive out evil spirits.
column3: Sh g hemajkam chum hems ab uꞌu g Paul haꞌichu eniga ch hekaj ab tattam g kokꞌodam. Kush ha dodad. Tsh g jijawul im hu hab wo i e juh ab ha amjed hegam mo an ha uꞌukch.

column2: Some Jews who were going around exorcising decided to use the name of the Lord Jesus when they drove out evil spirits. They'd say, “I command you to leave in the name of the Jesus that Paul talks about.”  The ones doing this were the seven sons of Sceva, a Jew and a chief priest.
column3: Sh eda an haꞌi ep oiopo g Tutuligo ch hab chum e wua mo im hu hab i ha wua g jijawul ab ha amjed g hemajkam. Kush am hema g uhgchu pahl hab chehgig Sceva ch wewaꞌak aꞌalidag. Sh idam hab waꞌap chum im hu hab i ha wua g jijawul ab ha amjed g hemajkam. Am hu hebai, sh idam am hema neid g oꞌodham mash g jiawul an uꞌukch ch hab kaij, “Ab g i dagito ihda oꞌodham, ahpi jiawul. Bani si m‑ahgid heg gewkdagkaj Jesus mo g Paul ab amjed ha mihshmad.”

column2: But one day an evil spirit responded, “I know Jesus, and I know Paul, but who are you?”
column3: Sh wabshaba hab kaij g jiawul ab ha wui, “S‑mahch ani g Jesus ch ep s‑mahch mo hedai wud hegai Paul ch wabshaba ahpim pi shaꞌi em‑mahch mams hedai wud.”

column2: The man with the evil spirit jumped on them and overpowered all of them. He beat them so severely that they ran out of the house, naked and badly injured.
column3: Kutsh ihda cheoj mo g jiawul an si uꞌukch haha wabsh ha dadge k s‑koꞌokam ha juh. Tsh gam hu neꞌiopa ab amjed g kihj k d wabsh i ehꞌed. K g ha‑wehschuga wantshas.

column2: People living in Ephesus, both Jews and Greeks, heard about this. They were all in awe at what had happened, and the name of the Lord Jesus gained great respect.
column3: Kutsh wehsijj kah ihda amai Ephesus t am k atsh si s‑ehbeni k ab si has i el g t‑kownalig Jesus.

column2: Many came to trust in the Lord and confessed their sins, openly admitting their evil practices.
column3: Tsh muꞌijj hegam matsh ab i s‑wohoch s‑kehg haꞌichu ahga ab amjed g Jesus am i e hemapad k mahsko wua g pi ap e‑chuꞌijig am wehs ha tahgio g hemajkam.

column2: A number of those who used to practice sorcery collected their books on magic and brought them to be burned publicly. They worked out how much the books were worth, and the total was fifty thousand silver coins.
column3: Tsh muꞌijj hegam mash hab chum e elid mo d mamakai am uꞌapa hegam e‑oꞌohana mo an ahgas g hihoina k am ha chehgid k ha mei. Tsh eda am i kuint g ha‑namkig idam oꞌohana mash am mei. Kutsh ai g hetaspo wehst‑mahm mihl pihsh (50,000).

column2: In this way the word of the Lord grew strong and spread widely.
column3: Kutsh hab masma hekaj si s‑gewkam am i hih g haꞌichu ahga ab amjed g Jesus k am i e gantad. Sh g hemajkam baꞌich i s‑gewkam ab uꞌukch.

column2: Some time after this Paul decided to go to Jerusalem, passing first through Macedonia and Achaia. “After I've been there, I'll have to go to Rome,” he said.
column3: Tsh amjed hab i e ah g Paul matsh gam hu wo hih Macedonia ch Greece jejewed oidk k amjed gam hu haha wo hih Jerusalem wui k amjed am Rome wui wo hih.

column2: He sent two of his helpers, Timothy and Erastus, to Macedonia, while he stayed on for a while in the province of Asia.
column3: Kush eda g Timothy ch Erastus am wehmaj. Kush am ha ahgid g Paul matsh am wo hihi Macedonia wui. Tsh g Paul am wih Asia ch ed heꞌes i tash.

column2: It was about this time that serious problems occurred regarding the Way.
column3: Kutsh iaꞌi idani am i e kudu g hemajkam ab Ephesus t ab heg hekaj Jesus himdag.

column2: A man called Demetrius, a silversmith, was producing small silver replicas of the temple of the goddess Artemis. This business brought in a great deal of work for such craftsmen.
column3: Amai ash am hema kehk g geꞌe cheopi. Kush am eda e kehshch g uwi ha‑jioshga ch hab chehgig Artemis. Kush am hema d plahda chikpandam ch hab chehgig Demetrius. Sh id pionag g plahdakaj ha nahto g al kihki mo heg wepogidas cheopi ch muꞌi nahto g lial ha gagdadch.

column2: Demetrius called them together, along with others who worked in similar trades, and said, “Fellow-workers, you know that it's through this business we make our money.
column3: Kutsh g Demetrius am i ha hemapai hegam mash hab waꞌap mahs chikpan hab wua k am si s‑gewkam hab kaij ab ha wui, “Ni‑naipijju, s‑mahch am mo g s‑t‑kaistalig ab him id amjed chikpan.
