column2: As you're no doubt aware from what you've seen and heard—not just here in Ephesus, but throughout almost the whole of Asia—this man Paul has convinced and misled many people, telling them that there are no such things as gods made by human hands.
column3: Kum eda si neid ch ep kah ihda hab chehgi Paul mo hab kaij mo idam t‑jijoshga pi d shaꞌi jijosh. T hab am gawul juh g e‑chegitoi g muꞌi hemajkam ab i s‑wohochudk iia Ephesus t am ch chum alo wehsko am Asia jewed oidk.

column2: It's not just a question that our business will be in danger of losing respect, but that the temple of the great goddess Artemis will be considered worthless. Artemis herself would be dethroned from her high position as the one whom everyone in Asia and the whole world worships.”
column3: Kut wo e padch g t‑chikpan nat pi pi ab hu hab masma wo e ihmad g Artemis mo hemuch wehsko ab si e ihm. T g cheopigaj pi ab hu wo e haꞌichuch.”

column2: When they heard this they became furious, and shouted out, “Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!”
column3: Tsh am i kah idam mat am e hemapai k atsh si babgat k si s‑kaidam hihnk ch hab kaij, “B ach si has elid g t‑jioshga Artemis.”

column2: The city was in complete chaos. People rushed towards the amphitheatre, dragging along with them Gaius and Aristarchus, Paul's traveling companions who were from Macedonia.
column3: Sh wehsko kaidag g ha‑hihinki ch wehs ha babgach g kihkam. Tsh gohk ha ui hegam mash am wehmaj g Paul k am ha uꞌapa chichwikud ed. Hegam mamtsh ha ui ash d Gaius ch Aristarcas.

column2: Paul thought he should confront the mob, but the other believers would not let him.
column3: Tsh g Paul am chum s‑wahkim ha shahgid. Tsh wabshaba g wehmaj wohochuddam pi hiwigi.

column2: Some of the provincial officials, who were Paul's friends, also sent a message begging him not to go into the amphitheatre.
column3: Tsh haꞌi hegam mash d hahaꞌichu ch d naipijjuj g Paul hab waꞌap ahgid matsh pi am hu wo hih mamt am i ha ui idam gohk.

column2: Some were shouting one thing, and some something else, for the crowd that had gathered was in total confusion—most of them had no idea why they were there.
column3: Tsh eda heg oidam am i si e gewkai g kudutadag. Sh haꞌijj si hihnk has i kaidam. Sh haꞌi am wa gawul haꞌichu ep hihnk heg hekaj mash muꞌijj pi shaꞌi mahch mas haschu ahgch ia e chehm.

column2: The Jews in the crowd pushed Alexander to the front. Alexander motioned with his hand for them to be quiet, wanting to explain things to the people.
column3: Tsh g Tutuligo am hema i kei mat am wo him k ab wo i kekiwua ha wehhejed k am wo ha ahgi mo pi d ha‑chuꞌijig g Tutuligo. Id ash hab chehgig Alexander ch am wabsh i chum ha baꞌich i kekiwua mat am wo neo.

column2: But when they realized he was a Jew, they all took up a chant that lasted for about two hours, shouting “Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!”
column3: Tsh am i nei g hemajkam mo d Tuhligo k pi ab hu shaꞌi kaiham k wabsh si hihnk e wehm am hu i gohk ohla ab hab kaijch, “B ach si has elid g t‑jioshga Artemis.”

column2: After the town clerk had managed to quiet the mob down, he told them, “People of Ephesus, who doesn't know that the city of the Ephesians is the guardian of the temple of the great Artemis and of her image that fell from heaven?
column3: Tsh g s‑has haꞌichu oꞌohandam ha shohbi g hemajkam ash hab kaijch, “Ahpim kihkam! Wehsijj am s‑mahch mo ia Ephesus t am e nuhkud g cheopigaj g si s‑has haꞌichu t‑jioshga Artemis ch ia ep e nuhkud hegai hodaigaj mat ab dahm kahchim t amjed i gei.

column2: Since these facts can't be denied, you should stay calm—don't do anything rash.
column3: T pi hedai hab wo shaꞌi chei mas pi woho ihda. Kumt ab wabsh wo i e bahbgi k pi am hu haꞌichu wabsh wo si has juh.

column2: You have brought these men here, but they haven't robbed any temples or blasphemed against our goddess.
column3: Neh, mamt i ha uꞌapa idam oꞌodham. T eda pi haꞌichu shaꞌi ha ehs ab cheopi t amjed, niꞌis am hu shaꞌi pi ap has ahg g t‑jioshga.

column2: So if Demetrius and the other craftsmen have a complaint against anyone, then go to the authorities and the courts. They can press charges there.
column3: Neh, k am dadha g hahaꞌichu lodaita tash ch ed. Kut idam Demetrius am haꞌab wo ha uꞌapa matp ab haꞌichu wo s‑ha abchudam.

column2: If there's anything else, it can be taken to the legal assembly.
column3: K am ep e nanmek g kihkam ch haꞌichu i aꞌaga ch am i apꞌechud. Kumt am wo uꞌapa mamtp haꞌichu ep tatchua.

column2: In fact we ourselves are in danger of being accused of being responsible for this riot today, since there was no reason for it, and we can't justify why it happened.”
column3: T hahawa pi ab hu wo t‑abch g kownal machs wabsh t‑cheggia heg hekaj mat haschu has i e juh id tashkaj. Kutt pi wo shaꞌi t‑nako machs wo ah mat haschu ahgk hab e juh haꞌichu.”

column2: When he had finished speaking, he dismissed the crowd.
column3: Neh, bash kaij ch ha dagito.

column2: Once the uproar had died down, Paul called the believers together and encouraged them. Then he said goodbye, and left for Macedonia.
column3: Tsh am i dodolimat haꞌichu. Tsh g Paul am i ha hemapai g e‑wehm wohochuddam k am si i ha gewkemhun k am hahawa ha dagito k gam hu aigo i chesh Macedonia t am

column2: He passed through the area, sharing many words of encouragement with the believers there, and then traveled on to Greece.
column3: k am heg oidk i ha gewkemhunahi muꞌikpa ha mihshmadk. Am heꞌes d i tash, t ia jiwia Greece jewed t am

column2: After he had spent three months there and just as he was about to sail to Syria, it was discovered that the Jews were plotting against him. So he decided to return through Macedonia.
column3: k ia haꞌichugkahim waik mashad. T am hebai i cheka, t am hahawa i chum e nako mat am aigo i chesh Syria jewed wui. Tsh wabshaba g Tutuligo am i e nako mat wo be k wo mua. T hekaj hab i e ah mat am uhpam ep wo hih Macedonia wui.

column2: These were the people who traveled with him: Sopater of Berea, the son of Pyrrhus; Aristarchus and Secundus from Thessalonica; Gaius from Derbe; Timothy; Tychicus and Trophimus from the province of Asia.
column3: Tsh haꞌi oi g Paul mat gam hu hih. Hema o d Sopater ch ab Berea t amjed ch d alidaj g Pyrrus. K haꞌi ep d Aristarcas ch Secundus ch ab Thessalonica t amjed. Tki hegai Gaius mo ab Derbe t amjed ch Timothy am ha oi. Tki hegam ep ha oi Tychicus ch Trophimus mo ab amjed g Asia jewed.

column2: They went on ahead and waited for us at Troas.
column3: T ia dada Philippi kihhim t am. Ni ahni Luke ia wabsh kia haꞌichug ch am hahawa oi g Paul. T wabshaba hegam haꞌi iꞌajed gam hu t‑baꞌich i chehchsh Troas kihhim wui matsh am wo t‑nenida.

column2: After the Feast of Unleavened Bread we sailed from Philippi, and met them five days later in Troas, where we spent a week.
column3: T eda e ai mat g Tutuligo wuhshad g e‑shohshon ha‑doꞌibiadag k hab pi koꞌa hegai pahn mo jewajidas. Kutt am hahawa gahi i shul g geꞌe wahlkokaj k am ha nam Troas t am mo d hetasp tash amjed mat hegam am i t‑dagito. Kuch wehsijj am haꞌichugkahim hemako domig.

column2: Paul was speaking on the first day of the week as we gathered together to break bread. He was planning to leave in the morning, and went on speaking until midnight.  (The upstairs room where we were meeting was lit by many lamps.)
column3: Am hu hebai d i shahwai hudunk. Tt am i t‑hemapai mo an hebai uhgk g kih k am t‑wehm t‑gegos matt am wo hehgigchul g Jiosh. K an muꞌi e mehmheidch g lalampa. T g Paul am neok k shaꞌi si tash am t‑mihshmad natsh pi wo hih baꞌich tash ed. Kut eda i huh g s‑chuhugam.

column2: A young man called Eutychus was sitting in the window, and he began feeling very sleepy. As Paul went on speaking he fell sound asleep and tumbled down from the third story. When they picked him up they found he was dead.
column3: K an hema daha g wechij oꞌodham wintani t an ch hab chehgig Eutycus ch atsh am i s‑kohsim k kohsh k i gei ab wintani t amjed k ged hu gei jewedo. K eda waik e dahm kihki mat amjed ab i gei. T am hahawa haꞌi be k am s‑mai matki heki hu muh.

column2: Paul went down, stretched himself out upon him, and hugged him. “Don't worry, he's alive,” he said.
column3: T wabshaba g Paul am i huduni k an si kohm k hab kaij, “Pi g am wo has e tahtkkad. Do doakam.”

column2: Paul went back upstairs, broke bread, and ate together with them. He went on talking with them until dawn came, and then he left.  They took the young man home alive and well, and were very thankful for this.
column3: T g hajunij gam hu hahawa i bei hegai wechij oꞌodham kihj wui si s‑ap e tahtkch mo d doakam. Kut gam hu hahawa uhpam ep i chehchsh mo an e mihshmad k am hab juh hegai chemait hugi mat hekaj wo s‑chegitok g Jesus muhkig. T g Paul am hahawa ep ha mihshmad k gam hu hahawa hih.

column2: We went on ahead to the ship and sailed to Assos. There we were due to pick up Paul, since that was what he had planned as he decided to travel on foot.
column3: K am hahawa t‑ahgid g Paul mattsh gam hu wo nam mo am d Assos kihhim natsh pi wabsh wo i keish g wohg k am wo hih. Kutt heg hekaj gahi i shul g geꞌe wahlkokaj k gam hu dada.

column2: He did indeed meet us at Assos. We picked him up, and went on to Mitylene.
column3: T am hahawa t‑nam k an t‑wehm dahiwua. Tt am ep gahi i shulig k gam hu ai g Mitylene kihhim

column2: Sailing on from there we arrived off Kios, and the next day we stopped briefly at Samos, and the following day we arrived at Miletus.  Paul had planned to sail on past Ephesus so he wouldn't have to spend time in the province of Asia. He was keen to get to Jerusalem in time for the Day of Pentecost.
column3: k amjed gam hu ai g Chios kihhim. K am baꞌich d ep i tash, tt gam hu ai g Samos kihhim. K eda e aihim mat g Tutuligo gam hu wo hihi Jerusalem wui k am hab wo juh g hehgchulida Jiosh wui mat s‑ap i ha wehmt k am babhaijid g ha‑eꞌesha. K heg wui s‑himimk g Paul ch s‑e hohtkid ch hekaj hab kaij matt pi am hu wo i huhud Ephesus t am. Kutt hekaj am wabsh gahi wuwha. K am baꞌich d i tash, tt gam hu dada Miletus kihhim t am.

column2: From Miletus Paul sent a message to the elders of the church in Ephesus.
column3: K oi wa s‑ha neidamk g Paul hegam mo d geꞌeged am ha shahgid g t‑wehm wohochuddam ab Ephesus t ab. Kut ab i ha wai Miletus wui.

column2: When they arrived, he told them, “You know how I always behaved while I was with you from the first day I arrived in the province of Asia.
column3: T am i dada. K hab kaij ab ha wui:

column2: I served the Lord in humility and in tears. I put up with the troubles and stress caused by the plots of the Jews.
column3: Ni ab wabsh i ni‑shoꞌigchud ch hebai ni‑ohꞌog iawua am hab junihidch g Jiosh chikpan nani pi si pihk ni‑elid em‑hekaj. Am o chum e nakog g ni‑wehm oꞌodham mat wo ni‑mua. Ni heg hekaj ab nakog g s‑wihnk haꞌichu.

column2: However I never held back from sharing with you anything that would be to your benefit, and I taught you in public, going from house to house.
column3: Kum s‑mahch mani pi haꞌichu shaꞌi ehstohim ch wabshaba am wehs em‑ahgid mani haschu hab elid mat d wo i em‑wehmtadagk. Ni am em‑mashcham g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga mam am e hehemapad ch amai ep si heheꞌejel em‑kihki ed.

column2: I witnessed both to Jews and Greeks that it was essential to repent and turn to God, and to trust in our Lord Jesus Christ.
column3: Kuni am si tasho ha ahgid g ni‑wehm oꞌodham ch gawul mahs hemajkam mat wo s‑ohhod g pi ap e‑chegitoi k ab wo i e dagito Jiosh wui k ab wo bei g t‑kownalig Jesus.

column2: Now the Spirit is insisting that I go to Jerusalem, and I have no idea what will happen to me there.
column3: K hemuch hab si tahhadag g ni‑ihbdag mant am wo hih Jerusalem wui. Pi ani mahch mas haschu has wo mahsk am ni‑wehhejed amai.

column2: All I know is that in every city I visit the Holy Spirit warns me that prison and suffering are waiting for me.
column3: Id ani hi wa s‑mahch mani heg wui am him mantp hems wo ni‑kuhpachud k wo ni‑shoꞌigch no pi heki hu am i ni‑tashogid g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag mani hebai i jijiwhia.

column2: But I don't consider my life as worth anything to me. I only want to finish my mission and the ministry that the Lord Jesus gave to me, to witness to the good news of the grace of God.
column3: Pi o d shaꞌi haꞌichu g ni‑doakag manis wo si s‑huwidad hejel ni‑wehhejed. Heg ani waꞌi hab s‑junimk mant wo nahto hegai mo g t‑kownalig Jesus ab ni‑chehani mant am hab wo juh. K d ihda mant am wo i ahgahi g Jiosh hemajimatalig.

column2: Now I am certain that you will not see my face again, you among whom I shared the news of the kingdom.
column3: “Neh, pi amtki hekid ep wo shaꞌi ni‑nei. Ni heg hekaj s‑em‑ahgidamk mani wa wehs haꞌichu em‑ahgid ab amjed g Jiosh kownaltalig.

column2: So I declare to you today that I am not responsible if anyone is lost.
column3: K pi d ni‑chuꞌijig mamtp hema i pi wo e doꞌibia.

column2: I didn't hesitate to tell you everything God wants you to know.
column3: Wehs ant em‑ahgi hegai mo haschu g Jiosh am hab elid k pi haschu shaꞌi ehsto ab em‑amjed.

column2: Take care of yourselves and of all the flock, which the Holy Spirit has given to you to supervise. Feed the Lord's church which he bought with his own blood.
column3: Ab g hejel wo e nuhkudad ch ep wo ha nuhkudad g e‑wehm wohochuddam. Hegam o g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag em‑nuhkudachud hab masma mamt wo haꞌi ha nuhkudach g kahwal e‑shoshoiga. Kumt wo s‑chegitok mat g t‑kownalig Jesus ehꞌed e iawua mat am ha wehhejed e muhkid k ha doꞌibia.

column2: I know that after I leave vicious wolves will come among you, and won't spare the flock.
column3: Ab at haꞌi wo i wahp em‑shahgid mat hab masma wo s‑ta ehbidamak am em‑wehhejed mo g shehꞌe am ha wehhejed g kahwal k wo chum s‑em‑uꞌim.

column2: From among your own group men will rise up perverting what is right so they can lead believers to follow them.
column3: Kut am haꞌi wo i e maskogi g chechoj em‑shahgid k wo haꞌichu chum em‑iattogi ahpim wohochuddam mat hab masma haꞌi im hu gawul wo i em‑wanim.

column2: So watch out! Don't forget that for three years I went on instructing all of you night and day, often crying over you.
column3: Neh, mt wo si e nuhkudad ch wo s‑chegitokad mani em‑mashcham wehsijj waik ahid ab ch g ni‑ohꞌog iawua s‑chuhugam oidam ch tash oidam nani pi pihk ni‑elid em‑hekaj.

column2: Now I commit you in God's care and to the message of his grace, which is able to build you up and provide you with the inheritance that belongs to all who are kept right with him.
column3: “Pegih neh, ab ant wa em‑ahgi ab amjed g Jiosh hoꞌigeꞌidadag k am haha wo em‑dagito Jiosh nohnhoi ed. T g Jiosh wo wa em‑nuhkudad ch ab wo i gewkai g em‑wohochudadag k wo em‑mah hegai si s‑kehg haꞌichu mo ab ha makiog g e‑hemajkamga.

column2: I never had any desire for anyone's silver or gold or clothing.
column3: Pi ani hekid hedai ha‑lialigakaj o g wehschuga shaꞌi pihk ni‑elid.

column2: You know that I worked with my own hands to provide for my own needs, as well as for those who were with me.
column3: Ni wabsh g hejel ni‑nohnhoikaj am hab junihim g chikpan ch hekaj ni‑dagioꞌid ch ep ha dagioꞌid g ni‑wehm chikpandam.

column2: I have given you an example in everything: work to help those who are weak, remembering the words of the Lord Jesus: ‘It is more blessed to give than to receive.’ ”
column3: Ni hab wa masma am em‑chehgid mamt wo i ha wehmt hegam mo pi e amichud. T‑kownalig Jesus o hab kaij, ‘T wo s‑em‑hehgigch hegai mat ab wo haꞌichu em‑mah. Mt wabshaba baꞌich wo i s‑hehgigk mamt ab wo haꞌichu ha mah.’ Kumt id wo s‑chegitok mo has i kaij.”

column2: When he finished speaking, he kneeled down and prayed with all of them.
column3: I am i haꞌasa neo g Paul k am hahawa wehs ha wehm tohtonwua idam k am e hoꞌigeꞌidahu.

column2: They all wept as they hugged and kissed him.
column3: K wehsijj si shoani ch an si kokme no pi si pihk e elid hekaj ch hab ahg, “Jiosh at wo wa m‑wehmajk.”

column2: What upset them the most was what he said about never seeing him again... Then they walked down to the ship with him.
column3: K si pi ap e tahtk, wahm mat am i chegito mo hab kaij mat pi dahm ep wo nei. T am hahawa wehsijj hihi mo am daha g geꞌe wahlko.

column2: After we had said goodbye to them, we sailed directly to Cos, and the next day on to Rhodes. From there we went to Patara
column3: Kutt am hahawa si wehs i ha hoꞌigeꞌel g t‑wepnag k am ha dagito k am wabsh si shel gahi i shul g geꞌe wahlkokaj k ga hu dada Cos kihhim t ab. Am baꞌich d i tash, tt ga hu ai g Rhodes kihhim k amjed ga hu aigo i dada Patara kihhim t ab.

column2: where we found a ship going to Phoenicia. We went on board and set sail.
column3: Neh, k am hema daha g geꞌe wahlko matsh gam hu wo hih Phenicia jewed wui. Kutt heg ab an ha hekaj i chehchsh k gm hu oi.

column2: We passed within sight of Cyprus on the left, and continued on to Syria where we landed at Tyre, where the ship's cargo was to be unloaded.
column3: Tsh ab wo i e huhuds g wahlko mohtoi Tyre kihhim t am. Kutt am bihbij hugidaj an g Cyprus jewed k am dada amai Tyre t am.

column2: We found the believers and stayed there for a week. Through the Holy Spirit the believers told Paul not to go to Jerusalem.
column3: K am haꞌi kih g t‑wehm wohochuddam. Kutt ha chehg k am ha wehm dadha hemako domig ab. T am i ha tashogi g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag matsh am haꞌichu has wo e juh tahgio g Paul. Kum hab chum ahg mat pi am hu wo hih Jerusalem wui.

column2: When the time was up, we left and went back to the ship to continue our journey. All the believers, and wives and children, accompanied us as we left the city. We kneeled down on the beach and prayed, and said our goodbyes.
column3: T wabshaba am i e ai matt wo hihi. Tt gam hu hihi. T wehsijj gam hu t‑oi ha wehm g e‑wehm kihkam ch e‑aꞌaliga matt gm hu wo i wuwha ab kihhim t amjed. Tt wehsijj am i tohtonwua ge shuhdagi bahsho k am t‑hoꞌigeꞌidahun

column2: Then we boarded the ship, and they went back home.
column3: k ab hahawa aꞌai t‑ahgid mat wo t‑wehmajk g Jiosh. Tt ahchim gan hu hahawa i chehchsh geꞌe wahlko ch ed. T hegam gm hu epai hihi uhpam.

column2: Our voyage from Tyre ended at Ptolemais where we greeted the believers and stayed with them for a day.
column3: Kutt gam hu hahawa ep gahi i shul g geꞌe wahlkokaj Ptolemais kihhim wui. K am haꞌi kih g t‑wehm wohochuddam. Ch am ha wehmajkahim hemako tash ab.

column2: The next day we left and went to Caesarea. We stayed at the house of Philip the evangelist (one of the Seven).
column3: Am baꞌich d i tash, tt ga hu dada Cesaria kihhim t ab.

column2: Philip had four unmarried daughters who prophesied.
column3: Kuch am wehmajkahim heꞌekia i tash. Ihda Philip o giꞌik uꞌuwi aꞌalidag. K idam pi ha kuhkun ch am ahgahim hegai mo haschu g Jiosh am ha tashogid.

column2: After we'd stayed there for several days, a prophet called Agabus arrived from Judea.
column3: Kut ab Judea t amjed heg ab jiwia Jiosh haꞌichu i tashogiddam mo hab chehgig Agabus.

column2: Approaching us, he took Paul's belt, and bound his own hands and feet. Then he said, “The Holy Spirit says, ‘This is how the Jews in Jerusalem will bind the man who owns this belt, and will hand him over to the foreigners.’ ”
column3: Ch am t‑mihshmad. T heg an bei g Paul giwud k an hekaj wuh g e‑kakhio ch e‑nohnhoi ch hab kaij, “Bamtsh masma hab wo m‑juh maptp am wo hih Jerusalem wui. T‑wehm oꞌodham atsh an wo si m‑wud k ab wo m‑dagito gawul mahs hemajkam ha wui. Id o am ni‑tashogid g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag.”

column2: When we heard this, we and the believers there pleaded with Paul not to go to Jerusalem.
column3: Kutt am i kah ihda k ab chum si i ahgid g Paul mat pi am hu wo hih Jerusalem wui.

column2: However Paul answered, “What are you doing, crying and breaking my heart? I'm ready not only to be bound in Jerusalem, but to die in Jerusalem for the sake of the Lord Jesus.”
column3: K wabshaba hab wabsh kaij, “Pi g am wo shoanid. Pi am ap ni‑tahtchud. Ni‑nahtokch ani mamtp wo ni‑wulsh o chum hems wo ni‑mua g t‑kownalig Jesus wehhejed.”

column2: Since he couldn't be persuaded otherwise we gave up, and said, “May the Lord's will be done.”
column3: Kutt pi shaꞌi t‑nako machs wo shohbi k am wabsh i dagito k hab kaij, “Pegih, id ach waꞌi tatchua mat g Jiosh haꞌichu apꞌechuda am hab wo e juh.”

column2: After this we packed our bags and headed for Jerusalem.
column3: Kuch am ep haꞌichug heꞌes i tash ch am hahawa i t‑nakog k gam hu hihi Jerusalem wui.

column2: Some of the believers from Caesarea came with us, and they took us to the home of Mnason, where we were going to stay. He came from Cyprus and was one of the early believers.
column3: T am haꞌi t‑oi Jerusalem wui k am i t‑ui heg kih wui matt am wehmaj wo dadhaiwua. Id o hab chehgig Mason ch ab d si kihkam Cyprus jewed t ab ch ash heki hu waꞌi s‑wohochud mo g Jesus d Jiosh si Kehsha.

column2: When we arrived in Jerusalem, the believers there welcomed us warmly.
column3: T si s‑ap i e taht g t‑wehm wohochuddam ab i t‑neidok.

column2: The next day Paul went with us to see James, and all the church leaders were there.
column3: Idam ha‑uhgchuga ash d James. Kutt heg chehgio am wehmaj g Paul. K am wehsijj dadha hegam mo d geꞌeged.

column2: After greeting them, Paul went through in detail everything God had done for the foreigners through his ministry.
column3: T g Paul ab wehs i ha hoꞌigeꞌid k am hahawa si s‑ap ha ahgid wehs haꞌichu mat g Jiosh s‑kehg am hab juh am gahi wuhshanim am ha shahgid g gawul mahs hemajkam.

column2: When they heard what had happened they praised God and told Paul, “Brother, you can see how many thousands of Jews have come to trust in the Lord, and they all keep the Law very carefully.
column3: T am i kaiok ab si ihm g Jiosh k wabshaba hab kaij ab Paul wui, “Neh, t‑wehnag, s‑mahch ap mat muꞌi mihl t‑wehm oꞌodham ab i s‑wohoch g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga k ab ihm g t‑kownalig Jesus k eda ab wabsh kia si has elid g heki hu t‑chehanig.

column2: They have been told that you teach Jews living among the foreigners to ignore the Law of Moses, telling them not to circumcise their children and not to follow our customs.
column3: Idam o kah mapsh ahpi ha mashcham hegam t‑wehm oꞌodham mo an aꞌai kih nahnko mahs hemajkam ha shahgid mat wo s‑ohhod g t‑chehanig k pi an hu wo ha oꞌoha an ha pahl hikuchk g e‑aꞌaliga.

column2: So what should we do about it? People will certainly get to hear that you've arrived here.
column3: Do wabsh si shel mat wo kah mapt ia jiwia. Pegih, k hab chum mahs

column2: This is what we want you to do: Four men among us have taken a vow.
column3: mapt am hab wo e juh matt has wo i m‑ah. M o haꞌi d chechoj ch d giꞌik mat heꞌes pi hih g e‑moꞌo nat pi ab haꞌichu ahꞌad g Jiosh.

column2: Go with them and perform the purification rituals with them, paying for them to have their heads shaved. That way everyone will know there's no truth to the rumors they've heard about you, but that you yourself observe the Law in the way that you live.
column3: Pt am wo ha oid k am ha wehm wo e dagito Jiosh wui geꞌe cheopi t am. Am apt ha wehhejed wo namkid mat haschu wo i chum ha namkid heg hekaj. Kumt am haha wo hih g e‑moꞌo. Pt hab masma wo ha chehgi g t‑wehm oꞌodham map am hab junihim g t‑himdag. T heg amjed wo s‑mahchk mo pi woho hegai mam haschu ab m‑abchud.

column2: As to the foreigners who have trusted the Lord, we already wrote a letter regarding our decision that they should refrain from eating food sacrificed to idols, from blood, from any animal that is strangled, and from sexual immorality.”
column3: P am wa s‑mahch matt haschu am ha oꞌohani hegam gawul mahs hemajkam mat ab i s‑wohoch g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga. Bo chuꞌig g t‑oꞌohana mat hegam pi wo koꞌad g ehꞌed ch hegai mo pi gam hu e iawua g ehꞌed e mumꞌajch kch hegai mo ab e toꞌid hegai mo haschu hab chum e elid mo d jiosh. Kut wo si e nuhkud hab masma mat hegai waꞌi si e‑hohnig o g si e‑kun wehm wo kihk.”

column2: So Paul took the men with him, and the next day went and purified himself with them. Then he went to the Temple to give notice regarding the end of the time of purification and the offering which would be made for each of them.
column3: K wa woho am baꞌich d i tash. T g Paul am i ha ui hegam chechoj k am ha wehm i e dagito Jiosh wui k am hahawa i wah geꞌe cheopi ch ed k am ha ahgid mat d wo wewaꞌak tashk, t wo kuhgit hegai mat ab ahꞌad. T am hab wo e juh hegai mat am hahawa haꞌichu wo iagchul Jiosh wui.

column2: The seven days were almost over when some Jews from Asia saw Paul in the Temple and incited the crowd against him and seized him.
column3: K am i e aihim mat wo kuhgit hegai wewaꞌak tash. T am hih g Paul k am i wah geꞌe cheopi ch ed. Kutsh haꞌi am chehg k an bei hegam Tutuligo mo ab Asia jewed t amjed. K eda muꞌi an oiopo g hemajkam. Kutsh am si i ha kudut

column2: “Men of Israel, help!” they shouted. “This is the man who is teaching everyone everywhere to oppose our people, the Law, and the Temple. He's also brought Greeks into the Temple, defiling this holy place.”
column3: k ash si hihnk ch hab kaij, “T‑hajuni, ia g wo i t‑wehmt. Ihda oꞌodham o an wehsko si has ahg g t‑himdag ch t‑chehanig ch ihda geꞌe cheopi. Pi o d ha‑apꞌedag g gawul mahs hemajkam mas ia hu wo i wahp. Kutki eda ihda haꞌi i ha wahpkid k hab uamhu g geꞌe cheopi.”

column2: (They said this because they had seen him previously in the city with Trophimus the Ephesian and presumed that Paul had brought him into the Temple).
column3: Bash kaij nash pi am hu hebai neid g Paul hema wehm g gawul mahs oꞌodham ch hab e ahg mat am i wahki. Hegai mo wa am wehmaj o hab chehgig Trophimus ch ab Ephesus t ab d kihkam.

column2: The whole city was shocked by this and people came running. They grabbed hold of Paul and dragged him out of the Temple. Immediately the doors were shut.
column3: T am wabsh wehsko chehmo g pi ha‑apꞌedag amai kihhim t am. T ab aꞌaijed i wohp g hemajkam k an wabsh si bei g Paul k gam hu i chewaim ab amjed g geꞌe cheopi. T ab ha hekaj si e kuhkp g geꞌe cheopi kihkijeg.

column2: As they tried to kill him, news came to the Roman troop commander that the whole of Jerusalem was in an uproar.
column3: K idam s‑babgam hemajkam chum mumꞌa g Paul. Kumtsh am ahgi g shondal ha‑geꞌejig mash am ge e cheggia.

column2: Immediately the commander took some centurions and soldiers and ran down to the mob. When the mob saw the commander and the soldiers, they stopped beating Paul.
column3: T ab ha hekaj daꞌiwush muꞌi ha wehm g e‑shondalig k haꞌi ehp g ha‑geꞌegeꞌejig k ged hu woꞌi mat am e hemapai g hemajkam. T hegam am ha hekaj wabsh si haꞌasa cheggia g Paul am i ha neidk.

column2: Then the commander came over and arrested Paul, and ordered him to be bound with two chains. He asked who he was, and what he had done.
column3: T g shondal am him k an bei g Paul. T g ha‑geꞌejig hab ha ah mat an wo si wuh g gohk e hukshchim wainomikaj. Kut hab juh. T ab hahawa ha kakke g hemajkam, “Dohꞌo wud ihda oꞌodham ch haschu has juh?”

column2: Some in the mob were shouting one thing and some another. Since the commander couldn't find out the truth due to all the noise and confusion, he ordered Paul brought into the fortress.
column3: K haꞌi g hemajkam am hu has i ahg. K haꞌijj ehp am wa gawul ep ahg. T am wabsh i ge nahnko e juh g haꞌichu ha‑ahga. Kut pi shaꞌi amich ihda shondal ha‑geꞌejig mat haschu has e juh k heg hekaj am wabsh ha ahgid g e‑shondalig mat ged hu wo kuh g Paul.

column2: When Paul got to the stairs, he had to be carried by the soldiers because the mob was so violent.  People in the crowd that was following were shouting, “Get rid of him!”
column3: T an i bei mo an cheshajkudag. T wabshaba wabsh e nondagch g hemajkam k an chum s‑behimk ch si hihnk ch hab kaij, “Muꞌawo! Muꞌawo!” T heg hekaj wabsh uhgk i ul g shondal mat pi wo e muhkid.

column2: Just as he was about to be taken inside the fortress, Paul asked the commander, “Can I tell you something?”
column3: T am haha wabsh i chum wahki g Paul e‑kolhai ed. K hab kaij g Greek ha‑neꞌokikaj ab wui g shondal ha‑geꞌejig, “M ani haꞌichu chum s‑m‑ahgidamk.”

column2: “Aren't you the Egyptian who recently incited a rebellion and led four thousand Assassins into the desert?”
column3: Ps hemsi d hegai Egypt t am oꞌodham mat wa am hu hebai ia i chum shonwuich g cheggiadag. T wa am i wehmt g giꞌik mihl chechoj ch uꞌa g cheggiakud am tohono jewed oidk.”

column2: “I am a Jew, a citizen of Tarsus in Cilicia, an important city,” Paul replied. “Please let me talk to the people.”
column3: K hab kaij g Paul, “Pi ani d hegai. Dani Tuhligo ch ab d mahsikam Tarsus kihhim t ab am Cilicia jewed ch ed ch ab uꞌukch g ni‑shel ab amjed g si s‑has haꞌichu kihhim. Pt ab wo si i s‑ni‑hoꞌigeꞌid k wo ni‑hiwigi mant am wo neo ha wui g hemajkam.”

column2: The commander gave Paul permission to speak. So Paul stood on the stairs and motioned for silence. When it was quiet he spoke to them in Aramaic.
column3: T wa woho am hiwigi g shondal ha‑geꞌejig. T an i kekiwua mo an cheshajkudag ab ha baꞌich g hemajkam k am neo g hejel e‑neꞌokikaj k hab kaij:

column2: “Brother and fathers,” he said, “Please listen as I give my defense before you.”
column3: “Ni‑hajuni ch ahpim geꞌeged hemajkam, ab g wo i ni‑kaiham mant am hejel ni‑wehhejed wo neo.”

column2: When they heard him speaking to them in Aramaic, they became very quiet.
column3: T am i kah mo g ha‑neꞌokikaj neok k gam hu wabsh i pi shahmuni. K hab hahawa kaij g Paul:

column2: “I am a Jew, born in Tarsus in Cilicia,” he began. “However, I was brought up here in this city, and sat at the feet of Gamaliel. I was taught to strictly observe the law of our fathers. I was zealous for God, just like all of you here today,
column3: “Ahni ani d Tuhligo ch ab d mahsikam Tarsus kihhim t am am Cilicia jewed ch ed ch wabshaba ia geꞌeda Jerusalem kihhim t am k ia ni‑mashcham. K wa g Gamaliel d ni‑mashchamdam ch ab si s‑gewkam ni‑mashcham g t‑chehanig. Ni hab wa masma am chum si s‑gewkam oid g Jiosh himdag mam ahpim hemuch id i tashkaj.

column2: and I persecuted the people of this Way—having them put to death, and imprisoning both men and women.
column3: Kuni wa heg hekaj ha shoꞌigchud ch ha kokda hegam mo an uꞌukch ihda wechij haꞌichu ahga ch wa an ha uꞌu g chechoj ch uꞌuwi ch am ha shulig kukpaikud ch ed.

column2: As the high priest and the council of the elders can also verify, I received from them letters of authorization addressed to the Jewish brothers in Damascus, and went there to arrest these people and bring them as prisoners to Jerusalem to be punished.
column3: T g uhgchu pahl ch hegam e jehnigiddam am wo wohokamch ihda mani em‑ahgid. Bani wa ha ahg mant am wo hih Damascus kihhim wui. T hegam ab ni‑mah g oꞌohana am ha wui hegam mo d uꞌugchu am ha eda g t‑wehm oꞌodham amai Damascus ch ed. Nt wa am hi wa i hih mant wo ha wupulsh g e hukshchim wainomikaj hegam mo ab s‑wohochud ihda wechij haꞌichu ahga k wo uhpam i ha ui ab Jerusalem wui mat wo bei g s‑koꞌok e‑namkidadag.

column2: At around noon, while I was on my way and approaching Damascus, suddenly a bright light from heaven shone all around me.
column3: “Neh, am att wa hihim k gam hu i aihim g Damascus kihhim. K wa am hu d i dahm juhk mat haha wabsh haꞌichu si ton ab amjed g dahm kahchim an wehsko ni‑wehgaj.

column2: I fell to the ground, and I heard a voice saying to me, ‘Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me?’
column3: Nt wa am i gei jewedo. T wa ab hema si neo ni‑wui k hab kaij, ‘Saul, s‑wohom ap hig ni‑shoꞌigchud.’

column2: ‘Who are you, Lord?’ I answered.
column3: “Kuni si has elid ch hab kaij, ‘Dohp wud ch ab neok?’

column2: Those who were traveling with me did see the light, but they didn't hear the voice that spoke to me.
column3: K hegam mo am ni‑wehmaj hi wa neid hegai geꞌe tonlig ch wabshaba pi amichud g neꞌoki.

column2: ‘What shall I do, Lord?’ I asked.
column3: “Ni ab hahawa kakke, ‘Shahnt wo ni‑juh, ni‑kownalig?’

column2: Since I couldn't see because of the brightness of the light, those who were with me led me by the hand into Damascus.
column3: “Tki eda pi ni‑nenich heg hekaj mat wa am si s‑masma ton. T wa am wabsh i ni‑wanim hegam mo am ni‑wehmaj k ged hu ni‑uꞌapa Damascus t am.

column2: There a man called Ananias came to see me. He was a religious man who observed the law, and was highly respected by the Jews who lived in the town.
column3: “Kuki wa am hema kih g oꞌodham ch hab chehgig Ananias ch ab si ihm g Jiosh ch ep am si oid g chehanig. K ab si has elid g t‑wehm oꞌodham amai Damascus t am.

column2: He stood in front of me and said, ‘Brother Saul, receive back your sight.’ At that very moment I could see again, and I looked at him.
column3: Heg at wa am jiwia ni‑wui k ab kehk ch hab kaij, ‘Ni‑nawoj Saul, ab g behꞌi g e‑nentalig!’ Nt ha hekaj s‑ap haꞌichu neid k ab si i nei.

column2: He told me, ‘The God of our fathers has appointed you to know his will, to see the One who is truly right, and to listen to what he has to say to you.
column3: “K wa hab kaij ab ni‑wui, ‘Neh, am antsh wo m‑ahgi matsh ahpi am i m‑kei g Jiosh mapt wo s‑mahchk g tatchuij ch wo nei g si s‑apꞌekam Kehshaj k wo kah mat am hejel wo m‑ahgi g haꞌichu e‑ahga. K d waꞌi ihda Jiosh mo an uꞌukch g t‑shohshonbad.

column2: You will testify for him to everyone about what you have seen and heard. So what are you waiting for?
column3: K hab d elidaj mapt d wo hema hegamk mapt am wo si i wohokamch g Jesus k am wo i ha ahgi g hemajkam mapt haschu i neid k haschu i kah.

column2: Get up, be baptized, and wash away your sins as you call on his name.’
column3: Pt ha hekaj wo i e nakog k wo e pahl wako ab ihmadch g Jesus. T heg gam hu hab wo i juh g pi ap m‑chuꞌijig.’ Neh, bo ni‑ahg.

column2: I returned to Jerusalem, and as I was praying in the Temple, I fell into a trance.
column3: “Nt wa am hab juniok ab i hih Jerusalem wui k am hu hebai am ni‑hoꞌigeꞌidahun geꞌe cheopi ch ed. T wa am haha wabsh ni‑nena ed haꞌichu hab e juh

column2: I saw a vision of the Lord telling me, ‘Hurry! You need to leave Jerusalem quickly, because they will not accept what you are telling them about me.’
column3: mani neid g Jesus. K hab kaij ab ni‑wui, ‘Ia g ha hekaj dagito g Jerusalem k hihm ab amjed nat pi g m‑wehm oꞌodham iia pi ab hu wo kaiha g haꞌichu m‑ahga ab ni‑amjed.’

column2: I replied, ‘Lord, they certainly know that I went from synagogue to synagogue, beating and imprisoning those who trusted in you.
column3: “Ni hab kaij, ‘Tp hems wo wa ni‑kaiha, ni‑kownalig, no pi s‑ap s‑mahch mani d ahni mani wa an wahkhim ha eda g ha‑chechopi ch an ha uꞌud ch ha gewittan hegam mo ab m‑ihm.

column2: When Stephen was killed for testifying about you I was standing there in full agreement with those who killed him, holding their coats for them.’
column3: Kuni wa am ha wehmaj ch am nuhkud g ha‑wehschuga hegam mat mua hegai Steven mat am si s‑mahch k ah ab m‑amjed.’

column2: The Lord told me, ‘Leave now, for I am sending you far away to the foreigners.’ ”
column3: “K wabshaba hab kaij g Jesus ab ni‑wui, ‘Am g wa hihm nant pi am i m‑kei mapt am mehk wo hih ha wui g nahnko mahs hemajkam.’ ” Neh, bo kaij g Paul.

column2: Up until this point they had listened to what he was saying, but then they started shouting, “Get rid of this man from the earth—he doesn't deserve to live!”
column3: K wa ab hi wa s‑ap kaiham idam hemajkam. T wabshaba am hab wabsh chum chei ihda matsh g Jesus am i kei matsh am wo hih ha wui g nahnko mahs hemajkam. T am ha hekaj i hihinkiad si s‑kaidam k hab kaij, “Muꞌawo! Muꞌawo! Pi o an hu hab chum chuꞌig mas in d wo doakamk.”

column2: They screamed and tore off their coats and threw dust into the air.
column3: K si hihnk ch ab si shahmud g e‑wepschuga ch g jewed shashkum ch am uhgk si nenꞌeichud nat pi am i si babgat.

column2: The commander ordered Paul brought into the fortress, and gave orders for him to be interrogated by flogging so he could find out the reason people were shouting so much against Paul.
column3: T g shondal ha‑geꞌejig am hahawa ha cheha g e‑shondalig mat gam hu wo i wahki g Paul shondal ha‑kih ed. T am i wahki. T am ha cheha mat wo gewitta am hugkam mat am wo ha ahgi mat has e juh mo hekaj si hihnkoid g Tutuligo.

column2: As they stretched him out and tied him down to flog him, Paul asked the centurion standing there, “Is it legal to flog a Roman citizen who hasn't had a trial?”
column3: T an wulsh mat wo chum gewitta. K am hema kehk g shondal ha geꞌejig. K ab wui hab kaij g Paul, “Ab ani uꞌukch g ni‑shel hab masma mo g Rome t am oꞌodham. K heg hekaj pi hab chum mahs mams wo ni‑gewitta pi koi ni‑lodaidk.”

column2: When the centurion heard what Paul said, he went to the commander and asked him, “What are you doing? This man is a Roman citizen.”
column3: T heg am i kah ihda k am wui hih g si uhgk shondal ha‑geꞌejig k ab kakke ch hab kaij, “Nap s‑mahch maptki has wo chum chuꞌi? Ihda oꞌodham oki ab uꞌukch g e‑shel hab masma mo g Rome t am oꞌodham.”

column2: The commander came, and asked Paul, “Tell me, are you a Roman citizen?”
column3: T am hahawa hih g si uhgchu shondal ha‑geꞌejig am Paul wui k ab kakke ch hab kaij, “Am g ni‑ahgid. Nap ab uꞌukch g e‑shel hab masma mo g Rome t am oꞌodham?”

column2: “I paid a lot of money to buy Roman citizenship,” said the commander.
column3: K hab hahawa kaij g ha‑geꞌejig, “A pt has hig masma ab bei g e‑shel. Ahni ant hi ab bei muꞌi lial ha namkid.”

column2: Those who were about to interrogate Paul left immediately. The commander was worried when he found out that Paul was a Roman citizen because he had placed him in chains.
column3: T ga hu taꞌi si i gegokiwua hegam mo an wulshch g Paul mat wo chum gewitta. T g shondal ha‑geꞌejig ep si e tods nat pi ha cheha mat hab wo juh.

column2: The next day, wanting to find out the reason why the Jews were accusing Paul, he had him released and taken before the chief priests and the whole council which he ordered to assemble. He had Paul brought down and placed him before them.
column3: Am baꞌich d i tash, tsh g shondal ha‑geꞌejig am i ha cheha g uꞌugchu papal mat am wo i ha hemapai g e jehnigiddam nash pi s‑mahchimk mo haschu ab abchud g Paul. T g shondaligaj gam wulꞌo g e hukshchim wainomi ab ab g Paul k am i be k am i kei ha wui.

column2: Paul, looking right at the council, said, “Brothers, right up to now I have always conducted myself before God with a clear conscience.”
column3: K g Paul ab si ha neid g e jehnitiddam ch hab kaij, “Ni‑hajuni, chum ani hekid si ni‑nakog mant am hab wo waꞌi junihid g s‑apꞌekam ch hab pi wo shaꞌi haꞌichukaj si has ni‑elidad am tahgio g Jiosh ia i himdam tashkaj.”

column2: Ananias the high priest ordered the officers standing beside Paul to hit him on the mouth.
column3: Kut hegai uhgchu pahl mash hab chehgig Ananias am ha cheha hegam mo an miabidch gegok mat ab wo si shonihi g Paul chinij ab. T ab shonihi.

column2: Paul said to him, “God will hit you, you whitewashed wall! You're sitting there to judge me according to the law, and you order me to be hit in contravention of the law!”
column3: K hab kaij g Paul, “Jiosh at hemho ab wo wa uhpam i nodagi ihda am m‑wui ahpi map s‑chu iattomk. Ab ap dak ch ni‑lodait g t‑chehanigkaj ch eda ep melchkwuhim g t‑chehanig map ab ha chehani mat ab wo ni‑shonihi.”

column2: The officers standing beside Paul said, “How dare you insult the high priest!”
column3: K hab kaij hegam mo an miabidch gegok g Paul, “S‑koꞌokam ap has ahg g uhgchu pahl.”

column2: “Brothers, I didn't know that he was the high priest,” Paul replied. “As Scriptures say, ‘You must not speak evil of any ruler of your people.’ ”
column3: K hab kaij g Paul, “Ni‑hajuni, mant hems wo s‑mahchk mokis d uhgchu pahl, nt pi hab wo shaꞌi chei, no pi hab chuꞌig g Jiosh oꞌohana:

column2: When Paul realized that some of the council were Sadducees and the others Pharisees, he shouted out, “Brothers, I am a Pharisee, the son of a Pharisee! I'm on trial because of my hope in the resurrection of the dead!”
column3: K hegam e jehnigiddam haꞌi d Sajusi ch haꞌi ep d Palasi. T id am i s‑mai g Paul k am si s‑kaidam neok ha wui ch hab kaij, “Ni‑hajuni, ahni ani d Palasi ch d ha amjedkam g Palasi ch ha wepo s‑wohochud mat g koꞌi ep wo i wuwha ab hihaꞌini t amjed. Kum heg hekaj ni‑lodait.”

column2: When he said this, a tremendous argument broke out between the Pharisees and Sadducees that split the council.
column3: T id am i kah g e jehnigiddam k am ha hekaj aꞌai e neꞌowin k pi ab hu i e wehmt.

column2: (The Sadducees say there is no resurrection from the dead, no angels, and no spirits, but Pharisees believe in all of these.)
column3: Hegam mo d Sajusi o pi ab hu wohochud mat g koꞌi wo i wuwha ab hihaꞌini t amjed ch ep pi wohochud mo an haꞌichug g anghil o g kokꞌoi. K wabshaba g Palasi wehs s‑wohochud ihda.

column2: A great commotion erupted and some of the Pharisee teachers of the law stood up and argued fiercely, saying, “We find this man not guilty! Maybe a spirit spoke to him, or an angel!”
column3: T am hahawa i si e gewkai g ha‑hihinki. T am haꞌi gegokiwua hegam mo d chehanig hudawogam ch d Palasi k am si s‑gewkam ha shohbid k hab kaij, “Pi att haꞌichu shaꞌi cheh mas pi ap hab juh ihda oꞌodham. Tp hems wa woho g anghil am wehmaj neo.”

column2: The argument was getting out of hand, so the commander, concerned that they would tear Paul to pieces, ordered the soldiers to go and rescue him from them by force, and take him back into the fortress.
column3: T am baꞌich i si e gewkai g ha‑neꞌowina. Kum hab e ahg mat am hu wo wantsh g Paul. K g shondal ha‑geꞌejig am hahawa ha chehani g e‑shondalig mat am wo ha wohppoꞌi. Kut am hihim k be k ged i bei e‑kih wui.

column2: Afterwards, during the night, the Lord stood by Paul, and told him, “Keep up your courage! Just as you have given your testimony about me in Jerusalem, so you must be my witness in Rome as well.”
column3: Sh am baꞌich d i hudunk, tsh am i e chehgi g Jesus Paul wui k hab kaij, “Ia ap si s‑mahch ch am ahgahim haꞌichu ab ni‑amjed. Kuni am i m‑gewkemhun mapt hab wo wa masma hab e juh am Rome t am.”

column2: Next day some Jews plotted together, and they took an oath not to eat or drink until they had killed Paul.
column3: K am baꞌich d i tash wabsh i siꞌalim, tsh am haꞌi e hemapai g Tutuligo k am chum Jiosh tahgio aꞌai si e ahgid mat pi haꞌichu wo hug k hoꞌip mua g Paul.

column2: Over forty were part of this conspiracy.
column3: Kush i baꞌiwechkim giꞌikko wehst‑mahm idam matsh hab masma e apꞌech.

column2: They went to the chief priests and leaders and said, “We have taken a solemn oath not to eat anything until we have killed Paul.
column3: Tsh am hahawa hihi ha wui g uꞌugchu papal ch geꞌeged ch hab kaij, “Matt am Jiosh tahgio aꞌai si t‑ahgi matt pi haꞌichu wo hug k hoꞌip mua hegai Paul.

column2: So you and the council should send word to the commander that he should bring Paul down to meet with you, as if you wanted to examine his case in more detail. We're ready to kill him along the way.”
column3: Kumt ahpim g e jehnigiddam ha wehm am wo ahgi g shondal ha‑geꞌejig mat ab wo i bek g Paul em‑wui. Kumt hab wo e wuad mam baꞌich haꞌichu s‑mahchimk ab amjed. Kutt ahchim wo t‑nahtokchid matt wo mua mat koi ia hu wo jiwia em‑wui.”

column2: But Paul's nephew (his sister's son) heard about their planned ambush, and he went into the fortress and told Paul about it.
column3: Tsh wabshaba g Paul cheoj maꞌi am i kah ihda k am him k am i wah shondal ha‑kih ed k am ahgid g Paul.

column2: Paul called over one of the centurions, and told him, “Take this young man to the commander, because he has some information to share with him.”
column3: Tsh heg am hema wai g shondal ha‑geꞌejig k hab kaij ab wui, “Am g behꞌi ihda wechij oꞌodham am si uhgchu shondal ha‑geꞌejig wui, matsh wo haꞌichu ahgi.”

column2: So the centurion took Paul's nephew and brought him to the commander and told him, “The prisoner Paul called me over and asked me to bring this young man to you. He has something to tell you.”
column3: Tsh wa woho am i bei wui k hab kaij, “Ihda wechij oꞌodham at ia jiwia k am nei hegai Paul mo ia e kuhpch. T heg am ni‑waid k hab ni‑ahg mant ab wo i bei m‑wui matsh wo haꞌichu m‑ahgi.”

column2: The commander took the young man by the hand and drew him aside. “What do you have to tell me?” he asked quietly.
column3: Tsh g si uhgchu ha‑geꞌejig ab bei nowij an k gam hu hekelko i wanimed k ab kakke, “Shahchu apt wo ni‑ahgi?”

column2: “The Jews have arranged to ask you to bring Paul to the council tomorrow, as if they wanted to ask more detailed questions about his case,” he explained.
column3: K hab kaij, “Ni‑wehm oꞌodham at am i e apꞌech matsh siꞌalim ab wo m‑tai mamt am wo i bei g Paul e jehnigiddam ha wui hab wabsh s‑e junimk mat am baꞌich haꞌichu wo i s‑mai ab amjed.

column2: “Please don't listen to them, because they have planned to ambush him with more than forty men who have taken an oath not to eat or drink until they have killed him. They're ready right now, waiting for you to agree to the request.”
column3: Pt wabshaba pi ab hu wo ha kaiha. Giꞌikko wehst‑mahm i baꞌiwechkim chechoj atsh am wo e eꞌestok ch wo kihshad nat pi am chum Jiosh tahgio aꞌai si e ahgi matsh pi haꞌichu wo hug k hoꞌip mua g Paul. K hemuch e nahtokch mat am hab wo e juh ch wabsh nenida mapt has wo e juh.”

column2: The commander sent the young man on his way, warning him, “Don't tell anyone that you've told me about this.”
column3: Sh hab kaij g si ha‑uhgchuga, “Pi g am hedai shaꞌi ahgid hegai mapt haschu ia ni‑ahgi.” Tsh gam hu hahawa hih g Paul maꞌi.

column2: He summoned two centurions and told them, “Get two hundred soldiers ready to go to Caesarea, together with seventy cavalry-men and two hundred spearmen. Be ready to leave at nine p.m. tonight.
column3: Tsh g si uhgchu shondal ha‑geꞌejig gohk am ha wai g ha‑geꞌegeꞌejig k hab kaij, “Am g wo haꞌi i ha gawulkad gohk siant shondal ch wewaꞌakko wehst‑mahm ehp mo g kakawyu ha chehchej ch gohk siant ehp mo s‑e mahch ab is‑pahyo t ab. Kut hegam wo e nahtok ch wo hihi mat d wo i humukt ohlak chuhug am Cesaria kihhim wui.

column2: Provide horses for Paul to ride to make sure he gets to Governor Felix safely.”
column3: Kumt am haꞌi wo i ha apꞌech g kakawyu mat g Paul wo hekaj. Mt am s‑ap wo i be k am wo uꞌapa heg wui geꞌe kownal mo d Felix.”

column2: He also wrote a letter that went like this:
column3: Neh, bash kaij ch am hahawa oꞌohani hegai uhgchu kownal ihda:

column2: “From Claudius Lysias to His Excellency Governor Felix, greetings!
column3: “Ab g i s‑ni‑hoꞌigeꞌid ahpi uhgchu ni‑kownalig Felix. Am ant wo m‑oꞌohani ahni mani d Claudius Lysius

column2: This man was seized by the Jews and they were about to kill him, when I arrived on the scene with soldiers and rescued him, because I had found out he was a Roman citizen.
column3: nat pi g geꞌe haꞌichu has e juh. Tutuligo at am wabsh hema si be k chum alo mua. Kunt s‑mai mo ihda ab uꞌukch g e‑shel hab masma mo g Rome t am kihkam. Kutt hekaj g ni‑shondalig ha wehm am doꞌibia.

column2: I wanted to know the reason for their accusations, so I took him before their council.
column3: Nt amjed am i bei Tutuligo e jehnigiddam ha wui s‑mahchimk hegai mam haschu ab abchud.

column2: I found out the charges against him had to do with issues regarding their law, but he was not guilty of anything that merited death or imprisonment.
column3: Kuki wabshaba pi am hu d shai hegai mas hekaj wo e muhkid o wo e kuhpach. Heg amki ab waꞌi abchud mat g hejel ha‑chehanig melchkwua.

column2: When I discovered a plot against this man I sent him to you right away, ordering his accusers to make their complaints before you.”
column3: Sh am hahawa haꞌi e nakog idam Tutuligo matsh wo mua. Kunt am ha hekaj ha cheha g ni‑shondalig mat ab m‑wui wo bei. Kuni hab ha ahg hegam mo ab haꞌichu abchud mat ahpi m‑wui wo gagda. Neh, id o wud waꞌi.”

column2: So the soldiers followed their orders and took Paul overnight to Antipatris.
column3: Tsh am hab e juh g shondal hegai mam haschu ab i ha chehani k am i bei g Paul chuhug ch ed k am uꞌapa Antipatris kihhim t am.

column2: The next morning they sent him on with the cavalry, and went back to the fortress.
column3: Sh am baꞌich d i tash, tsh hegam shondal mo wabsh e‑tahtadkaj hihim gam hu uhpam hihi Jerusalem wui.

column2: When the cavalry arrived at Caesarea they delivered the letter to the governor and brought Paul before him.
column3: Tsh hegam mo shoshoigakch am i bei Cesaria wui k am dada k am i mah g kownal g oꞌohana k ab wui hahawa i dagito g Paul.

column2: After reading the letter, the governor asked Paul what province he came from. When he learned he was from Cilicia he told Paul,
column3: Tsh g kownal am neꞌokchul hegai oꞌohana k ab kakke g Paul mas haschu jewed amjed. Sh heg am ahgid mo ab Cilicia jewed amjed.

column2: “I will investigate your case when your accusers arrive.” He ordered Paul detained in Herod's palace.
column3: Sh hab kaij ab wui, “M ant wo wa m‑nei mat hekid wo dada hegam mo ab haꞌichu m‑abchud.” Sh g shondaligaj am hahawa nuhkud kownal kih ed.

column2: Five days later Ananias the high priest arrived with some of the Jewish leaders, and with a lawyer called Tertullus. They presented formal charges against Paul to the governor.
column3: K am d i hetasp tash, t am hih hegai si uhgchu pahl mo hab chehgig Ananias. T g Tutuligo ha‑geꞌegedga am haꞌi oi. T heg ep ha oi mo d chehanig ab s‑chu amichuddam ch hab chehgig Tertullus. T wehs idam am i dada kownal wui k am gagda g Paul.

column2: When Paul was summoned, Tertullus began making his case against him. He said, “Your Excellency Governor Felix, we have enjoyed a long period of peace under you, and as a result of your wise judgment reforms have been enacted for the benefit of the nation.
column3: T am wai g Paul. T ihda s‑chu amichuddam am hahawa i ahgahi hegai mam haschu ab abchud g Paul hab kaijch:

column2: All of us throughout the country are so very grateful to you for this.
column3: ch si s‑ap t‑tahtk chum hekid ch wabsh chum hebai ch ab si s‑m‑hoꞌigeꞌelid.

column2: But in order not to bore you, please be so kind as to give us your attention for a short while.
column3: Kuni hi wa chum pi hohhoꞌid mant tash an wo m‑uꞌukch ch hekaj ab si i m‑tahni mapt ab wo si s‑t‑hoꞌigeꞌelid k am heꞌes wo i kaiha ihda al shopol haꞌichu t‑ahga.

column2: We discovered that this man is a real pest,  stirring up rebellions among Jews all over the world, a ringleader of the Nazarene sect.
column3: “Am att cheh ihda oꞌodham. Kuki wa wehsko shaꞌi si ha kudut g t‑wehm oꞌodham ch am i ha chuꞌamun mat wo cheggia g kownal ch pi apko ha wanimed mat ab wo i hema s‑wohoch mo pi d wohokam ch ab Nazareth t amjed.

column2: He tried to defile the Temple, so we arrested him.
column3: Kutt am cheh mat ep chum uamhu g geꞌe cheopi ab Jerusalem t ab. Kutt hekaj an bei matt wo lodai g t‑chehanigkaj.
T wabshaba g shondal ha‑geꞌejig Lysias am i wahk k si s‑bagam am t‑wohppoꞌid

column2: By interrogating him yourself you will discover the truth of our accusations.”
column3: k ha cheha mat ia haꞌab wo i e bei m‑wui. Kutsh hegam mo ab haꞌichu abchud ab m‑wui wo gagda. Pt hems ab wo haꞌichu kakke ihda oꞌodham k wo s‑mai ab amjed wehs haꞌichu mach haschu ab i abchud.”

column2: The Jews joined in, saying that this was all true.
column3: Neh, bo kaij. T wehsijj am wohokamch hegam Tutuligo mat am e nam.

column2: The Governor motioned for Paul to respond. “Recognizing you have been a judge over this nation for many years, I gladly make my defense,” Paul began.
column3: T ab i ai g Paul. T g kownal ab ahgi mat am wo neo. K hab kaij:

column2: “You can easily verify that I arrived in Jerusalem to worship just twelve days ago.
column3: M apt wo i hoan k wo wohokamch mo pi woho g haꞌichu ha‑ahga idam.

column2: Nobody found me arguing in the Temple with anyone, or inciting people to riot in any synagogue or anywhere in the city.
column3: Kunt pi woho shaꞌi hedai kamꞌo am geꞌe cheopi ch ed k pi woho shaꞌi am ha kudu g hemajkam amai o hebai i am Jerusalem ch ed.

column2: Nor can they prove to you any of their accusations against me.
column3: Pi at wo shaꞌi e nako mas wo wohokamch hegai mo haschu ab i ni‑abchud no pi pi woho.

column2: But I will admit this to you: I serve the God of our fathers following the beliefs of the Way, which they call a heretical sect. I believe everything the law teaches and what is written in the books of the prophets.
column3: “M o hi wa woho mani ab ihm g Jiosh am oidch ihda himdag mo idam hab elid mo pi d wohokam. K eda d waꞌi Jiosh mani ab ihm ch d ha‑Jioshga g t‑shohshon. Kuni wehs ab s‑wohog elid g t‑chehanig ch hegai mat g kekelibad Jiosh haꞌichu i tashogiddam an oꞌoha.

column2: I have the same hope in God that they do, believing that there will be a resurrection of the good and the wicked.
column3: Ni‑wehm oꞌodham o s‑wohochud mat g Jiosh ab wo i ha wuwhas g koꞌi muhkig t amjed k ab wo i ha gawulkai g s‑apꞌekam k gam hu wo i ha gawulkai g pi apꞌekam. Ni ahni hab waꞌap s‑wohochud ihda

column2: Consequently I try to make sure I always have a clear conscience before God and everyone.
column3: ch hekaj chum hekid am si ni‑nakog mant am hab wo waꞌi junihid g s‑apꞌekam ch hab pi wo shaꞌi haꞌichukaj si ni‑el am tahgio g Jiosh ch am ha tahgio g hemajkam.

column2: Having been away for a few years I returned to bring some money to help the poor and to give offerings to God.
column3: “Tash ani gam hu oimmed am ha oidk g gawul mahs hemajkam ch pi ab hu haꞌichug Jerusalem t ab. T hegam gawul mahs hemajkam ab i toꞌahi g lial k am ni‑nuhkudach mant am wo i ha uꞌi g ni‑wehm oꞌodham ab Jerusalem t ab. Nt heg ab ha mah am jiwiak k am hahawa i ni‑dagito Jiosh wui k ab ihm ch am hab wua g iagchulida geꞌe cheopi ch ed.

column2: That's what they found me doing in the Temple—completing the ceremony of purification. There was no crowd and no disturbance.
column3: K pi shaꞌi muꞌi ni‑wehmaj. Kuni pi d shaꞌi ahni manis am i shonwua g kudutadag.

column2: But some Jews from the province of Asia were there, who should be present here before you today to bring their charges, if they have anything against me.
column3: K wabshaba d hegam mat am ni‑chehg k am i shonwua g kudutadag k d ni‑wehm oꞌodham ch ab dada Asia jewed t amjed. T ia wo chum uꞌapa m‑wui hegai mo haschu ab ni‑abchud k wabshaba pi ia hu dada.

column2: Otherwise let these men here explain themselves what crime they found me guilty of when I stood before the council,
column3: T idam m ia gegok am wo chum ah matp woho cheh g pi ap chuꞌijig ab ni‑ab mant wa am i kekiwua ha wui g e jehnigiddam.

column2: except for the time when I shouted out to them, ‘I am on trial before you today because of my belief in the resurrection of the dead.’ ”
column3: Ahni ant wo em‑ahgi mani wa hab kaij, ‘Ia am ni‑lodait id i tashkaj heg hekaj mani ab s‑wohochud mat g koꞌi uhpam wo i wuwha ab muhkig amjed.’ Naꞌas id pi hohhoꞌid.” Neh, bo kaij g Paul.

column2: Felix who was well-informed about the Way then adjourned the trial. “When Lysias the commander comes I will make my decision regarding your case,” he said.
column3: Felix o si s‑ap s‑mahch ihda Jesus himdag. Kut am i haꞌasa neo g Paul. T g Felix am i kuhgi g haꞌichu kaihama hab kaijch, “M ant wo wa i apch ihda mat hekid wo i jiwia g Lysias ab Jerusalem t amjed.”

column2: He ordered the centurion to keep Paul in custody but to allow him some measure of freedom and to let Paul's friends care for him without interference.
column3: Neh, bo kaij ch am hahawa cheha g shondal ha‑geꞌejig mat am wabsh wo i uꞌukchid g Paul ch wabshaba hi wo wa hiwgidad matp hems am wo neidad g naipijjuj ch am wo haꞌichukaj i wehmtad.

column2: Some days later Felix returned with his wife Drusilla, who was Jewish. He sent for Paul and listened to him speak about trusting in Christ Jesus.
column3: K g felix wehm kihkam d Tuhligo ch hab chehgig Drusilla. Sh idam ab s‑kaimk g Paul. Tsh g Felix am ha cheha mamt am wo i wahki g Paul. Sh heg am ha ahgid am jiwiak mamt ab wo i chum s‑wohoch g Jesus Christ. Sh am hugkam wabsh s‑ap kaiham idam.

column2: He discussed with them about living right, self-control, and the coming judgment. Felix became alarmed and told Paul, “You can go now, and I'll send for you when I get the chance.”
column3: Sh am hahawa i ha ahgidahim mat am wo i e dagito s‑apꞌekam wui k pi am hu hab wo junihid g pi apꞌekam no pi e aihim mat g Jiosh gam hu wo i ha gawulkai g pi apꞌekam hemajkam. Tsh g Felix si s‑ehbenid k hab kaij, “Oi g gam hu hihm. M ant wo wa ep i m‑wai mat hekid am wo s‑ni‑apꞌek.”

column2: Hoping that Paul would give him a bribe, Felix often sent for Paul and talked with him.
column3: K eda hab chum em‑ahg mat g Paul wo haꞌi namkid g lial mat wo dagito ch heg hekaj muꞌikko ab i wappaid mat am wo wehmaj neo.

column2: Two years passed and Felix was succeeded by Porcius Festus. To stay in favor with the Jews, Felix left Paul in prison.
column3: Kut am i e baꞌiwich g gohk ahidag. T am hema ep dahiwua g kownal Felix kehkud ed k hab chehgig Porcius Festus. T wa eda g Felix pi shaꞌi dagito g Paul no pi si tatchua mat si s‑ap ab wo i nei g Tutuligo.

column2: Three days after Festus had arrived in the province he left Caesarea to go to Jerusalem.
column3: Sh am d i waik tash amjed mat am i dahiwua g Festus Cesaria t am, tsh gam hu hih Jerusalem wui.

column2: The chief priests and Jewish leaders came to him and brought their charges against Paul.  They begged Festus as a favor to send Paul to Jerusalem, plotting to ambush and kill him on the way.
column3: Tsh ab wui i hihi g uꞌugchu papal ch geꞌeged hemajkam k am ahgid hegai mo haschu ab i chum abchud g Paul ch ab si tahni mat ab wo i bei Jerusalem wui. Kush eda idam am heki hu e aꞌaga mat wo mua g Paul mat ab wo uꞌad.

column2: But Festus replied that Paul was in custody at Caesarea and that he himself would be there shortly.
column3: Sh hab kaij g Festus, “Am o d wabsh kia lihso Cesaria t am. Nt eda hemuch am uhpam wo hih.

column2: “Your leaders can come with me, and make their accusation against this man, if he has done anything wrong,” he told them.
column3: Kumt am haꞌi wo ni‑oid k am wo ah mam haschu ab abchud.”

column2: After staying there with them for no more than eight or ten days, Festus returned to Caesarea. The following day he took his seat as judge, and ordered that Paul be brought before him.
column3: K am dakahim g Festus am hu i hemako domig k gam hu hahawa hih Cesaria wui. T hegam geꞌeged hemajkam gam hu ep hihi.

column2: When he came in the Jews that had come from Jerusalem surrounded him and brought many serious charges against him that they couldn't prove.
column3: T am i wahki. T an wehgaj gegokiwua k ab ha hekaj si pi ap haꞌichu abchud ch wabshaba pi e nako mas wo wohokamch ihda.

column2: Paul defended himself, telling them, “I have not sinned at all against the Jewish law, the Temple, or Caesar.”
column3: T g Paul am e wehhejed neok k hab kaij, “Pi ant haꞌichu shaꞌi pi ap hab juh manis melchkwua g t‑chehanig ahchim Tutuligo k pi shaꞌi uamhu g geꞌe cheopi k pi ab hu shaꞌi wui kehk g kownal.”

column2: But Festus, who was looking to gain favor with the Jews, asked Paul, “Are you willing to go to Jerusalem and be tried before me there about these matters?”
column3: K hab kaij g Festus ab wui, “Pt hig am wo hih Jerusalem wui mant am haꞌab wo m‑lodai.” Bo kaij no pi hab elid mat wo s‑hohhoꞌi g Tutuligo.

column2: “I'm standing before Caesar's court to be tried, right where I should be,” Paul replied. “I have not done any wrong to the Jews, as you very well know.
column3: K hab kaij g Paul, “Ia ani kehk kownal lodaita kih ed mant ia haꞌab wo chum ni‑lodaitach. Am ap wa si s‑mahch mant pi haꞌichu am hu hab shaꞌi juh mas pi apꞌe am ha wui g ni‑wehm oꞌodham.

column2: If I've committed a crime and have done something that deserves death, I do not ask to be pardoned from a death sentence. But if there's no substance to these accusations they're making against me, then nobody has the right to hand me over to them. I appeal to Caesar!”
column3: Pi ant ab hu wo em‑tai mams wabsh wo ni‑dagito matp hab wo sha mahsk mant mul g chehanig. M o wa s‑apꞌe mamt wabsh wo ni‑muhkid mantp am hugkam mul. K wabshaba pi woho hegai mo ab ni‑abchud. T heg hekaj pi hedai wo e nako mas ab wo i ni‑dagito ha wui. Ab ant wui wo i gei g si uhgchu kownal.” Neh, bo kaij g Paul.

column2: Festus then conferred with the council, and replied, “You have appealed to Caesar. To Caesar you shall go!”
column3: K eda am dadha hegam mo am haꞌichu i shelamid ch am aꞌaga ihda. K g Festus ab ha kahk ch hab hahawa kaij ab Paul wui, “Neh, pt hemho wa am wo e uꞌapa si uhgchu kownal wui napt pi ab wui i gei.”

column2: Several days later, King Agrippa and his sister Bernice arrived in Caesarea and came to pay their respects to Festus.
column3: K am hu hebai hema d kownal ch hab chehgig Agrippa. Sh g uwi wehngaj hab chehgig Bernice. Tsh idam am chehgio g Festus noki pi s‑ap ab i neid.

column2: They were staying some time so Festus presented Paul's case to the king, explaining, “There's a man that Felix left as a prisoner here.
column3: Sh am heꞌekia i tash amjed, sh am ha ahgid g Festus ab amjed g Paul ch hab kaij, “Ia o hema kuhpi g oꞌodham ch hab chehgig Paul. T g Felix pi i wuhshad.

column2: When I was in Jerusalem, the Jewish chief priests and leaders came and made accusations against him and asked me to sentence him.
column3: Kunt wa am hih Jerusalem wui k am ha nei g Tutuligo uꞌugchu papal ch geꞌeged. K hegam ab haꞌichu abchud ihda lihso ch ab ni‑chehani mant wo mua.

column2: I replied that it is not according to Roman law to convict anyone without having them face their accusers and giving them the opportunity to defend themselves against the charges.
column3: Ni wabshaba am ha ahgid mo pi hab mahs g t‑kownalig chehanig. T hemho wa wehpeg am wo i e hudaw g lihso ha wehm hegam mo ab haꞌichu abchud k am wo neo e wehhejed. T g kownal ab haha wo mah g namkidadgaj.

column2: So when his accusers arrived here, I wasted no time and convened the court the very next day. I ordered the man to be brought in.
column3: “T wa woho i dada hegam Tutuligo ha wanimeddam. Nt am ha hekaj dahiwua kownal daikud ed mant wo ha kaiha. Kumt ab i wahki g lihso.

column2: However, when the accusers got up they didn't bring charges of criminal acts as I expected.
column3: T am gegokiwua hegam mo ab haꞌichu chum abchud. Kuni hab ni‑ahg matp hems geꞌe haꞌichu ab wo abch ab t‑chehanig amjed.

column2: Instead they brought up controversies over religious questions, and over a man called Jesus who was dead but whom Paul insisted was alive.
column3: K wabshaba ab wabsh e‑himdag amjed ab haꞌichu neꞌowin ch heg amjed ehp oꞌodham mash hab chehgig Jesus ch atsh heki hu muh. K eda g Paul hab kaij mat uhpam e chegito.

column2: Since I was undecided as to how to proceed in investigating such matters, I asked him if he was willing to go to Jerusalem and be tried there.
column3: “Nt am wabsh i pi ni‑amich mant has masma si tasho haꞌichu wo s‑mai ab amjed k heg hekaj ab kakke g Paul mas wo s‑hohhoꞌi mat am uhpam wo hih Jerusalem wui k ab haꞌab wo e lodaitach.

column2: However Paul appealed for his case to be heard by the emperor, so I ordered him detained until I could send him to Caesar.”
column3: K wabshaba ab t‑ahgid g Paul mat ab wo i gei si geꞌe kownal wui mat heg am wo mamche hegai mo haschu ab i abchud. Nt wa woho am ha cheha g shondal mat wo si nuhkud k ab wo ai mat am wo e uꞌapa si geꞌe kownal wui.”

column2: “I would like to hear the man myself,” Agrippa told Festus.
column3: Kush hab kaij g Agrippa am Festus wui, “Ahni ani hab waꞌap chum s‑kaimk ihda oꞌodham.”

column2: The next day Agrippa arrived with Bernice in great ceremonial splendor and entered the auditorium with the commanders and leading citizens. Then Festus ordered Paul to be brought in.
column3: K am baꞌich d i tash, t hab masma i ha wahpki g Festus mo d si s‑has hahaꞌichu idam Agrippa ch Bernice. K hegam ep ha wehmaj mo d si uꞌugchu shondal ha‑geꞌegeꞌejig ch hegam mo d si s‑has hahaꞌichu heg eda kihhim. Kumt am i wahki g Paul.

column2: “King Agrippa, and everyone who is present here with us,” Festus began, “you see before you this man whom all the Jewish people, both here and in Jerusalem, have complained to me about, shouting that he shouldn't be allowed to live.
column3: K g Festus hab hahawa kaij:

column2: However I discovered he has not committed any crime that deserves death, and since he has appealed to the emperor I decided to send him there.
column3: Nt wabshaba pi shaꞌi cheh g chuꞌijigaj mas heg hekaj wo e muhkid.

column2: But I don't have anything specific to write about him to His Imperial Majesty. That's why I have brought him before you so I can have something definite to write.  It doesn't seem fair to me to send on a prisoner without explaining the charges made against him.”
column3: Ni wabshaba pi ni‑amichud mant haschu am wo oꞌohani g si geꞌe kownal ab amjed. K pi hab chum mahs mas am wo e uꞌapa g lihso pi am hu tasho ahgk mas haschu d chuꞌijigaj. Nt heg hekaj ia uꞌapa em‑wui mamt am wo i kaiha, wahm ahpi Agrippa map d kownal. Ntp hems haha wo s‑mai ab em‑amjed mant haschu am wo oꞌoha.”

column2: Agrippa then said to Paul, “You are free to speak on your own behalf.”
column3: K hab kaij g Agrippa ab wui g Paul, “B ant m‑mah g apꞌedag mapt am hejel e wehhejed wo neo.” T ab ha baꞌich i kekiwua g Paul k am e wehhejed neok

column2: “I am delighted, King Agrippa, to make my defense before you today regarding everything I am accused of by the Jews,  particularly because you are an expert in all Jewish issues and customs. I beg your patient indulgence as you listen to what I have to say.
column3: k hab kaij:

column2: All the Jews know my life story—from my earliest days beginning in my own country and then in Jerusalem.
column3: “S‑mahch o g ni‑wehm oꞌodham mani has i masma ga hu i amjed mani d wabsh kia si ali nani pi wa eda am wabsh i kih ni‑jewedga ed ab Jerusalem t ab.

column2: They have known me for a long time and can verify, if they choose to, that I have followed the religious school that observes our faith in the strictest way—I lived as a Pharisee.
column3: Dani Palasi wohochuddam. K g ni‑wehm oꞌodham s‑mahch mani am si s‑gewkam oid g t‑himdag.

column2: Now I am standing here to be judged regarding the promised hope God gave to our fathers
column3: Ia ani kehk ch wo ni‑lodai nani pi ab s‑wohochud mat g Jiosh woho hab wo juh hegai mat haschu am ha ahgi g t‑shohshonbad.

column2: that our twelve tribes hoped to receive as they continually dedicated themselves in God's service. Yes, it's because of this hope that I'm accused by the Jews, Your Majesty!  Why should any of you think it's unbelievable that God raises the dead?
column3: Bo ha ahg mat uhpam wo i ha wuwhas g koꞌi ab muhkig t amjed. Id o chum s‑wohochud g ni‑wehm oꞌodham ch eda s‑ni‑lodaitamk nani pi s‑wohochud mat hab i juh.

column2: Previously I was sincerely convinced I should do as much as I could to oppose the name of Jesus of Nazareth.
column3: “Bani wa wa elid mant am wo si i ni‑nakog k wo shohbi g himdaj hegai Jesus mo ab Nazareth t amjed.

column2: This is what I did in Jerusalem. I threw many of the believers in prison, having been given authority to do this by the chief priests. When they were sentenced to death I cast my vote against them.
column3: Ni wa wa woho am hab chum ni‑junihim amai Jerusalem t am. T wa g uꞌugchu papal ab i ni‑mah g ni‑apꞌedag. Kunid muꞌi ha kuh hegam mo ab s‑wohochud hegai himdag k ha wehm apꞌech g e jehnigiddam mamt wo ha kokda.

column2: I had them punished in all the synagogues, trying to make them recant. I was so furiously opposed to them that I went to cities outside our country to persecute them.
column3: Kunt wa muꞌikko am apꞌech mamt wo ha shoꞌigch an i aꞌai ha‑chechopi ed k am chum ha chehani mat hab wo chei mo pi apꞌe hegai Jesus. Kunid wa shaꞌi si s‑ha kehꞌid ch am i ni‑nako mant am i wah gawul jewed kihhim ch ed mant wo ha shoꞌigch amai.

column2: That's why one day I was on my way to Damascus with the authority and orders from the chief priests.
column3: “Kunid wa ab si ha tai g uꞌugchu papal g ni‑apꞌedag k am hih Damascus wui heg wa si hekaj mant wo ha kuh hegam mo s‑wohochud mo hegai Jesus d Jiosh si Kehsha.

column2: At about noon as I was on my way, Your Majesty, I saw a light from heaven that blazed brighter than the sun. It shone around me and those who were traveling with me.
column3: “Pegih neh, ahpi si s‑has haꞌichu, am achd hihim wohg ch ed am hu i dahm juhk. Kud am hab e juh mat am baꞌich i s‑mahs ton mo g tash tonlig an t‑wehgaj.

column2: All of us fell to the ground. Then I heard a voice speaking to me in Aramaic, ‘Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me? It's hard for you to fight against me!’
column3: Kutt wehsijj i shul am jewedo.

column2: ‘Who are you, Lord?’ I asked.
column3: “Kunid si has elid ch hab kaij, ‘Dohp wud ch ab neok?’

column2: ‘But pick yourself up and get to your feet. The reason why I've appeared to you is to appoint you as my servant, to be a witness for me, telling others how you have seen me and everything I will reveal to you.
column3: Ab g i wamig k kekiwua. Ia ant i ni‑chehgi m‑wui mant am wo i m‑kei mapt d wo ni‑pionagk. Kupt am wo ha ahgi g hemajkam ihda map neid ch kah. Kunt am haꞌichu ep wo m‑chehgi imhab i baꞌich. Pt heg am ep wo ha ahgi.

column2: I will save you from you own people and from the foreigners. I am sending you to them
column3: Nt wo m‑doꞌibia ab ha amjed g m‑wehm oꞌodham. Kupt am wo ahgahid g haꞌichu ni‑ahga am ha wui g gawul mahs hemajkam. Nt am ep wo m‑nuhkud k wo m‑doꞌibia ab ha amjed.

column2: to open their eyes so they can turn from darkness to light, from the power of Satan to God, and so that they can receive forgiveness for their sins and a place with those who are set right as they trust in me.’
column3: Kupt am wo i ha tashogi mo pi am hu ni‑tatchui oidch hab e junihim ch am wabsh jiawul tatchui oidch hab e junihim. T ab wo m‑kaiham k ab wo i e dagito ni‑wui. Nt hekaj gam hu hab wo i juh g pi ap ha‑chuꞌijig k hab wo ha juh mat d wo ni‑hemajkamgak.’ Neh, bo kaij g Jesus ab ni‑wui.

column2: Clearly, King Agrippa, I could not disobey this vision from heaven.
column3: “Pegih neh, Agrippa map d kownal, bad wa masma am i e chehgi ni‑wui hegai mo d si geꞌe kownal am wehs haꞌichu dahm k hab wa masma ni‑cheha. Kunt ahni ab wohog elid

column2: First in Damascus, then in Jerusalem, and then all over Judea and also to the foreigners I shared the message of repentance: how they should turn to God, demonstrating their repentance through their actions.
column3: k am ha hekaj i ahgahi Damascus t am g haꞌichu ahgaj k amjed am ahgahi Jerusalem t am ch wehsko Judea chekshani ch ed. K am hahawa ni‑tashogid g Jiosh mant am ha wui wo hih g nahnko mahs hemajkam. Ni am muꞌikpa ha ahgidahim mat gam hu wo s‑ohhod g pi ap e‑chegitoi k ab wo i e nohnogi Jiosh wui k amjed hab wo junihid g s‑apꞌekam.

column2: That's why the Jews seized me in the Temple and tried to kill me.
column3: Neh, k d ihda mad heg hekaj an ni‑bei g ni‑wehm oꞌodham am geꞌe cheopi ch ed k chum alo ni‑mua.

column2: God has looked after me so I can stand here today as a witness to everyone, both to ordinary people and to those who are important. I am only repeating what Moses and the prophets said would happen—
column3: K wabshaba iaꞌi himdam g Jiosh am ni‑wehmaj ch ni‑nuhkud. Ni heg hekaj ia kehk ch am si tasho em‑ahgid ahpim mam d s‑has hahaꞌichu mani haschu am ep ha ahgid g shoꞌig hemajkam. K ihda haꞌichu ni‑ahga d waꞌi hegai mo haschu g Mosesbad ch hegam kekelibad Jiosh haꞌichu i tashogiddam am heki hu ahgahim mat am hab wo e juh.

column2: how the Messiah had to suffer, and that by being the first to rise from the dead he would announce the light of God's salvation to both Jews and foreigners.”
column3: Sh idam am ahg matsh wa g Jiosh si Kehsha wo e shoꞌigchud k wo e muhkid k uhpam wo i wuhsh ab muhkig t amjed k id hekaj wo kuhpiꞌo g doꞌibiadag am ha wehhejed g Tutuligo ch nahnko mahs hemajkam.”

column2: Festus interrupted Paul as he made his defense, shouting out, “Paul, you've gone mad! All your knowledge is driving you insane!”
column3: Neh, bo wa masma hejel e wehhejed neok g Paul. K g Festus ab si s‑kaidam hab kaij, “Ahpi aptki wabsh e lohgoch, Paul. Haꞌichu m‑mahchig atki wabsh m‑lohgoch.”

column2: “I'm not mad, Festus your Excellency,” Paul replied. “What I am saying is true and makes sense.
column3: K hab kaij g Paul, “Pi ant shaꞌi ni‑lohgoch, si s‑has haꞌichu Festus. Hegai mani haschu hab ahg d si wohokam

column2: The king recognizes this, and I'm explaining it very clearly. I am sure that he is aware of what's been happening, because none of this took place as if it were hidden in a corner.
column3: ch am wabsh si tasho hab e junihim t‑shahgid. K g Agrippa wehs s‑mahch.

column2: King Agrippa, do you believe what the prophets said? I'm sure you do!”
column3: Agrippa map d kownal, m ap wa s‑ha wohochud g Jiosh haꞌichu i tashogiddam.”

column2: “Do you think you can convince me to become a Christian so quickly?” Agrippa asked Paul.
column3: K hab kaij g Agrippa ab wui g Paul, “Nap hab elid mapt ha hekaj wabsh s‑pehegi wo i ni‑nodagi id wui Jesus himdag?”

column2: “Whether it takes a short time or a long time doesn't matter,” Paul answered. “But my prayer to God is that not just you, but everybody listening to me today would become like me—except for these chains!”
column3: K g Paul hab kaij, “Chum anis ha hekaj o gam hu baꞌich. K wabshaba g ni‑hoꞌigeꞌidahuna am Jiosh wui d ihda mamt wehsijj ahpim mam am ni‑kaiham id tashkaj hems ab wo s‑wohochud k hab wo chuꞌigk mani ahni ch wabsh hi wo wa pi e wupulshch g e hukshchim wainomikaj.”

column2: The king stood up, along with the governor and Bernice, and everyone who had been sitting with them.
column3: T am hahawa wehs i gegokiwua

column2: They conferred together after they had left. “This man hasn't done anything that deserves death or imprisonment,” they concluded.
column3: k ab aꞌai e wui hab kaij am hihimadch, “Pi atki haꞌichu has shaꞌi juh ihda oꞌodham mat hekaj wo e muhkid o mas wo e kuhpach.”

column2: Agrippa told Festus, “He could have been freed if he hadn't appealed to Caesar.”
column3: K hab kaij g Agrippa ab wui g Festus, “T wo wa chum e dagito ihda mat hems pi ab hu wo e ah mat ab wo i gei si geꞌe kownal wui.”

column2: When the time came for us to sail to Italy, Paul and some other prisoners were handed over to a centurion called Julius of the Imperial Regiment.
column3: Mt am hahawa dagito g Paul ch haꞌi ep lilso shondal ha‑geꞌejig wui mat am wo i ha ui geꞌechu kownal wui. Id o hab chehgig Julius ch d ha‑geꞌejig hegam mo hab e aꞌaga Geꞌechu Kownal Shondalig.

column2: We boarded a ship based in Adramyttium that was headed to the coastal ports of the province of Asia, and we set sail. Aristarchus, a Macedonian from Thessalonica, went with us.
column3: K am hema daha g geꞌe wahlko ch atsh am gahi wo i wua Asia jewed wui. T g Julius g e‑shondalig ha wehm am ha ui g lilso k am i chehchsh heg ab wahlko. Nt ahni Luke ep ha oi. T heg ha oi Aristarcas mo ab d kihkam Thessalonica t ab am Macedonia jewed ch ed. Kutt am gahi i shul g ge shuhdagi.

column2: The next day we had a brief stop at Sidon, and Julius was kind enough to let Paul go ashore and visit his friends so they could provide what he needed.
column3: Am baꞌich i tash, tt am dada Sidon kihhim t am. K eda g Julius s‑hoꞌigeꞌid g Paul ch hiwigi mat am wo him k wo ha nei g e‑naipijju mat hegam wo dagioꞌi.

column2: We set out from there and sailed to the leeward of Cyprus because the winds were against us.
column3: Tt amjed am hahawa gahi ep i shul. K wabshaba g hewel ab si s‑gewkam med huduni tahgio t amjed ab t‑wui. Tt hekaj an bihbij Cyprus jewed wehgaj mat pi wo heb hu t‑wiꞌichkwua.

column2: Then we sailed directly across the open sea off the coast of Cilicia and Pamphylia, arriving at the port of Myra in Lycia.
column3: T am hebai i cheka. Tt am gahi i shul hegai ge shuhdagi mo an miabidch g Cilicia jewed ch Pamphylia jewed k ga hu dada mash ab d Myra kihhim am Lycia jewed ch ed.

column2: There the centurion found a ship from Alexandria that would be sailing to Italy, and arranged for us to join it.
column3: T amai g shondal ha‑geꞌejig am hema ep cheh g geꞌe wahlko. Id ash ab Alexandria t amjed am Egypt jewed ch ed ch atsh gam hu wo gahi i gei Italy jewed wui. Kutt heg ab i chehchsh

column2: We sailed slowly for several days and eventually arrived off Cnidus. But since the winds wouldn't allow us to continue we sailed across to the lee of Crete, near to Salmone.
column3: k am gahi i shul.

column2: With some difficulty we made our way along the coast until we arrived at a place called Fair Havens, near to the town of Lasea.
column3: Kutt heg hugid an bihbij k am hu wa has masma ga hu dada mash hebai s‑ap dadhaiwup g wapalko. K ia amjed pi shaꞌi mehk hegai kihhim mo d Lasia.

column2: We'd lost a lot of time, and the voyage was becoming dangerous because it was now after the Fast. Paul warned them,
column3: Kuttki pi oi baꞌich hihim k ab wabsh ai mat wo si hewedad s‑hehpichꞌed. T hekaj wo s‑ta ehbidamak matt am gahi wo i shul.

column2: “Men, I predict that this voyage will result in much hardship and loss—not just of the cargo and the ship, but also our very lives.”
column3: ch hab kaij, “Nehꞌe! Bani masma neid matki wo s‑ta ehbidamak matt am gahi wo i shul iaꞌi amjed. T am hu wo e padch g wahlko ch hegai mo mohto. Kuttp hems ep wo haꞌi t‑koꞌij.”

column2: But the centurion paid more attention to the advice of the ship's captain and its owner than to what Paul said.
column3: T wabshaba g shondal ha‑geꞌejig ab si s‑ha wohoch g wahlko nuhkuddam ch enigakam k pi ab hu kaiha g Paul mo ab chum ha ahgid.

column2: Since the harbor was not large enough to over-winter in, the majority were in favor of leaving and trying if possible to reach Phoenix and spend the winter there—a harbor in Crete that faces northwest and southwest.
column3: Pi o apkodag amai ha wehhejed g wapalko s‑hehpichꞌed. K heg hekaj muꞌijj hab kaij matt am gahi wo i shulig k wo chum si s‑ahim g Phoenix kihhim am Crete t am. Am o e shohbidch g shuhdagi toꞌotonk. K g wapalko am wabsh s‑ap dadhaiwup.

column2: When a moderate south wind began to blow, they thought they could do what they planned. They pulled up the anchor and sailed close inshore along the coast of Crete.
column3: Kut ab s‑bahbagi i meh g hewel wakolim tahgio amjed. K hab e ahg hegam mo himchud g wahlko mat am hab wo e juh mat has masma am e aꞌaga ch heg hekaj am wupulshpiꞌo g wahlko k am himch si miabidch g jewed hugidag.

column2: But it wasn't long before a hurricane-force wind called a “northeaster” blew from the land.
column3: T wabshaba ab haha wabsh s‑gewkam i meh g juhpin hewel ab jewed dahm amjed

column2: The ship was forced out to sea and could not face into the wind. So we had to give in and allow ourselves to be driven before the wind.
column3: k ab si s‑ta ehbidam wiꞌichkwua g t‑wahlko. Kut am i pi e nako mas wo moꞌoshk himch g wahlko ihda hewel. Kutt am wabsh i dagito k wabsh hiwigi g hewel mat am i t‑wiꞌichkwuhi.

column2: We were eventually able to run into the lee of a small island called Cauda, and managed with some difficulty to secure the ship's boat on board.
column3: K am hema al jewedag ch hab chehgig Cauda. K hi wa sha e shohbid matt an wecho bihbij. K eda am wabsh kia e chewaimed g al chum wahlko shuhdagi ch ed. Kutt am hahawa s‑hasigam i cheshaj.

column2: After hoisting it aboard, the sailors bound ropes around the hull to strengthen it. Then, worried that they would be wrecked on the Syrtis banks, they lowered the sea anchor and allowed the ship to be driven along.
column3: T g chikpandam an hahawa si s‑wihnam wupulsh g geꞌe wahlko mat pi wo e padch. Am attp hems wo t‑wiꞌichkwua jewed wui. T g wahlko am hu wo e hiash hia ch ed. T heg hekaj g chikpandam ab i huhuds hegai lohna mo hekaj himchud g wahlko k wabsh hiwigi mat g hewel am i t‑wiꞌichkwuhi.
