column2: John addressed the crowds that came to him to be baptized. “You viper's brood! Who warned you to flee from the coming judgment?” he asked.  “Demonstrate that you have truly repented. Don't try to justify yourselves by saying, ‘We're Abraham's descendants.’ Let me tell you, God can create children of Abraham from these stones.
column3: Tsh muꞌi am wui e chehm g hemajkam matsh ab ab wo e pahl wapko. Haꞌi idam o pi am hu gawul junimk g pi ap e‑chegitoi. Kush hab ha ahg g John, “Hah, ahpim mam pi ap chegitoidag, bamki e elid mamt wo e doꞌibia ab amjed g s‑koꞌok e‑namkidadag heg wabsh hekaj mam ab d Abrahambad amjedkam. Nt wabshaba wo em‑ahgi mamt pi woho wo e doꞌibia, heg hi wa mamt am wo e chehgi am hab junihidch g s‑apꞌekam mamt gam hu s‑ohhod g pi ap e‑chegitoi. Wehs hegam mat gam hu wo s‑ohhod g pi ap e‑chegitoi at d wo Jiosh hemajkamgak ch hab masma wo e kuint mo d Abrahambad amjedkam, chum wa g nahnko mahs hemajkam.

column2: The ax is set to begin chopping at the base of the trees. Any tree that doesn't produce good fruit will be chopped down and thrown into the fire.”
column3: Kumt ahpim gam hu wo s‑e ohhod hab masma mat g pi kehg bahidkam uꞌus mamtp pi gam hu wo s‑ohhod g pi ap e‑chegitoi k pi am hu hab wo junihid g s‑apꞌekam.”

column2: “So what should we do?” the crowds asked him.
column3: Kush haꞌi g hemajkam ab kakke, “Pegih, tt has hig wo chum t‑juh?”

column2: “If you have two coats, then share with someone who doesn't have one. If you have food, then share with those who don't,” he told them.
column3: Kush hab kaij ab ha wui, “Mt am wo i apꞌech g e‑chegitoi Jiosh wui k amjed pi wo daꞌi g e‑eniga. Neh, tp hems hema pi wo ha kotonik. Kumt ab wo hema mah. Tp hems hema pi wo haꞌichu chekk. Mt ab wo mah g haꞌichu hugi.” Neh, bash kaij g John.

column2: Some tax collectors came to be baptized. “Teacher, what should we do?” they also asked.
column3: Kush haꞌi hegam matsh am wui dada k wo e pahl wapko d lial ha kowlantdam am kownal wehhejed ch ash ab kakke, “T‑mashchamdam, tt ahchim has wo chum masmak?”

column2: “Don't collect any more tax than you're meant to,” he replied.
column3: Kush hab ha ahg, “Pi amt gamai hu wabsh baꞌich i muꞌi wo ha kowlant mo heꞌekkia i mohtoꞌis g oꞌodham.”

column2: “What about us?” some soldiers asked. “What should we do?”
column3: Kush haꞌi d shondal ch ab epai kakke, “Tt ahchim has wo chum masmak?”

column2: The people were waiting expectantly, and wondered whether John himself might be the Messiah.
column3: Kush g hemajkam pi am hu dodolimad am oidahimch mas hu id d Jiosh si Kehsha matsh wo ha doꞌibia.

column2: John replied and explained to everybody, “Yes, I am baptizing you in water. But the one who is coming is more important than me, and I'm not worthy to undo his sandals. He will baptize you with the Holy Spirit and with fire.
column3: Kush heg hekaj hab kaij g John, “Pi g hab wo ni‑elid manis ahni d si haꞌichu. Ab at hema wo i wuhsh ni‑oidk mat d wo si haꞌichuk. Ahni ani hi wa em‑pahl wapkon. T wabshaba heg ab wo em‑mah g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag k gam hu hab wo i juh pi em‑apꞌekam hab sha masma mat g mehi wo mei g shaꞌi.

column2: His winnowing fork is in his hand and he's ready to separate the wheat from the chaff on his threshing floor. He'll gather the wheat into his barn, but he will burn up the chaff with fire that can't be extinguished.”
column3: “Nam hig pi nehnichud g pilkani mamt g mohgaj gam hu wo i gawulkad k wo mehid k g pilkani ged hu wo i baꞌiha. Pegih, t hab waꞌap am aꞌai wo i ha gawulkai g hemajkam am lodaita ch ed ihda mani em‑ahgid k wo ha doꞌibia g s‑apꞌekam k g pi apꞌekam s‑koꞌokam wo ha namkid. T g ha namkidadag pi hekid wo huhug.”

column2: John gave many warnings like this as he announced the good news to the people.
column3: Neh, bash kaij g John ch nahnko masma am i chum ha tashogid g hemajkam g s‑kehg haꞌichu ahgaj g Jiosh.

column2: But when John reprimanded Herod the ruler for marrying Herodias, Herod's brother's wife, and for all the evil things he'd done,
column3: Sh eda hegai kownal mash hab chehgig Herod geꞌe hab junihim g pi apꞌekam ch atsh g e‑wehnag ehs g hohnigaj. Sh hab chehgig hegai Herodias. Kush g John ab s‑kehꞌid g kownal ch hab kaij mat pi hab wo chum e juh.

column2: Herod added to his crimes by having John thrown into jail.
column3: Tsh g Herod am baꞌich i pi ap haꞌichu hab juh matsh ged hu si kuh g John.

column2: Now it happened that after everyone had been baptized, Jesus was baptized as well. As he was praying, heaven was opened,
column3: Tsh wabshaba koi e kuh g John k wehs ha pahl wapko hegam matsh am wui e chehm ab s‑wohochudch g Jiosh. Tsh g Jesus hab waꞌap am wui jiwia k e pahl wakon k am e hoꞌigeꞌidahun. Tsh g dahm kahchim gam i e kuhpiꞌo.

column2: and the Holy Spirit descended upon him, taking the form of a dove. A voice came from heaven, saying, “You are my son, the one I love. I am truly pleased with you.”
column3: Kutsh g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag i hud ab ab g Jesus k hab sha mahs mo g hohhi. Sh ab neok g Jiosh ab dahm kahchim t amjed ch hab kaij ab wui g Jesus, “Ahpi ap d si ni‑tatchuidch ni‑alidag ch am si ni‑tatchui oidch hab masma.”

column2: Jesus was around thirty when he began his public ministry. People presumed he was the son of Joseph. Joseph was the son of Heli,
column3: Jesus ash am hu d i waikko wehst‑mahm aꞌahidag matsh eda am i himch g e‑chikpan k am i ahgahi g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga. Kush idam d shohshonaj mant g ha‑chechgig an wo ha oꞌoha. Bash masma s‑e mahch mo d Josephbad alidag.

column2: Jesus, full of the Holy Spirit, returned from the Jordan River and was led by the Spirit into the desert,
column3: Jesus atsh gam hu hih ab amjed g Jordan akimel matsh hebai e pahl wako. Kush g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag ab mahkch g si geꞌe gewkdag ch hab ahg mat gam hu wo hih am tohono jewed wui.

column2: where he was tempted by the devil for forty days. He didn't eat anything during that whole time, so at the end he was starving.
column3: Kush am haꞌichugkahim giꞌikko wehst‑mahm tash ab. Sh heg oidam g jijawul ha‑geꞌejig am chum s‑wuimk pi apꞌekam ch ed.

column2: The devil said to him, “If you are the Son of God, command this stone to become bread.”
column3: Sh g ge Jiawul ab wui hab kaij, “Bap chum e elid map d Jiosh alidag. Pegih, ab g hig chehani ihda hodai mat wo e pahnch naptki pi bihugim.”

column2: “It is written in Scripture, ‘You shall not live on bread alone,’ ” Jesus answered.
column3: Kush hab kaij g Jesus, “Pi ant hab wo juh. An o hab chuꞌig Jiosh oꞌohana ed:

column2: The devil led him up to a high place, and in a rapid view showed him all the kingdoms of the world.
column3: Neh, tsh g Jiawul am hahawa shaꞌi si s‑hohtam wuhpuij tahgio wehs i mahsid g kokownaltalig id dahm jewed

column2: Then the devil said to Jesus, “I will give you authority over all of them, and their glory. This authority has been given to me, and I can give it to anyone I want.  Bow down and worship me and you can have it all.”
column3: k ab wui hab ep kaij, “Wehs o ab ni‑mahks ihda gewkdag ch kaisdag ch d ni‑eniga mant wo wa mah mani hedai hab i elid. Kunt wehs ab wo m‑mah mapt ab ni‑wui wo i gehsh k ab wo has ni‑el.”

column2: “It is written in Scripture, ‘You shall worship the Lord your God, and you shall serve only him,’ ” Jesus replied.
column3: Kush hab kaij g Jesus, “Pi ant hab wo juh. An o hab chuꞌig Jiosh oꞌohana ed:

column2: The devil took Jesus to Jerusalem, set him on the top of the Temple, and told him, “If you are the Son of God, then jump!
column3: Kutsh am hahawa wuhpuij tahgio i mahsid hegai geꞌe cheopi mo am kehk Jerusalem t ab k hab ahg, “Maptp d wo Jiosh alidagk, pegih, am g i dahꞌi amjed mo gan hu si uhgk kihtas.

column2: For it is written in Scripture, ‘He will order his angels to care for you,
column3: No hig pi an hab chuꞌig Jiosh oꞌohana ed:

column2: “It is written in Scripture, ‘You shall not tempt the Lord your God,’ ” Jesus replied.
column3: Sh hab kaij g Jesus ab wui, “Pi ant wo pipꞌich g Jiosh. An o hab chuꞌig oꞌohanaj ed:

column2: When the devil had completed all his temptations, he waited for another opportunity.
column3: Kush g Jiawul am hahawa sha dagito g Jesus am i wehs nahnko masma chum s‑wuimkk pi apꞌekam ch ed.

column2: Jesus returned to Galilee, full of the Spirit's power. News about him spread everywhere.
column3: Tsh gam hu hahawa hih g Jesus Galilee chekshani wui. Sh g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag si geꞌe mahkch g gewkdag. Tsh gam hu aꞌai s‑e mai g haꞌichu ahga ab amjed.

column2: Jesus taught in their synagogues, and everyone praised him.
column3: Kush am ha mashcham ha eꞌeda g ha‑chechopi. Sh wehsijj ab si has elid g hemajkam.

column2: When he arrived in Nazareth, where he had grown up, he went to the synagogue on the Sabbath day as usual.
column3: Kush am him k am hekid. Tsh gam hu hih g Jesus Nazareth kihhim wui mash wa am d si kihkam. Tsh g shahwai am i e ai. Kutsh am i e chehm g hemajkam cheopi ch ed nash pi eda e mihshmad. Tsh am jiwia g Jesus k am dahiwua hab masma mash wa chum hekid am hab e junihim. Kumtsh am hiwigi. Tsh am kekiwua matsh wo neꞌokchul g Jiosh heki hu oꞌohana.

column2: The scroll of the prophet Isaiah was handed to him. Jesus unrolled the scroll and found the place where it's written:
column3: Kumtsh ab hema mah g holiwk oꞌohana. Sh d oꞌohanaj g Isaiabad. Tsh an neꞌokchul mo an hab chuꞌig matsh g Jiosh si Kehsha hab wo chei:

column2: He rolled up the scroll and gave it back to the attendant. Then he sat down. Everybody in the synagogue was staring at him.
column3: Tsh g Jesus ab i holiwkai g oꞌohana k ab uhpam mah g nuhkuddam k am hahawa dahiwua mat haꞌichu hab wo chei. Sh wehsijj ab si kaiham mat has wo chei.

column2: “This Scripture you've just heard has been fulfilled today!” he told them.
column3: Kutsh am i neok k hab kaij ab ha wui, “Neh, hemu at e ai. Ni ahni hab wua ihda mant am neꞌokchul em‑wehhejed.”

column2: Everybody expressed their approval of him, amazed at the gracious words that came from his lips. “Isn't this Joseph's son?” they wondered.
column3: Tsh wehsijj ab si has i el no pi si s‑ap neok k wabshaba hab kaij, “Aha no hig pi woho d Josephbad alidag?”

column2: Jesus replied, “I'm sure you'll repeat this proverb to me, ‘Physician, heal yourself!’ and ask, ‘Why don't you do here in your own hometown what we heard you did in Capernaum?’
column3: Sh hab kaij g Jesus, “No hig pi woho mamt ab ni‑wui hab wo chei hegai hab ha‑cheꞌidag mo hab chuꞌig, Am g i e maskogid maptp d ge mahkai, k hab ep wo chei, Ia g hu hig hab ep juhni g s‑hasig haꞌichu e‑kih am mapsh has masma am hab ge junihim Capernaum kihhim t am.”

column2: But I tell you the truth, no prophet is accepted in his hometown.
column3: Sh hab ep kaij g Jesus, “Mo wa woho mam pi ab hu has elid g Jiosh haꞌichu i tashogiddam amai mo hebai d i si kihkam.

column2: I guarantee that there were many widows in Israel during the time of Elijah when there was a drought for three and a half years, causing a great famine throughout the country.
column3: Elijabad wehm oꞌodham ash wa hab masma pi ab hu has elid. Tsh heg hekaj pi am hu hema i wehmt matsh eda pi ha juh waik eda hugkam aꞌahid ab. Tsh g bihugig i gei. Muꞌij ash g heheꞌejel wiꞌikam uꞌuwi amai.

column2: Yet Elijah wasn't sent to any of them. He was sent to a widow in Zarephath in the region of Sidon!
column3: Tsh wabshaba g Jiosh am cheha g Elijabad matsh am wo hih Seraphath kihhim wui am Sidon jewed ch ed k am wo hema i wehmt g hejel wiꞌikam uwi amai.

column2: Even though there were many lepers in Israel in the time of Elisha, the only one who was healed was Naaman the Syrian!”
column3: Kush muꞌi kokꞌo g Tutuligo heg hekaj pi ha doddakam mumkidag mo hab e aꞌaga ‘leprosy’. Tsh eda pi hema shaꞌi ha doaj hegai kelibad Jiosh haꞌichu i tashogiddam mash hab chehgig Elisha. Sh hema heg hekaj mumku g gawul mahs oꞌodham ch hab chehgig Naaman ch am kih Syria jewed ch ed. Kutsh heg waꞌi doaj g Elishabad.”

column2: When they heard this everyone in the synagogue became furious.
column3: Tsh wehsijj hegam mash am haꞌichug cheopi ch ed si babgat am i kaiok ihda

column2: They jumped to their feet and threw him out of the town. Then they dragged him to the top of the hill on which the town was built in order to throw him off the cliff.
column3: k atsh gam si neꞌiopa k am i chewaim g Jesus gam hu jegko. K eda g Nazareth an kehk kawulk t ab. Kutsh am i bei mo am hu hebai ge uhgk i koa g kawulk hab chum ahgk mat amjed wo i daꞌich.

column2: But he walked right through them and went on his way.
column3: Tsh wabshaba g Jesus am wabsh ha shahgid wuhshani k gam hu hih.

column2: Jesus went down to Capernaum, a town in Galilee. On Sabbath he started teaching them.
column3: Tsh gam hu hahawa hih g Jesus Capernaum wui heg eda chekshani k am ha mashcha g hemajkam cheopi ch ed mo am d i ha‑mihshmda tash.

column2: They were amazed at what he taught them for he spoke with authority.
column3: Kutsh wehsijj si has i el kaiok mo has masma ha mashcham no pi si s‑e mamachim neok.

column2: In the synagogue there was a man who was possessed by a demon. He cried out,
column3: Sh am hema daha mo g jiawul an uꞌukch. Kush si s‑kaidam hihnk ch hab kaij,

column2: “So, what do you want with us, Jesus of Nazareth? Have you come to destroy us? I know who you are: God's Holy One!”
column3: “Gam g hu hihm ahpi Jesus map ab Nazareth t ab d kihkam. A napt hab ahgk ia jiwia mapt wo t‑kokda. S‑mahch ani map hedai wud. Dap Jiosh si hekia s‑apꞌekam kehsha.”

column2: Jesus interrupted him, saying. “Be quiet!” Then he ordered the demon, “Come out of him!” Throwing him to the ground right before them, the demon left the man without injuring him.
column3: Tsh g Jesus ab si chehmo g jiawul k hab kaij, “Pi g shahmuni k ab i wuhshani id amjed oꞌodham.” Tsh g jiawul am si wua hegai oꞌodham wehsijj ha tahgio k ab i wuhsh amjed k pi shaꞌi koꞌokam has juh.

column2: They were all amazed and asked each other, “What is this teaching? With power and authority he orders evil spirits to leave—and they do!”
column3: Kutsh wehsijj ab si has i el g Jesus k hab kaij ab aꞌai e wui, “Shaꞌi si s‑gewkdag g neꞌokij. Ab o chehani g jijawul mat ab wo i wuwha. K wa woho hab e wua.”

column2: News about Jesus spread throughout the nearby region.
column3: Kutsh wehsko e kah ihda anai heg oidk jejewed.

column2: Leaving the synagogue, Jesus went to Simon's house. Simon's mother-in-law was sick with a high fever and those who were there asked Jesus to help.
column3: Tsh amjed gam hu hih g Jesus heg kih wui mo hab chehgig Simon. Sh eda g hohnigaj jeꞌe ihda si mumku k ch s‑toni iajidch. Kumsh am ahgid g Jesus ab amjed.

column2: Jesus went and stood over her. He told the fever to leave her—which it did. She got up right away and prepared a meal for them.
column3: Tsh am him k am i kekiwua heg woꞌikud hugid an k am e hoꞌigeꞌidahu. Tsh am ha hekaj apꞌet k am i wamig k ha hihidol.

column2: When the sun set, they brought to him all who were sick, suffering from various diseases. Jesus placed his hands on them, one after the other, and he healed them.
column3: Tsh gam hu hud g tash. Tsh wehsijj hegam mo g ha‑naipijju kokꞌo g nahnko mahs mumkidagkaj am ha uꞌapa Jesus wui. Kut wehsijj ab i ha tahtmahim k ha dodaj.

column2: Demons came out of many people, shouting, “You are the Son of God.” But Jesus stopped them and refused to let them speak because they knew he was the Christ.
column3: Tsh muꞌi ab wui i hihi hegam mo g jijawul an ha uꞌukch. Sh idam jijawul si hihnk ch hab kaij, “Ahpi ap d Jiosh alidag.” Kush ab si s‑ha kehꞌid g Jesus ch gam hu i ha wuwhasid ch pi ha hiwgid mas am hu has wo kaijjid no pi s‑mahch idam mo heg d Jiosh si Kehsha.

column2: Early the following morning Jesus left to find some peace and quiet. But the crowds went out looking for him, and finally found him. They tried to stop him leaving because they did not want him to go.
column3: Sh am hu hebai wabsh i siꞌalim, tsh g Jesus gam hu jegko i wuhsh. Tsh am i gahghi g hemajkam k am i chehg k chum pi hiwigi mat wo hih ab ha amjed.

column2: But he told them, “I have to go to other towns to tell them the good news of the kingdom of God too, because that is what I was sent to do.”
column3: Kush wabshaba hab kaij ab ha wui, “Hemho wa ant am wo i ahgahi g s‑kehg haꞌichu ahga ab amjed g Jiosh kownaltalig an aꞌai kihhim ch ed hab wa ehp nat pi hab ahgk i ni‑kei g Jiosh.”

column2: So Jesus went on traveling around, teaching the good news in the synagogues of Judea.
column3: Tsh wa woho am i ha mihshmdahi wehsko ha‑chechopi ed amai Galilee chekshani ch ed.

column2: One day, as Jesus was standing beside the Sea of Galilee, people crowded around him to hear the word of God.
column3: Sh am hu hebai g Jesus an kehk mo an i koa hegai al kahchki mo hab chehgig Galilee Kahchki. Kutsh g hemajkam ab wabsh i shodbinidahi s‑kaimkch g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga.

column2: Jesus noticed two boats lying on the shore, left there by fishermen who were washing their nets.
column3: Sh neid mo gohk wapalko am wupulshpi shuhdagi ch ed. Tsh g enigakam am ha dagito k ged hu ha wapkon g e‑chuchagia.

column2: Jesus got into a boat, the one that belonged to Simon, and asked him to push it out into the water, just offshore. Then Jesus sat down in the boat and taught the people from there.
column3: Kutsh am i chesh g Jesus hema ha eda idam wapalko. Sh heg d Simon eniga. Sh hab ahg matsh am wo shaꞌi nuꞌichkwua shuhdagi ch ed. Tsh g Simon hab juh. Tsh ab i dahiwua g Jesus wahlko ch ed k am ha mashcha g hemajkam.

column2: After he'd finished speaking, he told Simon, “Go out into deeper water, and let down your nets for a catch.”
column3: Tsh am i haꞌasa haꞌichu ha ahgid k hab ahg ihda Simon mat am wo i himch g e‑wahlko mo am s‑juhk g shuhdagi k am wo i huduni g e‑chuchagia ha wehm g e‑wehm chikpandam.

column2: “Lord, we worked hard all night, and didn't catch anything. But if you say so, I'll let down the nets,” Simon replied.
column3: Sh hab kaij g Simon, “T‑mashchamdam, ge att chuhug shaꞌi si chikpan k pi haꞌichu shaꞌi bei. P wabshaba am t‑ahgid matt am ep wo i huduni g t‑chuchagia. Pegih, tt am hab wo t‑juh.”

column2: Having done this, a large shoal of fish filled the nets full to breaking point.
column3: Kutsh wa woho am hihim k am i ha huhuds ge e‑chuchagia k atsh shaꞌi si muꞌi waptopi ha ui matsh chum alo e wanikumia g ha‑chuchagia.

column2: They waved to their partners in the other boat, asking them to come over and help. The others came over and together they filled both of the boats with fish. The boats were so full that they began to sink.
column3: Kush am haꞌi ep chikpan hema wahlko ch ed. Kumtsh idam ab hahawa si ha wai mat am wo i ha wehmt. Tsh wa woho ab i himch g e‑wahlko k wehs ha shuhshud g waptopikaj mat chum alo wachkk g ha‑wapalko.

column2: When Simon Peter saw what had happened, he dropped to his knees before Jesus. “Lord, please stay away from me, for I am a sinful man!” he exclaimed.
column3: Tsh am i nei g Simon mat haschu has i e juh k ab si i gei g e‑tohtonkaj Jesus wui k hab wabsh kaij, “Ih, dani wabsh pi apꞌekam oꞌodham. K pi hab chum mahs maps wo ni‑wehmajk ahpi s‑apꞌekam ni‑kownalig.”

column2: For he and everybody with him were completely amazed by the catch of fish that they had landed.
column3: Kutsh wehsijj hegam mash wehmaj si e totods neidch mat has e juh.

column2: James and John, the sons of Zebedee, Simon's partners, felt the same way.
column3: Haꞌi hegam wehmaj chikpandam g Peter ash d James ch John ch ash d aꞌalidaj hegai mash hab chehgig Zebedee.

column2: So they dragged the boats onto the shore, left everything, and followed Jesus.
column3: Tsh am wabsh i chum ai g shuhdagi koa idam k am i ha wuwhas g wapalko k wehs haꞌichu am wabsh i dagito k gm hu i oi g Jesus.

column2: Once when Jesus was visiting one of the towns, he met a man there who had a very bad case of leprosy. The man fell with his face to the ground and begged Jesus, “Please Lord, if you're willing, you can make me clean.”
column3: Sh am hu hebai g Jesus am hasko kihhim ch ed oimmed. Kush am hema g oꞌodham wehsko maꞌishch hegai mumkidag mo g chuhkugaj muhkhim. Tsh am jiwia g Jesus. Kutsh heg am i chehg k ab si kupal i gei wui k hab kaij, “Ab g si i s‑ni‑hoꞌigeꞌid k i ni‑doajid pej maptp wo tatchuad.”

column2: Jesus reached out and touched the man. “I am willing,” he said. “Be clean!” Immediately the leprosy disappeared.
column3: Tsh g Jesus ab tahtam k hab kaij, “Am o wa s‑apꞌe. Doajini.” Tsh am ha hekaj i doa.

column2: “Say nothing to anyone,” Jesus instructed him. “Go and show yourself to the priest and make the ceremonial offerings as required by the law of Moses as proof that you've been healed.”
column3: Tsh g Jesus ab chehani k hab kaij, “Pi g am hedai ahgid ab amjed ihda k wabshaba am ha hekaj wo hih pahl wui. T am wo m‑chechga k wo wohokamch mapt doa. Pt am hab haha wo juh hegai iagchulida mo wa g Jiosh em‑chehani Mosesbad oꞌohana ed. T hab wo s‑mahchk g hemajkam mapt woho doa.”

column2: Yet the news about Jesus spread more and more. Large crowds came to hear Jesus and to be healed from their diseases.
column3: Tsh amjed gam hu hih hegai oꞌodham. Kutsh wehsko i e ahgahi ihda matsh g Jesus hab juh. Tsh hekaj muꞌi hemajkam am wui hihi mat wo kah g haꞌichu ahgaj k wo e dodaj.

column2: But Jesus often used to retreat to quiet places and pray.
column3: Tsh g Jesus am wo ha mihshmad k wo ha dodajid k amjed gam hu hejelko wo him k wo e hoꞌigeꞌidahu.

column2: One day when Jesus was teaching, the Pharisees and religious teachers who had come from all over Galilee, Judea, and Jerusalem were sitting there. The power of the Lord to heal was with him so he could heal.
column3: Sh am hu hebai ehp mash g Jesus am ha mashcham. Sh am haꞌi dadha g chehanig ha mashchamdam ch hegam mo si oid g chehanig ch hab e aꞌaga Palasi. Idam atsh ga hu aꞌaijed am dada ab amjed g Galilee chekshani ch Judea chekshani ch ab Jerusalem kihhim t amjed. Tsh g Jiosh ab si mah g gewkdag g Jesus mat wo ha dodaj g kokꞌodam.

column2: Some men arrived carrying a paralyzed man on a mat. They tried to take him in and lay him in front of Jesus.
column3: Tsh am haꞌi dada g chechoj hema uꞌadch g pi himidkam. Id ash ab wabsh i s‑moik ch am woꞌo e‑wahkus ed.

column2: But they couldn't find any way through the crowd, so they went up on the roof and made a hole in the roof tiles. Then they lowered the man down on the mat, right into the crowd in front of Jesus.
column3: Kush am i chum s‑wahkidamk kih ch ed matsh wo chehgi g Jesus ab si hiwigch mat wo doaj. Sh wabshaba shaꞌi si s‑hemajkamag. Kutsh pi has masma am hu wo i e wahki. Tsh heg hekaj gan hu hahawa i cheshaj kih dahm k am ge maggad g kih maꞌishpadag k amjed ab i huduni g woꞌikudaj am ha shahgid g hemajkam k am woi mash am kehk g Jesus.

column2: When Jesus saw the trust they had in him, he said to the man, “Your sins are forgiven.”
column3: Tsh am i nei g Jesus moki ab si hiwig idam k hab kaij ab wui ihda oꞌodham, “Ni‑nawoj, ab ani s‑m‑hoꞌigeꞌid ch gam hu hab i juh g pi ap m‑chuꞌijig.”

column2: The religious teachers and the Pharisees began to argue with that. “Who is this who's speaking blasphemies?” they asked. “Who can forgive sins? Only God can do that!”
column3: Kush hegam chehanig ha mashchamdam ch Palasi wabsh hejel hab e ahg, “Ih, shaꞌi si pi ap neok ihda oꞌodham hab masma e wepogidch g Jiosh. Heg at waꞌi Jiosh wo e nako mat gam hu hab wo i juh g pi ap ha‑chuꞌijig.”

column2: Jesus knew what they were arguing about, so he asked them, “Why are you thinking to question this?
column3: Sh g Jesus s‑mahch mo haschu am oidahim ch hab kaij ab ha wui, “Pi g am wo shaꞌi oidahim manis pi woho edgid g gewkdag mant gam hu hab wo i juh g pi ap ha‑chuꞌijig.

column2: What is easier? To say your sins are forgiven, or to say get up and walk?
column3: Bam elid mo s‑pehegim hab e kaij mat gam hu hab i e juh g pi ap chuꞌijigaj no ge hedai s‑mahch mas s‑wohom hab e juh.

column2: However I will prove to you that the Son of man has the authority here on earth to forgive sins.” Then he said to the paralyzed man, “I tell you: Get up, pick up your mat, and go home.”
column3: Pegih, nt wo em‑chehgi mani woho ge gewkdag ch hab wua mani has i kaij ahni Jiosh si Kehsha.” Neh, bash kaij ch hab hahawa kaij heg wui pi himidkam, “I g wamig k am behꞌi g e‑wahkus k hihm am uhpam.”

column2: Immediately the man stood up in front of them. He picked up the mat he'd been lying on, and went home, praising God as he went.
column3: Tsh am ha hekaj i wami hegai oꞌodham k am bei g e‑wahkus k gam hu uhpam hih ab si ihmch g Jiosh.

column2: Everyone was completely astonished at what had happened, and in great awe they praised God, saying, “What we saw today was amazing!”
column3: Tsh g hemajkam si has i elid k ab ihm g Jiosh hab kaijch, “Shaꞌi si s‑kehg haꞌichu ach neid id tashkaj.”

column2: Later, as Jesus was leaving the town, he saw a tax collector called Levi sitting at his tax booth.
column3: Sh hema d lial kowlantdam g kownal wehhejed ch hab chehgig Levi. Tsh g Jesus am cheh. Kush am daha heg eda kih mo am chikpan.

column2: Levi stood up, left everything, and followed Jesus.
column3: Tsh g Levi am ha hekaj i wuhshani k am wabsh i dagito wehs haꞌichu k gam hu i oi.

column2: Levi organized a large banquet at his home in Jesus' honor. Many tax collectors and others were in the crowd that sat down to eat with them. But the Pharisees and the religious teachers complained to Jesus' disciples, asking,  “Why do you eat and drink with tax collectors and sinners?”
column3: Am waꞌi mia amjed, tsh g Levi am hab juh g geꞌe gegosig am wehhejed g Jesus. Sh am haꞌi oiopo g Palasi mash idam haꞌi d chehanig ha mashchamdam. Sh eda muꞌijj hegam mash am ha wehm e gegosid d lial kowlantdam hab masma mo g Levi.

column2: “Healthy people don't need a doctor—but sick people do,” Jesus replied.
column3: Sh g Jesus hab kaij ab ha wui, “Idam pi ap hemajkam o s‑e doꞌibiamk hab masma mat g kokꞌodam wo s‑e doajidam. Hegam mo hab e elid mo s‑apꞌe at pi wo tatchua g mahkai.

column2: “I didn't come to call those who are living right to repentance—I came to call sinners.”
column3: Pi ant hab ahgk ia jiwia manis wo ha doꞌibia hegam mo pi e doꞌibiamk.”

column2: “Well, John's disciples often fast and pray, and the Pharisees' disciples do so as well. But your disciples don't—they go on eating and drinking,” they told him.
column3: Sh haꞌi g hemajkam hab kaij ab wui g Jesus, “Neh, muꞌikko o pi e gegosid ch wabsh e hoꞌigeꞌidahun hegam mo ab wecho e mashcham g John ch hegam mo ab ha wecho e mashcham g Palasi. Kuki wabshaba ahpi g m‑wohochuddam pi hab e wua.”

column2: “Should the groomsmen fast while the bridegroom is with them?” Jesus asked.
column3: Sh hab kaij g Jesus ab ha wui, “Nat hig pi wo e gegos g wo ha hohntam naipijju mat eda heg am wo ha wehmajk?

column2: “No—but the time is coming when the bridegroom will be taken away from them. Then they can fast.”
column3: T am wo i e ai mat pi am hu wo ha wehmajk. T am hahawa pi wo e gegos. Pegih, bat wo wa e juh idam ni‑naipijju mant hekid pi ia hu wo ha wehmajk.”

column2: Then he gave them an illustration: “You don't tear out a patch from new clothes to mend old clothes. Otherwise you'd ruin new clothes, and the patch from the new wouldn't match the old.
column3: Sh am hahawa chum ha tashogid g Jesus mat g mashchamaj pi ap wo wehnad g ha‑himdag ash hab kaij, “Pi at hedai g wechij ikuskaj wo shohsho g hekiuchij lihwa mat wo s‑e wia nat pi wo i dahiwua k baꞌich wo i wantsh g hekiuchij. T hab waꞌap pi wo apꞌet g hekiuchij nat ge wo wepo mahsk g wechij ikus.

column2: You don't put new wine into old wineskins, because if you did the new wine would burst the wineskins. Then both wine and wineskins would be wasted.
column3: T pi hedai g wechij nawait am wo toa hekiuchij haꞌichu elidag kokstal ch ed. Tp hab wo sha e juh, t g wechij nawait wo wantsh g haꞌichu elidag. T g nawait wo iawua k g haꞌichu elidag wo e padch.

column2: You put new wine in new wineskins.
column3: Neh, hemho wa at g wechij nawait am wo e toa wechij haꞌichu elidag kokstal ch ed.

column2: And nobody after drinking old wine wants new wine, for they say, ‘the old tastes good.’ ”
column3: “Pi o hedai tatchua mat wo ih g wechij nawait hekid ab i jehkiok g hekiuchij nawait nat pi hab wo chei mo baꞌich i s‑ap hab kahk g hekiuchij.”

column2: One Sabbath while Jesus was walking through grainfields, his disciples began picking some heads of grain, rubbing them in their hands, and eating them.
column3: Sh am hu hebai hihim idam Jesus ha mihshmda tash ed. Kush am eshas g pilkani wohg huhugid an. Sh hegam mash am wehmaj g Jesus ab ha wohni g pilkani ch i mohon g e‑nohnhoikaj ch koꞌa.

column2: Some of the Pharisees questioned him, asking, “Why are you doing what is not permitted on the Sabbath?”
column3: Sh haꞌi g Palasi ha neid ch hab kaij, “Shahchu am ahgch hab wua hegai mo g t‑chehanig pi t‑hiwgid machs hab wo wuad mihshmda tash ed?”

column2: Jesus replied, “Have you never read what David did when he and his men were hungry?
column3: Kush hab kaij g Jesus, “Bo wabsh masma hab e wua matsh wa g Davidbad. Pi amtki chegito matsh heg has e juh am i bihugimk. Bo chuꞌig g Jiosh oꞌohana

column2: How he went into the house of God and took the consecrated bread? He ate it, and gave it to his men too. That's not permitted either. The consecrated bread is only for the priests.”
column3: matsh am i wah geꞌe cheopi ch ed k am ui g pahn k huh hegam ha wehm mash am wehmaj. Kush d hegai pahn mo am e toꞌaw k ch hegam d waꞌi ha wuikam mo d papal. T eda hemho wa am hab e juh. K heg hekaj am wa s‑apꞌe mat huh.”

column2: Then he told them, “The Son of man is Lord of the Sabbath.”
column3: Sh hab hahawa ep kaij g Jesus, “Dani Jiosh si Kehsha ch gewkdag am dahm g mihshmda tash.”

column2: On another Sabbath he went into the synagogue to teach. A man was there with a crippled right hand.
column3: Sh am hu hebai d ep mihshmda tash. Tsh am i wahp idam Jesus hema cheopi ch ed. Kush g Jesus am ha mashcham g hemajkam. Sh am hema daha g oꞌodham mash g s‑apkojed nowij mahnikodag.

column2: The religious teachers and the Pharisees were observing Jesus closely to see if he would heal on the Sabbath. They wanted to find something to accuse him of.
column3: Sh am haꞌi dadha g chehanig ha mashchamdam ch Palasi ch an wa s‑nenꞌoid nash pi ab haꞌichu s‑abchudamk g Jesus ch hekaj an neid mas wo hi wa ha doaj mihshmda tash ch ed.

column2: But Jesus knew what was in their minds. He told the man with the crippled hand, “Get up, and stand here in front of everyone.” The man got up and stood there.
column3: Sh g Jesus s‑mahch mo haschu am chegito ch ash hab kaij heg wui mahnikokam, “Kekiwuani k ab i hihm ia hu ha baꞌich g hemajkam.” Tsh ab i kekiwua.

column2: Then Jesus turned to them and said, “Let me ask you a question. Is it legal to do good on the Sabbath, or to do bad? To save life, or to destroy it?”
column3: Sh g Jesus ab hahawa ha kakke ch hab kaij, “Shahchu am ahgch hab elid mo pi hiwgidas mihshmda tash ed mamt wo i ha wehmt hegam mo e shoꞌigchud? Ab o em‑ab mamt wo i ha wehmt g shoꞌigkam k ep wo ha doꞌibia hegam mat am hu wo e koꞌij. Aha namt wabsh wo ha hiwigi mat wo e koꞌij?”

column2: He looked round at all of them there. Then he said to the man, “Hold out your hand.” The man did so, and his hand became like new.
column3: Neh, bash kaij ch an hahawa wehsijj i ha neid k hab hahawa kaij ab wui hegai oꞌodham, “Ab g si i shelin g e‑nowi.” Kutsh am wabsh i chum shelin k am waꞌi hekaj apꞌet.

column2: But they flew into a rage, and began to discuss what they could do to Jesus.
column3: Tsh hegam hahaꞌichu wabsh wohoꞌi babgat matsh ha doaj ha mihshmda tash ab k am ha hekaj i e wehm aꞌaga mas has wo juh g Jesus.

column2: One day shortly after, Jesus went up a mountain to pray. He remained there all night, praying to God.
column3: Tsh am waꞌi mia amjed am hu hebai gam hu i chesh g Jesus kawulk dahm k ge chuhug oidam e hoꞌigeꞌidahu Jiosh wui.

column2: When morning came he called together his disciples, and chose twelve of them. These are the names of the apostles:
column3: Kut am i mahsi. Tsh ab hahawa i ha wai hegam mash ab si wecho e mashcham k g gamai gohk am ha ui mat d wo si chuhchaij.

column2: Simon (also called Peter by Jesus), Andrew his brother, James, John, Philip, Bartholomew,
column3: Hema hegam ash d Simon. Kutsh heg hab ep chehch Peter mo hab d ahga ‘Hodai.’ Kush hema d Andrew ch d si wehngaj g simon. Kush haꞌi d James ch John ch Philip ch Bartholomew

column2: Matthew, Thomas, James the son of Alphaeus, Simon the Revolutionary,
column3: ch Matthew ch Thomas. Sh hema d hegai James mash g ohgaj hab chehgig Alphias. Sh hema hab ep chehgig Simon ch d hema hegam mash tatchua mat g Tutuligo hejel wo himchudad g e‑kownaltalig.

column2: Judas the son of James, and Judas Iscariot (who became a traitor).
column3: Sh hema d hegai Judas mash g ohgaj hab chehgig James. Kush hema d Judas Iscariot ch d hegai matsh wa gagda g Jesus. Neh, idam gamai gohk ash am d hahawa si chuhchaij g Jesus.

column2: Jesus went back down the mountain with them, and stopped at a place where there was some flat ground. There a crowd made up of his disciples and many other people from all over Judea, Jerusalem, and the sea coast of Tyre and Sidon, had gathered to listen to him and to be cured from their diseases.
column3: Tsh ab hahawa i huhud hegam Jesus. Sh muꞌi am ep haꞌichug g hemajkam ab amjed g Judea chekshani ch Jerusalem kihhim ch ab amjed g ge shuhdagi hugidag an miabidch g Tyre ch Sidon kihhim.

column2: Those who were troubled by evil spirits were also healed.
column3: Wehsijj ash s‑kaimk g Jesus. Kush ab wui hihim g kokꞌodam ch hegam mash g jijawul an ha uꞌukch. Sh g Jesus ha dodajid ch gam hu hab i ha wua g jijawul.

column2: Everyone in the crowd tried to touch him, because power was coming out from him and healing them all.
column3: Kush wehsijj ab chum s‑tahtmamk g Jesus nash pi g gewkdaj ab wuhshani amjed ch wehs ha doajid.

column2: Looking at his disciples, Jesus told them,
column3: Tsh g Jesus ab i ha nei hegam mash ab si hiwig k hab kaij:

column2: But I say to those of you who are listening: Love your enemies. Do good to those who hate you.
column3: “Nt wo em‑ahgi mamt has wo masmak am ha wui. Ab g wabsh wo i si pihk e elidad ha wui g e‑obga k wabsh g s‑ap haꞌichu hab wo ha juni hegam mo s‑em‑kehꞌid.

column2: Bless those who curse you. Pray for those who mistreat you.
column3: Idam atp hems wo pi kehg neneokad ab em‑wui ch wo em‑shoꞌigchudad. Mt wabshaba wabsh wo si s‑hemajimak am ha wui ch wo e hoꞌigeꞌidahu am ha wehhejed.

column2: If someone hits you on one cheek, turn the other cheek. If someone takes your coat, don't prevent them taking your shirt.
column3: Tp hems s‑koꞌokam has wo em‑juh. Mt wabshaba ab wabsh wo i s‑ha hoꞌigeꞌel. Tp hems hema ab wo em‑shonihi em‑kahm ab. Kumt wabsh wo hiwigi mat aigojed ab ep wo em‑shonihi. Tp hems hema wo em‑wohppoꞌi g em‑lihwa. Kumt g e‑kotoni ep wo mah.

column2: Give to anyone who asks you. If someone takes something from you, don't ask for it back.
column3: Tp hems hema haꞌichu wo i em‑tai. Kumt wo mah. Kutp hems hema haꞌichu wo bei mo d em‑eniga. Kumt pi uhpam wo tai.

column2: Do to others what you want them to do to you.
column3: Bamt wo ha juhkchid g hemajkam mam has i chum ha elid mat hab wo em‑juhkchid.

column2: If you love those who love you, why should you deserve any credit for that? Even sinners love those who love them.
column3: “Pi at wo em‑mah g s‑ap tahhadkam g Jiosh mamtp hegam ab wo waꞌi ha tatchuad mo ab uhpam em‑tatchua. Chum o hems g pi ap hemajkam ab ha tatchua hegam mo ab uhpam ha tatchua.

column2: If you do good to those who do good to you, why should you deserve any credit for that either? Sinners do that as well.
column3: Pi at wo em‑mah g s‑ap tahhadkam g Jiosh mamtp hegam waꞌi ha wehhejed hab wo juh g s‑ap haꞌichu mo s‑ap haꞌichu hab em‑junid. Chum o hems g pi ap hemajkam hab wa masma hab e wua.

column2: If you lend money expecting to be repaid, why should you deserve any credit for that? Sinners lend money to other sinners as well, expecting to be repaid what they loaned.
column3: Pi at wo em‑mah g s‑ap tahhadkam g Jiosh mamtp hegam waꞌi haꞌichu wo ha hiwigi mam hab ha elid mat wo wa uhpam em‑mah. Chum o hems g pi ap hemajkam hab waꞌap aꞌai haꞌichu e hiwgid hab e elidch mat ab uhpam ep wo ui haꞌakia mat heꞌekia ha hiwigi.

column2: No: love your enemies, do good to them, and lend without expecting to be repaid anything. Then you will receive a great reward, and you will be children of the Most High God, for he is kind to ungrateful and wicked people.
column3: “Neh, mt ab wo pihk e elidad ha wui g e‑obga ch am hab wo ha junidad g s‑ap haꞌichu ch wo haꞌichu ha mah mamt pi ab hu uhpam wo ge neidad. Bamt masma am wo e chehgi mam d aꞌaligaj g Jiosh. T heg muꞌi s‑kehg haꞌichu ab wo em‑mah. Jiosh o hab wa masma s‑ha hoꞌigeꞌid g pi ap hemajkam ch hegam mo pi ab hu uhpam hoꞌigeꞌelid.

column2: Be compassionate, just as your Father is compassionate.
column3: Am g hab wo juhkchid g hoꞌigeꞌidadag hab masma mo g em‑ohg Jiosh am hab juhkch.

column2: Don't judge,  and you won't be judged; don't condemn, and you won't be condemned; forgive, and you'll be forgiven;
column3: “Pi g am hedai s‑koꞌokam has wo ahgad o ab wo ha mohtoꞌidad g pi apꞌekam. B at uhpam wo i e nodagi ab em‑wui. Gam g hu wabsh wo pi chegito mat hema s‑koꞌokam has wo em‑juh. Kut hab wa masma gam hu wabsh wo pi e chegito mamtp hems hema s‑koꞌokam has wo juh.

column2: give, and you will be given generously in return. When what you're given is measured out, it's pressed down so more can be added, spilling out over the top, pouring into your lap! For how much you give will determine how much you receive.”
column3: Ab g wo haꞌichu ha mahkad. T g Jiosh ab haꞌichu wo em‑mahkad. Ab amt baꞌich i geꞌe wo bei mamt heꞌes ab i ha mah no pi g Jiosh baꞌich i s‑hemajima matp hems g hemajkam. Ab at wo i e nodagi em‑wui mamt has i masma ab wo neidad hema.

column2: Then he illustrated the point: “Can a blind person lead another? Wouldn't they both fall into a ditch?
column3: “Pi at has masma wo em‑wanimedad wohokam ch ed hegai mat hedai pi wo mahchk g wohokam. Heg at wo wa wepok matp hems hema g pi neadam haꞌi ep wo i ha wanim g pi neneadam. Kutp hems wehsijj am wo i shul hiktani ch ed.

column2: Do students know more than the teacher? Only when they've learned everything: then they will be like their teacher.
column3: S‑mahch am mat g ha mashchamdam ha baꞌich wo i chum s‑mahchk hegai mo haschu i ha mashcham. E mashchamdam at am hugkam wo chum s‑mahchk g e‑mashchama am i s‑ap nahtok mo hegai mat hedai i ha mashcha.

column2: Why are you so worried about the speck that's in your brother's eye when you don't even notice the plank that's in your own eye?
column3: “Pi g am wo si s‑nenꞌoidad g hema chuꞌijig. Tp hems baꞌich i geꞌej g hejel em‑chuꞌijig. T heg wo wa wepok mam g chum haꞌichu ab i s‑wuhshdamk wuhij ed mo eda baꞌich i geꞌe haꞌichu ab woꞌo em‑wuhi ed.

column2: How can you say to your brother, ‘Brother, let me take out the speck that's in your eye,’ when you don't even see the plank that's in your own eye? Hypocrite! Take out the plank from your own eye first, and then you'll be able to see well enough to take out the speck from your brother's eye.
column3: Do iattogi mamtp hab wo chei mamt ab wo haꞌichu i wuhshad ha‑wuhi ed mo eda baꞌich i geꞌe haꞌichu am woꞌo em‑wuhi ed. Hemho wa amt wehpeg wo i apꞌech g pi e‑apꞌedag k haha wo e nako mamt haꞌi ep wo i ha wehmt k wo i apꞌech g pi ha‑apꞌedag.

column2: A good tree doesn't produce bad fruit, and a bad tree doesn't produce good fruit.
column3: “Mt wo s‑mai mas hedai d s‑apꞌekam oꞌodham hab wa masma mamt wo s‑mai mas haschu d s‑kehg uhs. S‑kehg uhs at s‑kehg wo bahidagt ch g pi kehg uhs pi kehg wo bahidagt.

column2: You recognize a tree by the fruit it produces. You don't pick figs from thorn bushes, or harvest grapes from brambles.
column3: Uhs o s‑e mahch ab e‑bahidag ab. Pi amt ab hu wo ui g suhna hoꞌi t ab o g uhdwis ab shaꞌi t ab.

column2: Good people produce what's good from the good things they value that they have stored inside them. Bad people produce what's bad from the bad things they have stored inside them. What fills people's minds spills out in what they say.
column3: K hab waꞌap masma g oꞌodham matp wo s‑apꞌek ch s‑kehg haꞌichu hab wo wuad o wo pi apꞌek ch pi kehg haꞌichu hab wo wuad. Matp has i masma haꞌichu chegito g oꞌodham, t hab masma wo neokad.”

column2: So why do you bother to call me, ‘Lord, Lord,’ when you don't do what I say?
column3: Sh hab ep kaij g Jesus, “Haꞌijj am chum hekid hab ni‑aꞌaga ‘ni‑kownalig’ ch eda pi am hu hab wua mani haschu em‑ahgid.

column2: I'll give you an example of someone who comes to me, hears my instructions, and follows them.
column3: Ab g wo ni‑hiwgad ch ab wo s‑wohog elidad g haꞌichu ni‑ahga. T hab wo s‑apꞌek g em‑doakag.

column2: That person is like a man building a house. He digs down deep and lays the foundations on solid rock. When the river bursts its banks and the floodwater breaks against the house it's not damaged because it's built so well.
column3: Id at heg wo wa wepok matp hems hema wo s‑wihnam shondad g e‑kihta. T hab pi wo i gei mat hekid wo hewed k juh k wo s‑gewkam mel g shuhdagi. Pegih, mt hab wa masma s‑wihnam wo gegokkad mo ihda kih mamtp ab wo s‑ni‑wohog elidad.

column2: The person who hears me but doesn't do what I say is like a man who builds a house without foundations. When the floodwater breaks against the house it collapses immediately, completely destroyed.”
column3: “T wabshaba pi wo apꞌek g em‑doakag mamtp pi ab hu wo wohog ni‑elidad. Id at heg wo wa wepok matp hems hema pi wihnam wo shondad g e‑kihta. T ab wo mel g shuhdagi. T ha hekaj wo i gei g kihj k am wabsh wo i e padch. Pegih, t hab wa masma wo i e padch g em‑doakag mamtp pi ab hu wo wohog ni‑elidad.”

column2: When he'd finished speaking to the people, Jesus left for Capernaum.
column3: Neh, tsh am i haꞌasa haꞌichu ha mashcha g Jesus amai k gam hu hahawa hih Capernaum wui. Kutsh g chuhchaij am wehmaj hihi.

column2: A centurion lived there who had a servant he greatly valued who was sick and was about to die.  When he heard about Jesus, the centurion sent some Jewish elders to him, asking him to come and heal his servant.
column3: Kush amai am hema d shondal ha‑geꞌejig ch ab d ha‑kehsha Rome t amjed ch kah ab amjed g Jesus. Sh id pionag hema muhkhim. Kush ab si tatchua g e‑pionag ch hekaj ab ha tahni g Tutuligo ha‑geꞌegedga mat ab wo i wai g Jesus. T wo doaj g piongaj.

column2: When the elders came to Jesus, they pleaded with him strongly, saying, “Please come and do what he asks. He deserves your help,
column3: Tsh hegam am dada k ab si e shoꞌigch Jesus wui k hab kaij, “Am g i wehmt ihda oꞌodham.

column2: because he loves our people and he built a synagogue for us.”
column3: Ab o si t‑tatchua ahchim Tutuligo ch am hema i kei g cheopi t‑wehhejed.”

column2: Jesus went with them and as they approached the house, the centurion sent some friends to Jesus to tell him, “Lord, please don't trouble yourself by coming into my house, because I'm not worthy of that.
column3: Kutsh gam hu ha oi g Jesus k am i aihi g kihj hegai shondal ha‑geꞌejig.

column2: I didn't even think that I was worthy to come and see you. Just give the command, and my servant will be healed.
column3: o manis hejel am wo hih m‑wui. Am apt hab wabsh wo chea. T wo doa g ni‑pionag.

column2: For I'm under the authority of my superior officers, and I have soldiers under my authority too. I command one to go and he goes, another to come and he comes. I command my servant to do something and he does it.”
column3: S‑amichud ani g m‑gewkdag no pi g ni‑geꞌejig gewkdag am ni‑dahm. Ni ahni hab waꞌap gewkdag am ha dahm g ni‑shondalig ch ni‑pionag. T hab wo juh mant haschu ab wo i ha chea. Ni heg hekaj s‑mahch mat am hab wo e juh mapt haschu am hab wabsh wo i chei.’ Neh, bo kaij.”

column2: When Jesus heard this he was astounded. He turned to the crowd that was following him, and said, “I tell you, I haven't found trust like this even in Israel.”
column3: Tsh g Jesus ab si has i el ab kaiok ihda. Sh muꞌi hemajkam an oidahim. Kush ab ha wui hab kaij, “Pi ani koi hebai shaꞌi neid mas hema haꞌas geꞌe ab si ni‑hiwig, chum hems am ha shahgid g Tutuligo,” k am hahawa ha chea hegam mat ab dada mat g m hu uhpam wo hihi.

column2: Then the centurion's friends returned to the house and found the servant in good health.
column3: Tsh am uhpam dada k chum nei. Kutsh doa g piongaj g shondal ha‑geꞌejig.

column2: Soon after Jesus went to a town called Nain, accompanied by his disciples and a large crowd.
column3: Kush am baꞌich d i tash. Tsh gam hu hihi hegam Jesus heg wui kihhim mash d Nain. Kutsh muꞌi hemajkam ha oi.

column2: As he approached the town gate a funeral procession was coming the other way. The man who had died was the only son of a widow, and a sizeable crowd from the town was with her.
column3: Tsh am wabsh i chum dada mo ab kihjeg g kolhai an wehgaj g kihhim. Sh ab g muhki e uꞌa. Sh g jeꞌej g muhki d hejel wiꞌikam. K id d si hemako madaj. Kush muꞌi ha wehmaj g hemajkam ab kihhim t amjed.

column2: When the Lord saw her he was filled with compassion for her. “Don't cry,” he told her.
column3: Kutsh am i nei g Jesus ihda uwi k si pi ap e taht wehhejed k hab wabsh kaij ab wui, “Pi g am shoakad,”

column2: Jesus went over to the coffin and touched it, and the pall-bearers stopped.
column3: k ch amjed am him k an taht hegai mo an ab woꞌichug g muhki.

column2: The dead man sat up and began to talk, and Jesus gave him back to his mother.
column3: Tsh am ha hekaj i dahiwua ihda oꞌodham k ab ha hekaj wabsh neok. Tsh g Jesus am wamgid k hab ah mat gam hu wo i oi g e‑jeꞌe.

column2: A sense of awe filled everyone there and they praised God, saying, “A great prophet has arisen among us,” and “God has visited his people.”
column3: Kutsh wehsijj si e totodsid k ab si ihm g Jiosh ch hab kaij, “Ia atki hema jiwia t‑shahgid g Jiosh haꞌichu i tashogiddam,” ch haꞌi hab ep kaij, “Jiosh atki ia jiwia t‑shahgid mat wo t‑doꞌibia mattp hedai d hemajkamgaj.”

column2: News about Jesus spread throughout Judea, and all around.
column3: Kutsh ihda mat haschu has e juh an wehsko e aꞌaga Judea chekshani oidk ch an wehgaj.

column2: The disciples of John told John about all this.
column3: Sh eda ged hu e kuhpach hegai John mash am ha pahl wapkonahim g hemajkam. Kush am ahgid hegam mash ab si wecho e mashchamahim mash haschu has junihim g Jesus. Tsh heg gohk ab i ha waid

column2: John called two of his disciples and told them to go and see Jesus, and ask, “Are you the one we've been expecting, or should we wait for someone else?”
column3: k am ha cheha mat am wo hihim k ab wo kakke g Jesus mas wa woho d Jiosh si Kehsha aha nat ab hahawa hema wo i wuhsh mat d wo hegaik?

column2: When they came to Jesus, they said, “John the Baptist sent us to you, to ask you, ‘Are you the one we've been expecting or should we wait for someone else?’ ”
column3: Tsh idam am dada Jesus wui k hab kaij, “Ab o t‑chehani g John matt ab wo m‑kakke maps woho d Jiosh si Kehsha aha nat ab hahawa hema wo i wuhsh mat d wo hegaik?”

column2: Right at that time Jesus healed many people of their diseases, illnesses, evil spirits, and made blind people see.
column3: Tsh g Jesus heg i tashkaj muꞌi ha dodaj g kokꞌodam k muꞌi ha wuwhas g jijawul ab ha amjed hegam mo an ha uꞌukch k ha‑nench g pi neneadam. Kush heg wehs neid idam John chuhchai.

column2: Jesus answered John's disciples, “Go and tell John what you've seen and heard. The blind see, the lame walk, the lepers cured, the deaf hear, the dead raised back to life, the poor are told the good news.
column3: Sh hab hahawa ha ahg g Jesus, “Am g uhpam wo hihim k wo ahgi g John mam haschu i neid ch haschu i kah. Ha ani dodajid g pi ha dodajidam kokꞌodam ch pi neneadam ch pi hihimidkam ch pi chechkaidkam ch ha chechegitoichud g koꞌi ch am ha ahgid g shoꞌigkam mat g Jiosh wo ha doꞌibia.

column2: How good it is for those who are not offended because of me!”
column3: T g Jiosh ab wo s‑em‑hoꞌigeꞌidad mamtp hedai ab wabsh wo ni‑hiwgad ch pi wo ni‑dagito.”

column2: After the messengers from John had left, Jesus began telling the crowd, “About John: what did you expect to see when you went out to meet him in the desert? Some reed blown about by the wind?
column3: Tsh am i gam hu hihi hegam John chuhchai. Sh g Jesus am haꞌichu ha ahgid g hemajkam ab amjed g John ch hab kaij, “Neh, am amt wa hihim k ab kaiha g John. K wa eda am oimmelhim pi apkokam jewed ch ed. Kumt pi woho am hu wo i wuwha wui matp d wabsh s‑pehegi oꞌodham ch am gawul wo wuad g e‑neꞌoki. Pi o an aꞌai e wanchkwua g John.

column2: Did you come looking for a man dressed in fine clothes? No, those who have stylish clothes and live in luxury are found in palaces.
column3: Kumt pi hema s‑neidam mo s‑kakaisim e enigadadch. Hegam mo hab masma e enigadadch o si s‑kakaisim kih.

column2: Were you looking for a prophet? Yes he is, and I'm telling you, he's much more than a prophet.
column3: Neh, heg amt s‑kaim Jiosh haꞌichu i tashogiddam k heg wa woho kah. K g John am baꞌich haꞌichu k ed ep kehk

column2: It was written about him in Scripture: ‘Look, I'm sending my messenger to go before you to prepare your way.’
column3: no pi d hegai mo ab amjed an oꞌohanas mo g Jiosh hab ahg ch hab kaij:

column2: I tell you, no one born of women is greater than John, but even the most unimportant person in God's kingdom is greater than he is!”
column3: “Kunt wo em‑ahgi mo g John wehs hemajkam ha baꞌich d i si haꞌichu am hugkam mat am i wuhsh g Jiosh kownaltalig id dahm jewed. T hahawa chum hems g si pi haꞌichukam hemajkam am Jiosh kownaltalig ed baꞌich d wo i s‑has haꞌichuk mo hegai John.”

column2: When they heard this, all of them—even the tax collectors—followed what God said was right, for they had been baptized by John.
column3: Neh, bash kaij g Jesus. Kutsh wehs ab kaiha hegam mat ab s‑wohog el g Jiosh k am e pahl wapko ab John wecho, chum hems hegam mo g lial ha kowlant g kownal wehhejed.

column2: But the Pharisees and the religious teachers rejected what God wanted them to do, for they had refused to be baptized by John.
column3: Tsh wabshaba pi ab hu wohog el g Jiosh tatchui pi e pahl wapkonk hegam mo d Palasi ch hegam mo d chehanig ha mashchamdam.

column2: “What shall I compare these people to?” asked Jesus. “What are they like?
column3: Kush heg hekaj hab kaij g Jesus, “Bo masma pi ta wepoma mo g aꞌal hegam mat pi ab hu wohog el g John k pi ab hu ni‑bei.

column2: They're like children sitting in the market who tell one other, ‘We played the flute for you but you didn't dance; we sang sad songs but you didn't cry.’
column3: Neh, tp hems am wo chichwid g aꞌal ch hab wo chei, ‘Am att em‑gehged g e hohontam ha‑piastakaj. Kumt pi e waila. Am att nei g muhki neꞌi. Kumt pi shaꞌi shoshani.’

column2: When John the Baptist came he didn't eat bread or drink wine, but you say he's demon-possessed.
column3: “Id ani hab ahg mat g John ab i wuhshani k pi ihꞌe g nawait ch muꞌikko pi e gegosid ab e hoꞌigeꞌidahunch Jiosh wui. K muꞌijj hab kaij mo g jiawul an uꞌukch g chegitoidaj.

column2: Now the Son of man is here, and eats and drinks with people, but you say, ‘Look, he spends his time eating too much food and drinking too much wine.  Plus he's a friend of tax collectors and sinners.’
column3: Nt ahni ia jiwia Jiosh si Kehsha k wabsh chum hedai ha wehm ni‑gegosid. K muꞌijj hab kaij mani s‑banma ch s‑iꞌidag ch d ha‑nawoj g s‑ta kekeꞌidamakam lial ha kowlantdam ch hegam mo pi ap oid g t‑shohshon ha‑chehanig. Neh, bo masma pi ta wepoma

column2: However, God's wise ways are proved right by all who follow him!”
column3: ch im hu hab wabsh i juh g Jiosh amichudadag. K wabshaba hegam mo ab s‑wohochud am chehgidch mo d wohokam.”

column2: One of the Pharisees invited Jesus to come and eat with him. Jesus went to the Pharisee's house and sat down to the meal.
column3: Tsh hema g Palasi ab i wai g Jesus mat am wo wehmaj e gegos. Tsh am hih g Jesus kihj wui k am i dahiwua mat wo e gegos.

column2: A woman who was a sinner in that town found out that Jesus was eating in the Pharisee's house. She went there, carrying an alabaster jar of perfume.
column3: Kush eda am hema d uwi heg eda kihhim ch si pi ap d hemajkam. Sh am dak ch e gegosid g Jesus.

column2: She kneeled beside Jesus and with her tears wet his feet, and dried them with her hair. She kissed his feet, and then she poured the perfume over them.
column3: Tsh id am jiwia k am wehgaj i kekiwua am uꞌadch g s‑ap uhw shuhdagi al s‑toa hodai haꞌa ch ed. Sh eda am e shelinch g Jesus mo hab masma dadhaiwup ch e gegosid. K si shoak ihda uwi. Kush g ohꞌogaj an iawua tahtadaj an. Kutsh an i dagio g cheꞌechew e‑moꞌokaj k an si ha chintad k an hahawa iawua ga s‑ap uhw shuhdagi tahtadaj ab.

column2: When the Pharisee who had invited Jesus saw this he said to himself, “If this man was really a prophet he would know who this woman was who's touching him, and what kind of person she was—that she's a sinner!”
column3: Kush hab wabsh hejel e ahg hegai kihkam, “T wo chum s‑mahchk mo si pi ap d uwi ihda matp woho d wo Jiosh haꞌichu i tashogiddamk ch pi wo hiwigi mas an wo taht.”

column2: Jesus spoke up and said, “Simon, I have something to tell you.”
column3: Sh g Jesus wabsh s‑mahch mo hab masma oidahim ch ab wui hab kaij, “Simon, ab ant wo haꞌichu m‑ahgi.”

column2: “Once two people were in debt to a money-lender. One owed five hundred denarii, the other only fifty.
column3: Kutsh g Jesus am ahgi ihda haꞌichu wepogida e‑ahga k hab kaij, “Matp hema ab wo e wulshch g hetasp siant pihsh heg ab mo g lial ha hiwgid ch hema ab ab wo e wulshch g hetaspo wehst‑mahm pihsh

column2: Neither of them could repay him, so he forgave the debts. Which one will love him the most?”
column3: k pi wo e nako mat wo uhpam namkid. Kut im hu hab wo i juh g ha‑wulshpadag. Neh, t hedai idam baꞌich ab wo i si tatchua?”

column2: “The one he forgave the most, I would think,” Simon answered.
column3: Sh hab kaij g Simon, “Naꞌas hegai mamt baꞌich i muꞌi im hu hab i juh g wulshpadaj.”

column2: Turning to the woman, he said to Simon, “You see this woman? When I came into your house, you didn't give me water to wash my feet. But she has washed my feet with her tears, and wiped them with her hair.
column3: ab g neid ihda uwi. Ia ant jiwia m‑kih am. Kupt pi ni‑mah g shuhdagi mant wo i wapko g ni‑tahtad. T wabshaba ihda am i wapko g ni‑tahtad g e‑ohꞌogkaj k am i ha dagio g cheꞌechew e‑moꞌokaj.

column2: You didn't give me a kiss, but since I came in she hasn't stopped kissing my feet.
column3: Pi apt ab hu ni‑chintad mant ia jiwia. K wabshaba id g ni‑tahtad chintad.

column2: You didn't anoint my head with oil,  but she poured perfume over my feet.
column3: Pi apt ab hu i huhu g ni‑moꞌo. T wabshaba id g uhw shuhdagi an iawua ni‑tahtad an.

column2: So I tell you, her many sins have been forgiven—that's why she loves so much. But whoever is forgiven little, only loves a little.”
column3: Neh, nt hab wo chei mat am geꞌe chehgi mo ab si ni‑tatchua. T heg am wohokamch mat g muꞌi pi ap chuꞌijigaj im hu hab i e juh. Hegai mam hedai pi shaꞌi geꞌe im hu hab i wua g ha‑chuꞌijig o pi shaꞌi geꞌe am hu chehgid g e‑tatchuidag.”

column2: Then Jesus said to the woman, “Your sins have been forgiven.”
column3: Sh hab hahawa kaij g Jesus heg wui uwi, “Im ant hu hab i juh g pi ap m‑chuꞌijig.”

column2: Those who were sitting eating with him began talking among themselves, saying, “Who is this who even forgives sins?”
column3: K hegam haꞌi mo ab dadha mihsa wui hab kaij ab aꞌai e wui, “K hedai e elid ihda ch im hu hab i chum wua g pi ap ha‑chuꞌijig?”

column2: But Jesus told the woman, “Your trust has saved you, go in peace.”
column3: Sh hab kaij g Jesus id wui uwi, “Ab ap ni‑hiwig ch hekaj e doꞌibia. Gamai g s‑ap e tahtk hihm.”

column2: Soon after this Jesus went around the towns and villages announcing the good news of God's kingdom. The twelve disciples went with him,
column3: Sh amjed am hu hebai, tsh g Jesus am hih ha oidk g kihhim k am ahgahim g s‑kehg haꞌichu ahga ab amjed g Jiosh kownaltalig. Kush hegam gamai gohk chuhchaij am wehmaj.

column2: along with a number of women who had been healed from evil spirits and sickness: Mary called Magdalene from whom he had cast out seven demons;
column3: Kutsh muꞌi am ha oi g uꞌuwi. Idam atsh wa ha dodaj g Jesus. Kush am haꞌichukaj i ha wehmt. Hema idam ash d Mary Magdalene. Id atsh g Jesus ab amjed i ha wuwhas g wewaꞌak jijawul.

column2: Joanna, the wife of Herod's manager Chuza; Susanna; and many more who provided support from their personal resources.
column3: Kush hema d Joanna. Sh g wehmaj kihkam ihda hab chehgig Chusa ch d haꞌichu am kownal wecho. Kush hema ehp d Susanna. Tsh idam uꞌuwi wo em‑nolawt hegai mash haschu i tatchua hegam Jesus.

column2: Once when a large crowd of people gathered, coming from many towns to see him, Jesus spoke to them, using a story as an illustration.
column3: Kutsh muꞌi hemajkam ab hihi Jesus wui ga hu aꞌai kihhim amjed. Tsh am ha ahgi g Jesus ihda wepogida ahga:

column2: “A farmer went out to sow his seed. As he scattered the seed, some fell on the road where people trampled on it and birds ate it up.
column3: “Nt wo haꞌichu em‑mashcha ab amjed g Jiosh kownaltalig wepogidch mat hema an ei g haꞌichu e‑kaichka e‑oidag ed. T haꞌi gan hu wabsh shul wohg ch ed. T g hemajkam am keish k g uꞌuwhig am huh.

column2: Some fell on stony ground, and once the seeds had sprouted they withered for lack of moisture.
column3: T haꞌi gan hu shul mo pi geꞌej g jewed ab waw t ab. T ab i chum wuhsh g eꞌes k wabsh gaksh no pi pi wadag amai.

column2: Some seeds fell among thorns and as they both grew the thorns choked the plants.
column3: T haꞌi gan hu shul g kaichkaj shaꞌi ch ed. T heg am wabsh wehnadk i geꞌege k ha kokda g esha.

column2: Some seeds fell on good earth and after they grew they produced a harvest one hundred times more than what had been sown.” After he told them this, he called out, “If you have ears, then listen!”
column3: T wabshaba hegam mat an s‑ap shul moihuna ch ed an wuhshani k siant ab kait hehemako.” Sh hab hahawa ep kaij g Jesus, “Neh, am g wo i aꞌamichud ahpim mam kah ihda.”

column2: But his disciples asked him, “What does this illustration mean?”
column3: Kush g Jesus chuhchai ab kakke mas has d ahga ihda wepogida ahga.

column2: Jesus replied, “You've been given insights into the mysteries of God's kingdom, but the rest are given illustrations, so that, ‘Even though they see, they don't really see; and even though they hear, they don't really understand.’
column3: Sh hab kaij g Jesus, “Nt wo em‑ahgi mo has d ahga no pi g Jiosh em‑hiwgid mamt wo s‑mai hegai mo haschu hemu am maskogid ab amjed g e‑kownaltalig. Ni wabshaba heg waꞌi ha ahgid haꞌichu wepogida ahga hegam mo pi ab hu wohochudamk. T hab pi wo amich haꞌichu ab amjed g Jiosh kownaltalig, chum as wo haꞌichu neid k wo haꞌichu kah.”

column2: This is the meaning of the illustration: The seed is God's word.
column3: Kush hab ep kaij g Jesus, “Neh, nt wo em‑tashogi ihda haꞌichu wepogida ni‑ahga. Jiosh haꞌichu ahga o wepogidas mo g haꞌichu kai ch am wo e gantad hemajkam ha‑iꞌibdag ed.

column2: The seeds that fall on the road are those who hear the message, but then the devil comes and steals away the truth from their minds so they won't trust in God and be saved.
column3: K eda haꞌi g ha‑iꞌibdag s‑kawpk hab masma mo g wohg. K g Jiawul am wabsh s‑pehegi ha wohppoꞌid hegai mo haschu i kah. T hab pi ab hu wo wohoch g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga k pi wo e doꞌibia.

column2: The seeds that fall on the stony ground are those who hear and welcome the message with joy but don't have any roots. They trust for a while but when difficult times come they give up.
column3: “K haꞌi g ha‑iꞌibdag hab sha masma mo hebai pi geꞌej g jewed ab waw t ab. T idam wo si s‑hohhoꞌi g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga ab kaiok k wabshaba pi wihnam ab hu wo bebhe k ch ab hi wa al heꞌes wo s‑wohochudad. T ab wabsh wo i chum hih g aꞌappema. T ha hekaj wabsh wo taꞌi i shul.

column2: The seeds that fall among thorns are those who hear the message but it's choked out by life's distractions—worries, wealth, pleasure—so they don't produce anything.
column3: “K haꞌi g ha‑iꞌibdag hab sha masma mo hebai s‑shaꞌig no pi e shaꞌijidch heg hekaj kudutadag ch s‑kaisdag ch s‑tahhadkam. Kut pi haꞌichu hab wo juh am Jiosh wehhejed.

column2: The seeds sown on good earth are those who are honest and do what is right. They hear the message of truth, hold on to it, and through their perseverance produce a good harvest.
column3: “K haꞌi g ha‑iꞌibdag s‑moik hab masma mo g moihuna. Kut ab wo kaiha g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga k am wo si i nuhkud e‑ihbdag ed k am wo e nako mat am hab haꞌichu wo juh Jiosh wehhejed.

column2: You don't light a lamp and then cover it with a bucket, or hide it under a bed. No, you put it on a stand, so that anyone who comes in can see the light.
column3: “Wohokam o wepogidas mo g lahmpa tonlig. Namt hig wo ehsto g lahmpa ab mehidk aha namt an wo dai mat hebai wo em‑tonlidch. Pegih, mt hab wa masma pi wo chum ehsto g wohokam.

column2: For there's nothing hidden that won't be revealed; there's nothing secret that won't become known and obvious.
column3: Wehs at wo s‑e mai matp haschu chum e ehstokch. T haschu wo i chum e maꞌishchid wo e chehg k am wo i e wuhshad.

column2: So pay attention how you ‘hear.’ To those who have received, more will be given; from those who don't receive, even what they think they have will be taken away!”
column3: “Am g wo s‑amichud mam haschu i kah. Hegam mat s‑ap wo hekaj g e‑apꞌedag at baꞌich ep wo i nei. T wabshaba hegam mat pi ap wo hekaj wabsh wo heb hu wua.”

column2: Then Jesus' mother and brothers arrived, but they couldn't get through the crowd to see him.
column3: Tsh am chum dada g Jesus jeꞌe ch wepngaj. Sh wabshaba si muꞌij g hemajkam an wehgaj. Kutsh pi e nako matsh ab wo miabi.

column2: Jesus was told, “Your mother and your brothers are outside. They want to see you.”
column3: Sh hema hab kaij ab wui g Jesus, “M‑jeꞌe ch m‑wepnag o am gegok jeg ed s‑m‑neidamkch.”

column2: “My mother and my brothers are those who hear God's word, and do what it says,” Jesus replied.
column3: Sh hab ahg g Jesus, “Neh, idam mo ab ni‑kaiham ch ab s‑wohog elid g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga o heg wa wepo mo d ni‑jeꞌe ch ni‑wepnag.”

column2: One day Jesus said to his disciples, “Let's cross over to the other side of the lake.” So they got into a boat and set off.
column3: Sh am hu hebai hab ha ahg g Jesus g e‑chuhchai, “Am att hu hig shuhdagi aigojed wo i chehchsh.” Tsh wa woho am dadhaiwua wahlko ch ed k am gahi i shul.

column2: As they were sailing, Jesus fell asleep, and a storm came down on the lake. The boat began filling with water and they were in danger of sinking.
column3: Sh am hebai him g wahlko shuhdagi ch ed. Tsh g Jesus am i woꞌiwua k koi. Kutsh g hewel ab haha wabsh i meh. Tsh ab i toꞌotonkai g shuhdagi k am iawua wahlko ch ed mash s‑ta ehbidam hab mahs ha wehhejed.

column2: They went over to Jesus and woke him up. “Master, master, we're going to drown!” they said. Jesus woke up and commanded the wind and the rough waves to stop. They stopped, and all was calm.
column3: Kutsh g chuhchaij am wui dada g Jesus k am wuhan k hab kaij, “T‑mashchamdam, ttki wo t‑koꞌij.”

column2: “Where is your trust?” he asked them. Terrified and amazed, they said to each other, “So who is this? He gives commands to the winds and the water, and they obey him!”
column3: Sh hab hahawa kaij ab ha wui, “Ab g wabsh wo ni‑hiwgad.”

column2: They sailed across to the Gerasene region that lies opposite Galilee.
column3: Tsh am hihim k gam hu dada ga hu aigojed g Galilee shuhdagi heg maibidch kihhim mash d Geresa.

column2: When Jesus stepped out of the boat onto the shore, a demon-possessed man from the town came to meet him. For a long time he hadn't worn any clothes or lived in a house. He lived in the tombs.
column3: Kush am hema oimmed g cheoj jeg ed ch am chum kih heg eda kihhim. Sh wabshaba g jijawul an uꞌukch g chegitoidaj. Kush gan hu wabsh kih mash an chehchog ch an e hihashp g koꞌi.

column2: When he saw Jesus he screamed, fell down at Jesus' feet, and asked in a loud voice, “What do you want with me, Jesus, Son of the Most High God? Please don't torture me, I beg you!”
column3: Tsh id am chehg k si s‑kaidam hihnk ch ab i meh pi haꞌichu enigadadch mash hab wa chuꞌig k ab wui i gehsh k si s‑kaidam hab kaij, “Jesus, alidaj g si uhgk Jiosh, gam g hu hihm k pi koꞌokam has ni‑juhni.”

column2: For Jesus had already commanded the evil spirit to leave the man. It had often seized him, and despite being tied down with chains and shackles, and placed under guard, he would break the chains apart and would be driven by the demon into the desert areas.
column3: Bash kaij nash pi g Jesus ab si ha chehani g jijawul mat ab wo i wuwha amjed.

column2: “What is your name?” Jesus asked him. “Legion,”  he replied, for many demons had entered him.
column3: Sh hab kaij g Jesus ab wui, “Shahp chehgig?”

column2: They begged Jesus not to order them to go into the Abyss.
column3: Tsh g jijawul ab si e shoꞌigch Jesus wui matsh pi am hu wo ha shul Jiawul kih ed.

column2: There was a large herd of pigs feeding on the nearby hillside, and the demons begged him to be allowed to go into the pigs. Jesus gave them permission,
column3: Sh eda muꞌi an oiopo g kokji kawulk bahsho ch e gegosid. Sh idam jijawul ab si tahni g Jesus matsh am wo ha dagito. Tsh am wo i wahp ha eda idam kokji. Tsh am ha hiwigi g Jesus.

column2: so the demons left the man and entered the pigs. The herd rushed down the steep slope into the lake and drowned.
column3: Tsh ab i wuwha ab amjed g oꞌodham k am i wahp ha eda g kokji. Kutsh wehsijj idam kokji am agshp i wohp k gam hu shul shuhdagi ch ed k wachkk.

column2: When the pig-keepers saw what had happened they ran off and spread the news through the town and the countryside.
column3: Tsh hegam mo am ha nuhkud gam hu uhpam wohp k am ahgahim ihda kihhim ch ed ch an ha oidk hegam mo an oꞌoidag.

column2: The people went out to see what had happened. When they came to Jesus they found the man freed from the demons. He was sitting there at Jesus' feet, wearing clothes and in his right mind; and they became scared.
column3: Tsh g hemajkam am himto mat wo nei mat haschu has e juh. Kush ihda oꞌodham am daha Jesus wui ch ab e enigadadch ch wabsh si s‑ap haꞌichu chegito. Kutsh wabsh wohoꞌi e totods.

column2: Those who had seen what happened explained how the demon-possessed man had been healed.
column3: Kush hegam mash neid am ha ahgid mat has masma e doaj ihda oꞌodham.

column2: Then all the people from the Gerasene region asked Jesus to leave because they were overwhelmed by fear. So he got into the boat and went back.
column3: Kush wehsijj idam Geresa t am hemajkam ab ahgid g Jesus mat gam hu wo hih ab ha amjed natsh pi shaꞌi si s‑ehbeni. Tsh wa woho hab e juh k an dahiwua wahlko ch ed mat gam hu wo hih.

column2: The man who had been freed from the demons begged to go with him, but Jesus sent him away.
column3: Kutsh hegai oꞌodham matsh ab i wuwha g jijawul amjed ab si e shoꞌigch Jesus wui k hab kaij, “Nt wo m‑oi.”

column2: “Go back home, and tell people all that God has done for you,” Jesus told him. So he went away, telling the whole town all that Jesus had done for him.
column3: “Uhpam g hihm k am wo i ha ahgidahi mat haschu hab juh g Jiosh m‑wehhejed.”

column2: A crowd of people was there to welcome Jesus when he returned, all eagerly expecting him.
column3: Tsh ga hu aigojed hahawa ep dada hegam Jesus. Kush muꞌi hemajkam am nenida ch si s‑ap i e taht k ab i nei.

column2: One was a man called Jairus, a synagogue leader, who came and fell at Jesus' feet. He pleaded with Jesus to come to his home  because his only daughter was dying. She was about twelve years old.
column3: Tsh am hema jiwia g oꞌodham k hab chehgig Jairus ch wabsh d haꞌichu am cheopi ch ed. Sh id chehiaga muhkhim ch d gamai gohk aꞌahidag. Kutsh ab wecho si i gei g Jesus k ab ahgid matsh gam hu wo oi kihj wui. Tsh gam hu chum wehmaj hih g Jesus.

column2: In the crowd was a woman who had suffered with bleeding for twelve years. She had spent all she had on doctors, but none of them had been able to help her.
column3: Kush eda am hema haꞌichug g uwi ch gamai gohk aꞌahidag mumku heg hekaj mo g ehꞌedaj jegwoni. Tsh pi hedai e nako mas wo doaj, chum as wehs hugio g e‑lialiga ha namkidch g mamakai.

column2: She approached Jesus from behind and touched the hem of his cloak. Immediately the bleeding stopped.
column3: Kutsh ab i hih Jesus wehgaj k an taht g kahbaj hugidag. Kutsh am wabsh si haꞌasa g ehꞌed jegwoni.

column2: “Who touched me?” Jesus asked. Everybody around denied doing so.
column3: Sh hab kaij g Jesus, “Doht an ni‑taht.” Tsh pi hedai am hu e ah.

column2: “Someone touched me,” Jesus replied. “I know because power went out from me.”
column3: Sh wabshaba hab kaij g Jesus, “Ab at hema ni‑taht. Ni s‑mahch nat pi ab i wuhsh g gewkdag ab ni‑amjed.”

column2: When the woman realized she couldn't go unnoticed, she came forward, trembling, and fell down before him. Right in front of everybody she explained the reason why she had touched Jesus, and that she'd been cured immediately.
column3: Tsh am i nei hegai uwi mamt s‑mai k ab hahawa i him k si gigiwek ch ab i gei Jesus wecho amai hemajkam ha tahgio k ash am ahgid g Jesus mat haschu ahgk ab taht k has masma ha hekaj doa.

column2: Jesus said to her, “Daughter, your trust has healed you, go in peace.”
column3: Sh hab kaij g Jesus ab wui, “Pegih, ni‑uwiga, am apt wa doa napt pi ab i ni‑hiw. Gamai g s‑ap e tahtk hihm k am wabsh s‑doakad.”

column2: While he was still speaking, someone came from the home of the synagogue leader to tell him, “Your daughter's dead. You don't need to bother the Teacher any longer.”
column3: Kush hab wabsh kia kaij ihda g Jesus. Tsh ab hema mel ab kihj amjed g Jairus k ash hab kaij, “Muh at g m‑chehiaga. Kupt pi am hu ep wo kudu g ha mashchamdam.”

column2: But when he heard this, Jesus told Jairus, “Don't be afraid. If you trust, she will be healed.”
column3: Kutsh kah g Jesus k hab kaij ab wui g Jairus, “Pi g am shaꞌi e todsid. Ab g wabsh i ni‑hiwig. Kut wabsh wo e chegito.”

column2: When Jesus arrived at the house he didn't allow anyone else to go in except Peter, John, and James, and the girl's father and mother.
column3: Kutsh ged hu dada kihj am. Tsh hegam waꞌi ha ui g Jesus Peter ch James ch John ch hegam jehjij g chehia. Tsh am e wehm i wahp.

column2: All the people there were crying and mourning for her.
column3: Kush eda wehsijj shoani ch pi ap e tahtk wehhejed g chehia. Kush hab kaij g Jesus, “Pi g am wo shoanid. Heg o wa wepo ni‑wehhejed mo wabsh kohsh g chehia.”

column2: They laughed at him, because they knew that she was dead.
column3: Kush wabsh has ahg hegam nash pi si s‑mahch mat muh.

column2: But Jesus took her by the hand, and said in a loud voice, “My child, get up!”
column3: Tsh wabshaba g Jesus ab bei nowij ab k ab si neok wui ch hab kaij, “I wamigi, chehia.”

column2: She came back to life, and she got up at once. Jesus told them to give her something to eat.
column3: Kutsh uhpam e chegito k ha hekaj i wami. Sh g Jesus am ha chehani mat wo haꞌichu mah. T wo huh.

column2: Her parents were astonished at what had happened, but Jesus instructed them not to tell anyone about it.
column3: Tsh hegam jehjij am wabsh e totods matsh e chegito. Sh g Jesus am ha ahgid mat pi hedai wo ha ahgi mat haschu has e juh.

column2: Jesus called the twelve disciples together. He gave them power and authority over all demons, and the ability to heal diseases.
column3: Am hu hebai, tsh am i ha wai g Jesus g e‑chuhchai. Tsh am wui i e hemapai. Kutsh ab ha mah g gewkdag mat gam hu wo i ha wuwhas g jijawul ab ha amjed hegam mo an ha uꞌukch k wo ha dodaj g kokꞌodam

column2: Then he sent them out to proclaim God's kingdom and to heal the sick.
column3: k am hahawa ha cheha mat am wo i ahgahi ab amjed g Jiosh kownaltalig.

column2: “Take nothing with you for the journey,” he told them. “No staff, no bag, no bread, no money, not even any extra clothes.
column3: Pi atsh koi hihi, sh hab ha ahg, “Gm amt wabsh wo i hihim k pi haꞌichu wo uꞌuk, chum hems pi g cheowikud nih g limoshan kostal nih g haꞌichu hugi nih g lial nih chum hems hema ep lihwa.

column2: Whatever house you enter, stay there, and when you leave, leave from there.
column3: Am amt wo dadkkad heg kih am mat hedai i si s‑ap ab wo i em‑nei am hugkam mamt hekid wo i hihi ab amjed hegai kihhim.

column2: If people refuse to accept you, shake the dust off your feet when you leave town as a warning against them.”
column3: Kutp hebai pi ap ab hu wo i em‑nei g hemajkam, mt am wo dagito hegai kihhim k ab wo si shahmud g e‑shuhshk mamt wo ha chehgi mamt wo ha dagito k pi wo ha ahgi ab amjed g Jiosh.”

column2: They left and went around the villages, announcing the good news and healing everywhere they went.
column3: Tsh wa woho am hihi idam chuhchaij ha oidk g kihhim k am ahgahim g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga ch ha doajid g hemajkam wehsko.

column2: Herod the tetrarch had heard about all that was happening, and he was very puzzled. Some were saying that John had been raised from the dead;
column3: Sh eda g Herod am wabsh kia d kownal Galilee ch ed ch am i kah wehs ihda mash haschu has e wua. Am amsh wehsko aꞌaga mas hedai wud ihda Jesus. Haꞌijj ash hab kaij, “Doki hegai Johnbad mo wa ha pahl wapkonahim. Heg amt mua. Kutki wabshaba uhpam e chegito.”

column2: others that Elijah had appeared; still others that one of the ancient prophets had come back to life.
column3: Kush haꞌijj hab kaij, “Doki Elijabad o hema ep hegam kekelibad Jiosh haꞌichu i tashogiddam.”

column2: Herod said, “There's no question I beheaded John. So who is this man? I'm hearing all these things about him.” And he tried to find a way to meet Jesus.
column3: k hab kaij, “Am ant wa ha cheha mat an e hikuch g John moꞌo. Kus hedai wud ihda oꞌodham mani muꞌi haꞌichu kah ab amjed?” bash kaij ch wabsh am chum i e nakog mat wo nei g Jesus.

column2: When the apostles returned they reported to Jesus what they had done. Then he left with them and went to a town called Bethsaida.
column3: Tsh am hu hebai am i uhpam dada g Jesus chuhchai k am ahgid g Jesus wehs haꞌichu mat haschu has i juh. Tsh gm hu hahawa i ha ui matsh gam hu hejelko hasko hihi maibidch hegai kihhim mo hab chehgig Bethsaida.

column2: However the crowds found out where he was going and followed him there. He welcomed them and explained the kingdom of God to them, and healed those who needed healing.
column3: Tsh am i kah g hemajkam k am i ha oi s‑neidamk g Jesus. Tsh g Jesus si s‑ap ab i ha neid k am ha ahgi ab amjed g Jiosh kownaltalig k ha dodaj g kokꞌodam.

column2: Late in the day, the twelve disciples came to him and said, “You should send the crowd away now so they can go to the villages and farms nearby and find a place to stay and food to eat—there's nothing here where we are.”
column3: Kutsh gam hu i juh. Tsh g chuhchaij am dada wui k hab kaij, “Am g ha chehani g hemajkam mat am wo hihi kihhim wui o am hasko oꞌoidag wui k wo bei g haꞌichu hugi k an hasko wo kohk heg hekaj mo ia hu wabsh si heb hu iia.”

column2: “You give them something to eat!” said Jesus.
column3: Sh wabshaba hab kaij g Jesus ab ha wui, “Ahpim amt wo haꞌichu ha mah mat wo huh.”

column2: There were about five thousand men present.
column3: Kush eda shaꞌi muꞌij g hemajkam mash hetasp mihl d chechoj.

column2: The disciples did so, and everybody sat down.
column3: Tsh wa woho hab e juh g chuhchaij. Kutsh wehsijj am i dadhaiwua.

column2: Jesus picked up the five loaves and the two fish, and looking up to heaven, he blessed the food and broke it into pieces. He kept on giving the food to the disciples to share with the people.
column3: Tsh g Jesus am ha ui hegam hetasp pahn ch gohk waptopi k ab i nea dahm kahchim wui k ab hoꞌigeꞌel g Jiosh k am hahawa hahain k ab ha mah g e‑chuhchai. Tsh idam ab i ha mahkhi g hemajkam.

column2: Everybody ate until they were full, and then twelve baskets of leftovers were collected.
column3: Tsh wehsijj e gegosid k kokwod. Tsh g chuhchaij an i uꞌihi g ha wihpiꞌidag g hemajkam ahim matsh wo shuhshud g gamai gohk hoha.

column2: At another time, when Jesus was praying in private with just his disciples with him, he asked them, “All these crowds of people—who do they say I am?”
column3: Sh am hu hebai am hejelko e hoꞌigeꞌidahun g Jesus. Tsh am wui dada g chuhchaij. Kutsh am haꞌasa e hoꞌigeꞌidahun k hab kaij, “Dohꞌo ni‑elid g hemajkam?”

column2: “Some say John the Baptist, others say Elijah, and still others say one of the ancient prophets risen from the dead,” they replied.
column3: Sh hab kaij hegam, “Haꞌijj o hab kaij map d ha‑wapkondam, Johnbad. K haꞌijj hab kaij map d Elijabad. K haꞌijj hab ep kaij map d hema ehp hegam kekelibad Jiosh haꞌichu i tashogiddam ch ia uhpam e chegito.”

column2: “But what about you?” he asked. “Who do you say I am?”
column3: Sh hab kaij ab ha wui, “Kum ahpim hedai ni‑elid?”

column2: Jesus gave them strict orders not to tell anybody about this.
column3: Sh hab kaij, “Dani ahni. Kumt wabshaba pi hedai wo shaꞌi ahgi hemu mani hedai wud.

column2: “The Son of man must experience terrible sufferings,” he said. “He will be rejected by the elders, the chief priests, and the religious teachers. He will be killed, but on the third day he will rise again.”
column3: Wehpeg at hemho wo wa ni‑bei g geꞌeged ch uꞌugchu papal ch chehanig em‑mashchamdam ahni Jiosh si Kehsha k muꞌi wo ni‑shoꞌigchud k am wo i ni‑dagito mant wo ni‑muhkid. Nt wabshaba uhpam wo i wuhsh muhkig amjed heg eda waik tash amjed mamt wo ni‑mua.”

column2: “If any one of you wants to follow me, you must deny yourself, pick up your cross daily, and follow me,” Jesus told all of them.
column3: Sh hab hahawa ep kaij ab wehsijj ha wui, “Mamtp am wo s‑oidam g ni‑himdag k hemho wa gam hu wo dagito g hejel e‑tatchui k ahni ni‑tatchui hab wo junihid ni‑wehhejed e shoꞌigchudch. Heg at wo wa wepok mam ab mohto g kots ch ab ab wo e muhkid.

column2: “For if you want to save your life, you will lose it; and if you lose your life for my sake, you will save it.
column3: Pi amt wo heki wua g e‑doakag mamtp wo hekaj am ni‑wehhejed. Heg at wo heki wua g e‑doakag matp hedai wo chum s‑daꞌad.

column2: What do you benefit by gaining the whole world if you end up lost or destroyed?
column3: “Pi at haꞌichu wehhejed wo s‑kehgajk matp g oꞌodham wehs wo bei hegai mo haschu i tatchua id dahm jewed k wabshaba pi wo e doꞌibia.

column2: If you are ashamed of me and my message, the Son of man will be ashamed of you when he comes in his glory, and in the glory of the Father and the holy angels.
column3: Pi g am wo si e elidad ni‑hekaj ahni Jiosh si Kehsha ch hekaj g ni‑mashchamadag. Nt ahni hab waꞌap pi wo si ni‑elidad em‑hekaj mant hekid ia ep wo jiwia. Idani at si s‑tondam ab wo e chehgi g ni‑gewkdag ch ni‑ohg gewkdag ch ha‑gewkdag g s‑apꞌekam anghil.

column2: I tell you the truth, some standing here won't taste death until they see the kingdom of God.”
column3: Neh, ia am haꞌi haꞌichug mamt hoꞌip kia nei g Jiosh kownaltalig k haha wo koꞌok. Am g wo s‑chegitok mani id am em‑ahgid.”

column2: About eight days later, after he had told them this, Jesus took Peter, John, and James with him and went up a mountain to pray.
column3: Sh am hu d i hemako domig amjed mash hab kaij ihda. Kutsh g Jesus gan hu wo e hoꞌigeꞌidahu uhgk doꞌag t ab k ab i ha wai hegam Peter ch John ch James matsh gan hu wehmaj wo i chehchsh.

column2: While he was praying, his face changed in appearance, and his clothing became a dazzling white.
