column2: As Scripture says, “God's character is defamed among the foreigners because of you.”
column3: An o hab chuꞌig Jiosh oꞌohana ed:

column2: Being circumcised  has value only if you do what the law says. But if you break the law, your circumcision is as worthless as those who are not circumcised at all.
column3: Do si haꞌichu g pahl hikuchka em‑wehhejed mamtp ab wo wohog elidad g chehanig. Mtp wabshaba pi ab hu wo wohog elidad, k pi has d shaꞌi ahga g pahl hikuchka.

column2: If a man who is not circumcised keeps the law, he should be considered as being circumcised even though he's not.
column3: Matp hema ab wo sha wohog elidad g Jiosh chehanig, t g Jiosh hab masma ab wo neidad mo pahl hikuchkas, chum as pi d Tuhligo ch pi woho hikuchkas.

column2: The uncircumcised foreigners who keep the law will condemn you if you break the law, even though you have the written law and circumcision.
column3: Gawul mahs hemajkam o pi pahl hikuchkas ch eda haꞌi hab e junihim mo hab masma hab chuꞌig g chehanig. Kut heg hekaj ab wo e chuꞌijigch g Tutuligo no pi edgid g chehanig ch eda melichkwuhim.

column2: It's not what's on the outside that makes you a Jew; it's not the physical sign of circumcision.
column3: Pi o d Jiosh hemajkamga hegam mat wabsh gawul juh g e‑chuhkug g pahl hikuchkakaj.

column2: What makes you a Jew is on the inside, a “circumcision of the heart” that doesn't follow the letter of the law but the Spirit. Someone like that is looking for praise from God, not from people.
column3: Hegam o hi d Jiosh hemajkamga mat gawul juh g e‑ihbdag. Kut pi wo e nako mas g chehanigkaj hab wo juh ihda. Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag at hemho wo wa gawul juh g t‑ihbdag. Tp hems ab wo em‑hehgchul g hemajkam mamt gawul wo juh g e‑chuhkug. T wabshaba g Jiosh ab wo em‑hehgchul mat gawul wo e juh g em‑ihbdag.

column2: So does a Jew have any advantage? Does circumcision have any benefits?
column3: Pegih, mtp hems a haꞌijj hab wo chei, “Pi oki haꞌichu d shaꞌi ha‑apꞌedag g Tutuligo ha dahm g gawul mahs hemajkam.”

column2: Yes, there are many benefits! First of all, God's message was entrusted to them.
column3: Nt wabshaba wo em‑ahgi mo muꞌi haꞌichu d t‑apꞌedag. Hema o d ihda mat g Jiosh ab t‑hiwigi g haꞌichu e‑ahga matt wo ha ahgi g nahnko mahs hemajkam.

column2: What if some of them didn't trust in God? Does their lack of trust in God obliterate the trustworthiness of God?
column3: K hi wa chum woho mo haꞌijj g ni‑wehm oꞌodham pi ab hu wohog elid g haꞌichu ahgaj. T wabshaba g Jiosh woho am hab wo juh hegai mo has i kaij.

column2: Of course not! Even if everyone else is proved to be lying, God always tells the truth. As Scripture says, “What you say will be proved right, and you will win your case  when you are judged.”
column3: Chum o hekid ahg g wohokam, chum as wehs hemajkam g iattogi hab wua. Neh, bo chuꞌig an Jiosh oꞌohana ed:

column2: But if the fact that we're wrong helps to show that God is right, what should we conclude? That God is wrong to pronounce judgment on us? (I'm talking from a human perspective here).
column3: Haꞌijj o hab kaij, M o wa s‑apꞌe matt hab wo junihid g pi apꞌekam no pi heg hekaj tasho am chehgid mo g Jiosh hab wua g s‑apꞌekam. T heg hekaj pi ap hab wo e juh g Jiosh matp s‑koꞌokam wo t‑namkid heg hekaj. Neh, bo kaij.

column2: Of course not! How else could God judge the world?
column3: Nt wabshaba wo em‑ahgi mo ahg g iattogi. Jiosh o chum hekid hab wua g s‑apꞌekam. Pi at has masma wo e nako mat wo t‑lodai matp d wo pi apꞌekamk.

column2: Someone could say, “Why am I still condemned as a sinner if my lies make the truth of God and his glory more obvious in contrast?”
column3: K hab kaij idam, T‑iattogi o am tashogid mo g Jiosh chum hekid ahg wohokam. Kuch heg hekaj am chehgid mo heꞌes i geꞌej g Jiosh haꞌichu k ed. Pegih, k haschu ahgch hab kaij g Jiosh machs d pi ap chuꞌijkam ch wo bei g s‑koꞌok namkidadag.

column2: Is it a case of, “Let's sin to bring about good”? That's what some people have slanderously accused us of saying. They should be rightly condemned!
column3: Haꞌijj o an ha iattogid manish hab kaij matt am hab wo junihid g pi apꞌekam ch hab masma wo tashogi g s‑apꞌekam. T wabshaba g Jiosh wo s‑koꞌokam ha namkid heg hekaj.

column2: So then, are we Jews better than others? Definitely not! Remember that we've already argued that both Jews and foreigners are under the control of sin.
column3: Neh, pi o shaꞌi baꞌich i s‑apꞌe g Tutuligo mo g gawul mahs hemajkam. Wehsijj ach wa ab mohtois g pi apꞌekam. K id an t‑uꞌukch. Kutt pi hedai wo shaꞌi t‑nako machs pi hab wo junihid g pi apꞌekam.

column2: As Scripture says, “No one does what is right, not even one.
column3: An o hab chuꞌig Jiosh oꞌohana ed:

column2: It's clear that everything in the law applies to those who live under the law so that no one could have any excuses, and to make sure everyone in the whole world is answerable to God.
column3: Jiosh at ab baꞌich wo i ha chuꞌijigch hegam mo edgid g chehanigaj ch pi am hu heg oidch hab e junihim. K hekaj hab mahs mo g Jiosh wehs ab ha abchud g hemajkam.

column2: For no one is made right before God by doing what the law requires. The law only helps us recognize what sin really is.
column3: Pi at hedai wo e nako mas wehs am hab wo junihid g Jiosh chehanig ch hekaj wo i e apꞌech am Jiosh tahgio. Chehanigaj at am wo i t‑tashogi mach haschu pi apꞌekam hab wua.

column2: But now God's character of goodness and right  has been demonstrated. It has nothing to do with law-keeping, even though it was spoken of by the law and the prophets.
column3: Iaꞌi idani at am i tashogi g Jiosh mat has masma wo i ha apꞌech g hemajkam am e tahgio. Chehanig at pi wo shaꞌi t‑apꞌechud k wabshaba heg wohokamchud mat has masma g Jiosh wo i t‑apꞌech. K g kekelibad Jiosh haꞌichu i tashogiddam id hab waꞌap wohokamchud.

column2: This right character of God comes to everyone who trusts in Jesus Christ, those who place their confidence in him. It doesn't matter who we are:
column3: Jiosh at am wo i ha apꞌech hegam matp hedai ab wo i s‑wohoch g haꞌichu ahgaj k ab wo hiwgad g Jesus Christ, chum as has mahs d wo hemajkamk.

column2: We have all sinned, and we fall far short of God's glorious ideal.
column3: Wehs hemajkam at hab juh g pi apꞌekam k pi am hu ais g Jiosh hab elida.

column2: Yet through the free gift of his grace God makes us right through Christ Jesus who sets us free.
column3: K wabshaba g Jiosh ab i s‑t‑hoꞌigeꞌid. T g alidaj Jesus Christ ab moht g s‑koꞌok t‑namkidadag am t‑wehhejed. T hekaj ab i t‑apꞌech g Jiosh e wui.

column2: God openly presented Jesus as the gift that brings peace to those trusting in him, the one who shed his blood. God did this to demonstrate he is truly right, for previously he would hold back and pass over sins,
column3: Jiosh at am i apꞌech mat g alidaj wo e muhkid am t‑wehhejed k hekaj gam hu hab wo i juh g pi ap t‑chuꞌijig mattp hedai ab wo i s‑wohoch. Ab o wabsh s‑ha hoꞌigeꞌid hegam heki hu hemajkam mo ab s‑wohochud ch pi chegima g ha‑chuꞌijig

column2: but now at this present time God proves he is fair and does what is right, and that he makes right those who trust in Jesus.
column3: nat pi g alidaj wo e muhkid am wehs t‑wehhejed. Bo wa masma am t‑chehgidch g Jiosh mo chum hekid hab wua g s‑apꞌekam ch wo e nako mat am wo i ha apꞌech g pi ap chuꞌijkam mat hekid ab wo bei g Jesus nat pi heg ab moht g s‑koꞌok t‑namkidadag.

column2: So do we have anything to boast about then? Absolutely not, there's no place for that! And why's that? Is it because we follow the law of observing requirements? No, we follow the law of trusting in God.  We conclude that people are made right with God through their trust in him, and not from legal observance.
column3: Neh, k pi haꞌichu d shaꞌi hegai machs hekaj wo chum si t‑haschudad. Pi att wo shaꞌi t‑nako machs wo i t‑apꞌech am Jiosh tahgio am hab junihidch g s‑apꞌekam. Jiosh at am wo i t‑apꞌech e wui matt hekid ab wo i s‑wohoch g haꞌichu ahgaj.

column2: Is God only the God of the Jews? Isn't he the God of other people as well? Of course he is!
column3: Pi o hegam d waꞌi ha‑Jioshga mat ab ha mah g chehanig ch wabshaba wehs hemajkam d ha‑Jioshga.

column2: There is only one God, and he makes us right through our trust in him, whoever we are, Jew or foreigner.
column3: Ab o ha wehnad ch wepo masma ab ha neid g Tutuligo ch hegam mo pi d Tutuligo. Wehsijj at hab waꞌi masma wo i e apꞌech am Jiosh tahgio mat ab wo i s‑wohoch g haꞌichu ahgaj ab amjed g Jesus.

column2: Does that mean that by trusting in God we do away with the law? Of course not! In fact we affirm the importance of the law.
column3: Id o pi hab d ahga machs im hu hab i juh g Jiosh chehanig matt hekid ab i s‑wohoch. T‑wohochudadag o am i t‑gewpkad matt am hab wo junihid g tatchuij mo hab wa chum d ahga g chehanigaj.

column2: Let's take Abraham as an example. From a human viewpoint he is the father of our nation. Let's ask, “What was his experience?”
column3: Am ant wo i wuhshad g Abrahambad mant am wo i em‑tashogi ihda mani wa em‑ahgid. Ihda Abrahambad ash d t‑shohshon ahchim Tutuligo

column2: For if Abraham was set right by what he did, he would have had something to boast about—but not in God's eyes.
column3: ch ab i s‑wohoch g Jiosh. Tsh g Jiosh heg hekaj am i apꞌech e tahgio. Pi atsh wa hejel am i e apꞌech heg hekaj mas hab junihim g s‑apꞌekam. K heg hekaj wa pi am hu haꞌichu d shaꞌi hegai matsh wa heg hekaj wo chum si e haschudad g Abrahambad.

column2: However what does Scripture say? “Abraham trusted God, and so he was considered as being right.”
column3: An o hab chuꞌig Jiosh oꞌohana ed:

column2: Now is this blessing just for the Jews, or is it for others too? We've just stated that Abraham was accepted as right because he trusted God.
column3: David o pi hegam hab waꞌi ha ahg mo pahl hikuchkas ch wabshaba hegam hab ep ha ahg mo pi pahl hikuchkas. Heki ani hu ahg matsh g Abrahambad ab i s‑wohoch g Jiosh. Sh g Jiosh heg hekaj hab kaij mo d s‑apꞌekam.

column2: But when did this happen? When Abraham was a Jew or before?
column3: Id at hab e juh mat koi e pahl hikuch g Abrahambad.

column2: It was actually before he became a Jew by being circumcised, which was a confirmation of his trust in God to make him right. This happened before he was circumcised, so he is the father of everyone who trusts in God and are considered as right by God, even though they may not be circumcised Jews.  He is also the father of circumcised Jews not merely because they're circumcised, but because they follow the example of the trust in God our father Abraham had before he was circumcised.
column3: Ab ash wa s‑wohochud g Jiosh. Sh g Jiosh heg hekaj hab kaij mo d s‑apꞌekam. T heg i dahm am hahawa e pahl hikuch mat hab masma am wo wohokamch g e‑wohochudadag mat heg hekaj am i apꞌech g Jiosh. T g Jiosh hab masma wehs am wo i ha apꞌech hegam mat hab waꞌap ab wo i s‑wohoch, chum hems hegam mo pi pahl hikuchkas. Heg o wa wepo mach ahchim Jiosh wohochuddam woho d Abrahambad amjedkam nach pi hab masma apꞌedag. Hemho wa att ab wo s‑wohochudad ch ab wo hiwgad hab masma mash wa g Abrahambad.

column2: God's promise to Abraham and his descendants that the world would belong to him was not based on his keeping of the law, but because he was made right through his trust in God.
column3: Jiosh ah am ha ahgid g Abrahambad ch amjedkamaj matsh am wo i ha apꞌech e tahgio k wehs ab wo ha mah g jewed kahchki matp ab wo i s‑wohoch.

column2: For if the promised inheritance is based on keeping the law, then the issue of trusting God is not necessary, and the promise is pointless.
column3: Kut pi haꞌichu wehhejed wo s‑kehgajk g ha‑wohochudadag matp id hab wo sha ha juni g Jiosh hegam mo pi ab hu wohochud ch am hab wabsh junihim hegai mo an oꞌohanas chehanig ed. T g Jiosh d wo s‑iattomkamk matp am hab wo sha ha juni.

column2: For the law results in punishment but if there's no law then it cannot be broken.
column3: Pi att ab hu wo shaꞌi i t‑apꞌech g chehanigkaj k wabshaba heg hekaj ab wo t‑abch g t‑chuꞌijig matt ab wo bei g s‑koꞌok t‑namkidadag. T hegam mo pi edgid pi heg hekaj ab hu wo e abch.

column2: So the promise is based on trusting God. It is provided as a free gift, guaranteed to all the children of Abraham—not merely to those who follow the law,  but also to those who trust like Abraham, the father of us all.
column3: Pi at ahchim am waꞌi i t‑apꞌech g Jiosh mach wa an uꞌukch g heki hu chehanigaj. Ahpim at am ep i em‑apꞌech mamt hab waꞌap ab i s‑wohoch g haꞌichu ahgaj. Batt masma am oidk hab t‑juh g Abrahambad k ab hiwig g Jiosh hemajimatalig. Id o heg wa wepo mo g Abrahambad d t‑ohg. K g Jiosh heg hekaj am t‑chehgidch mat has wo chum masmak.

column2: As Scripture says, “I've made you the father of many nations.” For in the presence of God, Abraham trusted in the God who makes the dead alive and speaks into existence what didn't previously exist.
column3: Bo masma an oꞌohadag mash g Jiosh am ahgid g Abrahambad:

column2: Now that we have been made right by God by trusting in him, we have peace with him through our Lord Jesus Christ.
column3: Am at i t‑apꞌech g Jiosh e tahgio ahchim matt ab i s‑wohoch g haꞌichu ahgaj ab amjed g t‑kownalig Jesus Christ. Kuch heg hekaj ab wui si s‑ap t‑tahtk.

column2: It's through Jesus, trusting in him, that we've gained access to this position of grace where we now stand, looking forward with happiness and confidence to sharing in God's glory.
column3: Shoꞌo waꞌi si s‑hemajima a t‑wui. Kuch si s‑hehgig ch ab nenida mat ab wo i t‑wahpki e‑kihdag ed k ab wo si t‑haꞌichuch.

column2: Not only this—we also remain confident when problems come, because we know that experiencing problems develops spiritual stamina.
column3: Chum as haꞌichu t‑kudut, ch eda si s‑hehgig nach pi s‑mahch mo g t‑kudutadag hab t‑wua matt wo s‑chu nakogad.

column2: Spiritual stamina in turn develops a mature character, and this mature character results in confident hope.
column3: T g Jiosh s‑ap wo i t‑el mach s‑chu nakog. Kutt id hekaj am wo i t‑gewpkai heg wui mach ab nenida.

column2: Since we have this hope we're never disappointed, for God's love has been poured into our hearts through the Holy Spirit he's given us.
column3: Ab at i t‑mah g Jiosh g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag. K heg ab t‑mahtchulid mo si pihk e elid g Jiosh ab t‑wui. Ch hekaj s‑mahch mat woho am wo i t‑wahpki g Jiosh e‑kihdag ed.

column2: When we were completely helpless, at just the right time Christ died for us ungodly people.
column3: Dach wa pi ap chuꞌijkam ch pi ha gewkdag machs hab wo juh haꞌichu matt hekaj am wo i t‑apꞌech. T wabshaba g Jiosh am i apꞌech mat g alidaj e muhkid am t‑wehhejed.

column2: Who would die for anybody else, even someone who does what's right? (Though perhaps somebody would be brave enough to die for someone really good.)
column3: Pi o hedai e muhkidamk hema wehhejed. Tp hems hema hi wo wa e muhkid hema wehhejed mo d si oꞌodham.

column2: But God demonstrates his love for us in that Christ died for us while we were still sinners.
column3: Kuch eda d wa chum pi ap chuꞌijkam. T g Jiosh am t‑chehgi mo heꞌes ab si i t‑tatchua am i apꞌechudk mat g alidaj am t‑wehhejed muh k gam hu hab i juh g pi ap t‑chuꞌijig.

column2: Now that we are made right by his death, we can be absolutely sure we'll be saved by him from the coming judgment.
column3: Kuch hab s‑mahch mat hahawa pi heg hekaj ab hu wo t‑namkid.

column2: While we were his enemies, God made us his friends through the death of his Son, and so we can be absolutely sure that he will save us through the life of his Son.
column3: Heki ach hu pi ab hu hajunima g Jiosh. T g alidaj muh am t‑wehhejed mat hab wo t‑juh matt ab haha wo hajunit g Jiosh. Pegih, ch baꞌich ab i apꞌedag am Christ doꞌibiatalig ed no pi d doakam ab muhkig amjed ch wo e nako mat wo i t‑wehmtad.

column2: In addition to this we now celebrate what God has done through our Lord Jesus Christ to reconcile us and make us his friends.
column3: Kuch si s‑hehgig mat g t‑kownalig Jesus Christ gam hu hab i juh g pi ap t‑chuꞌijig k am i t‑apꞌech mach ab hahawa si s‑hajunima g Jiosh.

column2: For through one man sin entered the world, and sin led to death. In this way death came to everyone, for everyone sinned.  Even before the law was given, sin was in the world, however it wasn't counted as sin because there was no law.  But death still ruled from Adam until Moses, even over those who didn't sin in the same way as Adam did.
column3: Ab atsh haꞌichu cheha g Jiosh hegai mo d wehpeg oꞌodham ch hab chehgig Adam. Tsh heg mulin k hab i shonwuich g pi apꞌekam jewed dahm. Tsh hekaj am i shonwua muhkig. Tsh g Jiosh pi hab ep juh g chehanig am hugkam matsh an i wuhsh g Mosesbad. Sh eda wehsijj hab wua g pi apꞌekam. Kush heg hekaj g muhkig wehsijj ab ha aꞌahe, chum as pi mulin g chehanig hab masma matsh wa g Adambad.

column2: But the gift of Jesus is not like the sin of Adam. Though many people died because of one man's sin, God's grace is so much greater and has been shared with so many through his gracious gift in the person of Jesus Christ.
column3: Wehsijj atsh ab haꞌichu i wahpki am wehs ha wehhejed g hemajkam. K wabshaba gawul mams hegai mat ab i wahpki. Do muhkig hegai matsh g Adambad ab i wahki wehs ha wehhejed g hemajkam. K wabshaba d Jiosh hemajimatalig hegai matsh g Jesus Christ ab i wahki wehs t‑wehhejed.

column2: The result of the gift is not like that of the sin. The result of Adam's sin was judgment and condemnation, but the gift sets us right with God, despite our many sins.
column3: K d al hemako hegai chuꞌijig mat hekaj am i wah g s‑koꞌok namkidadag. K wabshaba muꞌij g pi ap t‑chuꞌijig. K eda g Jiosh wehs gam hu hab i junihog am t‑wehhejed. Ab o d t‑wuikam hegai s‑koꞌok namkidadag nach pi ab d Adambad amjedkam. K wabshaba d Jiosh mahkig ihda mat hab t‑juni gm hu hab i juhk g pi ap t‑chuꞌijig.

column2: As a result of one man's sin, death ruled because of him. But God's grace is so much greater and his gift sets us right, for everyone who receives it will rule in life through the person of Jesus Christ!
column3: Muhkig at ab wehsijj t‑maꞌish heg hekaj. Adambad pi ap chuꞌijig. K wabshaba g Jiosh si s‑hemajim ab t‑makiog g hoꞌigeꞌidadag. Kutt am aigo dahm i chehchsh g muhkig ahchim matt ab bei. Ab o t‑mahkch g apꞌedag am gahi wuhshanim g Christ matt s‑ap wo himad g t‑doakag id dahm jewed.

column2: Just as one sin brought condemnation on everyone, in the same way one right act gave everyone the opportunity to live right.
column3: Pegih, id ani em‑ahgid mat g Adambad ab i wahki g s‑koꞌok namkidadag am wehs t‑wehhejed heg hekaj hemako pi ap e‑chuꞌijig. T wabshaba g Christ am hab juh g doꞌibiadag am wehs t‑wehhejed heg hekaj hemako s‑ap e‑chuꞌijig ch ab t‑makiog g wechij doakag.

column2: Just as through one man's disobedience many became sinners, in the same way through one man's obedience many are made right with God.
column3: Adambad at pi wohog el g Jiosh. K heg hekaj muꞌijj d pi ap chuꞌijkam. Christ at hejel ab s‑wohog el g Jiosh. Kut heg hekaj muꞌijj ab wo i e apꞌech am Jiosh tahgio.

column2: When the law was introduced, sin became even more obvious. But while sin became much more obvious, grace became even more obvious!
column3: Hemajkam o pi hohhoꞌid g chehanig ch baꞌich hab i s‑junimk g pi apꞌekam wa chum s‑mahchch g chehanig. K wabshaba ab t‑mahks matt hekaj wo s‑mahchk mo heꞌes i geꞌej g pi ap t‑chuꞌijig. K eda g Jiosh hoꞌigeꞌidadag baꞌich i geꞌej no pi gam hu hab i junihog g t‑chuꞌijig.

column2: Just as sin ruled us and brought us death, now grace rules by making us right with God, bringing us eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord.
column3: Pegih, tt wo chum nei mat am t‑gewito g pi apꞌekam nach pi heg hekaj ab aihim g muhkig. Heg o wa wepo mo d t‑maliomig g pi apꞌekam ch am t‑wanchshulig muhkig wui. Kuch wabshaba hemuch edgid g Jiosh hemajimatalig ab i s‑wohochudk g s‑kehg haꞌichu ahgaj ab amjed g t‑kownalig Jesus Christ.

column2: So what's our response? Should we continue to sin so we can have even more grace?
column3: Pegih, tp hems haꞌi hab wo chei matt hig baꞌich am hab wo i junihid g pi apꞌekam. T g Jiosh baꞌich wo i s‑t‑hoꞌigeꞌel.

column2: Of course not! Since we're already dead to sin, how can we continue to live in sin?
column3: K eda pi hab shaꞌi chum mahs machs am hab wo junihid g pi apꞌekam. Am att i dagito g pi apꞌekam. K pi am hu hahawa ha gewkdag t‑dahm. Id o heg wa wepo matt heki hu muh natt pi pi hab hahawa ep wo junihid g pi apꞌekam.

column2: Don't you know that all of us who were baptized into Christ Jesus were baptized into his death?
column3: Ab att t‑chehgi g t‑pahl wakonakaj matt ab i t‑hemakoj Jesus Christ wehm. K heg wa wepo matt am wehmaj muh natt pi ab i t‑hemakoj heg wehm mat muh.

column2: Through baptism we were buried with him in death so that just as Christ was raised from the dead through the glory of the Father we too can live a new life.
column3: T‑pahl wakona o wepogidas matt wehmaj ged hu t‑hiash am i muhk. T g Jiosh ab i t‑mah g wechij doakag heg hekaj si geꞌe e‑gewkdag mat hekaj ab i wamigi g Christ muhkig amjed.

column2: If we've become one with him in dying like he did, then we'll be raised like him too.
column3: Ab att i t‑hemakoj heg wehm mat am t‑wehhejed muh. Kut hekaj ab t‑mah g wechij doakag. Id o wepo masma matt am wehmaj koꞌo k wehmaj ep t‑chechegito.

column2: We know that our old self was crucified with him to dispose of the dead body of sin so that we wouldn't be enslaved by sin any longer.
column3: Am att i dagito g heki hu t‑doakag. Kut hab gam hu hab i e juh g pi ap t‑tatchui. K pi an hu hahawa t‑wulshch g pi apꞌekam.

column2: Anyone who has died has been set free from sin.
column3: Nat hig hab ep wo juh g pi apꞌekam hegai mat heki hu muh? Pegih, tt ahchim hab wa masma am i dagito g pi apꞌekam ab i s‑wohochudk mat g Christ am t‑wehhejed muh.

column2: Since we died with Christ, we have confidence that we will also live with him,
column3: Heg muhkig o d t‑muhkig no pi d t‑namkidadag. Id att ab i s‑wohoch. T g Jiosh heg hekaj ab t‑mah g wechij doakag k ab wo i t‑wuwhas muhkig amjed hab masma mat hab juh g Christ.

column2: for we know that because Christ has been raised from the dead he won't ever die, because death has no longer any power over him.
column3: Pi at hekid ep wo muh g Christ mat wa uhpam ep e chegito. Muhkig o pi am hu dahm gewkdag.

column2: In dying, he died to sin once and for all, but now he lives, and he lives for God!
column3: Hemho at muh mat wo kuhgi g pi apꞌekam gewkdag am t‑dodakag ed k ep e chegito k hemuch d doakam wehhejed g Jiosh.

column2: In just the same way you should consider yourselves dead to sin, but alive to God through Christ Jesus.
column3: Pegih, mt wo chum kuhgi g pi apꞌekam e‑dodakag ed k d wo dodakamk wehhejed g Jiosh ab i e hemakochudk g Jesus Christ wehm.

column2: Don't let sin have control over your mortal body, don't give in to its temptations,
column3: Pi g wo hiwgidad g pi apꞌekam mas am ep wo i chikp g em‑doakag mamt hekaj hab wo juh g pi ap e‑tatchui.

column2: and don't use any parts of your body as evil tools of sin. Instead dedicate yourselves to God as those who have been brought back from death to life, and use all parts of your body as tools to do something good for God.
column3: Wehs amt am wo i e‑dagito Jiosh wui namsh pi d e doꞌibiakam ab amjed g muhkig. T am haha wo i em‑hekaj g Jiosh mamt am hab wo junihid g s‑apꞌekam. Pi g wo shaꞌi e hiwgid mas wo em‑hekaj g pi apꞌekam has i masma.

column2: Sin won't rule over you, because you're not under law but under grace.
column3: Heki ach hu ab wecho g chehanig ch wabshaba hemuch edgid g Jiosh hemajimatalig ch hab pi hab wo chum junihid g pi apꞌekam.

column2: So then, should we sin because we're not under law, but under grace? Of course not!
column3: Pegih, t hahawa pi ab hu haꞌichu wo t‑abch g chehanig nat pi g Jiosh ab s‑t‑hoꞌigeꞌid k t‑doꞌibia. Kutp hems heg hekaj haꞌi hab wo elidad mat am hab wabsh wo i junihid g pi apꞌekam.

column2: Don't you realize that if you make yourselves someone's slaves, obeying their orders, then you are slaves to the one you obey? If you are slaves of sin, the result is death; if you obey God, the result is you are made right with him.
column3: T wabshaba g pi apꞌekam an wo ha uꞌukchid matp hab wo junihid. T g Jiosh s‑koꞌokam ab wo ha namkid. Ab amt wo s‑wohog elidad g Jiosh. T heg am wo i em‑apꞌech e wehhejed.

column2: Thank God that though you once were slaves to sin, you whole-heartedly chose to follow the truth about God that you learned.
column3: Pi apꞌekam o wa an em‑uꞌukch. Kumt wabshaba ab i s‑wohoch g wohokam ab amjed g Jiosh. Kuni id hekaj ab si hoꞌigeꞌid g Jiosh.

column2: Now that you've been freed from sin, you've become slaves of doing right.
column3: E amt wulꞌo ab amjed g pi apꞌekam. K g s‑apꞌekam an hahawa em‑uꞌukch.

column2: I'm using this everyday example because your human thinking is limited. Just as you once enslaved yourselves to immorality, piling up sin upon sin, now you must enslave yourselves to what is pure and right.
column3: Ni wabsh g pi hasig neꞌokikaj em‑tashogid nam pi pi koi si s‑amichud. Am amki wa e dagitokch si s‑uam haꞌichu wui ch hab junihim g pi apꞌekam. Tsh g Jiosh em‑doꞌibia. Kumt am hahawa wehs wo i e dagito s‑apꞌekam wui ch hab wo junihid g Jiosh tatchui.

column2: When you were slaves to sin you were not required to do what's right.
column3: Pi am ab hu kaiham g s‑apꞌekam mo hekid g pi apꞌekam an em‑uꞌukch.

column2: But what were the results back then? Aren't you ashamed of the things you did? Such things that lead to death!
column3: Kut pi haꞌichu s‑ap hab em‑juni g pi apꞌekam. Si am wa e ehꞌelid mam wa am hab junihim. K g pi apꞌekam ab wabsh em‑ahijidahim g s‑koꞌok em‑namkidadag.

column2: But now that you're set free from sin, and have become God's slaves, the results will be a pure life—and in the end, eternal life.
column3: Kumt wabshaba e wulꞌo ab amjed g pi apꞌekam. K g Jiosh d hahawa em‑ahmo ch hab em‑juh mam d hahawa s‑apꞌekam. K ab him mamt ab wehs wo bei g pi ha huhugedam doakag.

column2: The wage sin pays is death, but God's free gift is eternal life through Christ Jesus our Lord.
column3: Hegam mat hab wo junihid g pi apꞌekam at ab wo ai g s‑koꞌok e‑namkidadag. T wabshaba hegam mat ab wo i e dagito t‑kownalig Jesus Christ wui ab wo bei g pi ha huhugedam doakag.

column2: Brothers and sisters, (I'm speaking here to people who know the law), don't you see that the law has authority over someone only while they're alive?
column3: Neh, ni‑wepnag, s‑mahch amki mo has chuꞌig g t‑chehanig. Kuni heg hekaj hab em‑elid mamt wo s‑amich ihda mant wo em‑ahgi. Chehanig o an uꞌukch g oꞌodham am hugkam mat heꞌes i tash d wo doakamk.

column2: For example, a married woman is bound by the law to her husband while he's alive, but if he dies, she's released from this legal obligation to him.  So if she lives with another man while her husband is alive, she would be committing adultery. However, if her husband dies and then she marries another man, she wouldn't be guilty of adultery.
column3: Pegih, k hab chuꞌig g chehanig mat g uwi pi ep wo ha kunt mat eda g kunaj d wabsh wo kia doakamk. K wabshaba hiwgidas mat wo ha kunt matp g kunaj heki hu wo muh. Pi o ab hu hahawa shohbidch g chehanig.

column2: In the same way, my friends, you've become dead to the law through the body of Christ, and so now you belong to someone else—Christ, who was raised from the dead so that we could live a productive life for God.
column3: Pegih, k hab waꞌap chuꞌig am t‑wehhejed ahchim matt ab i s‑wohoch g s‑kehg haꞌichu ahgaj g Jiosh. Am att i t‑hemakoj g Christ wehm. K id heg wepogidas matt am wehmaj muh. K pi an hu hahawa t‑uꞌukch g chehanig. Dach enigaj hegai mat e chegito ab muhkig amjed ch hekaj s‑ap haꞌichu hab wo chum junihid am wehhejed g Jiosh.

column2: While we were controlled by old nature, our sinful desires (as revealed by the law) were at work within us and resulted in death.
column3: Am o wabsh ha chuꞌamun g chehanig hegam mo pi mahch g Jiosh. K baꞌich hab i junihim g pi apꞌekam. K g s‑koꞌok ha‑namkidadag ab ha aihim.

column2: But now we've been set free from the law, and have died to what kept us in chains, so that we can serve in the newness of the spirit and not the old letter of the law.
column3: Tt wabshaba ab i t‑hemakoj g Christ wehm. T g Jiosh t‑wulꞌo ab amjed g chehanig. Heki ach hu am chum chikpanid g Jiosh g chehanigkaj. K wabshaba hemu g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag t‑wanimed. Ch hahawa woho chikpanid.

column2: So what do we conclude? That the law is sin? Of course not! I wouldn't have known what sin was unless the law defined it. I wouldn't have realized that wanting to have other people's things for myself was wrong without the law that says, “Don't desire for yourself what belongs to someone else.”
column3: Haꞌi o hab elid mo pi apꞌe g Jiosh chehanig. K wabshaba pi woho. Chehanig o am t‑tashogid g pi ap t‑chuꞌijig. Neh, pi att wo chum mahchk mo pi apꞌe mach si pihk t‑elid g haꞌichu t‑enigakaj. K wabshaba g chehanig am t‑tashogid mo pi apꞌe.

column2: But through this commandment sin found a way to stir up in me all kinds of selfish desires—for without law, sin is dead.
column3: Kuch wa am hahawa baꞌich i s‑gewkam si pihk t‑elid g haꞌichu t‑enigakaj. Matp pi an hu wo haꞌichugk g chehanig, t d wabsh wo pi haꞌichuk g pi apꞌekam.

column2: I used to live without realizing what the law really meant, but when I understood the implications of that commandment, then sin came back to life, and I died.
column3: Neh, pi ani has shaꞌi ni‑tahtk mani eda pi ap mahch g chehanig. Nt hahawa s‑mai. T baꞌich am i si e chehgi g pi apꞌekam am ni‑eda. Kunt s‑mai maniki aihog g s‑koꞌok ni‑namkidadag.

column2: I discovered that the very commandment that was meant to bring life brought death instead,  because sin found a way through the commandment to deceive me, and used the commandment to kill me!
column3: Jiosh at hab juh g e‑chehanig matt heg hekaj wo s‑mai matt has masma wo bei g s‑ap doakag. Kunid eda heg ab am cheh maniki d pi ap chuꞌijkam ch ab aihog g ni‑muhkig ch s‑koꞌok ni‑namkidadag.

column2: However, the law is holy, and the commandment is holy, right, and good.
column3: Do hekia s‑apꞌekam ch s‑kehgaj g chehanig ch am t‑tashogid matt has wo chum t‑junihid.

column2: Now would something that is good kill me? Of course not! But sin shows itself to be sin by using good to cause my death. So by means of the commandment, it's revealed how evil sin really is.
column3: Pi at g chehanig hab ni‑juh mani ab aihog g ni‑muhkig ch s‑koꞌok ni‑namkidadag. Pi apꞌekam at hab ni‑juh mani wa ab aihog. Chehanig o s‑kehgaj. K g Jiosh heg hekaj am t‑tashogid mo haschu d pi apꞌekam ch has masma si pi apꞌe.

column2: We realize that the law is spiritual; but I'm all-too-human, a slave to sin.
column3: Pegih, k d hekia s‑apꞌekam g chehanig. Kuni wa wabshaba d wabsh oꞌodham. K wa g pi apꞌekam an ni‑uꞌukch.

column2: I really don't understand what I'm doing. I do the things I don't want to do, and what I hate doing, that's what I do!
column3: Pi o wa ta amichudama g ni‑doakag am ni‑wehhejed mani wa eda wabsh hejel ab ni‑hiwig. S‑mahch ani mo haschu d s‑apꞌekam ch wabshaba pi am hu hab junihim ch heg hab waꞌi junihim mani haschu i pi hohhoꞌid.

column2: But if I'm saying that I do what I don't want to, this shows that I admit the law is right.
column3: Id ani wa hekaj wohokamchud mo g chehanig s‑apꞌe.

column2: So it's no longer me who does this, but sin living in me—
column3: Pi ani wa hab chum junimk g pi apꞌekam. K wa wabshaba heg an ni‑uꞌukch. K wa heg hekaj heg wa wepo mani wa pi d si ahni ch am hab junihim.

column2: for I know that there's nothing good in me as far as my sinful human nature is concerned. Even though I want to do good, I'm just not able to do it.
column3: Ni‑doakag o wa d wabsh hekia pi apꞌekam mani wa eda pi ab hu hiwig g Jiosh. Kuni wa pi shaꞌi ni‑nakog manis am hab wo junihid g s‑apꞌekam, chum anis wa hab s‑junimk.

column2: The good I want to do, I don't do; while the evil I don't want to do, that's what I end up doing!
column3: Heg ani hab waꞌi junihim pi apꞌekam, chum anis pi hab chum junimk.

column2: However if I'm doing what I don't want to, then it's no longer me doing it, but sin living in me.
column3: Heg ani wa hekaj hab kaij mani pi d si ahni ch hab junihim. Pi apꞌekam o wa an ni‑uꞌukch.

column2: This is the principle I've discovered: if I want to do what's good, evil is always there too.
column3: Pegih, boki chuꞌig g t‑doakag mach eda pi ab hu hiwig g Jiosh. Pi att wo t‑nako machs hejel am hab wo junihid g s‑apꞌekam, chum achs hab s‑junimk.

column2: My inner self is delighted with God's law,
column3: S‑mahch ach mo s‑apꞌe g Jiosh chehanig.

column2: but I see a different law at work within me that is at war with the law my mind has decided to follow, making me a prisoner of the law of sin that is within me.
column3: K wabshaba g pi apꞌekam an t‑uꞌukch ch hab t‑wua mach ab wui gegok.

column2: I'm totally miserable! Who will rescue me from this body that's causing my death? Thank God—for he does this through Jesus Christ our Lord!  Here's the situation: while I myself choose with my mind to obey God's law, my human nature obeys the law of sin.
column3: Pegih, boki chuꞌig g t‑doakag mach eda pi ab hu hiwig g Jiosh. Bach chum s‑junimk g Jiosh chehanig ch wabshaba am hab wabsh junihim g pi apꞌekam. K pi in hu hedai haꞌichug mas wo t‑doꞌibia. Kuch heg hekaj si pi ap t‑tahtk. T wabshaba g Jiosh am i kei g e‑alidag Jesus Christ. Kut heg t‑doꞌibia. Id ach hekaj ab si hoꞌigeꞌid g Jiosh.

column2: So there is now no condemnation for those who are in Christ Jesus.
column3: Pi o ab hu hahawa t‑abchud g Jiosh g haꞌichu t‑chuꞌijig ahchim mach ab si hiwig g Jesus Christ.

column2: The law of the Spirit of life in Christ Jesus has set me free from the law of sin and death.
column3: Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag at t‑wulꞌo ab pi apꞌekam t amjed k ab t‑mah g wechij doakag. K pi ab hu hahawa t‑aihog g s‑koꞌok t‑namkidadag.

column2: What the law couldn't do because it was powerless due to our sinful nature,  God was able to do! By sending his own Son in human form, God dealt with the whole problem of sin and destroyed sin's power in our sinful human nature.
column3: Pi att wo shaꞌi t‑nako machs am hu hab wo junihid g chehanig ch hekaj wo t‑doꞌibia nach pi d wabsh oꞌodham. T wabshaba g Jiosh am i kei g e‑alidag mat wo t‑doꞌibia. T heg ia i wuhsh jewed dahm k hab masmakahim mach ahchim ch wabshaba pi ha chuꞌijig ch gam hu hab i juh g pi ap t‑chuꞌijig.

column2: In this way we could fulfill the good requirements of the law by following the Spirit and not our sinful nature.
column3: Jiosh at hab masma am i t‑apꞌech e‑tahgio k hab masma ab t‑neid matt pi hekid shaꞌi mul g chehanig ahchim mach ab i t‑dagitokch Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag wui ch pi am hu hab junihim g hejel pi ap t‑tatchui.

column2: Those who follow their sinful nature are preoccupied with sinful things, but those who follow the Spirit concentrate on spiritual things.
column3: Hegam mo hab junihim g hejel e‑tatchui o heg hekaj an e uꞌukch. K hegam mo hab junihim g tatchuij g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag heg hekaj an epai e uꞌukch.

column2: The sinful human mind results in death, but having the mind led by the Spirit results in life and peace.
column3: Am o hihim s‑koꞌok e‑namkidadag wui hegam mo hab junihim g hejel e‑tatchui. Ch ahchim mach hab junihim g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag tatchui am Jiosh kihdag wui hihimad ch hekaj wo si s‑ap t‑tahtkkad.

column2: The sinful human mind is hostile to God because it refuses to obey the law of God—in fact it never can,
column3: Do obgaj g Jiosh hegai mo hedai g hejel e‑tatchui hab junihim no pi pi ab hu wohog elid g Jiosh ch pi wo shaꞌi e nako mas am hab wo e juh.

column2: and those who follow their sinful nature can never please God.
column3: Pi at wo e nako hegam mo hab wua g hejel e‑tatchui mas hab wo juh g Jiosh tatchui.

column2: But you're not following your sinful nature, but the Spirit—if it's true that the Spirit of God is living in you. For those that don't have the Spirit of Christ in them don't belong to him.
column3: Ch wabshaba ahchim pi g hejel t‑tatchui hab wua. Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag o am t‑eda hab chuꞌig. Kuch heg tatchui hab wua. Hegam mo pi am hu ha eda g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag o pi d Jiosh hemajkamga.

column2: However if Christ is in you, even though your body is going to die because of sin, the Spirit gives you life because you're now right with God.
column3: T ahchim am i t‑apꞌech g Christ am tahgio g Jiosh k ab t‑mah g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag. Kuch heg hekaj edgid g wechig doakag, chum as hi wa g muhkig ab wehs ha aihog g hemajkam g pi ap ha‑chuꞌijigkaj.

column2: The Spirit of him who raised Jesus from the dead lives in you. He who raised Jesus from the dead will also give life to your dead bodies through his Spirit that lives in you.
column3: Kut am uhpam ep wo t‑chegitoich g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag hab masma mat hab juh g Christ.

column2: So brothers and sisters, we don't have to follow  our sinful nature that operates according to our human desires.
column3: Pegih, ni‑wepnag, ab o d t‑wuikam matt hab wo junihid g Jiosh tatchui.

column2: For if you live under the control of your sinful nature, you're going to die. But if you follow the way of the Spirit, putting to death the evil things you do, then you will live.
column3: Jiosh at gam hu hab wo i t‑juh mattp am hab wo sha junihid g hejel t‑tatchui. Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag o am i em‑wehmaj. Kumt gam hu wo s‑ohhod g pi ap haꞌichu hab e‑juni k hab wo edgidad g wechij doakag.

column2: All those who are led by the Spirit of God are God's children.
column3: Ab at t‑mah g Jiosh g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag. K heg am t‑wanimed. Ch hab s‑mahch mach d Jiosh aꞌaliga

column2: You were not given a spirit to enslave and terrify you once more. No, what you received was the spirit that makes you children in God's family. Now we can shout out, “God is our Father!”
column3: ch ab ihm mo d t‑ohg ch pi shaꞌi ehbid.

column2: The Spirit himself agrees with us that we're God's children.
column3: Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag o am t‑tashogid mach d aꞌaligaj g Jiosh.

column2: If we're his children, then we're his heirs. We are heirs of God, and heirs together with Christ. But if we want to share in his glory we must share in his sufferings.
column3: Jiosh at ab wehs mah g e‑alidag g e‑hoꞌigeꞌidalig k hab waꞌap wo t‑mah nach pi hab waꞌap d aꞌaligaj. Kutt wabshaba wehpeg ab wo nako g shoꞌigdag hab masma mat heg hab e juh mo d si alidaj.

column2: Yet I'm convinced that what we suffer in the present is nothing compared to the future glory that will be revealed to us.
column3: Si atsh geꞌe ab wo has t‑elidad g Jiosh. Kutt hab pi wo shaꞌi kuint g al t‑shoꞌigdag ia jewed dahm.

column2: All of creation is patiently waiting, longing for God to reveal his children.
column3: Jiosh atsh wehs haꞌichu dahm wo t‑mahsko wua ahchim aꞌaligaj. K wehs haꞌichu nahtoij heg nenida.

column2: For God allowed the purpose of creation to be frustrated.  But creation itself waits in hope for the time when it will be set free from the slavery of decay and share the glorious freedom of God's children.
column3: Do Jiosh hab elida mat wehs e padch g nahtoij mat eda g oꞌodham pi ap chuꞌi. Wehs haꞌichu o ab hahawa e wulshch g pi apꞌekamkaj. Tsh wabshaba g Jiosh wo wulꞌo g e‑nahtoi mat hekid am wo mahsko t‑wua ahchim aꞌaligaj. Tsh wehs haꞌichu hahawa ep si s‑kehg hab wo mahsk.

column2: We know that all creation groans with longing, suffering birth-pains even up till now.
column3: S‑mahch ach mo hemuch g haꞌichu nahtoij g Jiosh shahag wepo mo shahshani hab sha masma mat g uwi g ali wo be k ab i taht g s‑koꞌok.

column2: Not only creation, but we too, who have a foretaste of the Spirit, we groan inwardly as we wait for God to “adopt” us—the redemption of our bodies.
column3: Ahchim mo g Jiosh ab t‑mahkch g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag ach hab waꞌap shahshani ch ab si nenida mat am wo i nahto g t‑doꞌibiadag k wo wechijid g t‑chuhkug. Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag o d wehpeg mahkigdaj g Jiosh ab t‑wui.

column2: For we were saved by hope. Yet hope that's already seen isn't hope at all. Who hopes for what they can already see?
column3: Ab att i s‑wohoch g Jiosh. Kut t‑doꞌibia. K wabshaba am wabsh kia wiꞌis mat wo nahto g t‑doꞌibiadag k am wo i t‑wahpki e‑kihdag ed. Kuch s‑wohochud mat id hab wo t‑juni.

column2: Since we're hoping for what we haven't yet seen, we wait for it patiently.
column3: Wohochudadag o hab d ahga mamt s‑e tahtk ch ab wo nenidad hegai mamt koi nei.

column2: Similarly the Spirit helps us in our weakness. We don't know how to speak with God, but the Spirit himself intercedes with and through us by groans that can't be put into words.
column3: Pi ach ahim gewkdag. K wabshaba g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag i t‑wehmaj. Pi ach mahch matt has masma wo t‑hoꞌigeꞌidahunad am Jiosh wui. K wabshaba g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag ab t‑mahtchulid. Kuch hab shahshani ch shoak am Jiosh wui ch pi shaꞌi mahch matt has masma hab wo chei hegai mo haschu ab t‑tahtchud.

column2: The One who examines the minds of everyone knows the Spirit's motives, because the Spirit pleads God's cause on behalf of the believers.
column3: K wabshaba g Jiosh s‑mahch g t‑ihbdag ch ep s‑mahch hegai mo haschu ab t‑tahtchud g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag. Heg o hab wua g t‑hoꞌigeꞌidahuna am Jiosh tatchui oidch. Kuch ab tahni g i wehmtadag am ha wehhejed g Jiosh hemajkamga.

column2: We know that in all things God works for the good of those who love him, those who he has called to be part of his plan.
column3: Ab at i t‑wai g Jiosh matt d wo hemajkamgajk. Kuch ab wui si pihk t‑elid. K g Jiosh heg hekaj wehs haꞌichu am i apꞌechud mat t‑wehhejed wo s‑ap i wuhsh haꞌichu.

column2: For God, choosing them in advance, set them apart to be like his Son, so that the Son would be the first of many brothers and sisters.
column3: Heki o hu s‑mahch g Jiosh mat hedai ab wo kaiha g waidaj ch am apꞌech matt wo wepo chuꞌigk g alidaj ch wehmaj d wo aꞌaligajk. T g alidaj d wo wehpeg t‑siꞌihegk.

column2: Those that he chose, he also called; and those that he called, he also made right; and those that he made right, he also glorified.
column3: T wa woho ab i t‑waid k am i t‑apꞌech e tahgio k hahawa pi ab hu haꞌichu t‑chuꞌijigchud. K am baꞌich ehp mat ab t‑mah g si has e‑elidadag.

column2: So what's our response to all this? If God is for us, who can be against us?
column3: Pegih, bo masma am t‑wehhejed kehk g Jiosh. T hab pi hedai wo e nako mas ab t‑wui wo kekiwua.

column2: God, who did not hold back his own Son, but gave him up for all of us, won't he also freely give us everything?
column3: Pi at shaꞌi t‑daꞌi g Jiosh g e‑alidag. Kuch heg hekaj s‑mahch mat pi haꞌichu ep wo shaꞌi t‑daꞌi. Alidaj at ab wui e iagchul am t‑wehhejed.

column2: Who can accuse God's special people of anything? It's God who sets us right,
column3: T g Jiosh heg hekaj gam hu hab i juh g pi ap t‑chuꞌijig. T hab pi hedai wo e nako mas ab wo haꞌichu t‑abch.

column2: so who can condemn us? It's Christ Jesus who died—more importantly, who was raised from the dead—who stands at God's right-hand, presenting our case.
column3: Jiosh alidag at ab nako g s‑koꞌok t‑namkidadag am t‑wehhejed muhk. T hab pi wo t‑ai hegai t‑namkidadag. T g Jiosh ab i wuhshad muhkig amjed k an s‑apko dai e‑hugid an. K heg am t‑wehhejed e hoꞌigeꞌidahun ab Jiosh wui.

column2: Who can separate us from Christ's love? Can oppression, distress, or persecution? Or hunger, poverty, danger, or violence?
column3: Kuch eda hi wa hebaichujj ab nakog g kudutadag ch s‑hasig haꞌichu ch shoꞌigchudadag nach pi d Christ wohochuddam. Bihugig ch shoꞌigdag ch s‑ta ehbidam haꞌichu ch cheggiadag o ab ep t‑aihog.

column2: Just as Scripture says, “For your sake we're in danger of being killed all the time. We're treated like sheep to be slaughtered.”
column3: Bo chuꞌig g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga:

column2: I am in Christ, and what I say is true. I'm not lying! My conscience and the Holy Spirit confirm  how terribly sad I am, how I have never-ending pain in my heart,
column3: Muꞌijj g ni‑wehm Tutuligo o s‑ohhodamk g Jesus pi wohochudch mo d Jiosh si Kehsha. Kuni heg hekaj si pi ap ni‑tahtk. K g ni‑ihbdag shaꞌi si s‑koꞌok. S‑mahch ani mani g wohokam em‑ahgid nani pi pi ni‑elid ch em‑ahgid. K g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag an ni‑uꞌukch.

column2: for my own people, my brothers and sisters. I would rather be cursed myself, separated from Christ, if that would help them.
column3: Si ani tatchua mat wo e doꞌibia g ni‑wehm oꞌodham, chum anis hems heg hekaj pi wo ni‑doꞌibia.

column2: They are my fellow-Israelites, God's chosen people. God revealed to them his glory and made agreements with them, giving them the law, true worship, and his promises.  They are our forefathers—ancestors of Christ, humanly-speaking, the One who rules over everything, the eternally-blessed God. Amen.
column3: Do chum Jiosh hemajkamga. Jiosh at ab i ha chuhcha g t‑shohshonbad k am ha ahgid mat si s‑kehg haꞌichu hab wo t‑juni. Ab o si has t‑elid g Jiosh ch ab t‑mahkch g e‑chehanig. Kuch hab s‑t‑mahch ch hab junihim g ab si has elida Jiosh wui. T g Jiosh si Kehsha ab t‑amjed i wuhsh ia jewed dahm. Tt heg hekaj ab wo si has elidad g Jiosh chum hekid. Neh!

column2: It's not that God's promise has failed. For not every Israelite is a true Israelite,
column3: K eda muꞌijj g ni‑wehm oꞌodham pi ab hu wohochud g Jiosh si Kehsha. K wabshaba id pi hab d ahga mas g Jiosh pi am hu hab wo juh hegai mo hab kaij mat hab wo juh. Pi atsh wehsijj g Tutuligo d wo Jiosh hemajkamgak.

column2: and all those who are descended from Abraham are not his true children. For Scripture says, “Your descendants will be counted through Isaac,”
column3: Id ant am wo em‑tashogi am em‑ahgidch ab amjed g Abrahambad. Pi atsh wehsijj g Abrahambad amjedkam wo enigak hegai mash wa g Jiosh ab makiog. Gohk ash wa aꞌalidag g Abrahambad. Sh hema hab chehgig Isaac. Kush g Jiosh hab kaij ab Abrahambad wui:

column2: In addition Rebecca's twin sons had the same father, our forefather Isaac.
column3: Neh, tsh am hema hohnt g Isaacbad am i geꞌedak. Sh id hab chehgig Rebecca ch gohk ha mahmadt.

column2: But even before the children were born, and before they'd done anything right or wrong, (so that God's purpose could continue, proving God's calling of people is not based on human performance),  she was told, “The older brother will serve the younger one.”
column3: Sh hab kaij g Jiosh ab wui g Rebeccabad:

column2: So what should we conclude? That God was unjust? Certainly not!
column3: Pegih, naꞌams haꞌi hab elid mat pi ap chuꞌi g Jiosh. K wabshaba pi hab chuꞌig

column2: As he said to Moses, “I will be merciful to whoever I should show mercy, and I will have compassion on whoever I should show compassion.”
column3: nash pi hab kaij ab Mosesbad wui:

column2: Scripture records God saying to Pharaoh: “I put you here for a reason—so that through you I could demonstrate my power, and so that my name could be made known throughout the earth.”
column3: An o oꞌohanas mash hab kaij g Jiosh am wui g ha‑kownalig g Egypt t am hemajkam:

column2: Now you'll argue with me and ask, “So why does he still blame us then? Who can resist the will of God?”
column3: Neh, tp hems hema wo kah ihda k hab wo chei, “Pegih, pi at haꞌichu ab hu wo chum t‑abch g Jiosh matp heg hab wa masma hab t‑juh map has i kaij.”

column2: That's no way to speak, for who are you—a mere mortal—to contradict God? Can something that is created say to its creator, “Why did you make me like this?”
column3: Nt wabshaba wo em‑ahgi mo pi ab hu shaꞌi ab g oꞌodham mas ab wui wo neo g Jiosh. Dach Jiosh nahtoi ch pi edgid g apꞌedag machs ab wui hab wo chei mas haschu ahgk hab masma t‑nahto.

column2: Doesn't a potter have the right to use the same batch of clay to make both a decorative bowl and an everyday pot?
column3: Neh, nat hig pi hab wo ha juh g hahaꞌatdam g hab mams hahaꞌa mat wo tatchuad? Hema atp hems d wo s‑kehg haꞌak ch hema d wo pi kehg haꞌak.

column2: It's as if God, wanting to demonstrate his opposition to sin and to reveal his power, bears patiently with these “pots destined for destruction,”
column3: Pegih, t g Jiosh wehs hab ha juh g hemajkam. K haꞌi pi ap d hemajkam. K wabshaba g Jiosh s‑ha bahbgi. T am wo i e ai mat am wo chehgi g e‑gewkdag k wo s‑koꞌokam ha namkid.

column2: so that he might reveal the greatness of his glory through these “pots of mercy” which he has prepared in advance for glory.
column3: Kuch haꞌi s‑ap d hemajkam no pi ab si s‑t‑hoꞌigeꞌid g Jiosh. Am at i t‑apꞌech matt hab masma wo nei g gewkdaj.

column2: This is who we are—people he has called, not just from among the Jews, but from among the foreigners too...
column3: Ahpim gawul mahs hemajkam am d ep waidaj. Jiosh at ab ep i em‑gawulkai.

column2: As God said in the book of Hosea, “Those who are not my people I will call my people, and those who are not loved I will call the ones I love,”
column3: Neh, bo masma an oꞌohadag heg oꞌohana ed mash hab chehgig Hosea mo hab kaij g Jiosh:

column2: What shall we conclude, then? That even though the foreigners were not even looking to do right, they did grasp what is right, and through their trust in God did what was right.
column3: Pegih, pi am wa am hu e gahgid g Jiosh apꞌedag ahpim gawul mahs hemajkam ch wabshaba am i kah ab amjed g Jiosh alidag k ab i s‑wohoch. T g Jiosh am i em‑apꞌech e tahgio gam hu hab i juhk g pi ap em‑chuꞌijig.

column2: But the people of Israel, who looked to the law to make them right with God, never succeeded.
column3: K g ni‑wehm oꞌodham am i chum e apꞌechud g chehanigkaj ch pi bei g e‑apꞌedag

column2: Why not? Because they relied on what they did rather than trusting in God. They tripped on the stumbling-block,
column3: nat pi pi ab hu wohoch g Jiosh k pi ab hu bei g si Kehshaj k wabsh am hab chum s‑junimk g s‑apꞌekam mat hekaj wo s‑apꞌek am Jiosh tahgio. Id o heg wa wepo mat e huchwua ab hodai t ab.

column2: just as Scripture predicted: “Look, I'm placing in Zion a stumbling-block, a rock that will offend people. But those who trust in him won't be disappointed.”
column3: An o hab chuꞌig Jiosh oꞌohana ed mo hab kaij g Jiosh:

column2: My brothers and sisters, my heart's desire—my prayer to God—is for the salvation of the people of Israel!
column3: Ni‑wepnag, chum ani si tatchua mat hu wo i e doꞌibia g ni‑wehm oꞌodham ch heg hekaj am ni‑hoꞌigeꞌidahun Jiosh wui.

column2: I can testify to their passionate dedication to God, but it's not based on knowing him as he truly is.
column3: Hegam o tatchua mat am wo i e apꞌech Jiosh tahgio ch wabshaba pi ap mahch mas has masma hab wo e juh.

column2: They don't understand how God makes us right with him, and they try to make themselves right. They refuse to accept God's way of making people right.
column3: Jiosh at am i apꞌech matt has masma wo s‑apꞌek am tahgio. K g ni‑wehm oꞌodham wabsh s‑ohhodamk g apchudaj ch wabsh hejel am chum s‑e apchudamk

column2: For Christ is the fulfillment of the law. All those who trust in him are made right.
column3: ab s‑wohog elidch g Jiosh chehanig. K wabshaba g Jiosh am t‑chehgidch matt ab wabsh wo i s‑wohoch g s‑kehg haꞌichu ahgaj k ab wo i hiwigi g Christ. T heg am wo i t‑apꞌech am tahgio.

column2: Moses wrote, “Whoever does what is right by obeying the law will live.”
column3: An atki hi wa oꞌoha g Mosesbad mash hab kaij g Jiosh:

column2: What Scripture actually says is: “The message is very close to you—it's in your mouth and in your heart.”  In fact it's this message based on trust that we're presenting.
column3: Bo hig woho chuꞌig:

column2: As Scripture says, “Those who trust in him will not be disappointed.”
column3: Bo chuꞌig g Jiosh oꞌohana:

column2: For “everyone who calls on the name of the Lord will be saved.”
column3: Bo chuꞌig g Jiosh oꞌohana:

column2: Then Isaiah said it even more strongly: “I was found by people who weren't even looking for me; I revealed myself to people who weren't even asking for me.”
column3: Tki g Isaiabad an oꞌoha mash s‑gewkam hab kaij g Jiosh:

column2: But then I ask, “Has God rejected his people?” Of course not! I'm an Israelite myself, from the tribe of Benjamin.
column3: Pegih, naꞌas hab sha elidas mat gam hu s‑ha ohhod g Jiosh g Tutuligo mat pi d haha wo hemajkamgajk. K wabshaba pi hab mahs. Ahni ani hab waꞌap d Tuhligo. T g Jiosh pi gam hu ni‑ohhod. Benjaminbad o d si ni‑shohshon ch heg d amjedkamaj g Abrahambad.

column2: God has not rejected his chosen people. Don't you recall what Scripture says about Elijah? How he complained about Israel to God, saying,
column3: Pi at gam hu s‑t‑ohhod g Jiosh. Dach chum hemajkamgaj. Heki at hu ab i ha gawulkai g t‑shohshon.

column2: How did God answer him? “I still have seven thousand left who have not worshiped Baal.”
column3: Sh wabshaba hab kaij g Jiosh ab wui:

column2: So what do we conclude? That the people of Israel didn't achieve what they were striving for—only the chosen, while the rest became hard-hearted.
column3: Pegih, al heꞌekia at ab i ha gawulkai g Jiosh g ni‑wehm oꞌodham. T idam cheh g e‑gahgi. Muꞌijj at pi cheh no pi pi chechkaidag ab Jiosh wui.

column2: As Scripture says, “God dulled their minds so their eyes could not see and their ears could not hear, to this very day.”
column3: K hab chuꞌig g Jiosh oꞌohana:

column2: So am I saying that they stumbled and consequently failed completely? Not at all! But as a result of their mistakes, salvation came to other nations, to “make them jealous.”
column3: Neh, bo chuꞌig. Jiosh at am ha dagito hegam ni‑wehm oꞌodham mo pi ab hu kaiham. T heg hekaj am i e ahgahi g doꞌibiadag ahga gawul mahs hemajkam ha wui. Kutp hems haꞌi g ni‑wehm oꞌodham wo s‑ha hehgam k ab haha wo kaihamad g Jiosh. Kut pi wabsh wo s‑kehg ha hugio g Jiosh.

column2: Now if even their failure benefits the world, and their loss profits the foreigners, how much more beneficial it would be if they were to completely fulfill what they were meant to be.
column3: Pi at ap chuꞌi g ni‑wehm oꞌodham k ab ai g geꞌe shoꞌigdag T heg hekaj g geꞌe hoꞌigeꞌidalig ab hih nahnko mahs hemajkam ha wui. Ab o him g tash mat muꞌi Tutuligo ab wo i e nohnogi Jiosh wui k haꞌakia ab wo ai mo heꞌekia hab i ha elid g Jiosh mat wo ha doꞌibia. T g nahnko mahs hemajkam ab ep wo bei g geꞌe hoꞌigeꞌidalig heg hekaj.

column2: Now let me speak to you foreigners. Insofar as I'm a missionary to foreigners, I promote what I'm doing
column3: Dani kehshaj g Jesus Christ mant wo em‑ahgi ahpim gawul mahs hemajkam g haꞌichu ahgaj. Kunt wo si haꞌichuch ihda ni‑chikpan.

column2: that somehow I might make my people jealous and save some of them.
column3: Tp hems g ni‑wehm oꞌodham wo s‑em‑hehgam k haꞌijj wo e doꞌibia.

column2: If the result of God's rejection of them is that the world becomes God's friends, the result of God's acceptance of them would be like the dead coming back to life!
column3: Jiosh at ab i kuhpiꞌo g apꞌedag am ha wehhejed g gawul mahs hemajkam mat hekid gam hu hab i ha juh g Tutuligo. T g gawul mahs hemajkam baꞌich wo i bei g hoꞌigeꞌidadag mat hekid am wo i e ai g tash mat g Tutuligo ab wo i e nohnogi Jiosh wui. Kut woho ab wo i e nohnogi wui.

column2: If the first part of the bread dough given as an offering is holy, then so is all the rest; if the roots of a tree are holy, then so are the branches.
column3: Neh, ab ach mamka g Jiosh g wehpegkamaj g haꞌichu t‑gehgewa ch hab masma chehgid mo wehs d enigaj hegai t‑gehgewa. Pegih, t‑shohshon ahchim Tutuligo o d wehpegkam. K d si shel mat g ha‑amjedkam muꞌi ab wo i e nohnogi Jiosh wui. Uhs mahmhadag o d Jiosh eniga mamtp ab wo mah g tatkaj. T‑shohshon o d tatk. Ch ahchim d mahmhadgaj.

column2: Now if some of the branches have been broken off, and you—a wild olive shoot—have been grafted in, and have shared with them the benefit of nourishment from the olive tree's roots,
column3: Mt wabshaba wo hikkumiꞌa hegam mahmhadgaj mat pi ab hu wo bahidagt k ab wo ha namki ab hegam mat wo s‑kehg bahidagt. Pegih, t g Jiosh hab masma gam hu hab i ha juh hegam Tutuligo mo pi ab hu wohochud k ahpim em‑ui gawul mahs hemajkam mamt ab i s‑wohoch. Kum ab hahawa wehs apꞌedag hegai mo haschu d i chum ha‑apꞌedag hegam Tutuligo mo pi ab hu wohochud.

column2: then you shouldn't look down on the other branches. If you're tempted to boast, remember it's not you who are supporting the roots, but the roots that are supporting you.
column3: Mt pi wo e haschudad mat gam hu hab i ha juh. Jiosh at hab em‑juh mamt hab haha wo masmak mam d Abrahambad amjedkam. Pi am d ha‑shohshon ch wabsh heg wa wepo mam d mahmhadag.

column2: You could make the claim, “Branches were broken off so I could be grafted in.”
column3: Mtp hems hab wo chei mat g mahmhadgaj e hikkumiꞌa mat am wo em‑jegel.

column2: All well and good—but they were broken off because of their failure to trust in God, and you stay there because you trust in God. So don't think highly of yourselves, but be respectful,
column3: T wabshaba hab wa e juh nat pi pi ab hu wohoch g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga. Mt ahpim ab s‑wohochud k hekaj ab giꞌis shonaj ab. Mt wabshaba pi wo si e haschudad id hekaj.

column2: because if God didn't spare the original branches, he won't spare you either.
column3: Gm at hu hab i ha juh g Jiosh hegam Tutuligo mo pi ab hu wohochud. Kumt ahpim gam hu hab ep wo i e juh mamtp pi ab hu wo wohochudad.

column2: You should recognize both God's kindness and toughness—he was tough on the fallen, but God is kind to you so long as you trust in his kindness—otherwise you'll be removed too.
column3: Jiosh at wo si s‑hemajimak ab em‑wui mamtp ab wo s‑wohochudad ch wabshaba ab em‑wui wo kekiwua mamtp ab uhpam wo i e nohnogi pi apꞌekam wui. Pegih, ab g wo i oidahim ihda k an wo uꞌukchid g Jiosh hemajimatalig.

column2: If they no longer refuse to trust in God, they can be grafted in as well, for God is able to graft them back in again.
column3: Jiosh at ab uhpam ep wo ha ui hegam Tutuligo mat ab wo i s‑wohoch.

column2: If you could be cut from a wild olive tree, and then be grafted artificially onto a cultivated olive tree, how much more easily they could be grafted back naturally to their own tree.
column3: Ab at em‑ui ahpim gawul mahs oꞌodham. Kum wa chum pi e nahtokch. Id o wepo masma mamt wabsh chum hebai wo ha mul g iꞌibhonig k ab wo namki g uhs e‑eꞌes. Tutuligo o chum e nahtokch. T g Jiosh ab uhpam ep wo ha ui hegam mat ab wo i s‑wohoch. Id o wepo masma mamt ab uhpam ep wo ha namki g ha‑iꞌibhonig am i ha mulink.

column2: I don't want you, my brothers and sisters to miss this previously-hidden truth, for otherwise you could become conceited. The people of Israel have become hard-hearted in part, until the process of the foreigners coming in is complete.
column3: Neh, ni‑wepnag, hemu at haꞌichu mahsko wua g Jiosh. Kuni id s‑em‑ahgidamk. Kumt wo s‑mahchk ch hekaj pi hab wo chum ge e elidad mam si s‑chu aꞌamichud. Pi at chum hekid im hu hab wo i e juhkch g Tutuligo ab amjed g Jiosh. Jiosh at mahsko wua mat ab wui wo i e nohnogi am i dahm mamt ahpim gawul mahs hemajkam haꞌakia ab wui wo i e nohnogi mo heꞌekia hab i em‑elid g Jiosh.

column2: This is how all Israel will be saved.  As Scripture says, “The Savior will come from Zion, and he will turn Jacob away from his opposition to God.
column3: T haha wo e doꞌibia g Tutuligo. An o oꞌohadag mo hab kaij g Jiosh:

column2: Though they are enemies of the good news—and this is to your benefit—they are still the chosen people, and loved because of their forefathers.
column3: Ahchim Tutuligo ach d chum Jiosh hemajkamga nat pi ab i ha gawulkai g t‑shohshon. T wabshaba muꞌijj g ni‑wehm oꞌodham pi ab hu wohoch g Jiosh haꞌichu ahga k hab masma e obgach ab wui. K g Jiosh heg hekaj t‑chehani matt am wo ahgachugad g s‑kehg haꞌichu ahgaj em‑wui ahpim gawul mahs hemajkam.

column2: God's gifts and his calling can't be withdrawn.
column3: Pi at hekid am gawul wo juh g e‑chegitoi g Jiosh.

column2: At one time you disobeyed God, but now God has shown you mercy as a result of their disobedience.
column3: Ahpim gawul mahs hemajkam am wa pi ab hu wohog elid g Jiosh. K wa g Jiosh pi ab hu em‑hoꞌigeꞌid. T g Tutuligo gam hu i e nohnogi ab amjed g Jiosh. T g Jiosh heg hekaj ab em‑mah g hoꞌigeꞌidadag.

column2: In just the same way that they're now disobedient as you were, they will also be shown mercy like you received.
column3: K wabshaba ab him g tash mat hahawa em‑wepo masma wo bei g Jiosh hoꞌigeꞌidadag g Tutuligo.

column2: For God treated everyone as prisoners because of their disobedience so that he could be merciful to everyone.
column3: Wehs hemajkam o d pi ap chuꞌijkam am Jiosh nena ed. Kut g Jiosh wehs ha wepo wo s‑ha hoꞌigeꞌel hegam mat ab wui wo i e nohnogi.

column2: Oh how deep are God's riches, wisdom, and knowledge! How incredible his decisions, how unimaginable his methods!
column3: Shoꞌo waꞌi si geꞌej g Jiosh. K g haꞌichu amichudadaj ch haꞌichu mahchigaj shaꞌi si geꞌej. Pi at hedai wo shaꞌi e nako mas hejel wo s‑mai g hab elidaj o wehs wo s‑amich mo has masma hab wua haꞌichu.

column2: Who can know God's thoughts? Who can give him advice?
column3: Neh, bo chuꞌig an Jiosh oꞌohana ed:

column2: So I encourage you, my brothers and sisters, because of God's compassion for you, to dedicate your bodies as a living offering that is holy and pleasing to God. This is the logical way to worship.
column3: Pegih neh, ni‑wepnag, si o s‑t‑hoꞌigeꞌid g Jiosh. Tt heg hekaj wehs am wo i t‑dagito wui matt am wehhejed d wo dodakamk ch am hab wo junihid g tatchuij. Batt masma s‑wohom ab has wo elidad g Jiosh.

column2: Don't follow the ways of this world; instead be transformed by the spiritual renewal of your mind so you can demonstrate what God's will really is—good, pleasing, and perfect.
column3: Pi g am hu ha oidch hab wo masmak hegam mo pi ab hu ihm g Jiosh ch wabshaba ab wo i e dagito Jiosh wui. T heg am gawul wo juh g em‑chegitoidag. T hab wehs wo i e wechijid g em‑doakag. Bamt waꞌi masma wo s‑mahchk mo haschu d Jiosh tatchui. K heg d waꞌi si hekia s‑apꞌekam.

column2: Let me explain to all of you, through the grace given to me, that no one should think of themselves better than they ought to. You should think about yourselves realistically, according to the degree of trust God has shared with you.
column3: Jiosh o ab s‑ni‑hoꞌigeꞌid ch ab ni‑mah g gewkdag. Ni heg hekaj hab em‑ahg wehsijj mamt pi wo chum ge e haꞌichuchudad ch wo si s‑mahchk mam haschu am chegito. Wehsijj amt am wo si i mamche mo heꞌes ab i em‑mahkch g Jiosh g gewkdag ch haschu em‑tatchuid mamt am hab wo junidad am oidch g e‑wohochudadag.

column2: Just as there are many parts to the body, but they don't all do the same thing,
column3: Neh, no hig pi woho nahnko haꞌichu hab wua g oꞌodham chuhchuꞌidag, chum as d hemako g honshpadaj.

column2: so we are one body in Christ, even though we are many—and we all belong to one another.
column3: Pegih, tt hab wa masma nahnko haꞌichu wo junihid mat aꞌai d wo i t‑wehmtadagk ahchim mach ab t‑hemakochudch g Christ wehm.

column2: We each have different gifts that vary according to the grace given to us. So if it's speaking for God, then you should do so depending on how much you trust in God.
column3: Am g wo hekaj g e‑gewkdag aꞌai e wehhejed hab masma mo g Jiosh am apꞌechudch mamt hab wo e juh. Haꞌi o ab em‑mahkch g gewkdag mamt am wo ahgahid g haꞌichu ahgaj. Kumt ab wo s‑wohochudad ch wo ahgahid.

column2: If it's the ministry of service then you should serve; if teaching then you should teach;
column3: Haꞌi o d em‑mahkigdag mamt haꞌichukaj wo i ha wehmtad g e‑wehm wohochuddam o wo haꞌichu ha mashchamad

column2: if encouragement then you should encourage; if giving then you should give generously; if leadership then you should lead with commitment; if being merciful then you should do so gladly.
column3: o haꞌichukaj ab wo i ha gewkemhunad. Haꞌi o d em‑mahkigdag mamt ab wo haꞌichu ha hoꞌidad g e‑wehm wohochuddam. Am g s‑baꞌama hab wo wuad ch s‑ha hoꞌigeꞌid. Haꞌi o d em‑mahkigdag mamt d wo ha wanimeddamk. Kumt wo si chikpanad ch s‑gewkam am hab wo junihid. Haꞌi o d em‑mahkigdag mamt wo s‑ha hoꞌigeꞌid k wo i ha wehmt hegam mo e shoꞌigchud.

column2: Love must be genuine. Hate what is evil; hold on tightly to what is good.
column3: Pi g hab wabsh wo s‑e junimk mam ab pihk e elid hedai i ha wui ch wabshaba si s‑wohom ab si pihk e elid ab ha wui. Pi g hab wo junihid g pi apꞌekam ab hedai i wui ch wabshaba g s‑apꞌekam hab wo waꞌi junihid ab ha wui.

column2: Be completely dedicated to each other in your love as family; value others more than yourselves.
column3: Ab g wo si ha tatchuad g e‑wehm wohochuddam ch ab has wo ha elidad, chum as aigo pi ab hu has wo em‑elidad.

column2: Don't be unwilling to work hard; serve the Lord with an enthusiastic spirit.
column3: Mt wo si chikpanad ch pi wo papadmak. Si e‑ihbdagkaj amt ab wo ihmad g Christ ch wo chikpandad.

column2: Remain cheerful in the hope you have, put up with the troubles that come, keep on praying.
column3: Mt wo si s‑hehgigk heg hekaj mo haschu g Jiosh ab em‑wuichud. Am g wabsh wo i s‑dodolimak e‑kudutadag ed ch chum hekid wo e hoꞌigeꞌidahunad.

column2: Share in providing for the needs of God's people, and welcome strangers with hospitality.
column3: Haꞌi o e shoꞌigchud g t‑wehm wohochuddam. K ab t‑ab matt am wo i ha wahpki t‑kihki ed k ab wo i ha mah g i wehmta, chum as d wabsh wo ge oꞌodhamk.

column2: Bless those who persecute you—bless them, and don't curse them.
column3: Ab g wo i tahni g Jiosh mat ab wabsh wo i s‑ha hoꞌigeꞌel hegam mo em‑shoꞌigchud. Pi g wo shaꞌi has ha ahgad.

column2: Be happy with those who are happy; cry with those who are crying.
column3: Ab g wo si ha wehm s‑hehgigk hegam mo s‑hehgig ch ha wehm pi ap e tahtk hegam mo pi ap e tahtk.

column2: Think about one another.  Don't consider yourself more important than others; live humbly. Don't be conceited.
column3: Am g wabsh s‑ap e wehm wo kihkad. Pi g am wo chum e haꞌichuchudad ch ab wabsh wo ha tatchuad g shoꞌigkam ch am hab wabsh wo junihid wabsh chum has mahs chikpan. Pi amt hab wo e elidad mam d s‑chu aꞌamichuddam.

column2: Don't pay back anyone evil for evil. Make sure you show everybody that what you're doing is good,
column3: Am g hab wo junihid g s‑apꞌekam wehs ha wui ch pi ab hu uhpam wo i nodagi g pi apꞌekam hegam ha wui mat ab em‑wui hab wo juh g pi apꞌekam.

column2: and as far as it's up to you, live at peace with everyone.
column3: Am g wo i e nakog mamt s‑ap e tahtk ch ab wo ha neidad g hemajkam mamtp heꞌes wo i e nako.

column2: My dear friends, don't seek revenge, but leave it to God to execute judgment —as Scripture points out, “ ‘It's for me to dispense justice, I will repay,’ says the Lord.”
column3: Pi g am wo hejel e agwuan. Jiosh at am hab wo wa em‑juni. Neh, bo chuꞌig an oꞌohanaj ed g Jiosh:

column2: Everyone should obey government authorities, because no one has the power to rule unless God gives permission. These authorities have been put there by God.
column3: Am o apꞌechudch g Jiosh mat in wo haꞌichugk g kownaltalig ch am wo t‑dahmk. Tt heg hekaj ab wo wechok g ha‑chehanig g kokownal

column2: Whoever resists the authorities opposes what God has put in place, and those who do so shall find themselves judged accordingly.
column3: ch pi wo melchkwuad. Jiosh o ab ha mahkch g gewkdag. Kut wo t‑namkid matt wo sha melchkwuad.

column2: For rulers don't frighten those who do right, but those who do wrong. If you don't want to live in fear of the authorities, then do what is right, and you'll have their approval.
column3: Tt heg hekaj wo s‑ehbidad g kownal matt hab wo sha junihid g pi apꞌekam ch wabshaba pi wo ehbidad mattp g s‑apꞌekam hab wo junihid. Am g hab wo waꞌi junihid g s‑apꞌekam. T g hahaꞌichu s‑ap wo em‑elidad.

column2: Those in power are God's servants, put there for your own good. If you do wrong, you should be frightened—it's not without reason that authorities have the power to punish! They are God's servants, punishing offenders.
column3: Jiosh at am i ha chuhcha g kokownal mat wo t‑nuhkudad. Kut wo s‑ta ehbidamk mattp hab wo junihid g pi apꞌekam no pi g Jiosh ab ha mahkch g gewkdag mat s‑koꞌokam wo t‑namkid.

column2: So it's important to do as you're told, not just because of the threat of punishment, but because of what your conscience tells you.
column3: Hemho wa att wo himad g chehanig nach pi s‑mahch mo pi apꞌe matt wo melchkwua.

column2: That's why you have to pay taxes, for the authorities are God's servants taking care of such things.
column3: Ab o d wuikamaj g kownal hegai mo haschu ab t‑kowlant mat hekaj wo himad g e‑chikpan.

column2: Pay whatever you owe: taxes to the tax authorities, fees to the fee-collectors; give respect to those who should be respected, honor those who should be honored.
column3: Pegih, tt ab has wo ha elidad g hahaꞌichu k wo namkidad g kownal hegai mo haschu ab t‑chehani.

column2: Don't owe anybody anything, except love for one another—for those who love their neighbor have kept the law.
column3: Pi att hedai wui wo chum t‑wulshchid ch wabsh s‑ap wo ha namkidad. Id att waꞌi hekaj wo chum t‑wulshchid matt ab aꞌai t‑hekaj wo si pihk t‑elidad. Id o d Jiosh chehanig. Kuch ab s‑wohog elid g chehanigaj ab aꞌai si pihk t‑elidch.

column2: “You must not commit adultery, you must not kill, you must not steal, you must not jealously want things for yourself” —these and the other commandments are summed up in the statement, “Love your neighbor as yourself.”
column3: Bo chuꞌig g chehanigaj:

column2: You should do this because you realize how urgent the time is—that it's high time for you to wake up from your sleep. For salvation is closer to us now than when we first put our trust in God.
column3: Id att hab wo wuad heg hekaj mat mehk waꞌi hih g tash. E at ai matt ab wo si i t‑nenenashanich no pi e aihim mat g Jiosh ab wo i t‑wuwhas id amjed jewed.

column2: The night is nearly over, the day is almost here! So let's get rid of our dark deeds and put on the armor of light.
column3: Pegih, tt wo dagito g pi apꞌekam k g s‑apꞌekam am hab wo junihid. E o aihim matt s‑ap wo t‑doꞌibia.

column2: Let's behave properly, showing that we're people who are living in the light. We shouldn't spend our time going to wild parties and getting drunk, or having affairs and acting immorally, or getting into fights and being jealous.
column3: Tt wo si t‑elidad mattp wo ihꞌed ch wo t‑nondagch o attp wabsh chum hedai wehm wo woꞌiwup o attp s‑uam has wo t‑wuad o attp wo s‑ha hehgam o attp wo ha cheggia. Ab o t‑ab matt am wo dagito hewai hab mahs haꞌichu k heg hab wo waꞌi junihid mo d s‑apꞌekam.

column2: Instead put on the Lord Jesus Christ, and forget about following your sinful desires.
column3: Do si t‑kownalig g Jesus Christ. Kutt ab wui wo i t‑dagito matt pi am hu hab wo junihid g pi ap t‑tatchui.

column2: Accept those who are still struggling to trust in God, and don't get into arguments over personal opinions.
column3: Haꞌi atp hems am wabsh kia pi gewpkdag g em‑wehm wohochuddam am e‑wohochudadag ed. Kumt wabsh wo ha tatchuad ch pi wo neꞌowi heg amjed mo haschu al i s‑mahch.

column2: One person may believe they can eat anything, while another whose trust is weak only eats vegetables.
column3: Neh, am o wa s‑apꞌe matt wabsh chum haschu hugi wo koꞌad matp wo s‑gewkdagk g t‑wohochudadag. K wabshaba haꞌi pi gewkdag e‑wohochudadag ed ch heg hekaj hab e elid mo haꞌichu pi hiwgidas mat wo e koꞌad.

column2: Those who eat anything must not look down on those who won't, and those who won't eat must not criticize those who do—for God has accepted them both.
column3: Kutt pi aꞌai has wo t‑ehꞌel heg hekaj mach haschu i koꞌa nat pi g Jiosh ab i t‑ui.

column2: What right do you have to judge someone else's servant? It's their own master who decides whether they are right or wrong. With the Lord's help they will be able to take their stand for right.
column3: Pi o ab hu t‑ab machs wo has ahgad g t‑wehm wohochuddam. Do Jiosh pionag. Jiosh o d t‑ahmo ch heg am wo i aꞌappe mas s‑ap am hab e junihim g t‑wehm wohochuddam. T wabsh wo e nako mat s‑ap am hab wo junihid no pi g Jiosh am i wehmaj wehs haꞌichu k ed.

column2: Some people consider some days more important than others, while others consider each day the same. Everyone should be completely convinced in their own minds.
column3: Haꞌi o hab e elid mat am wo oidad g Tutuligo ha‑pipiast tash ch haꞌi hab elid mo wehs tash am wabsh i e wepodag. Ab o hejel t‑ab mattp has wo i elidad.

column2: Those who respect a special day do so for the Lord; and those who eat without worrying do so for the Lord since they give thanks to God; while those who avoid eating certain things do so for the Lord, and they also give thanks to God.
column3: Matp hedai ab wo si has elidad hema tash ch hab e wua mat heg eda ab wo si i ihm g Jiosh. Tp hedai wabsh chum haschu wo koꞌad ch ab wo si has i elidad g Jiosh nat pi ab wo si i hoꞌigeꞌel heg hekaj haꞌichu hugi. Kutp hedai pi wabsh chum haschu wo koꞌad ch hab waꞌap wo si has elidad g Jiosh nat pi ab wo chum hoꞌigeꞌel g Jiosh heg hekaj mo haschu i koꞌa k ab wo si has i el.

column2: None of us live for ourselves, or die for ourselves.
column3: Pi ach hedai wabsh hejel t‑wehhejed in d doakam ch wabshaba Christ wehhejed in d doakam ch wo muh mat hekid hab wo i el g Jiosh.

column2: If we live, we live for the Lord, or if we die, we die for the Lord—so whether we live or die, we belong to the Lord.
column3: Pegih, dach Christ hemajkamga mach in d doakam ch hab waꞌap d enigaj chum achs hems wo muh.

column2: This was the reason Christ died and came back to life—so that he could be the Lord of both the dead and the living.
column3: Christ at muh k ab uhpam i wuhsh muhkig amjed mat d wo t‑kownaligk, chum achs hems wo muh.

column2: So why do you criticize your fellow-believer? Why do you despise your fellow-believer? For all of us will stand before God's throne of judgment.
column3: Pegih, pi att am wo chum has ahgad g t‑wehm wohochuddam. Wehsijj att am wo i gegokiwua wui g Jiosh heg i eda lodaita tash.

column2: For the Scriptures say, “ ‘As surely as I am alive,’ the Lord says, ‘Every knee shall bow before me, and every tongue will declare that I am God.’ ”
column3: Neh, an o oꞌohadag mo hab kaij g Jiosh:

column2: Therefore let's not judge each other anymore, but decide to do this instead—we won't put obstacles in the way of fellow-believers, or cause them to fall.
column3: Pegih, mt hig wo haꞌasa aꞌai has e ahgad. Id amt am hab wo elidad mamt pi am hu wabsh has wo e wuad. T hekaj pi wo heki hih g em‑wehm wohochuddam o am wo gei pi apꞌekam ch ed.

column2: I'm certain—persuaded by the Lord Jesus—that nothing in itself is ceremonially unclean. But if someone considers it to be unclean, to them it is unclean.
column3: Ab ach s‑wohochud g t‑kownalig Jesus ch hekaj chum s‑mahch mo wehs g haꞌichu hugi hiwgidas matt wo huh. Tp wabshaba hema hab wo elidad mo pi hiwgidas, pegih, k pi apꞌe mas an wo bei.

column2: If your fellow-believer is hurt by you over matters of food, then you're no longer behaving in a loving way. Don't destroy someone for whom Christ died by the food you choose to eat.
column3: Kutp hems wo heki him k pi wo e doꞌibia matp hema an wo hekaj hegai mo haschu hab elid mo pi hiwgidas. Pi ach tatchua g t‑wehm wohochuddam mattp wo heki himch. T eda g Christ wehhejed muh chum s‑doꞌibiamk.

column2: Don't let the good things you do be misrepresented—
column3: Pi g am hu haꞌichu has wo juhni mamt heg hekaj wo has em‑ahgad, chum ams hems hab elid mo d s‑apꞌekam.

column2: for God's kingdom is not about eating and drinking, but about living right, having peace and joy in the Holy Spirit.
column3: Pi o d si haꞌichu machs haschukaj wo t‑gegosidad. K wabshaba id d si haꞌichu matt am hab wo junihid g s‑apꞌekam ch ab aꞌai t‑wui wo si s‑ap t‑tahtkk ch wo si s‑hehgigk mat g Hekia S‑apꞌekam Gewkdag am i t‑apꞌech Jiosh wui.

column2: Anyone who serves Christ in this way pleases God, and is appreciated by others.
column3: Pegih, tt hab wa masma am hab wo t‑junihid am wehhejed g Christ. T g Jiosh ab wo si s‑hohhoꞌi ihda. T g hemajkam pi haꞌichu wo cheh mas ab wo t‑abch.

column2: So let's pursue the path of peace, and find ways to encourage each other.
column3: Tt heg wui am wo i t‑nako matt haschukaj ab aꞌai wo i t‑gewkemhunad ch ab aꞌai t‑wui wo s‑ap t‑tahtkk.

column2: Don't destroy the work of God with arguments over food. Everything is clean—but it would be wrong to eat and offend others.
column3: Do Jiosh doꞌibiakam g t‑wehm wohochuddam. Pegih, pi g haꞌichu hab wo juhni mas hekaj wo heki hihi. Wehs haꞌichu hugi o hiwgidas. K wabshaba pi apꞌe machs wo koꞌad matt haschukaj wo ha heki hihimch g t‑wehm wohochuddam.

column2: It's better not to eat meat or drink wine or anything else that would cause your fellow-believer to stumble.
column3: Kutt heg hekaj wabsh wo dagito hegai mattp haschukaj wo heki himch g t‑wehm wohochuddam. Chuhkug attp hems wo dagito o g nawait o wabsh chum haschu.

column2: What you personally believe is between you and God. Happy are those who don't condemn themselves for doing what they think is right!
column3: Am att wabsh wo hejel nuhkudad mach haschu i s‑wohochud id amjed ch heg waꞌi Jiosh ab wo ahgi. Tt wo s‑hehgigk mattp hab wo junihid hegai mach haschu i s‑mahch mo s‑apꞌe. T hab pi wo heki hih g t‑wehm wohochuddam.

column2: But if you have doubts whether it's right or wrong to eat something, then you shouldn't, because you're not convinced it's right. Whatever isn't based on conviction  is sin.
column3: Pi g am hu hab wo juhni hegai mam haschu pi mahch mas d s‑apꞌekam k hab pi ab hu wo e chuꞌijigch heg hekaj.

column2: Those of us who are spiritually strong ought to support those who are spiritually weak. We shouldn't just please ourselves.
column3: Pi att wabsh hejel am wo t‑chegitod ahchim mach ab wabsh s‑ap s‑wohochud g Jiosh ch wabshaba ep wo ha chegitod hegam mo pi am hu i si s‑amichud mo haꞌichu s‑apꞌe.

column2: We should all encourage others to do what's right, building them up.
column3: Kut heg hekaj ab wo i e gewkemhunad ch baꞌich wo i s‑ap s‑amich mo haschu s‑apꞌe.

column2: Christ didn't live to please himself, but as Scripture says of him, “The insults of those who abused you have fallen on me.”
column3: Am o t‑chehgidch g Christ matt pi wabsh hejel wo t‑chegitok no pi pi wabsh hejel am hu e chegito mo wa in oimmed. An at oꞌoha g kelibad Jiosh haꞌichu i tashogiddam:

column2: May the God who gives patience and encouragement help you to be in full agreement among yourselves as you follow Christ Jesus,  so that you can with one mind and with one voice together glorify God, the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ!
column3: Do Jiosh mo ab i t‑gewkemhun matt s‑ap t‑tahtkk ch wo nenida g t‑apꞌedag. Kuni ab tahni mat hab wo em‑juh mamt am oidch hab wo e junihid g t‑kownalig Jesus Christ k ch wehs e wehm ab wo ihmad g ohgaj Jiosh ch hab s‑ap wo e tahtkkad ab aꞌai e wui.

column2: So accept one another, just as Christ accepted you, and give God the glory.
column3: S‑ap o ab t‑neid g Christ. Kutt ahchim hab wa masma ab aꞌai s‑ap wo t‑neidad ch hab ab wo has elidad g Jiosh.

column2: I maintain that Christ came as a servant to the Jews  to show God tells the truth, keeping the promises he made to their forefathers.
column3: Chum o hekid am hab junihim g Jiosh mo has i kaij. T heg hekaj ia jiwia g Christ mat am hab wo t‑juni ahchim Tutuligo hegai moki haschu g Jiosh ab ha ahgid g t‑shohshonbad.

column2: He also came that foreigners could praise God for his mercy, as Scripture says, “Therefore I will praise you among the foreigners; I will sing praises to your name.”
column3: Kumt heg hekaj ab ep wo ihm g Jiosh ahpim gawul mahs hemajkam mat ab hab waꞌap s‑em hoꞌigeꞌel. Neh, bo chuꞌig an Jiosh oꞌohana ed mo hema hab kaij am Jiosh wui:
